{{Infobox Canadian football game |number=108 |type=Grey Cup |image= |date=November 15, 2020{{cite news|url=http://3downnation.com/2018/11/23/eight-things-need-know-randy-ambrosies-state-league-address/|title=Eight things you need to know from Randy Ambrosie’s state of the league address|date=November 23, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.sportsnet.ca/football/cfl/state-cfl-ambrosie-mexico-halifax-realignment/|title=State of CFL: Randy Ambrosie on Mexico, Halifax, realignment and more|date=November 23, 2018}} (tentative) |stadium=TBD |city=TBD |visitor name= |home name= |visitor coach= |home coach= |visitor record= |home record= |visitor1= |visitor2= |visitor3= |visitor4= |home1= |home2= |home3= |home4= |MVP= |MV2= |anthem= |referee= |coin toss= |halftime= |attendance= |network=English: [[The Sports Network|TSN]]/[[TSN HD]]
French: [[Réseau des sports|RDS]]/[[RDS HD]] |announcers= |ratings= }} The '''108th [[Grey Cup]]''' {{cite news|title=Shaw, CFL announce Grey Cup sponsorship deal|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/1988297/shaw-cfl-announce-grey-cup-sponsorship-deal/|accessdate=October 2, 2018|work=Global News|publisher=Shaw Media|date=May 8, 2015}} will be played to decide the [[Canadian Football League]] (CFL) championship for the [[2020 CFL season|2020 season]]. The game will be televised in [[Canada]] nationally on [[The Sports Network|TSN]] and [[Réseau des sports|RDS]]. ==Date== As speculated with the [[107th Grey Cup]], the date for this game could come much earlier than in previous years. Currently, the Grey Cup is played on the fourth or fifth Sunday of November, as has been the case since [[2007 CFL season|2007]]. During the CFL's State of the League address on November 24, 2017, League Commissioner [[Randy Ambrosie]] suggested that the league could potentially move the date to the third week of October.{{Cite web |publisher=Ottawa Sun| url=http://ottawasun.com/sports/football/cfl/grey-cup-in-october-tv-deal-with-nfl-cfl-commish-speaks | title=Grey Cup in October? NFL Network TV deal could follow for CFL | date=November 24, 2017 | accessdate=October 2, 2018}} This would easily surpass the previous earliest date of November 16 (occurring in [[85th Grey Cup|1997]] and [[91st Grey Cup|2003]]). Reasons in favour of this were the weather being warmer in October as well as a potential television deal with the American-based [[NFL Network]]. The league's current American broadcasting agreement expires after the [[2018 CFL season]] and the season schedule is thought to be worked around this agreement.{{cite web|url=https://ottawasun.com/sports/football/cfl/ottawa-redblacks/q-and-a-with-cfl-commissioner-randy-ambrosie-on-randys-road-trip|first=Tim|last=Baines|title=Q and A with CFL commissioner Randy Ambrosie on Randy's Road Trip|work=Sun Media|date=February 2, 2018|accessdate=October 2, 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://ottawasun.com/sports/football/cfl/grey-cup-in-october-tv-deal-with-nfl-cfl-commish-speaks|first=Tim|last=Baines|title=Grey Cup in October? NFL Network TV deal could follow for CFL|work=Sun Media|date=November 24, 2017|accessdate=October 2, 2018}} Reasons against would be the increased overlap of the [[National Hockey League]]'s [[Stanley Cup playoffs]] in May and June (since the season would also have to start one month earlier) as well as the CFL's playoffs overlapping [[Major League Baseball]]'s playoffs in October. On November 23, 2018, Commissioner Ambrosie confirmed that the league schedule would start one week earlier, making the date for this year's game November 15, 2020. ==Host city== As of August 2018, three teams were interested in submitting bids as the league met with representatives of those unnamed clubs in [[Hamilton, Ontario|Hamilton]].{{Cite web |publisher=Standard-Freeholder| url=https://www.standard-freeholder.com/sports/football/cfl/edmonton-eskimos/cfl-taking-collaborative-approach-to-grey-cup-planning | title=CFL taking collaborative approach to Grey Cup planning | date=August 31, 2018 | accessdate=October 2, 2018}} Based on the location of the meeting and their previously-stated desire to host, the [[Hamilton Tiger-Cats]] were speculated to be one of the teams. The previous obstacle of the lawsuit over the construction of [[Tim Hortons Field]] was settled on May 31, 2018, which had prevented the Tiger-Cats from bidding on a Grey Cup game.{{Cite web |publisher=Global News| url=https://globalnews.ca/news/4245953/tim-hortons-field-stadium-lawsuit-officially-settled-says-hamilton-mayor/ | title=Tim Horton’s Field stadium lawsuit officially settled, says Hamilton mayor | date=May 31, 2018 | accessdate=October 2, 2018}} The Tiger-Cats had previously expressed interest in submitting a bid for the [[107th Grey Cup]] and with litigation cleared, they can move forward with bidding to host their first championship game since the [[84th Grey Cup]] in 1996.{{Cite web |publisher=Hamilton Spectator| url=http://www.thespec.com/sports-story/7208036-no-grey-cup-bid-until-stadium-legal-issues-solved/ | title=No Grey Cup bid until stadium legal issues solved | date=March 24, 2017 | accessdate=October 2, 2018}} The first club to openly confirm their plans to bid were the [[Saskatchewan Roughriders]], as stated by the club's president and CEO, Craig Reynolds, on October 1, 2018.{{Cite web |publisher=Leader Post| url=https://leaderpost.com/sports/football/cfl/saskatchewan-roughriders/rob-vanstone-saskatchewan-roughriders-2020-grey-cup-bid-should-be-a-lock-but-then-what | title=Rob Vanstone: Saskatchewan Roughriders' 2020 Grey Cup bid should be a lock ... but then what? | date=October 1, 2018 | accessdate=October 2, 2018}}{{Cite web |publisher=CJME| url=https://www.cjme.com/2018/10/01/riders-confirm-plan-to-bid-on-2020-grey-cup | title=Riders confirm plan to bid on 2020 Grey Cup | date=October 1, 2018 | accessdate=October 2, 2018}} The game would coincide with the 110th anniversary of the club and would be the fourth time the game would be hosted in Saskatchewan, if successful.{{Cite web |publisher=Riderville| url=https://www.riderville.com/2018/10/02/roughriders-want-stage-another-grey-cup/ | title=The Roughriders want to stage another Grey Cup | date=October 2, 2018 | accessdate=October 2, 2018}} The Roughriders' new facility, [[Mosaic Stadium]], opened in 2017 and the Roughriders last hosted the Grey Cup in [[101st Grey Cup|2013]]. On November 4, 2018, it was reported that the [[Montreal Alouettes]] were preparing a bid to see [[Olympic Stadium (Montreal)|Olympic Stadium]] host the 2020 championship game.{{cite web|url=http://3downnation.com/2018/11/04/alouettes-to-make-bid-for-2020-grey-cup/|title=Alouettes to make bid for 2020 Grey Cup: report|publisher=3DownNation|date=November 4, 2018}} The Alouettes confirmed that they had representatives in Toronto on November 6, 2018 to make their presentation at the league head office to host the game.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/MTLAlouettes/status/1059928412268056576|title=We're in Toronto today to bring the Grey Cup final back to the Olympic Stadium in 2020!|publisher=Montreal Alouettes|date=November 6, 2018}} It was confirmed on November 13, 2018 that the Tiger-Cats were indeed making a bid for the game as team representatives made their presentation to the league head office in Toronto the week prior.{{cite news|url=https://www.thespec.com/sports-story/9029887-ticats-one-of-three-in-running-to-host-2020-grey-cup-game/|title=Ticats one of three in running to host 2020 Grey Cup Game|publisher=Hamilton Spectator|date=November 13, 2018|author=Steven Milton}} Their Grey Cup festival concept included a downtown-centred event at venues like the Hamilton Convention Centre and Art Gallery of Hamilton. The Tiger-Cats' president of business operations, Matt Afinec, confirmed that the club had support from Hamilton's mayor, [[Fred Eisenberger]], and that three bids for the Grey Cup game had been made. The CFL's Grey Cup director, Céline Séguin, had previously stated that the league would like to announce hosts sooner. With the [[107th Grey Cup|previous year's game]] being announced 19 months prior, this game could be declared much earlier.{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/football/for-the-cfls-grey-cup-director-the-big-game-is-a-calling/article37086533/|title=For the CFL’s Grey Cup director, the big game is a calling|website=Theglobeandmail.com|date=November 24, 2017|accessdate=October 2, 2018|via=The Globe and Mail}} As stated in the Roughriders' press release, the announcement is expected later in 2018 (at most, 23 months prior). ==Trivia== As part of an [[April Fools' Day]] joke in 2016, the league had announced that the 2020 Grey Cup would be hosted in a secret [[Arctic]] location on November 29, 2020.{{cite web|url=https://www.cfl.ca/2016/04/01/cfl-announces-2020-grey-cup-northern-grey-cup-ever/|title=CFL Announces 2020 Grey Cup to be Most Northern Grey Cup Ever!|website=cfl.ca|date=April 1, 2016|accessdate=October 2, 2018}} A stadium would have been airlifted in by helicopter to seat 50,000 spectators in what would have been the most northern Grey Cup in history. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Grey Cup}} [[Category:Grey Cup]] [[Category:Scheduled sports events|Grey Cup]] [[Category:2020 in Canadian football|Grey Cup]]

{{Infobox event | title = Birgu polverista explosion | image = Birgu Architecture 30.jpg | caption = The site of the magazine | time = 06:15 | date = {{start date and age|1806|07|18|df=yes}} | location = [[Birgu]], [[Malta Protectorate]] | coordinates = {{coord|35|53|09|N|14|31|19|E|region:MT_type:event|display=inline,title}} | type = [[Gunpowder magazine]] explosion | cause = Negligence | reported deaths = {{circa}} 150–240 | reported injuries = {{circa}} 100 | reported property damage = Very extensive }}
The '''Birgu polverista explosion''' was the accidental detonation of ammunition in the gunpowder magazine (polverista) of [[Birgu]] in the British [[Malta Protectorate]] on 18 July 1806. The explosion occurred due to negligence while transferring shells from the magazine, and it resulted in the detonation of {{convert|40000|lbs|abbr=on}} of gunpowder. It killed approximately 200 people, including British and Maltese military personnel and Maltese civilians from Birgu. Parts of the [[fortifications of Birgu|city's fortifications]], some naval stores, and many houses were destroyed, and the affected area became known as ''l-Imġarraf'' (Maltese for "the destroyed").
==Background== In the 18th and early 19th centuries, the main gunpowder store in Birgu was located in a [[casemate]] within the city walls, close to the ''Porta Marina''. This was an improvised measure; the casemate was not intended to be used as a gunpowder magazine, but such practice was common at the time. Gunpowder was also stored in casemates at other locations, such as [[Fort St. Angelo]], [[Fort Ricasoli]], and [[fortifications of Mdina|Mdina]].<ref>{{harvnb|Spiteri|2012|pp=18–19}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Spiteri|2012|p=39}}</ref> The Birgu magazine was located close to civilian housing, and the residents had complained about the dangers before the explosion. Preparations had been made to find alternative sites but nothing had been done; the storerooms that were meant to store gunpowder were being used as barracks or military hospitals.<ref name="maltaramc"/>
The 1806 explosion was not the first time that a gunpowder disaster occurred in Malta. On 12 September 1634, a gunpowder factory in Valletta [[1634 Valletta explosion|blew up]], killing 22 people and causing severe damage to the [[Church of the Jesuits, Valletta|Church of the Jesuits]] and [[Old University Building, Valletta|the nearby college]].<ref>{{harvnb|Spiteri|2012|p=6}}</ref> In 1662, gunpowder that was stored in an [[bartizan|echaugette]] on one of Valletta's [[counterguard]]s exploded after being hit by lightning, but there were no casualties.<ref>{{harvnb|Spiteri|2012|p=38}}</ref>
==Explosion== In July 1806, British forces in Malta were preparing ammunition stocks to be sent to Sicily after ammunition there had run low, since it had been used to relieve the defending garrison of [[Gaeta]] which had been [[Siege of Gaeta (1806)|under siege]] by the French. On 18 July, a working party of 13 men commanded by garrison gunner Bdr. Anderson were preparing a consignment of shells from the Birgu magazine,<ref name="maltaramc">{{cite web|title=Explosion Polverista Vittoriosa |url=https://www.maltaramc.com/regsurg/rs1800_1809/rmo1806.html |website=Medical Officers of the Malta Garrison |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170222050937/http://maltaramc.com/regsurg/rs1800_1809/rmo1806.html |archivedate=22 February 2017 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> which was filled at full capacity with 370 barrels containing {{convert|40000|lbs|abbr=on}} of gunpowder, as well as 1,600 shells and grenades.<ref name="spiteri-42">{{harvnb|Spiteri|2012|p=42}}</ref> Anderson was using a metal chisel to remove the fuses from live shells, which was contrary to instructions, and this resulted in sparks which caused a massive explosion at 06:15.
Anderson and the working party were killed immediately, as were three British soldiers of the [[39th (Dorsetshire) Regiment of Foot]] and 23 Maltese soldiers of the [[Maltese Provincial Battalions|2nd Provincial Battalion]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The Maltese Provincial Battalions|url=http://maltaramc.com/regmltgar/1stprov.html|publisher=maltaramc.com|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171203152832/http://maltaramc.com/regmltgar/1stprov.html|archivedate=3 December 2017}}</ref> Between 150<ref name="vittoriosahistorica"/> and 200 civilians from Birgu were also killed, and approximately 100 others were injured by falling debris.<ref name="maltaramc"/> The explosion frightened the inhabitants of Birgu, and it was also heard in the nearby cities of [[Senglea]] and [[Cospicua]], as well as in the surrounding villages.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Bulletin, Volume 57, Issue 225 – Volume 58, Issue 232|date=2006|publisher=Military Historical Society (Great Britain)|url=https://books.google.com/books?redir_esc=y&id=dDNVAAAAYAAJ|page=147|ref=hv}}</ref>
The magazine was located within the city's fortifications, and a section of the walls "went up in the air" and left a large breach.<ref name="bugeja-buhagiar-fiorini-1993">{{cite book|editor1-last=Bugeja|editor1-first=Lino|editor2-last=Buhagiar|editor2-first=Mario|editor3-last=Fiorini|editor3-first=Stanley|title=Birgu: A Maltese Maritime City|volume= 1|date=1993|publisher=Malta University Services|isbn=9789990944006|pages=159–160|url=https://books.google.com/books?redir_esc=y&id=YI7iAAAAMAAJ}}</ref> The city gate at the Porta Marina, a small bastion, and part of a curtain wall were all destroyed and were never rebuilt.<ref>{{cite web|title=Birgu |url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1507.pdf |website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160820074930/http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1507.pdf |archivedate=20 August 2016 |date=28 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Short stretch of stepped curtain wall leading down to Birgu Creek – Birgu |url=http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1517.pdf |website=National Inventory of the Cultural Property of the Maltese Islands |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160819160212/http://www.culturalheritage.gov.mt/filebank/inventory/Knights%20Fortifications/1517.pdf |archivedate=19 August 2016 |date=28 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Parts of the Navy Store Houses were also damaged or destroyed during the explosion.<ref name="maltaramc"/> Birgu's cityscape was also altered by the explosion, since a large number of houses were destroyed or damaged by the explosion itself and by the rocks which fell from the bastions.<ref name="bugeja-buhagiar-fiorini-1993"/> Four hundred ninety-three people reported property losses due to the explosion.<ref name="spiteri-42"/>
==Aftermath== Many Maltese people were angered at the loss of lives caused by negligence on behalf of the military. Civil Commissioner [[Alexander Ball]] reported that:<ref name="maltaramc"/> {{cquote|those Maltese who had already become disaffected with the Government, fanned the embers and fermented great agitation by magnifying the casualties and working upon the weakness and credibility of the lower ranks.|20px}} Victims and their families were paid partial compensation, and Ball set up a committee overseeing aid distribution. He also urged the government to pay full compensation. This was initially denied, but eventually the poorer classes received a compensation equivalent to two thirds of their property which had been destroyed, while those of the upper classes received half of the value of their property. In 1811, £18,066.5s.10d{{efn|Comparing 19th-century costs and prices with those of the modern period is challenging. £18,066.5s.10d in 1811 could be equivalent to between £1.2 million and £78.4 million in 2016, depending on the price comparison used.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Officer|first1=Lawrence H.|last2=Williamson|first2=Samuel H.|title=Five Ways to Compute the Relative Value of a UK Pound Amount, 1270 to Present|url=https://www.measuringworth.com/ukcompare/|website=MeasuringWorth.com|accessdate=23 May 2017|date=2014}}</ref>}} was evenly distributed among those who had claimed damages.<ref name="maltaramc"/> A wine merchant named Woodhouse lost a large amount of wine and the government provided him with extensive storehouses at the former [[Slaves' Prison]] in Valletta as a compensation.<ref name="maltaramc"/>
[[File:Birgu and Cottonera fortifications 01.jpg|thumb|Triq il-Vittmi tal-Porvlista]]
A street close to where the explosion occurred is now known as ''Triq il-Vittmi tal-Porvlista'' (Maltese for "Polverista Victims Street"). The Vittoriosa Historical and Cultural Society installed a plaque at the St. Lawrence Cemetery on the 200th anniversary of the disaster in 2006, where most of the victims were buried.<ref name="vittoriosahistorica">{{cite news|title=200th anniversary of the explosion at l-Imgarraf |url=http://www.vittoriosahistorica.org/news-2006-08.html#link_1 |work=Vittoriosa Historical & Cultural Society |date=August 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160619083317/http://www.vittoriosahistorica.org/news-2006-08.html |archivedate=19 June 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Notes== {{notelist}}
==References== {{reflist|30em}}

Spiteri|title=Hospitaller Gunpowder Magazines|journal=Arx – International Journal of Military Architecture and Fortification|date=2012|volume=Occasional Papers|issue=2|url=http://www.militaryarchitecture.com/index.php/Journals/arx-occasional-papers-hospitaller-gunpowder-magazines.html|ref=harv}} {{Refend}} ==Further reading== *[https://books.google.com.mt/books?id=HbCzLhVYkBsC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q=1806&f=false Page 86]

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2011}} {{Use Australian English|date=September 2011}} {{Infobox Aircraft accident |name = Sierra Kilo CharlieAustralian Transport Safety Bureau 2001, p. 34. |image = VH-SKC B.King Air 200 Central Avn PER 29SEP99 (6788436514).jpg |alt = A small aircraft with two propeller engines and six cabin windows on the ground |caption = VH-SKC seen at [[Perth Airport]] one year before the disaster. |date = 4 September 2000 |type = [[Hypoxia (medical)|Crew incapacitation]] due to [[uncontrolled decompression]]; cause unknown |occurrence_type = Accident |site = {{cvt|65|km|order=flip}} south-east of [[Burketown]], [[Queensland]], [[Australia]] |coords = |aircraft_type = [[Beechcraft Super King Air|Beechcraft 200 Super King Air]] |tail_number = VH-SKC |origin = [[Perth Airport]], [[Perth]], [[Western Australia]] |destination = [[Leonora Airport]], [[Leonora, Western Australia]] |passengers = 7 |crew = 1 |fatalities = 8 (all) |survivors = 0 }} On Monday 4 September 2000, a chartered [[Beechcraft Super King Air|Beechcraft 200 Super King Air]] departed [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]] for a flight to the mining town of [[Leonora, Western Australia|Leonora]], Western Australia. The aircraft crashed near [[Burketown]], [[Queensland]], [[Australia]] resulting in the deaths of all eight occupants.{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2002/03/23/1016843080716.html|title=The lonely end to a fateful trip|work=The Age|first=Steve|last=Pennells|date=24 March 2002|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141113024924/http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2002/03/23/1016843080716.html|archivedate=13 November 2014|df=dmy-all}} During the flight, the aircraft climbed above its assigned altitude. When [[air traffic control]] (ATC) contacted the pilot, the pilot's speech had become significantly impaired and he was unable to respond to instructions. Three aircraft intercepted the Beechcraft but were unable to make radio contact. The aircraft continued flying on a straight heading for five hours before running out of fuel and crashing {{cvt|65|km|order=flip}} south-east of Burketown.[http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/english/200009/05/eng20000905_49748.html "Plane Crashes in Australia, All Eight Aboard Dead", ''Peoples Daily'', 5 September 2000. Retrieved 1 February 2012] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080916091901/http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/english/200009/05/eng20000905_49748.html |date=16 September 2008 }} The accident became known in the media as the "'''Ghost Flight'''".[http://www.abc.net.au/pm/content/2003/s860702.htm Family of Ghost Flight plane crash victims angry with aviation regulator, CASA] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080129025055/http://www.abc.net.au/pm/content/2003/s860702.htm |date=29 January 2008 }}, [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC]], 21 May 2003. Retrieved 1 February 2012[http://au.news.yahoo.com/thewest/a/-/news/9642425/no-sound-from-pilot-as-ghost-flight-kept-going/ No sound from pilot as ghost flight kept going] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120203112828/http://au.news.yahoo.com/thewest/a/-/news/9642425/no-sound-from-pilot-as-ghost-flight-kept-going/ |date=3 February 2012 }}, [[The West Australian]], 15 June 2011. Retrieved 1 February 2012 A subsequent investigation concluded that the pilot and passengers had become incapacitated and had been suffering from [[Hypoxia (medical)|hypoxia]], a lack of oxygen to the body, meaning the pilot would have been unable to operate the aircraft. Towards the end of the flight, the left engine began to be starved of fuel and the aircraft crashed into the ground. The accident report said that, due to extensive damage to the aircraft, investigators were unable to conclude if any of the eight aboard had used the oxygen system. The [[Australian Transport Safety Bureau]] (ATSB) final report could not determine what incapacitated the occupants. A number of safety recommendations were made following the accident. ==Background== The aircraft involved in the accident was a [[Beechcraft Super King Air|Beechcraft 200 Super King Air]], [[aircraft registration|registration]] VH-SKC, [[serial number]] BB-47, manufactured in 1975. The aircraft had about 19,000 hours of service before the accident.Australian Transport Safety Bureau 2001, p. 4. The amount of air passed into the cabin is controlled by [[bleed air]] valves on the engines. The positions of the bleed air valves can be altered by the pilot.Australian Transport Safety Bureau 2001, p. 7. According to the accident report, "The aircraft was not fitted with a high cabin altitude aural warning device, nor was it required to be."Australian Transport Safety Bureau 2001, p. 6. The aircraft was fitted with an [[emergency oxygen system]]—an [[oxygen tank]] which could supply [[oxygen]] to the crew through two masks located in the cockpit and to passengers through masks which drop from the ceiling of the cabin.Australian Transport Safety Bureau 2001, p. 8. Accident investigators concluded the aircraft was airworthy at the time the accident occurred, and a pilot who flew the aircraft earlier in the day said the aircraft functioned normally.Australian Transport Safety Bureau 2001, p. 12. "The maintenance release was current and an examination of the aircraft’s maintenance records found no recurring maintenance problems that may have been factors in the accident," the accident report stated.Australian Transport Safety Bureau 2001, p. 11. ==Accident== [[File:Sons of Gwalia mine, c1921.jpg|thumb|left|The aircraft was flying to [[Gwalia Gold Mine]], in [[Leonora, Western Australia|Leonora]], [[Western Australia]].|alt=A black and white photograph of a busy mine with several smoking chimneys and industrial buildings]] On 4 September 2000,Australian Transport Safety Bureau 2001, p. 1. the Beechcraft, chartered by mining company [[Sons of Gwalia]],{{cite web|last=Lalor|first=Peter|title=Media Release re: Aircraft Accident|url=http://www.asx.com.au/asx/statistics/displayAnnouncement.do?display=text&issuerId=1167&announcementId=202941|publisher=[[Sons of Gwalia]]|accessdate=5 January 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706102037/http://www.asx.com.au/asx/statistics/displayAnnouncement.do?display=text&issuerId=1167&announcementId=202941|archivedate=6 July 2011|df=dmy-all}} departed [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]], [[Western Australia]], for the town of [[Leonora, Western Australia|Leonora]], Western Australia, On board were seven mine workers travelling to [[Gwalia Gold Mine]]. The aircraft [[takeoff|took off]] from Perth at 6:09 pm local time (1009 [[Coordinated Universal Time]] (UTC)), and was cleared by ATC to climb to [[flight level|FL]]130 ({{convert|13000|ft|m}}). Five minutes later, at 1015, it was further cleared to its [[cruising altitude]] of FL250 ({{convert|25000|ft|m}}); with an instruction to be at FL160 by {{convert|36|nmi}} from Perth. The pilot acknowledged this transmission. Five minutes later, at 1020, as the aircraft climbed through FL156 ({{convert|15600|ft|m}}) it was cleared to [[waypoint]] DEBRA. The pilot again acknowledged. At approximately 1033 the aircraft passed through its cleared level and at FL256 ({{convert|25600|ft|m}}) ATC asked the pilot to confirm his altitude. “Sierra Kilo Charlie–um–standby," the pilot said. This was the final spoken transmission from the aircraft, and its climb continued. According to the accident report, several open-microphone transmissions followed, with the sound of background noise from the engines, a person breathing, "one unintelligible syllable", and "two chime-like tones, similar to those generated by electronic devices." During this time ATC attempted to regain contact with the pilot. "Sierra Kilo Charlie Sierra Kilo Charlie, Melbourne Centre, if receiving this transmission squawk ident" the controller said at 1040.Australian Transport Safety Bureau 2001, p. 36. At 1041, the controller asked again, "Sierra Kilo Charlie, only receiving open mike from you. Would you contact me on one two five decimal two."Australian Transport Safety Bureau 2001, p. 37. [[File:Alice Springs ridge.jpeg|thumb|The aircraft was sighted by the two aircraft in the [[Northern Territory]], northwest of [[Alice Springs]]|alt=An expansive plain with a large mountainous ridge running through it along a curved line]] The aircraft continued to climb and left radar coverage at 1102, passing FL325 ({{convert|32500|ft|m}}). Thirty-one minutes later, [[Search and rescue#Australia|Australian Search and Rescue]] asked the crew of a business jet to approach the Beechcraft. They reported that it was in level flight at FL343 ({{convert|34300|ft|m}}), and they could see no movement on the flight deck or in the cabin. However, the conditions made it difficult to observe closely. Two other aircraft which were asked to monitor the Beechcraft intercepted it over the [[Northern Territory]], north-west of [[Alice Springs]]. The pilots reported that it was now in a steady descent, and both aircraft followed it as its [[airspeed]] increased. "Although its external lights were on, nothing could be seen inside the cabin" the accident report stated. "The crews of the chase aircraft attempted to contact the pilot of the Beechcraft by radio but they did not receive a response." At 1510, the aircraft turned left through 90 degrees as it descended through {{convert|5000|ft|m}}. About {{cvt|65|km|order=flip}} south-east of [[Burketown]], Queensland, it hit the ground and broke up.{{cite news|title=Australian 'ghost flight' still a mystery|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/2253039.stm|accessdate=8 January 2011|newspaper=[[BBC News Online]]|date=12 September 2002|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060223105348/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/2253039.stm|archivedate=23 February 2006|df=dmy-all}} The pilot and seven passengers were killed.Australian Transport Safety Bureau 2001, p. 2. ==Investigation== The accident was investigated by the [[Australian Transport Safety Bureau]] (ATSB), a federal body responsible for investigating transportation accidents in Australia.Australian Transport Safety Bureau 2001, p. v. The final accident report was published in March 2001.Australian Transport Safety Bureau 2001, p. ii. The report was unable to make a definitive conclusion as to the cause of the crash.Australian Transport Safety Bureau 2001, p. vii. The report found all those aboard the aircraft, including the pilot, had likely become incapacitated and begun suffering from [[Hypoxia (medical)|hypoxia]].Australian Transport Safety Bureau 2001, p. 26. The accident report stated, "After the aircraft climbed above the assigned altitude of FL250, the speech and breathing patterns of the pilot, evidenced during the radio transmissions, displayed changes consistent with hypoxia."Australian Transport Safety Bureau 2001, p. 29. Investigators were, however, unable to conclusively dismiss toxic fumes as the cause.{{cite news|last=Marks|first=Kathy|title=Inquest fails to solve mystery of 'ghost plane' that flew for six hours|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/australasia/inquest-fails-to-solve-mystery-of-ghost-plane-that-flew-for-six-hours-642638.html|accessdate=8 January 2010|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=13 September 2002|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121110091522/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/australasia/inquest-fails-to-solve-mystery-of-ghost-plane-that-flew-for-six-hours-642638.html|archivedate=10 November 2012|df=dmy-all}} "The incapacitation of the pilot and passengers was probably due to hypobaric hypoxia because of the high cabin altitude and their not receiving supplemental oxygen" the report said, adding, "The reasons for the pilot and passengers not receiving supplemental oxygen [from the oxygen tank aboard the aircraft] could not be determined." The ATSB found it likely that the autopilot was engaged and this caused the aircraft to fly on a straight heading; the vertical path of the aircraft indicated climb power had been set before the occupants of the aircraft were incapacitated. "The design of the aircraft systems were such that, with the autopilot engaged, the engines would continue to operate and the aircraft would continue to fly without human input until it was disrupted by other events, such as collision or fuel exhaustion," according to the accident report. It was suggested that, towards the end of the flight, the fuel tank for the left engine was almost empty. "The near exhaustion of fuel in the left wing tanks may have produced at least one, and probably several, momentary losses of left engine power shortly before all power was lost" the report said. "The aircraft yawed and rolled towards the left engine, as was observed shortly before the aircraft collided with the ground."Australian Transport Safety Bureau 2001, p. 25. The accident report said due to the damage to the aircraft upon impact with the ground, investigators were unable to conclude if any of the eight aboard used the oxygen system. However, the report stated "The absence of a distress radio call, or an attempt to descend the aircraft, and the likelihood that the pilot did not don his oxygen mask, suggested that the pilot was unaware that the aircraft was unpressurised or depressurising." The passengers, the report added, were also likely not wearing their oxygen masks, as there was no noise recorded on the ATC transmissions indicating they were attempting to assist the pilot. Investigators were not able to determine what caused the depressurisation of the aircraft, but stated likely causes included either an incorrect switch selection due to [[pilot error]] or a mechanical failure in the aircraft pressurisation system. The air traffic control recordings suggested it was unlikely a [[rapid decompression]] had occurred. "During an explosive or rapid depressurisation of a pressurised aircraft, however, the noise, pressure changes, temperature changes and draughts within the cabin would have alerted the occupants that a substantial failure had occurred," the report added. The document listed the two main factors in the accident as, {{Quotation|1. The aircraft was probably unpressurised for a significant part of its climb and cruise for undetermined reasons.
2. The pilot and passengers were incapacitated, probably due to hypobaric hypoxia, because of the high cabin altitude and their not receiving supplemental oxygen.}} ==Aural warning== In the aftermath of an incident in 1999 in which the pilot of a Beechcraft Super King Air suffered hypoxia, the ATSB published Report 199902928 and recommended an aural warning be fitted on the flight deck of all Australian Beechcraft Super King Air aircraft.Australian Transport Safety Bureau 2001, p. 27.[http://www.atsb.gov.au/publications/investigation_reports/1999/aair/aair199902928.aspx Investigation No. 199902928] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120122140812/http://atsb.gov.au/publications/investigation_reports/1999/AAIR/aair199902928.aspx |date=22 January 2012 }} Australian Transport Safety Bureau, 7 February 2001. Retrieved 1 February 2012Australian Transport Safety Bureau 2001, Section 1.17, p. 20. The flight deck of the Beechcraft Super King Air only has visual warning of inadequate cabin pressure.Australian Transport Safety Bureau 2001, Section 1.6.3.1, p. 5. In the aftermath of the Ghost Flight, the Civil Aviation Safety Authority issued a Discussion Paper[http://www.casa.gov.au/newrules/parts/039/download/dp0102cs.pdf Discussion Paper DP 0102 CS - Proposal for Aural Warning to Operate With Cabin Altitude Alert Warning Systems] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080805164310/http://casa.gov.au/newrules/parts/039/download/dp0102cs.pdf |date=5 August 2008 }}, CASA, February 2001. Retrieved on 2012-02-01 and a [[Notice of proposed rulemaking|Notice of Proposed Rule Making]] (NPRM),[http://www.casa.gov.au/newrules/parts/039/download/nprm0216cs.pdf Notice of Proposed Rule Making 0216 CS - Proposal for Aural Warning to Operate With Cabin Altitude Warning Systems] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080805152004/http://casa.gov.au/newrules/parts/039/download/nprm0216cs.pdf |date=5 August 2008 }}, CASA, April 2002. Retrieved on 2012-02-01 both proposing aural warning in the Beechcraft Super King Air and other pressurised aircraft. The outcome of consultation on the NPRM was that the Civil Aviation Safety Authority did not mandate aural warning of inadequate cabin pressure and this angered the families of some of the victims. Instead, the Civil Aviation Safety Authority issued a notice to owners of pressurised aircraft registered in Australia recommending installation of an aural warning, but not making it mandatory. The notice said, "The benefit to your pilots and passengers lies in the reduction in risk of an uncommanded depressurisation leading to an incident or fatal accident. The benefit is much greater than the cost of purchase and installation of one of these low-cost systems."{{cite web|title=Aviation safety recommendations and advisory notices|url=http://www.atsb.gov.au/publications/recommendations/2000/r20000288.aspx|publisher=[[Australian Transport Safety Bureau]]|accessdate=8 January 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101212161417/http://atsb.gov.au/publications/recommendations/2000/r20000288.aspx|archivedate=12 December 2010|df=dmy-all}} ==Coroner's inquest== The West Australian Coroner, Mr. Alistair Hope, conducted an inquest into the deaths of the eight occupants of the aircraft. The inquest determined that the deaths were accidental, but was unable to determine the cause of the crash. The Coroner recommended an aural alarm system for pressurised aircraft, and a low-cost ''black box'' [[Flight data recorder|flight recorder]].[http://www.abc.net.au/pm/stories/s674866.htm Ian Townsend, "Coroner {{sic|critises}} ATSB following plane crash", ''ABC-PM'',12 September 2002. Retrieved 1 February 2012] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080208143632/http://www.abc.net.au/pm/stories/s674866.htm |date=8 February 2008 }} The Coroner was critical of the poor co-ordination between the ATSB, the Queensland Police and the [[Civil Aviation Safety Authority]] (CASA). He also criticised the ATSB for failing to take notes when interviewing witnesses, and for its poor presentation of evidence. ==Air traffic control== When the air traffic controller responsible for the Beechcraft received the open-microphone transmissions, he alerted his supervisor that he was concerned the pilot could be suffering from hypoxia. The controller and his supervisor completed the standard checklist which, at the time, did not include a procedure to follow in the case of incapacitation or hypoxia. In the aftermath of the accident, the checklist was changed to "incorporate procedures to be followed by air traffic controllers, when a controller suspects that a pilot has been affected by hypoxia."Australian Transport Safety Bureau 2001, p. 13. ==See also== {{Portal|Aviation|Australia}} *[[1999 South Dakota Learjet crash]] *[[2000 in aviation]] *[[2000 in Australia]] *[[Aviation safety]] *[[Helios Airways Flight 522]] *[[Uncontrolled decompression#Notable decompression accidents and incidents|Notable decompression accidents and incidents]] ==References== ;Notes {{reflist|3}} ;Bibliography *{{cite book|title='''Pilot and Passenger Incapacitation''' (Investigation Report 200003771) |publisher=[[Australian Transport Safety Bureau]]|isbn=0-642-20046-7|pages=50|location=Australia|url=https://www.atsb.gov.au/media/24344/aair200003771_001.pdf |date=March 2001}} {{Aviation accidents and incidents in 2000}} {{coord|-18.125|140.05|type:landmark_region:AU-QLD|name=65 km south-east of Burketown|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2000 Australia Beechcraft King Air Crash}} [[Category:Aviation accidents and incidents in 2000]] [[Category:Aviation accidents and incidents in Queensland]] [[Category:2000 in Australia|Australia Beechcraft King Air Crash, 2000]] [[Category:Airliner accidents and incidents caused by pilot incapacitation]] [[Category:Accidents and incidents involving the Beechcraft King Air]] [[Category:Decompression accidents and incidents]] [[Category:Disasters in Queensland]] [[Category:North West Queensland]] [[Category:20th century in Queensland]] [[Category:September 2000 events]]

{{refimprove|date=December 2015}} Throughout the 1980s and 1990s, Turkey relied heavily on [[Foreign direct investment|foreign investment]] for [[economic growth]], with trade above 40% of GNP.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.country-data.com/cgi-bin/query/r-13974.html |title=Turkey - Foreign Trade |publisher=Country-data.com |date=1964-12-01 |accessdate=2015-07-23}}</ref> The [[Politics of Turkey|Turkish government]] and banking systems lacked the financial means to support meaningful economic growth. The government was already running enormous [[budget deficit]]s, and one of the ways it managed to sustain these was by selling huge quantities of high-interest bonds to Turkish banks. Continuing inflation (likely a result of the enormous flow of foreign capital into Turkey) meant that the government could avoid defaulting on the bonds in the short term. As a consequence, Turkish banks came to rely on these [[High-yield debt|high-yield bonds]] as a primary investment.<ref>THE 2000-2001 FINANCIAL CRISIS IN TURKEY by Fatih Özatay and Güven Sak, Central Bank of Turkey and [[Ankara University]].August 2002 (revised)</ref>
==Political instability== In March 1997 a Coalition was formed between the [[Motherland Party (Turkey)|Motherland Party]]'s [[Mesut Yılmaz]] and the [[True Path Party]]'s [[Tansu Çiller]]. The plan was for Yilmaz and Cillar to alternate the [[Prime minister|Prime Ministry]].<ref>pp.169</ref> However, there was much public distraction caused by leader of the [[Welfare Party]] [[Necmettin Erbakan]]'s threats to investigate Cillar for corruption. Meanwhile, Erbakan, who had been excluded from the coalition, did everything he could to rally support for an Islamic NATO, and an Islamic version of [[European Union|the European Union]].
The Motherland Coalition collapsed in part because of Erbakan's widespread public support. Addition tensions wreaked havoc on the government. Yilmaz was forced to resign on June 6, 1996, with the government having lasted for only 90 days.<ref>pp.169</ref> Erbakan became Prime Minister on June 29 as the head of a Welfare/True Path coalition.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bohlen |first=Celestine |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/09/world/islamic-secular-coalition-cabinet-is-approved-in-turkey.html?n=Top/Reference/Times%20Topics/Subjects/I/Islam |title=Islamic-Secular Coalition Cabinet Is Approved in Turkey |location=Turkey; |publisher=NYTimes.com |date=1996-07-09 |accessdate=2015-07-23}}</ref> The success of the new Welfare-Path Coalition was viewed with hostility by the military. Erbakan's explicitly Islamist policies resulted in a post modern coup in which the military forced Erbakan to yield power to Demirel who yielded to Yilmaz on June 19, 1997. The political fighting between Yilmaz and Cillar on one side, and Erbakan on the other would continue, making coalitions difficult to create. In addition, corruption was rampant at this time. People were highly disillusioned with their government. This lack of faith and efficacy would cause foreign nations to carefully examine any investment in Turkey.
==Foreign divestment== The [[International Monetary Fund]] (IMF) team in 1996 warned of an impending [[financial crisis]] because of the deficit, which soon came into being. Turkey's unstable political landscape led many foreign investors to divest from the country. As [[Investment|foreign investors]] observed the political turmoil and the government's attempts to eliminate the budget deficit,<ref>THE 2000-2001 FINANCIAL CRISIS IN TURKEY by Fatih Özatay and Güven Sak, Central Bank of Turkey and Ankara University.August 2002 (revised)</ref> they withdrew $70 billion worth of capital from the country in a matter of months. This left a vacuum of capital that Turkish banks were unable to alleviate because the government was no longer able to pay off its bonds. With no capital to speak of, the [[Economy of Turkey|Turkish economy]] slowed dramatically.
==Stabilization efforts== In November 2000, the IMF provided Turkey with $11.4 billion in loans <ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/1057382.stm |title=BUSINESS | IMF agrees Turkish loans |publisher=BBC News |date=2000-12-06 |accessdate=2015-07-23}}</ref> and Turkey sold many of its state-owned industries in an effort to balance the budget. In the case of [[Turkish Airlines]], advertisements were placed in newspapers to attract offers for a 51% stake in the company.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/1193128.stm |title=BUSINESS | Turkish air sell-off delayed |publisher=BBC News |date=2001-02-28 |accessdate=2015-07-23}}</ref> By 2000 there was massive unemployment, a lack of medicine, tight credit, slow production to fight inflation and increasing taxes. Stabilisation efforts had yet to produce any meaningful effects, and the IMF loan was widely seen as insufficient.<ref>BEHIND THE 2000/2001 TURKISH CRISIS: Stability, Credibility, and Governance, for Whom? by Erinç Yeldan, [[Bilkent University]] Department of Economics</ref>
==Crash== On February 19, 2001, Prime Minister Ecevit emerged from a meeting with President Sezer saying, "This is a serious crisis."<ref>pp.176</ref> This underscored financial and political instability and led to further panic in the markets. Stocks plummeted and the [[interest rate]] reached 3,000%. Large quantities of [[Turkish lira]] were exchanged for [[United States dollar|U.S. dollars]] or euro, causing the [[Central Bank of the Republic of Turkey|Turkish central bank]] to lose $5 billion of its reserves.
The crash triggered even more economic turmoil. In the first eight months of 2001, 14,875 jobs were lost, the dollar rose to 1,500,000 liras, and [[income inequality]] had risen from its already high level.<ref>pp.178</ref>
==Significance== The crash was emblematic of the political and economic problems that had been wearing on Turkey for years. Confidence in the government had been eroded by corruption and the inability to form lasting coalitions. The [[stock market crash]] revealed Turkey's economic situation to be not only extremely fragile but also entirely dependent on foreign investment. Although not as significant as decreased foreign investment or the massive budget deficit, the crash highlights Turkey's recent political instability.
Critical interpretations look more fundamentally at the effects of the 2001 crisis on Turkish society and its post-1980s turn to neoliberalism. According to one journal article, the 2001 Turkish crisis and state-organised rescue served to preserve, renew, and intensify "the structurally unequal social relations of power and class characteristic of finance-led neoliberal capitalism" in ways institutionally specific to Turkish society.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Marois|first1=Thomas|title=Emerging market bank rescues in an era of finance-led neoliberalism: A comparison of Mexico and Turkey|journal=Review of International Political Economy|date=May 2011|volume=18|issue=2|pages=168–196|doi=10.1080/09692290903475474}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Turkish currency and debt crisis, 2018]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==References== * Ahmad, F. (2003). ''Turkey: The Quest for Identity''. Oxford: Oneworld.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Turkish Stock Market Crash Of 2001}} [[Category:Economic history of Turkey]] [[Category:2001 in Turkey]] [[Category:Economic crises]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 23 sources and tagging 2 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10ehf1)
revision.text:
{{update|date=September 2016}} In 2011, as the widely reported protests sparked off by [[Mohamed Bouazizi]]'s self-immolation in [[Tunisia]] began to have a clear impact on the Tunisian government, a wave of [[self-immolation]]s swept [[Algeria]]. These individual acts of protest mostly took place in front of a government building following an unsuccessful approach to the authorities. Four self-immolators have died of their burns so far.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ennaharonline.com/en/news/5671.html |title=Algeria: Third death by self-immolation |publisher=Ennahar Online |date= |accessdate=2011-02-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110204162256/http://www.ennaharonline.com/en/news/5671.html |archive-date=2011-02-04 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="Jeune Afrique">{{cite web|url=http://www.jeuneafrique.com/Article/ARTJAWEB20110212105526/algerie-pauvrete-tunisie-manifestationquatrieme-deces-par-immolation-en-algerie-a-la-veille-de-la-marche-du-12-fevrier.html |title=Jeune Afrique, 12/01/2011, Quatrième décès par immolation en Algérie, à la veille de la marche du 12 février |publisher=Jeune Afrique |date= |accessdate=2011-02-17| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110215082132/http://www.jeuneafrique.com/Article/ARTJAWEB20110212105526/algerie-pauvrete-tunisie-manifestationquatrieme-deces-par-immolation-en-algerie-a-la-veille-de-la-marche-du-12-fevrier.html| archivedate= 15 February 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
It began on 12 January, when 26-year-old Mohamed Aouichia set himself on fire in [[Bordj Menaiel]] in the compound of the ''[[Districts of Algeria|daira]]'' building. He had been sharing a room of 30 square metres with seven other people, including his sister, since 2003; he had repeatedly approached local authorities to get on the social housing list and been rebuffed.<ref name="courrierinternational1">{{cite web |url=http://www.courrierinternational.com/article/2011/01/21/je-brule-donc-je-suis |title=Courrier International, 21/01/2011, ''Je brûle donc je suis'' |publisher=Courrierinternational.com |date=2011-01-21 |accessdate=2011-02-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110124191523/http://www.courrierinternational.com/article/2011/01/21/je-brule-donc-je-suis |archive-date=2011-01-24 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> He has so far survived.
On 13 January, [[Mohsen Bouterfif]], a 37-year-old father of two, set himself on fire. He had gone with about twenty other youths to protest in front of the town hall of [[Boukhadra]] in Tebessa demanding jobs and houses, after the mayor refused to receive them. According to one testimony, the mayor shouted to them: "If you have courage, do like Bouazizi did, set yourself on fire!"<ref>{{cite web|url= http://dna-algerie.com/politique/42-interieure/1210-le-maire-a-mohcin-bouterfif-l-si-tu-as-du-courage-fais-comme-bouazizi-immole-toi-par-le-feu-r.html|title= Le maire à Mohcin Bouterfif : " Si tu as du courage, fais comme Bouazizi, immole-toi par le feu "|access-date= 2011-02-17|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110128205205/http://dna-algerie.com/politique/42-interieure/1210-le-maire-a-mohcin-bouterfif-l-si-tu-as-du-courage-fais-comme-bouazizi-immole-toi-par-le-feu-r.html/|archive-date= 2011-01-28|dead-url= yes|df= }}</ref> His death was reported on 16 January, and about 100 youths protested his death causing the provincial governor to sack the mayor.<ref name="bouterfif_aljaz">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/20111162363063915.html|title=Algerian dies from self-immolation|access-date=2011-02-17|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110217081340/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/01/20111162363063915.html|archive-date=2011-02-17|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> However, hospital staff the following day claimed he was still alive, though in critical condition.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jeuneafrique.com/Article/ARTJAWEB20110117084410/algerie-pauvrete-tunisie-mostaganemvague-de-tentatives-de-suicide-par-le-feu-en-algerie.html |title=''Vague de tentatives de suicide par le feu en Algérie'' |publisher=Jeune Afrique |date=2001-01-17 |accessdate=2011-02-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110120040940/http://www.jeuneafrique.com/Article/ARTJAWEB20110117084410/algerie-pauvrete-tunisie-mostaganemvague-de-tentatives-de-suicide-par-le-feu-en-algerie.html |archive-date=2011-01-20 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> [[Al Jazeera]] described the suicide as "echoing the [[Mohamed Bouazizi#Confiscation of wares and self-immolation|self-immolation]] that triggered the [[2010–2011 Tunisian protests|protests]] that toppled the leader of neighbouring Tunisia."<ref name="bouterfif_aljaz" /> He finally died on 24 January at a hospital in Annaba.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/xinhua/2011-01-25/content_1642189.html |title=Algeria reports 2nd death of self-immolation |author=Xinhua |date=2011-01-25 |work=[[China Daily]] |accessdate=2011-02-22 }}{{dead link|date=September 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
These suicides were followed by dozens more attempted or successful self-immolations across the country, so far without triggering nationwide demonstrations, most of them after the Tunisian dictator [[Zine El Abidine Ben Ali]] fled his country on 14 January; cases included: * 14 January: ** Said H. (26 years old, unemployed bachelor), in front of the Urban Security offices in [[Jijel]]; taken to hospital with no visits allowed.<ref>[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hIieaAjXEknufAnVTWckOC1QTiQA?docId=CNG.83a73467b5bde9d78bcc4ea009d81b00.7d1 AFP, 17/01/2011, ''Un Algérien s'immole par le feu''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120213090855/http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hIieaAjXEknufAnVTWckOC1QTiQA?docId=CNG.83a73467b5bde9d78bcc4ea009d81b00.7d1 |date=2012-02-13 }}, [http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/ils-ont-tente-de-mettre-fin-a-leur-vie-17-01-2011-107513_109.php El Watan, 17/01/2011, ''Jijel : Le jeune Saïd évacué à Aïn Naâdja''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110121063059/http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/ils-ont-tente-de-mettre-fin-a-leur-vie-17-01-2011-107513_109.php |date=2011-01-21 }}, [http://jijel.info/content/prions-pour-saïd Jijel.info, 19/11/2011, "Prions pour Saïd"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306220048/http://jijel.info/content/prions-pour-sa%C3%AFd |date=2012-03-06 }}</ref> * 15 January: ** Senouci Touati (34 years old, unemployed), in [[Mostaganem]] - had not heard of the previous Algerian cases; frustrated by what he considered an unjustified discharge from the army without a pension.<ref name="courrierinternational1"/> * 16 January: ** About 20 ''[[harraga]]'' (would-be illegal emigrants) from [[Annaba]], who attempted to set their boat on fire when approached by the coast guard; the fire was extinguished, but the fate of two of the people on the boat is unknown.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/une-vingtaine-de-harraga-brulent-leur-embarcation-18-01-2011-107691_109.php |title=El Watan, 18/01/2011, ''Une vingtaine de harraga brûlent leur embarcation'' |publisher=Elwatan.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110121063104/http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/une-vingtaine-de-harraga-brulent-leur-embarcation-18-01-2011-107691_109.php |archive-date=2011-01-21 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> ** Mehanaine Karim (38-year-old fireman, father of three), got two bottles of petrol and threatened to burn himself in the fire station at [[Oum El Bouaghi]] after being told he would be sent to [[Illizi]] in the extreme south; he was dissuaded by the local governor before lighting it.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dna-algerie.com/politique/42-interieure/1156-cinq-tentatives-de-suicide-par-immolation-en-moins-dune-semaine-en-algerie-le-feu-du-desespoir.html |title=DNA, 16/01/2011, ''ALGERIE : 5 tentatives de suicide par immolation en moins d’une semaine : Le feu du désespoir'' |publisher=Dna-algerie.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110119011630/http://dna-algerie.com/politique/42-interieure/1156-cinq-tentatives-de-suicide-par-immolation-en-moins-dune-semaine-en-algerie-le-feu-du-desespoir.html |archive-date=2011-01-19 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> * 17 January: ** Fatima (a woman in her 50s), in front of the town hall of [[Sidi Ali Benyoub]] near [[Sidi Bel Abbes]] - successfully dissuaded before lighting the fire. She had been living with her brothers, with whom she did not get along, and had repeatedly requested housing with no success; she decided to set herself on fire after her mother was "humiliated" by the town authorities while asking about housing.<ref>[http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/une-quinquagenaire-tente-de-s-immoler-par-le-feu-19-01-2011-107845_109.php El Watan, 19/01/2011, ''Une quinquagénaire tente de s’immoler par le feu''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110123103113/http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/une-quinquagenaire-tente-de-s-immoler-par-le-feu-19-01-2011-107845_109.php |date=2011-01-23 }}, [http://www.elwatan.com/weekend/7jours/immolation-je-brule-donc-je-suis-21-01-2011-108133_178.php El Watan] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110124022317/http://www.elwatan.com//weekend//7jours//immolation-je-brule-donc-je-suis-21-01-2011-108133_178.php |date=2011-01-24 }}, 21/01/2011, ''Immolation : Je brûle, donc je suis''</ref> ** Maamir Lotfi (36 years old, unemployed father of four), in front of the [[El Oued]] town hall; had unsuccessfully asked to meet the governor; taken to hospital with second-degree burns;<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/un-jeune-a-tente-de-s-immoler-par-le-feu-au-siege-de-l-apw-d-el-oued-17-01-2011-107600_109.php |title=El Watan, 17/01/2011, Un jeune a tenté de s'immoler par le feu au siège de l'APW d’El Oued |publisher=Elwatan.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-01 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> died on 12 February<ref name="Jeune Afrique"/> * 18 January: ** Karim Benidine (35-year-old bachelor said to have mental problems), in front of the town hall in [[Dellys]], critically burned and transferred to hospital.<ref>[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5img-ynFlpYF13EXdIZgg3RTMc9rA?docId=CNG.214b827978fda9860aa914900d62055f.6c1 AFP, 19/01/2011, ''Algérie: 7e tentative d'immolation par le feu dans l'est du pays''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120212205726/http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5img-ynFlpYF13EXdIZgg3RTMc9rA?docId=CNG.214b827978fda9860aa914900d62055f.6c1 |date=2012-02-12 }}; [http://www.letempsdz.com/content/view/51761/1/ Le Temps, 19/01/2011, ''3 personnes s’immolent par le feu à Dellys, Sidi Bel Abbès et El Oued''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713202058/http://www.letempsdz.com/content/view/51761/1/ |date=2011-07-13 }}</ref> He died from his burns on 22 January at Douera hospital in Algiers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/boumerdes-le-citoyen-qui-s-est-immole-par-le-feu-a-dellys-succombe-a-ses-blessures-23-01-2011-108410_109.php |title=El Watan, 23/01/2011, ''Boumerdès : le citoyen qui s’est immolé par le feu à Dellys succombe à ses blessures'' |publisher=Elwatan.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110126001719/http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/boumerdes-le-citoyen-qui-s-est-immole-par-le-feu-a-dellys-succombe-a-ses-blessures-23-01-2011-108410_109.php |archive-date=2011-01-26 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> ** A young man (23 years old), at [[Berriane]] in the Sahara; attempted to burn himself in front of the ''daira'' office; saved with only light burns on his right foot<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.monde-presse.com/algerie/2034-dellysberriane-et-el-oued-trois-autres-cas-dimmolation |title=Monde-Press, ''Dellys,Berriane et El-Oued, Trois autres cas d’immolation'' |publisher=Monde-presse.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-01 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20110123073713/http://www.monde-presse.com/algerie/2034-dellysberriane-et-el-oued-trois-autres-cas-dimmolation |archive-date=2011-01-23 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> * 19 January: ** Afif Hadri (37-year-old father of six), in [[El Oued]], saved in time by onlookers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leparisien.fr/international/en-algerie-un-vendeur-a-la-sauvette-tente-de-s-immoler-par-le-feu-19-01-2011-1234330.php |title=Le Parisien, 19/01/2011, ''En Algérie, un vendeur à la sauvette tente de s'immoler par le feu |publisher=Leparisien.fr |date=2011-01-19 |accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref> ** G. Seguir (54 years old, blind and handicapped), in [[M'Sila]], covered himself in an Algerian flag and sprinkled himself, his 11-year-old son, and his 8-year-old daughter with petrol while standing in front of the [[wilaya]] seat, threatening to set himself and them on fire. After an hour of tense negotiations with an official, he let the children go and tried to set himself on fire; the onlookers managed to stop the fire and took him to hospital. Reportedly, the immediate provocation was that his family's electricity had been left cut off by [[Sonelgaz]] even after he scraped together the money to pay the bill.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.elwatan.com/weekend/7jours/immolation-je-brule-donc-je-suis-21-01-2011-108133_178.php |work=El Watan |date=2011-01-21 |language=French |title=Immolation : Je brûle, donc je suis |access-date=2011-02-17 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110124022317/http://www.elwatan.com//weekend//7jours//immolation-je-brule-donc-je-suis-21-01-2011-108133_178.php |archive-date=2011-01-24 |dead-url=yes |df= }}; {{cite web |url=http://www.liberte-algerie.com/edit.php?id=149427&titre=Un%20p%E8re%20de%20famille%20tente%20de%20s%92immoler%20avec%20ses%20deux%20enfants |work=Liberté |date=2011-01-22 |title=Pour se plaindre de ses conditions de vie à M’Sila: Un père de famille tente de s’immoler avec ses deux enfants |language=French }}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}; {{cite web |url=http://www.elwatan.com/une/un-pere-et-ses-deux-enfants-tentent-de-s-immoler-a-m-sila-20-01-2011-108061_108.php |title=Un père et ses deux enfants tentent de s'immoler à M'sila ! |language=French |work=El Watan |date=2011-01-20 |access-date=2011-02-17 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110123013239/http://www.elwatan.com/une/un-pere-et-ses-deux-enfants-tentent-de-s-immoler-a-m-sila-20-01-2011-108061_108.php |archive-date=2011-01-23 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> ** K. L. (26 years old), inside the tribunal of [[Ras El Oued, Algeria|Ras El Oued]] near [[Bordj Bou Arreridj]], after the authorities refused to return his motorcycle which was confiscated after an accident; he was stopped quickly, and survived with only light burns.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.elwatan.com/weekend/7jours/immolation-je-brule-donc-je-suis-21-01-2011-108133_178.php |work=El Watan |date=2011-01-21 |title=Immolation : Je brûle, donc je suis |language=French |access-date=2011-02-17 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110124022317/http://www.elwatan.com//weekend//7jours//immolation-je-brule-donc-je-suis-21-01-2011-108133_178.php |archive-date=2011-01-24 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
The Ministry of Religious Affairs responded to this wave of self-immolations by devoting the Friday sermons of 21 January to admonitions of patience and reminders that suicide is forbidden in Islam.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.liberte-algerie.com/edit.php?id=149426&titre=Les%20imams%20déclarent%20"illicite"%20l’immolation%20par%20le%20feu |work=Liberté |date=2011-01-22 |title=Les imams déclarent "illicite" l’immolation par le feu |language=French }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> However, some cases continued to be reported over coming days:
* 23 January: ** A teenager in [[Oued Taourrira]] near [[Sidi Bel Abbes]] set himself on fire, apparently following a family altercation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/un-adolescent-tente-de-se-suicider-en-s-immolant-par-le-feu-a-oued-taourrira-sidi-bel-abbes-25-01-2011-108754_109.php |title=''Un adolescent tente de se suicider en s’immolant par le feu à Oued Taourrira (Sidi Bel Abbès)'' |publisher=El Watan |date=2011-01-25 |accessdate=2011-02-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110128033418/http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/un-adolescent-tente-de-se-suicider-en-s-immolant-par-le-feu-a-oued-taourrira-sidi-bel-abbes-25-01-2011-108754_109.php |archive-date=2011-01-28 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> * 25 January: ** Kamel Bouria (38-year-old fireman, father of one), in [[Oum El Bouaghi]], set himself on fire following workplace difficulties. Another fireman at the same station, Karim Mehanaine, had threatened to do the same some days earlier, but been dissuaded.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://dna-algerie.com/politique/42-interieure/1217-seconde-tentative-dimmolation-dans-une-caserne-a-oum-el-bouaghi-lacte-desespere-dun-pompier.html |title = Tentative d'immolation dans une caserne à Oum El Bouaghi : L’acte désespéré d’un pompier |last = Benslimane |first = Mehdi |publisher = ''DNA'' |date = 2011-01-25 |accessdate = 2011-01-25 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110127022727/http://dna-algerie.com/politique/42-interieure/1217-seconde-tentative-dimmolation-dans-une-caserne-a-oum-el-bouaghi-lacte-desespere-dun-pompier.html |archive-date = 2011-01-27 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref> * 26 January: ** A young man (26–28 years old, unemployed) in front of the wilaya seat at [[Djelfa]], who shouted "Hagrouni" (They have wronged me) as he burned; said to have been protesting exclusion from the housing list<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elwatan.com/une/un-jeune-s-immole-a-djelfa-26-01-2011-108919_108.php |title=Un jeune s'immole à Djelfa |last=Semmar |first=Abderrahmane |publisher=''El Watan'' |date=2011-01-26 |accessdate=2011-01-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110128015726/http://www.elwatan.com/une/un-jeune-s-immole-a-djelfa-26-01-2011-108919_108.php |archivedate=January 28, 2011 }}</ref> * 28 January: ** Abdelhafid Boudechicha (destitute 29-year-old day labourer living with his parents and five siblings), at [[Medjana]], who shouted repeatedly "I'm fed up!" then asked his mother's forgiveness - died the next day of his burns. Said by his friends to have despaired of ever finding a job or housing.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/un-jeune-decede-apres-s-etre-immole-par-le-feu-a-bordj-bou-arreridj-29-01-2011-109323_109.php |title = Un jeune décède après s’être immolé par le feu à Bordj Bou Arréridj |last = B. |first = A. |publisher = ''El Watan'' |date = 2011-01-29 |accessdate = 2011-01-29 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110201023828/http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/un-jeune-decede-apres-s-etre-immole-par-le-feu-a-bordj-bou-arreridj-29-01-2011-109323_109.php# |archive-date = 2011-02-01 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref> * 29 January: ** B. S. (29 years old, son of an entrepreneur from [[Aachacha]]), in front of Mohamed Khemisti High School next to the wilaya seat at [[Mostaganem]] - suffered third-degree burns. According to security forces, this was related to disappointment in love.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/une-seconde-tentative-d-immolation-a-mostaganem-29-01-2011-109328_109.php |title = Une seconde tentative d'immolation à Mostaganem |last = Yacine |first = A. |publisher = ''El Watan'' |date = 2011-01-29 |accessdate = 2011-01-29 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110131054240/http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/une-seconde-tentative-d-immolation-a-mostaganem-29-01-2011-109328_109.php |archive-date = 2011-01-31 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref> * 30 January: ** A Local Development Bank security guard at Staoueli (Algiers) attempted to burn himself in the course of a protest by bank workers against the bank's director.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/un-travailleur-de-la-bdl-tente-de-s-immoler-par-le-feu-a-staoueli-30-01-2011-109459_109.php |title = Un travailleur de la BDL tente de s’immoler par le feu à Staoueli |last = Aber |first = Imen |publisher = ''El Watan'' |date = 2011-01-30 |accessdate = 2011-01-30 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110131170611/http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/un-travailleur-de-la-bdl-tente-de-s-immoler-par-le-feu-a-staoueli-30-01-2011-109459_109.php |archive-date = 2011-01-31 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref> ** S. Hakimi (about 30 years old, working at the water company ADE) - sprinkled himself with petrol at ADE's director's office in [[Tizi Ouzou]] but was stopped from setting himself alight, apparently protesting an arbitrary transfer.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/tizi-ouzou-tentative-d-immolation-devant-le-siege-de-l-ade-30-01-2011-109462_109.php |title = Tizi Ouzou : Tentative d’immolation devant le siège de l’ADE |last = Azzouzi |first = Hafid |publisher = ''El Watan'' |date = 2011-01-30 |accessdate = 2011-01-30 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110131170606/http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/tizi-ouzou-tentative-d-immolation-devant-le-siege-de-l-ade-30-01-2011-109462_109.php |archive-date = 2011-01-31 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref> * 6 February: ** At a protest called for by the National Committee for the Rights of the Unemployed, a young man with a job as a security guard on 6000 dinars a month drenches himself in petrol, but is stopped before managing to light a match.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.letempsdz.com/content/view/52794/1/ |title = Au moment où les chômeurs manifestaient leur ras-le-bol devant le ministère du Travail Un jeune homme tente de s'immoler |last = A. |first = Samira |publisher = ''Le Temps DZ'' |date = 2011-02-06 |accessdate = 2011-02-17 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110713202138/http://www.letempsdz.com/content/view/52794/1/# |archive-date = 2011-07-13 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref> * 9 February: ** A 25-year-old man from [[Chrea]] near [[Tébessa|Tebessa]] sets himself on fire in protest of police's failure to respond to his complaint of having been beaten up; he is taken to hospital badly injured. <ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5glePaGLQtQfxoZKADy8ZIvpi6g6Q?docId=CNG.b5748abd7704db4f1a2c0b99acfebc28.191 |title = Algerian sets self on fire over police "disdain" |last = |first = |publisher = ''AFP'' |date = 2011-02-09 |accessdate = 2011-02-17 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110215135554/http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5glePaGLQtQfxoZKADy8ZIvpi6g6Q?docId=CNG.b5748abd7704db4f1a2c0b99acfebc28.191 |archive-date = 2011-02-15 |dead-url = no |df = }}</ref> * 18 February: ** A married man threatens to set himself on fire at the daira office of Sidi M'hamed ([[Algiers]]), but is dissuaded, and instead got to see the governor, Rabah Mokdad, about his housing problems.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.elwatan.com/weekend/7jours/sidi-m-hamed-alger-un-homme-tente-de-s-immoler-au-siege-de-la-daira-18-02-2011-112299_178.php |title = Sidi M’hamed (Alger) : Un homme tente de s’immoler au siège de la daïra |last = |first = |publisher = ''El Watan'' |date = 2011-02-18 |accessdate = 2011-02-18 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110219160336/http://www.elwatan.com/weekend/7jours/sidi-m-hamed-alger-un-homme-tente-de-s-immoler-au-siege-de-la-daira-18-02-2011-112299_178.php |archive-date = 2011-02-19 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref> * 21 February: ** Three fathers formerly working at [[Socothyd]] (a cotton factory), M. Ahmed, K. Sadek et S. Farid, between 35 and 43 years old, attempt to set themselves on fire in [[Issers]] near [[Boumerdes]], after their requests to return to the jobs they had been fired from in 2006 were rejected. They had been fired in the wake of a strike campaign against the privatisation of the factory. They were stopped with some injuries and taken to hospital.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/issers-boumerdes-trois-peres-de-famille-tentent-de-s-immoler-par-le-feu-21-02-2011-112730_109.php |title = Issers (Boumerdès) : Trois pères de famille tentent de s’immoler par le feu |last = |first = |publisher = ''El Watan'' |date = 2011-02-21 |accessdate = 2011-02-21 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110225005143/http://www.elwatan.com/actualite/issers-boumerdes-trois-peres-de-famille-tentent-de-s-immoler-par-le-feu-21-02-2011-112730_109.php |archive-date = 2011-02-25 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref> * 4 October **A 19-year-old, who was refused permission to resit the Baccalaureat exam at his former secondary school in Oran<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.english.rfi.fr/france/20111004-student-not-allowed-re-sit-baccalaureat-sets-himself-fire|title=Student sets himself on fire over exam resit refusal|date=4 October 2011|publisher=|access-date=2011-10-08|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111020203324/http://www.english.rfi.fr/france/20111004-student-not-allowed-re-sit-baccalaureat-sets-himself-fire|archive-date=2011-10-20|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> * 8 October ** An Algerian woman who had been evicted from her flat in Oran died after setting herself and her three-year-old son on fire. She had been evicted from her flat, for which she had recently paid her life savings.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2011/Oct-08/150804-homeless-algerian-mother-sets-herself-child-on-fire.ashx#ixzz1aDkuvqZw|title=Homeless Algerian mother sets herself, child on fire|date=8 October 2011|publisher=|access-date=2011-10-08|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111009113154/http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2011/Oct-08/150804-homeless-algerian-mother-sets-herself-child-on-fire.ashx#ixzz1aDkuvqZw#ixzz1aDkuvqZw|archive-date=2011-10-09|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Self-immolations in Tunisia]] * [[2013 Bulgarian self-immolations]]

page.title: Abd al-Rahman ibn Muhammad ibn al-Ash'ath

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox magazine | title = al-Manār | image_file = Cover of the second issue of al-Manar magazine, 1899.jpg | image_size = 100px | image_caption = Cover of the second issue of ''al-Manar'' magazine, 1899 | editor = | editor_title = | founder = [[Rashid Rida]] | frequency = Weekly
Monthly | circulation = | category = Islamic magazine
Political magazine | company = | publisher = | founded = 1898 | finaldate = 1935 | country = [[Egypt]] | based = [[Cairo]] | language = [[Arabic language|Arabic]] | website = | issn = }} '''''al-Manār''''' ({{lang-ar|المنار}}; ‘The Lighthouse’), was an [[Islamic]] magazine, written in [[Arabic]], and was founded and published by [[Rashid Rida]] from 1898 until his death in 1935.{{cite news|author=Joseph A. Kechichian|title=The Islamic reformer: Mohammad Rashid Reda|url=http://gulfnews.com/culture/people/the-islamic-reformer-mohammad-rashid-reda-1.1255055|accessdate=24 July 2015|work=Gulf News|date=14 November 2013}}{{cite book|author=Jakob Skovgaard-Petersen|title=Defining Islam for the Egyptian State: Muftis and Fatwas of the Dār Al-Iftā|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f9uyFx-TGuIC&pg=PA127|accessdate=25 July 2015|year=1997|publisher=BRILL|isbn=90-04-10947-1|page=69}} His goal in establishing the magazine was to articulate and disseminate [[reformist]] ideas and preserve the unity of the [[Muslim nations|Muslim nation]].{{cite web|title=Muhammad Rashid Rida|url=http://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/oi/authority.20110803100404794|work=Oxford Reference|accessdate=24 July 2015}} The magazine was based in [[Cairo]], [[Egypt]].{{cite web|title=Muhammad Rashid Rida|url=http://www.mideastweb.org/Middle-East-Encyclopedia/muhammad_rashid_rida.htm|work=Encyclopedia of the Middle East|accessdate=24 July 2015}} It was started as a weekly, but later its frequency was switched to monthly. Rashid Rida was the sole [[editor-in-chief]] of the magazine. Its content was heavily about the [[Quranic]] interpretations. However, the magazine also featured articles on [[politics]]. ==See also== *[[List of theological journals]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://archive.org/details/almanaralmanar al-Manar issues], in the [[Internet Archive]] {{Commons}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Manar}} [[Category:Arabic-language magazines]] [[Category:Defunct magazines of Egypt]] [[Category:Defunct political magazines]] [[Category:Islamic magazines]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1898]] [[Category:Magazines disestablished in 1935]] [[Category:Media in Cairo]] [[Category:Monthly magazines]] [[Category:Weekly magazines]] {{reli-mag-stub}}
