Pervasive levels of age discrimination are found in Belgium, England, France, Spain and Sweden. Job candidates revealing older age are found to get 39% (in Belgium) to 72% (in France) less job interview invitations compared to equal candidates revealing a younger name. Discrimination is heterogeneous by the activity older candidates undertook during their additional post-educational years. In Belgium, they are only discriminated if they have more years of inactivity or irrelevant employment.<ref>Baert, S., Norga, J., Thuy, Y., Van Hecke, M. (2015) [http://ftp.iza.org/dp9289.pdf Getting Grey Hairs in the Labour Market: An Alternative Experiment on Age Discrimination] IZA Discussion Paper Series, 9289.</ref><ref>Riach, P. A., Rich, J. (2006) [http://ftp.iza.org/dp2522.pdf An Experimental Investigation of Age Discrimination in the French Labour Market.] IZA Discussion Paper Series, 2522.</ref><ref>Riach, P. A., Rich, J. (2010) [https://www.jstor.org/stable/41219164 An Experimental Investigation of Age Discrimination in the English Labor Market.] Annals of Economics and Statistics, 99/100, 169–185.</ref><ref>Tinsley, M. (2012) [http://www.barrowcadbury.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/07/Policy-Exchange-2012-Too-much-to-lose.pdf Too much to lose: Understanding and supporting Britain’s older workers.] London: Policy Exchange.</ref><ref>Albert, A., Escot, L., Fernández-Cornejo, J. A. (2011) [http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/09585192.2011.540160?journalCode=rijh20#.VizlnyvF98E A field experiment to study sex and age discrimination in the Madrid labour market.] International Journal of Human Resource Management, 22, 351–375.</ref><ref>Riach, P. A., Rich, J. (2007) [http://ftp.iza.org/dp2522.pdf An Experimental Investigation of Age Discrimination in the Spanish Labour Market.] IZA Discussion Paper Series, 2654.</ref><ref>Ahmed, A. M., Andersson, L., Hammarstedt, M. (2012) [http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/13504851.2011.581199 Does age matter for employability? A field experiment on ageism in the Swedish labour market.] Applied Economics Letters, 19, 403–406.</ref>
==== Other grounds ====
Furthermore, European studies provide evidence for hiring discrimination based on former unemployment,<ref>Eriksson, S., Rooth, D.-O. (2014) [https://www.aeaweb.org/articles.php?doi=10.1257/aer.104.3.1014 Do Employers Use Unemployment as a Sorting Criterion When Hiring? Evidence from a Field Experiment.] American Economic Review, 104, 1014-1039.</ref><ref name="ftp.iza.org">Baert, S., Verhaest, D. (2014) [http://ftp.iza.org/dp8312.pdf Unemployment or Overeducation: Which is a Worse Signal to Employers?] IZA Discussion Papers, 8312.</ref> trade union membership,<ref>Baert, S., Omey, E. (2015) [https://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s10645-015-9252-1 Hiring Discrimination against Pro-Union Applicants: The Role of Union Density and Firm Size.] De Economist, 163, 263-280.</ref> beauty,<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Rooth | first1 = D.-O. | year = 2009 | title = Obesity, Attractiveness, and Differential Treatment in Hiring: A Field Experiment | url = http://jhr.uwpress.org/content/44/3/710.refs | journal = Journal of Human Resources | volume = 44 | issue = 3| pages = 710–735 | doi=10.1353/jhr.2009.0027}}</ref> HIV,<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Drydakis | first1 = N | year = 2010 | title = Labour Discrimination as a Symptom of HIV: Experimental Evaluation the Greek Case | url = http://jir.sagepub.com/content/52/2/201 | journal = Journal of Industrial Relations | volume = 52 | issue = 2| pages = 201–217 | doi=10.1177/0022185609359445}}</ref> religion,<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Drydakis | first1 = Nick | year = 2010 | title = Religious Affiliation and Labour Bias | doi = 10.1111/j.1468-5906.2010.01523.x | journal = Journal for the Scientific Study of Religion | volume = 49 | issue = 3| pages = 472–488 }}</ref> youth delinquency,<ref>Baert, S., Verhofstadt, E. (2015) [https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/00036846.2014.990620 Labour market discrimination against former juvenile delinquents: evidence from a field experiment.] Applied Economics, 47, 1061-1072.</ref> former underemployment,<ref name="ftp.iza.org"/> and former depression.<ref>Baert, S., De Visschere, S, Omey, E., Schoors, K. (2016) First Depressed, Then Discriminated Against? ''Social Science & Medicine'' DOI: 10.1016/j.socscimed.2016.06.033.</ref> Employment at the army is found to have no causal effect on employment opportunities.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Baert | first1 = S. | last2 = Balcaen | first2 = P. | year = 2013 | title = The Impact of Military Work Experience on Later Hiring Chances in the Civilian Labour Market. Evidence from a Field Experiment | url = http://www.economics-ejournal.org/economics/journalarticles/2013-37 | journal = Economics: the Open-Access, Open-Assessment E-Journal | volume = 7 | issue = | pages = 2013–37 }}</ref>
=== {{visible anchor|North America}} === ====Canada==== =====Ethnicity===== Research<ref name="Metropolis British Columbia">{{cite web | url=http://mbc.metropolis.net/assets/uploads/files/wp/2011/WP11-13.pdf |title=Why do some employers prefer to interview Matthew, but not Samir? New evidence from Toronto, Montreal, and Vancouver | publisher=Metropolis British Columbia | format=PDF | accessdate=21 November 2014}}</ref> conducted in 2010 by [[University of Toronto]] researchers [[Philip Oreopoulos]] and Diane Dechief has found that resumes featuring English-sounding names sent to Canadian employers were more than 35% more likely to receive an interview call-back as compared to resumes featuring [[Chinese people|Chinese]], [[Indian people|Indian]] or [[Greeks|Greek]]-sounding names. The study, supported by Metropolis BC., a federally funded diversity-research agency, was conducted to investigate why recent immigrants are struggling much more in the Canadian job markets than immigrants in the 1970s. In order to test this hypothesis, dozens of identical resumes, with only the name of the applicant changed, was sent to employers in [[Toronto]], [[Vancouver]] and [[Montreal]]. Of the three cities surveyed, Metro Vancouver employers, both large and small, were the least swayed by the ethnicity of an applicants' name. Resumes submitted to employers here were just 20% more likely to get a callback than those with Chinese or Indian names. Through interviews with Canadian employers, the researchers found that name-based discrimination on application forms were a result of time-pressed employers being concerned that individuals with foreign backgrounds would have inadequate English-language and social skills for the Canadian marketplace.<ref name="Metropolis British Columbia"/>
=====Disability===== In 2006, just over one-half (51%) of persons with disabilities were employed, compared to three in four persons without disabilities.<ref name="Statistics Canada">{{cite web |url=http://www5.statcan.gc.ca/olc-cel/olc.action?objId=89-628-X&objType=2&lang=en&limit=1 |title=The 2006 Participation and Activity Limitation Survey: Disability in Canada (89-628-X) |publisher=Statistics Canada |date=29 January 2010 |website=Statistics Canada |accessdate=17 December 2014}}</ref>
Employment rates are lower (under 40%) for persons with developmental and communication disabilities, whereas employment rates are closer to average for persons with a hearing impairment or for those who have problems with pain, mobility, and agility.<ref name="Statistics Canada"/>
Data from [[Statistics Canada]]'s Participation and Activity Limitation Survey<ref name="Statistics Canada"/> (PALS) show that, in 2006, one in four unemployed persons with a disability and one in eight persons with a disability who are not in the workforce believe that, in the past five years, they've been refused a job because of their disability. One in twelve employed persons with a disability also reported that they experienced discrimination, with the proportion of discrimination "increasing with the severity of activity limitations".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.canadianlabour.ca/sites/default/files/pdfs/Toward-Inclusion-of-People-with-Disabilities-EN.pdf |title=Toward Inclusion of People with Disabilities in the Workplace |date=December 2008 |format=PDF |accessdate=17 December 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140913203919/http://www.canadianlabour.ca/sites/default/files/pdfs/Toward-Inclusion-of-People-with-Disabilities-EN.pdf |archivedate=13 September 2014 |df= }}</ref>
=====Gender and sexual orientation===== According to 2011 [[Statistics Canada]] data,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www12.statcan.gc.ca/nhs-enm/2011/dp-pd/dt-td/Rp-eng.cfm?LANG=E&APATH=3&DETAIL=0&DIM=0&FL=A&FREE=0&GC=0&GID=0&GK=0&GRP=1&PID=106738&PRID=0&PTYPE=105277&S=0&SHOWALL=0&SUB=0&Temporal=2013&THEME=98&VID=0&VNAMEE=&VNAMEF= |title=2011 National Household Survey: Data tables |publisher=Statistics Canada |accessdate=17 December 2014}}</ref> the gender wage gap in Ontario is 26% for full-time, full-year workers. For every $1.00 earned by a male worker, a female worker earns 74 cents. In 1987, when the [[Equal pay for equal work#Canada|Pay Equity Act]] was passed, the gender wage gap was 36%. It is estimated that as much as 10 to 15% of the gender wage gap is due to discrimination.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.payequity.gov.on.ca/en/about/pubs/genderwage/wagegap.php |title=Gender Wage Gap |publisher=Pay Equity Commission of Ontario |accessdate=17 December 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141228123555/http://www.payequity.gov.on.ca/en/about/pubs/genderwage/wagegap.php |archivedate=28 December 2014 |df= }}</ref>
====United States==== =====Ethnicity===== By means of their seminal correspondence experiment, Marianne Bertrand and Sendhil Mullainathan, showed that applications from job candidates with white-sounding names got 50 percent more callbacks for interviews than those with African-American-sounding names in the United States at the start of this millennium.<ref>Bertrand, M., Mullainathan, S. (2004) [https://www.aeaweb.org/articles.php?doi=10.1257/0002828042002561 Are Emily and Greg More Employable Than Lakisha and Jamal? A Field Experiment on Labor Market Discrimination] American Economic Review, 94, 991-1013</ref> Similarly, a 2009 study found that black applicants for low-wage jobs in New York City were half as likely as whites to get callbacks with equivalent resumes, interpersonal skills, and demographic characteristics.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Pager|first1=D.|last2=Bonikowski|first2=B.|last3=Western|first3=B.|date=1 October 2009|title=Discrimination in a Low-Wage Labor Market: A Field Experiment|journal=American Sociological Review|volume=74|issue=5|pages=777–799|doi=10.1177/000312240907400505|pmc=2915472|pmid=20689685}}</ref> A Current Population Survey in 2006 noted that African-Americans were twice as likely to be unemployed than whites.<ref name=":18">Pager, Devah, and Hana Shepherd. 2008. “[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/pmc2915460/ The Sociology of Discrimination: Racial Discrimination in Employment, Housing, Credit, and Consumer Markets]”. Annual Review of Sociology 34:181-209.</ref> "Black men spend significantly more time searching for work"; and even when they are working, they have less stable employment, diminishing their work experience".<ref>Tomaskovic-Devey D, Thomas M, Johnson K. 2005. Race and the accumulation of humancapital across the career: a theoretical model and fixed-effects application. ''Am. J. Sociol.'' 111:58–89</ref>
Discrimination goes beyond the hiring process. "Controlling for parental background, education, work experience, tenure, and training, white men earn roughly 15% more than comparable blacks."<ref>Cancio AS, Evans TD, Maume DJ. 1996. [https://www.jstor.org/stable/2096391 Reconsidering the declining significance of race: racial differences in early career wages]. ''American Sociological Review.'' 61:541–56.</ref>
Within each race, darker complexion is also discriminated against. Multiple studies have found that lighter skin blacks "tend to have superior incomes and life chances". "Chicanos with lighter skin color and more european features had higher socioeconomic status" and "black Hispanics suffer close to ten times the proportionate income loss due to differential treatment of given characteristics than white Hispanics".<ref name=":19">Darity, William A., and Patrick L. Mason. "Evidence on discrimination in employment: Codes of color, codes of gender." ''Journal of Economic Perspectives'' 12.2 (1998): 63-90.</ref>
===== Sex ===== ''Main Article: [[Occupational sexism|Occupational Sexism]] and [[Motherhood penalty|Motherhood Penalty]].''
Women have had a long history of discrimination in the workplace. Feminist theory points to the concept of a [[family wage]]- a rate substantial enough to support a man and his family- as the explanation to why women's labor is cheap, claiming it preserves "male dominance and women's dependence in the family".<ref name=":2">Blankenship, Kim M. “Bringing Gender and Race in: U.S. Employment Discrimination Policy.” Gender and Society, vol. 7, no. 2, 1993, pp. 204–226. JSTOR, JSTOR, www.jstor.org/stable/189578.</ref> Though there has been legislation such as the [[Equal Pay Act of 1963|Equal Pay Act]] that combat gender discrimination, the implications of the act are limited. "As an amendment to the Fair Labor Standard Act, it exempted employers in agriculture, hotels, motels, restaurants, and laundries, as well as professional, managerial, and administrative personnel, outside salesworkers, and private household workers". Because high concentrations of women work in these fields (34.8% of employed women of color and 5.1% of white women as private household workers, 21.6% and 13.8% working in service jobs, 9.3% and 3.7% as agricultural workers, and 8.1% and 17.2% as administrative workers), "nearly 45% of all employed women, then, appear to have been exempt from the Equal Pay Act".<ref name=":2" />
The hourly wage rate for women is 65% of that of men, and annual earnings of full-time employed women is 71% of that of men. Among the male wage distribution, the average woman lies at the 33rd percentile.<ref>Blau, Francine D., M. Ferber, and A. Winkler, ''The Economics of Women, Men, and Work'', third edition. Upper Saddle River, NJ: Prentice Hall, 1998.</ref>
Within women, another level of discrimination takes place among mothers. Historically, this inequality stems from the belief that mothers are less productive at work. Visibly pregnant women are often judged as less committed to their jobs, less dependable, and more emotional compared to women who aren't visibly pregnant.<ref name=":6">Shelley J. Correll, Stephen Benard, and In Paik, “Getting a Job: Is There a Motherhood Penalty?” American Journal of Sociology, Vol. 112 No. 5 (2007), 1297-1338.</ref> A study conducted in 1998 showed that the wage rates of women without children were 81.3% of men's pay, but 73.4% of men's pay for women with children.<ref>Waldfogel, Jane, ‘‘[http://pubs.aeaweb.org/doi/pdf/10.1257%2Fjep.12.1.137 Understanding the ‘Family Gap’ in Pay for Women with Children],’’ ''Journal of Economic Perspectives'', Winter 1998, ''13'':1, 137– 56.</ref> An audit study in 2007 found that, childless women receive 2.1 times as many callbacks than equally qualified mothers. Though it doesn't receive as much attention as the gender gap, motherhood is a significant quality that is discriminated against. In fact, the pay gap between mothers and non-mothers is larger than the pay gap between men and women.<ref name=":6" /> =====Gender and sexual orientation===== The [[UCLA School of Law#Williams Institute on Sexual Orientation and Gender Identity Law and Public Policy|Williams Institute]], a national think tank at [[UCLA School of Law]], released a 2011 report<ref name="The Williams Institute">{{cite web | url=http://williamsinstitute.law.ucla.edu/wp-content/uploads/Sears-Mallory-Discrimination-July-20111.pdf |title=Documented Evidence of Employment Discrimination & Its Effects on LGBT People | publisher=The Williams Institute | format=PDF | accessdate=25 November 2014}}</ref> that has identified sexual orientation and gender identification discrimination in the workplace. According to the report, between 15-43% of lesbian, gay, bisexual, or transgender workers have experienced being fired, denied promotions, or harassed due to their sexual orientation or gender identification.<ref name="The Williams Institute"/> Additionally, only 20 states in the United States of America prohibit discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity in the workplace. Wisconsin and New Hampshire prohibit discrimination based on sexual orientation but not gender identity.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.aclu.org/map/non-discrimination-laws-state-state-information-map|title=Non-Discrimination Laws: State by State Information - Map|access-date=2016-09-20}}</ref> On October 4, 2017 Attorney General [[Jeff Sessions]] announced that the [[United States Department of Justice]] will no longer provide employment protection to [[transgender]] individuals under Title VII of the [[Civil Rights Act of 1964]], reversing the position of former Attorney General [[Eric Holder]], during the Obama administration.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Glasser|first1=Nathaniel M.|last2=Rhodes|first2=Kate B.|title=Attorney General Reverses Obama-Era Protection of Transgender Employees|url=https://www.natlawreview.com/article/attorney-general-reverses-obama-era-protection-transgender-employees|accessdate=15 October 2017|work=The [[National Law Review]]|publisher=Epstein Becker & Green, P.C.|date=3 October 2017}}</ref>
=====Age===== Most age discrimination occurs among the older workers when employers hold negative stereotypes about them. Though evidence on declines in productivity is inconsistent, "other evidence points to declines in acuteness of vision or hearing, ease of memorization, computational speed, etc.". Another factor employers take into consideration is the higher cost of health or life insurance for older workers.<ref name=":142">Neumark, D. 2003. [http://www.socsci.uci.edu/~dneumark/Neumark%20CEP%202003.pdf Age discrimination legislations in the United States]. ''Contemporary Economic Policy,'' 21: 297-317.</ref>
A 2013 report<ref name="AARP">{{cite web | url=http://www.aarp.org/content/dam/aarp/research/surveys_statistics/econ/2013/Staying-Ahead-of-the-Curve-Age-Discrimination.pdf |title= Staying Ahead of the Curve 2013: AARP Multicultural Work and Career Study Perceptions of Age Discrimination in the Workplace – Ages 45-74 | publisher=AARP | format=PDF | page=1 | accessdate=25 November 2014}}</ref> was completed by the [[AARP]] to identify the impact of [[ageism|age discrimination]] in the workplace. Of those 1500 individuals who responded to AARP's 2013 Staying Ahead of the Curve survey, almost 64% of those over 45–74 said they have seen or have experienced age discrimination in the workplace. Of those, 92% say it was somewhat or very common in their workplace.<ref name="AARP" /> "In 1963 the unemployment rate for men over age 55 was a full percentage point higher (4.5 percent) than for men aged 35-54 (3.5%)." Average durations of unemployment are higher for older workers as well- 21 weeks for men over age 45 as opposed to 14 weeks for men under 45.<ref name=":143">Neumark, D. 2003. [http://www.socsci.uci.edu/~dneumark/Neumark%20CEP%202003.pdf Age discrimination legislations in the United States]. ''Contemporary Economic Policy,'' 21: 297-317.</ref>
=====Criminal records===== {{main|Employment discrimination against persons with criminal records in the United States}} Laws restricting employment discrimination for persons who have been convicted of criminal offenses vary significantly by state.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gaines|first1=Joshua|title=State licensing laws unfairly restrict opportunities for people with criminal records|url=http://ccresourcecenter.org/2016/04/28/state-licensing-laws-unfairly-restrict-opportunities-for-people-with-criminal-records/|website=Collateral Consequences Resource Center|accessdate=15 August 2017|date=28 April 2016}}</ref> The U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has issued guidelines for employers, intended to prevent criminal record discrimination from being used as a proxy to effect unlawful racial discrimination.<ref>{{cite web|title=Consideration of Arrest and Conviction Records in Employment Decisions Under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964|url=https://www.eeoc.gov/laws/guidance/arrest_conviction.cfm|website=Equal Employment Opportunity Commission|accessdate=15 August 2017|date=25 April 2012}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Equal Remuneration Convention, 1951]] * [[Discrimination (Employment and Occupation) Convention, 1958]] * [[Economic discrimination]] * [[Involuntary unemployment]] * [[Labour and employment law]] * [[Marriage bars]] * [[Occupational segregation]]
== Notes and references == {{Reflist|2}}
== Bibliography == *{{cite book |author=Pager, Devah |title=Marked: Race, Crime, and Finding Work in an Era of Mass Incarceration |publisher=University of Chicago Press |year=2009 |pages= |isbn=978-0-226-64484-4}} *{{cite book|title=Organizational Communication: Perspectives and Trends|last=Papa|first=Michael J.|author2=Tom D. Daniels |author3=Barry K. Spiker |edition=5|publisher=SAGE|year=2007|isbn=1-4129-1684-4}} *{{cite journal |last=Trentham |first=Susan |author2=Laurie Larwood |year=1998 |title=Gender Discrimination and the Workplace: An Examination of Rational Bias Theory |journal=Sex Roles |volume=38 |issue=112 |pages=1–28 |doi=10.1023/A:1018782226876 }}<!--|accessdate=2009-08-29--> * [[Leila Schneps]] and [[Coralie Colmez]], ''Math on trial. How numbers get used and abused in the courtroom'', Basic Books, 2013. {{ISBN|978-0-465-03292-1}}. (Sixth chapter: "Math error number 6: Simpson's paradox. The Berkeley sex bias case: discrimination detection"). *{{cite news |first=Vivek |last=Wadhwa |title=The True Cost of Discrimination |newspaper=BusinessWeek Online |date=6 June 2006 |accessdate=29 August 2009 |url=http://www.businessweek.com/smallbiz/content/jun2006/sb20060606_087038.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090524174851/http://www.businessweek.com/smallbiz/content/jun2006/sb20060606_087038.htm |archivedate=24 May 2009 |df= }} * {{cite book | last1 = Muhs | first1 = Gabriella Gutiérrez y | last2 = Harris | first2 = Angela P. | last3 = Flores Niemann | first3 = Yolanda | last4 = González | first4 = Carmen G. | author-link1 = Gabriella Gutiérrez y Muhs | author-link2 = Angela P. Harris | title = Presumed incompetent: the intersections of race and class for women in academia | publisher = University Press of Colorado | location = Boulder, Colorado | year = 2012 | isbn = 9780874219227 }}
