page.title: Fake news websites in the United States

revision.text:
'''Fake news websites in the United States''' are [[fake news website]]s that deliberately publish [[fake news]], but specifically target [[Americans|American]] audiences by creating or inflaming controversial topics such as the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 election]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/02/22/us/parkland-shooting-conspiracy-theories-trnd/index.html|title=How the Florida school shooting conspiracies sprouted and spread|last=P. Murphy|first=Paul|date=February 22, 2018|work=CNN|access-date=2018-04-13|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|last2=Mezzofiore|first2=Gianluca}}</ref><ref name=":8">{{Cite news|url=http://www.politifact.com/punditfact/article/2017/apr/20/politifacts-guide-fake-news-websites-and-what-they/|title=PolitiFact's guide to fake news websites|last=Gillin|first=Joshua|date=April 20, 2017|work=PunditFact|access-date=2018-04-13|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref> Most fake news websites target readers by impersonating or pretending to be real [[news organization]]s,<ref name=":9">{{Cite news|url=https://docs.google.com/document/d/10eA5-mCZLSS4MQY5QGb5ewC3VAL6pLkT53V_81ZyitM/preview|title=False, Misleading, Clickbait-y, and Satirical "News" Sources|last=Zimdars|first=Melissa|date=2016|work=Google Docs|access-date=2018-04-17|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180413114622/https://docs.google.com/document/d/10eA5-mCZLSS4MQY5QGb5ewC3VAL6pLkT53V_81ZyitM/preview|archive-date=April 13, 2018|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref> such as the NBCNews.com'''.co''', which can lead to legitimate news organizations further spreading their message.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/blogs-trending-38156985|title='Pizzagate': The fake story that shows how conspiracy theories spread|last=Wendling|first=Mike|date=2016-12-02|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-04-13|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-GB}}</ref> Most notable in the media are the many websites that made completely false claims about political candidates usually focusing on [[Hillary Clinton]] and [[President Trump|President Donald Trump]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2016/04/02/in-the-year-of-trump-a-made-up-news-website-run-by-an-ex-convict-finds-success/|title=The pro-Trump fake news website that’s finding an audience — with Trump’s help|last=Bump|first=Philip|date=2016-04-02|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-04-17|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref> as part of a larger campaign to gain viewers and ad revenue or spread [[disinformation]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/25/world/europe/fake-news-donald-trump-hillary-clinton-georgia.html|title=Inside a Fake News Sausage Factory: ‘This Is All About Income’|last=Higgins|first=Andrew|date=2016-11-25|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-04-13|last2=McIntire|first2=Mike|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331|last3=Dance|first3=Gabriel J. X.}}</ref> Additionally, [[satire]] websites have received criticism for not properly notifying readers that they are publishing false or satirical content, since many readers have been duped by seemingly legitimate articles.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://newrepublic.com/article/118013/satire-news-websites-are-cashing-gullible-outraged-readers|title=These Satire News Sites Are Taking Advantage of You|last=Rensin|first=Emmett|date=June 5, 2014|work=The New Republic|access-date=2018-04-17|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.poynter.org/news/satirical-fake-news-site-apologized-making-story-too-real|title=A satirical fake news site apologized for making a story too real|last=Funke|first=Daniel|date=November 30, 2017|website=Poynter|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-18}}</ref>
== Definition == [[Fake news website]]s deliberately publish [[hoaxes]], [[propaganda]], and [[disinformation]] to drive [[web traffic]] inflamed by [[social media]].<ref name="russiadominates">{{cite news|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/08/06/how-russia-dominates-your-twitter-feed-to-promote-lies-and-trump-too.html|title=Trolls for Trump - How Russia Dominates Your Twitter Feed to Promote Lies (And, Trump, Too)|author1=Weisburd, Andrew|date=August 6, 2016|accessdate=November 24, 2016|publisher=[[The Daily Beast]]|author2=Watts, Clint|author2-link=Clint Watts}}</ref><ref name="snopesfieldguide">{{cite web|url=http://www.snopes.com/2016/01/14/fake-news-sites/|title=Snopes' Field Guide to Fake News Sites and Hoax Purveyors - Snopes.com's updated guide to the internet's clickbaiting, news-faking, social media exploiting dark side.|last=LaCapria|first=Kim|date=November 2, 2016|publisher=[[Snopes.com]]|accessdate=November 19, 2016}}</ref><ref name="divideeurope">{{cite news|url=http://www.dw.com/en/divide-europe-european-lawmakers-warn-of-russian-propaganda/a-36016836|title='Divide Europe': European lawmakers warn of Russian propaganda|author=Lewis Sanders IV|date=October 11, 2016|accessdate=November 24, 2016|publisher=[[Deutsche Welle]]}}</ref> These sites are distinguished from [[news satire]] as fake news articles are usually fabricated to deliberately mislead readers, either for profit or more ambiguous reasons, such as disinformation campaigns.<ref name="snopesfieldguide" /><ref name="tavernise" /> Many sites originate in or are promoted by Russia,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/08/06/how-russia-dominates-your-twitter-feed-to-promote-lies-and-trump-too|title=How Russia Dominates Your Twitter Feed to Promote Lies (And, Trump, Too)|last=Weisburd|first=Clint Watts{{!}}Andrew|date=2016-08-06|work=The Daily Beast|access-date=2018-04-13|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/the-real-paranoia-inducing-purpose-of-russian-hacks|title=The Real Paranoia-Inducing Purpose of Russian Hacks|last=Chen|first=Adrian|date=2016-07-27|work=The New Yorker|access-date=2018-04-13|language=en|issn=0028-792X}}</ref> Macedonia,<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/aug/24/facebook-clickbait-political-news-sites-us-election-trump|title=How Facebook powers money machines for obscure political 'news' sites|last=Tynan|first=Dan|date=2016-08-24|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-04-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-users-crowdsource-fake-news-document-2016-11|title=Fed up with fake news, Facebook users are solving the problem with a simple list|work=Business Insider|access-date=2018-04-17}}</ref> Romania,<ref name="Inc.com">{{Cite news|url=http://www.inc.com/tess-townsend/ending-fed-trump-facebook.html|title=The Bizarre Truth Behind the Biggest Pro-Trump Facebook Hoaxes|date=2016-11-22|work=Inc.com|access-date=2018-04-17}}</ref> and the United States.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2016/11/23/503146770/npr-finds-the-head-of-a-covert-fake-news-operation-in-the-suburbs|title=We Tracked Down A Fake-News Creator In The Suburbs. Here's What We Learned|work=NPR.org|access-date=2018-04-13|language=en}}</ref> Many sites directly targeted the United States both because the U.S. is a high-value ad consumer and extraordinary claims to be more likely to be believed during a political crisis.<ref name=":4" />
''The New York Times'' noted in a December 2016 article that fake news had previously maintained a presence on the Internet and within [[tabloid journalism]] in years prior to the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 U.S. election]].<ref name="tavernise">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/06/us/fake-news-partisan-republican-democrat.html|title=As Fake News Spreads Lies, More Readers Shrug at the Truth|last=Tavernise|first=Sabrina|date=December 7, 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=December 9, 2016|page=A1|quote=Narrowly defined, 'fake news' means a made-up story with an intention to deceive, often geared toward getting clicks.}}</ref> However, prior to the election between [[Hillary Clinton]] and [[Donald Trump]], fake news had not impacted the election process to such a high degree.<ref name="tavernise" /> Subsequent to that election, the issue of fake news turned into a political weapon between supporters of Clinton and Trump; due to these back-and-forth complaints, the definition of fake news as used for such argumentation became vaguer.<ref name="tavernise" />
== Methods == Fake news websites use a variety of methods to fool their readers into believing their content, either by attempting to persuade the readers that they are legitimate or by distracting readers with incredible news. {{multiple image | align = | direction = vertical | width = 250 | image1 = ABCnewscomco.png | alt1 = logo of ABCnews.com.co | caption1 = Impersonation/Typosquatting- [[ABCnews.com.co]], a [[fake news website]] that "crudely"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cjr.org/analysis/how_fake_news_sites_frequently_trick_big-time_journalists.php|title=How fake news sites frequently trick big-time journalists|work=[[Columbia Journalism Review]] |date=May 26, 2016 |accessdate=3 October 2017}}</ref> [[website spoofing|spoofs]] legitimate [[news media|journalistic]] organization [[ABC News]], but was in reality completely unrelated. The site published only fake stories, usually with a realistic [[clickbait]] headline, albeit with story-details containing enough flaws that the "discerning reader would likely notice" it was false.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/el-chapo-escape-rumors-mexican-government-photo-2016-7|title=Mexico's government shut down rumors of 'El Chapo' Guzmán's escape with this one photo|publisher=[[Business Insider]]}}</ref> | image2 = Denver Guardian logo.png | alt2 = logo of the Denver Guardian | caption2 = Clickbait - [[Denver Guardian]], a blog site registered in 2016 that claimed to be a legitimate newspaper in [[Denver]], but only ran a single fabricated story that went [[Viral phenomenon|viral]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.denverpost.com/2016/11/05/there-is-no-such-thing-as-the-denver-guardian/ |title=There is no such thing as the Denver Guardian, despite that Facebook post you saw |last=Lubbers |first=Eric |newspaper=[[The Denver Post]] |publication-date=2016-11-05}}</ref> | image3 = Everything on RealTrueNews Was A LIE.jpg | alt3 = logo of RealTrueNews with belated-added subheading revealing that 'Everything on RealTrueNews was a LIE' in reference to their prior story-publications | caption3 = Clickbait - RealTrueNews.com, which was created as a [[internet hoax|hoax]] that the author believed would teach their [[alt-right]] friends about reader gullibility.<ref name=chacon /><ref name=chacon2 /><ref name=bambury /> (The subheading shown here, which revealed the hoax—'everything was a lie'—got added only later.)<hr/> | footer = Three examples of [[fake news website]]s. }}
=== Clickbait === Fake news websites often have article titles that are incredulous, prompting the user to click on it and read more.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/facebook-fake-election-news-more-popular-than-real-news-buzzfeed-investigation/|title=Probe reveals stunning stats about fake election headlines on Facebook|last=|first=|date=November 17, 2016|work=CBS News|access-date=2018-04-18|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref> This method of enticing readers to view content on their website often leads to exaggerated or even fake titles. When linked to from other sites, usually social media, having an extraordinary story title played a large part in tricking users who cannot tell if the article is real or not. This became especially relevant in the 2016 election. Additionally, out-of-context or [[manipulated image]]s can cause readers to incorrectly assume an article's legitimacy, often due to their inflammatory image choice.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/baby-boon/|title=FACT CHECK: Is This a Photograph of a 12-Week Fetus?|last=Mikkelson|first=David|date=10 November 2013|work=Snopes|access-date=2018-04-18|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":10">{{Cite news|url=https://www.factcheck.org/2016/11/how-to-spot-fake-news/|title=How to Spot Fake News - FactCheck.org|date=2016-11-18|work=FactCheck.org|access-date=2018-04-17|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Impersonation === Another method of gaining readers is impersonating a legitimate news organization. This can come in two forms, either by copying a popular news organization's website formatting and pretending to be a lesser known publication or by completely copying an existing website down to its name and authors.<ref name=":8" /><ref name=":9" /> Exact copies can trick viewers into believing the website is an official organization such as the Bloomberg.ma,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/15/business/dealbook/twitter-shares-jump-after-fake-bloomberg-report.html|title=Twitter Shares Jump After Faked Bloomberg Report|last=Merced|first=Michael J. de la|date=2015-07-14|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-04-18|last2=Goldstein|first2=Matthew|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://fortune.com/2015/07/14/fake-twitter-bloomberg-report/|title=Fake Bloomberg News Report Drives Twitter Stock Up 8%|work=Fortune|access-date=2018-04-18|language=en}}</ref> or cnn-trending.com.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/jamesball/fake-news-site-uses-professor-stephen-hawking-to-sell-get-ri|title=Fake News Site Uses Stephen Hawking To Sell Get-Rich-Quick Scheme|work=BuzzFeed|access-date=2018-04-18|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cambridge-news.co.uk/business/business-news/faking-it-unravelling-fake-news-12468676|title=Faking it: Unravelling a fake news story involving Stephen Hawking|last=Scialom|first=Mike|date=2017-01-19|work=cambridgenews|access-date=2018-04-18}}</ref>
=== Typosquatting === Many popular fake news websites attempted to impersonate legitimate U.S. news publication by using a method known as [[Typosquatting]], where fake websites get as close as possible to the original URL, only differing by a letter or two. A clear example is ABCnews.com.co. Typosquatting relies on readers not actually checking the address they typed or clicked on, since often these websites target common misspellings, slight misphrasings and abuse of [[top-level domain]]s by used .com.co as opposed to .com. This also gets many viewers from social media who believe they are going to an actual news publication's website.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/news/2016/12/01/hackers-use-typo-squatting-lure-unwary-url-hijacking/94683460/|title=Hackers use typosquatting to dupe the unwary with fake news, sites|work=USA TODAY|access-date=2018-04-17|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.webtitan.com/blog/fake-news-typosquatting-and-cybersecurity-risks/|title=Crackdown on Fake News Shines Light on Typosquatting and Cybersecurity Risks - WebTitan|date=2016-12-28|work=WebTitan|access-date=2018-04-17|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Obscurity === Since the authors of these websites are not actual reporters, many fake news sites either pretend to have the identity of a reporter or simply do not include an 'About Us' page.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/2020/video/websites-fake-credentials-people-hired-24136909|title=Video: Websites Fake Credentials to Help People Get Hired|last=News|first=ABC|website=ABC News|language=en|access-date=2018-04-17}}</ref> These websites almost never have any other publications that reference them or information about themselves on tertiary sources like Wikipedia. When these sites get publicized by actual organizations, it gives them a bit of legitimacy, which helps them get viewers.<ref name=":10" /><ref name=":9" />
== Fake news campaigns == Fake news campaigns are when multiple fake news websites are published with similar topics in hopes of convincing a broader audience, either by quantity or by reference.
=== 2016 election cycle === Fake news websites played a large part in the online news community during the election, reinforced by extreme exposure on Facebook and Google.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/article/2016/dec/13/2016-lie-year-fake-news/|title=PolitiFact's 2016 Lie of the Year: Fake news|work=PolitiFact|access-date=2018-04-17|language=en}}</ref> Approximately 115 pro-Trump fake stories were shared on Facebook a total of 30 million times, and 41 pro-Clinton fake stories shared a total of 7.6 million times.<ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|last=Allcott|first=Hunt|last2=Gentzkow|first2=Matthew|date=Spring 2017|title=Social Media and Fake News in the 2016 Election|url=https://web.stanford.edu/~gentzkow/research/fakenews.pdf|journal=Journal of Economic Perspectives|volume=31|issue=2|pages=211–236|via=}}</ref> There were two main reasons for creating fake news, economical and ideological.<ref name=":12" /> The teenagers in Veles, for example, produced stories favoring both Trump and Clinton that earned them tens of thousands of dollars.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/2017/02/veles-macedonia-fake-news/|title=Inside the Macedonian Fake-News Complex|last=Subramanian|first=Samanth|date=2017-02-07|website=wired.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Some fake news providers seek to advance candidates they favor. The Romanian man who ran ''endingthefed.com'', for example, claims that he started the site mainly to help Donald Trump’s campaign.<ref name="Inc.com"/>
==== Major sites involved ==== * ''ABCnews.com.co'' - pro-right<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.snopes.com/?s=ABCnews.com.c|title=You searched for ABCnews.com.c {{!}} Snopes.com|website=Snopes.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-17}}</ref> * ''Conservative Daily Post'' - both anti-left and anti-right<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.politifact.com/punditfact/statements/2018/feb/19/conservative-daily-post/no-trump-did-not-declare-george-soros-security-thr/|title=No, Trump didn't declare George Soros a security threat|work=@politifact|access-date=2018-04-17|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2016/nov/04/conservative-daily-post/evidence-ridiculously-thin-sensational-claim-huge-/|title=Evidence ridiculously thin for Clinton sex network claim|work=@politifact|access-date=2018-04-17|language=en}}</ref> * ''Denver Guardian'' - known for anti-Hillary Clinton articles<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.denverpost.com/2016/11/23/the-man-behind-denver-guardian/|title=The man behind Denver Guardian (and many other fake news websites) is a registered Democrat from California|date=2016-11-23|work=The Denver Post|access-date=2018-04-17|language=en-US}}</ref> * ''Disinfomedia'' - anti-right articles that aimed to trick alt-rights<ref name="laurasydell" /> * ''Ending the Fed'' - pro-right<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.snopes.com/?s=Ending+the+Fed|title=You searched for Ending the Fed {{!}} Snopes.com|website=Snopes.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-17}}</ref> * ''News Examiner'' - anti-left articles<ref name=":11">{{Cite news|url=https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/every-other-given-sunday/|title=FACT CHECK: Obama Places Limits on Church Services|work=Snopes.com|access-date=2018-04-17|language=en-US}}</ref> * ''SubjectPolitics.com'' - known for anti-Hillary Clinton articles<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/craigsilverman/fever-swamp-election|title=How The Bizarre Conspiracy Theory Behind "Pizzagate" Was Spread|work=BuzzFeed|access-date=2018-04-17|language=en}}</ref> * ''[[YourNewsWire.com]]'' - inflammatory for both sides as well as conspiratorial<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.snopes.com/tag/yournewswire-com/|title=yournewswire.com Archives {{!}} Snopes.com|website=Snopes.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-17}}</ref>
==== Social media ==== Professor [[Philip N. Howard]] of the [[University of Oxford]] found that about one half of all news on [[Twitter]] directed at [[Michigan]] prior to the election was junk or fake. The other half came from real news sources. Criticized for failing to stop fake news from spreading on its platform during the 2016 election, [[Facebook]] thought that the problem could be solved by engineering, until May 2017 when it announced plans to hire 3,000 content reviewers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-to-hire-3000-moderators-to-keep-suicides-from-being-streamed-2017-5|title=Facebook will hire 3,000 more moderators to keep deaths and crimes from being streamed|work=Business Insider|access-date=2018-04-17}}</ref> Fraudulent stories during the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 U.S. presidential election]] popularized on Facebook included a viral post that [[Pope Francis]] and actor [[Denzel Washington]] had endorsed [[Donald Trump]].<ref name="alyssanewcomb">{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/facebook-google-crack-down-fake-news-advertising-n684101|title=Facebook, Google Crack Down on Fake News Advertising|author=Alyssa Newcomb|date=November 15, 2016|accessdate=November 16, 2016|publisher=[[NBC News]]}}</ref><ref name="didthepope">{{cite news|url=http://www.factcheck.org/2016/10/did-the-pope-endorse-trump/|title=Did the Pope Endorse Trump?|last=Schaede|first=Sydney|date=October 24, 2016|accessdate=December 7, 2016|publisher=[[FactCheck.org]]}}</ref> [[Alternet]] reported that Trump himself had been the source of some of the related misinformation.<ref name="AN-20170112">{{cite news|url=http://www.alternet.org/media/14-fake-news-stories-created-or-publicized-donald-trump|title=14 Fake News Stories Created or Publicized by Donald Trump|last=Holliway|first=Kali|date=January 12, 2017|accessdate=January 25, 2017|publisher=[[AlterNet]]}}</ref>
[[BuzzFeed|BuzzFeed News]] found that on Facebook during the last three months of the election, fake news stories received more attention than real news stories. It was discovered that the top twenty fake news stories had 8,711,000 shares, reactions, and comments, while the top twenty real news stories were only shared, commented on, and reacted to 7,367,000 times.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/craigsilverman/viral-fake-election-news-outperformed-real-news-on-facebook|title=This Analysis Shows How Viral Fake Election News Stories Outperformed Real News On Facebook|accessdate=2017-02-28|publisher=[[BuzzFeed]]}}</ref> One prominent fraudulent news story released after the election—that protesters at anti-Trump rallies in Austin, Texas, were "bused in"—started as a tweet by one individual with 40 Twitter followers.<ref name="maheshwari">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/20/business/media/how-fake-news-spreads.html|title=How Fake News Goes Viral|last=Maheshwari|first=Sapna|date=November 20, 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=November 20, 2016}}</ref> Over the next three days, the tweet was shared at least 16,000 times on Twitter and 350,000 times on Facebook, and promoted in the conservative blogosphere, before the individual stated that he had fabricated his assertions.<ref name="maheshwari" />
[[President of the United States|President]] [[Barack Obama]] commented on the significant problem of fraudulent information on social networks impacting elections in a speech the day before [[Election Day]] in 2016, saying lies repeated on social media created a "dust cloud of nonsense".<ref name="zuckerbergsays">{{cite news|url=http://www.computerworld.com/article/3140723/internet/zuckerberg-says-fake-news-on-facebook-didn-t-tilt-the-elections.html|title=Zuckerberg says fake news on Facebook didn't tilt the elections|author=John Ribeiro|date=November 15, 2016|work=[[Computerworld]]|accessdate=November 16, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2016/11/07/remarks-president-hillary-america-rally-ann-arbor-michigan|title=Remarks by the President at Hillary for America Rally in Ann Arbor, Michigan|author=President [[Barack Obama]]|date=November 7, 2016|publisher=[[White House Office of the Press Secretary]]|accessdate=November 16, 2016}}</ref> Shortly after the election, Obama again commented on the problem, saying in an appearance with [[Chancellor of Germany|German Chancellor]] [[Angela Merkel]]: "if we can't discriminate between serious arguments and propaganda, then we have problems".<ref name="jaketapper">{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/videos/politics/2016/11/17/fake-news-social-media-tapper-dnt-lead.cnn|title=Fake news stories thriving on social media - Phony news stories are thriving on social media, so much so President Obama addressed it. CNN's Jake Tapper reports.|last=Tapper|first=Jake|date=November 17, 2016|accessdate=November 18, 2016|publisher=[[CNN]]|authorlink=Jake Tapper}}</ref><ref name="HarrisEddy">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/18/world/europe/obama-angela-merkel-donald-trump.html|title=Obama, With Angela Merkel in Berlin, Assails Spread of Fake News|author1=Gardiner Harris|date=November 17, 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=November 18, 2016|author2=Melissa Eddy}}</ref> President Trump has also commented significantly on fake news, creating the [[Fake News Awards]] to highlight real news outlets that publicly misrepresented him.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/jan/17/trump-fake-news-awards-winners|title=Donald Trump faces backlash as he reveals 'Fake News Awards' winners|last=Siddiqui|first=Sabrina|date=2018-01-18|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-04-18}}</ref>
=== "Pizzagate" === {{See also|Pizzagate conspiracy theory}} In early November 2016, fake news sites and Internet forums falsely implicated the restaurant [[Comet Ping Pong]] and [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] figures as part of a fictitious [[child trafficking]] ring, which was dubbed "[[Pizzagate conspiracy theory|Pizzagate]]".<ref name="bbc-pizzagate">{{Citation|last=Wendling|first=Mike|title=The saga of 'Pizzagate': The fake story that shows how conspiracy theories spread|date=December 2, 2016|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/blogs-trending-38156985|publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=December 2, 2016}}</ref> The conspiracy theory was debunked by the fact-checking website [[Snopes.com]], ''[[The New York Times]]'', and [[Fox News]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.snopes.com/pizzagate-conspiracy/|title=FALSE: Comet Ping Pong Pizzeria Home to Child Abuse Ring Led by Hillary Clinton|last=LaCapria|first=Kim|date=November 21, 2016|accessdate=December 2, 2016|publisher=[[Snopes.com]]}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=Carlson|first=Margaret|title=A Fake Conspiracy for Our Fevered Age|date=November 23, 2016|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2016-11-23/a-fake-pizzagate-conspiracy-for-our-fevered-age|publisher=Bloomberg View|accessdate=November 29, 2016}}</ref><ref name="DCGunman">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/local/wp/2016/12/04/d-c-police-respond-to-report-of-a-man-with-a-gun-at-comet-ping-pong-restaurant/|title=N.C. man told police he went to D.C. pizzeria with assault rifle to 'self-investigate' election-related conspiracy theory|last=Svrluga|first=Susan|date=December 4, 2016|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=December 6, 2016|last2=Siddiqui|first2=Faiz}}</ref><ref name="Fox">{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2016/12/05/man-with-rifle-arrested-at-dc-restaurant-targeted-by-fake-news-conspiracy-theories.html|title=Man with rifle arrested at DC restaurant targeted by fake news conspiracy theories|date=December 5, 2016|work=Fox News|accessdate=December 9, 2016}}</ref> The restaurant's owners and staff were harassed and threatened on social media.<ref name="bbc-pizzagate" /><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/21/technology/fact-check-this-pizzeria-is-not-a-child-trafficking-site.html|title=This Pizzeria Is Not a Child-Trafficking Site|last=Kang|first=Cecilia|date=November 21, 2016|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref> After threats, Comet Ping Pong increased security for concerts held inside its premises.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://dcist.com/2016/12/comet_ping_pong_ups_security_as_bri.php|title=Comet Ping Pong Increases Concert Security In Response To Pizzagate|last=Kurzius|first=Rachel|date=December 2, 2016|accessdate=December 3, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161204131843/http://dcist.com/2016/12/comet_ping_pong_ups_security_as_bri.php|archivedate=December 4, 2016|deadurl=yes|publisher=[[DCist]]|df=}}</ref>
Days after the attack, [[Hillary Clinton]] spoke out on the dangers of fake news in a tribute speech to retiring Senator [[Harry Reid]] at the [[United States Capitol|U.S. Capitol]].<ref name="clintonattacksfake">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/powerpost/wp/2016/12/08/hillary-clinton-attacks-fake-news-in-post-election-appearance-on-capitol-hill|title=Hillary Clinton attacks 'fake news' in post-election appearance on Capitol Hill|last=Kane|first=Paul|date=December 8, 2016|work=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=December 9, 2016}}</ref><ref name="clintonwarnsepidemic">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-38258967|title=Hillary Clinton warns of 'fake news epidemic'|date=December 9, 2016|accessdate=December 9, 2016|publisher=[[BBC News]]}}</ref> Clinton called the spread of fraudulent news and fabricated propaganda an epidemic that flowed through social media.<ref name="clintonattacksfake" /><ref name="clintonwarnsepidemic" /> She said it posed a danger to citizens of the U.S. and to the country's political process.<ref name="clintonattacksfake" /><ref name="clintonwarnsepidemic" /> Clinton said in her speech she supported bills before the U.S. Congress to deal with fake news.<ref name="clintonattacksfake" />
== Notable examples of fake news websites == Many of these websites are categorized as fake news because they have a satirical take on the news, but ultimately fail to convince their readers that their content is actually fake.
=== RealTrueNews === Marco Chacon created the fake news site ''RealTrueNews'' to show his [[alt-right]] friends their alleged gullibility.<ref name="chacon">{{cite news|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/10/28/the-man-who-duped-trumpkins-fox-news.html|title=This 'Conservative News Site' Trended on Facebook, Showed Up on Fox News—and Duped the World|last=Collins|first=Ben|date=October 28, 2016|accessdate=November 27, 2016|publisher=[[The Daily Beast]]}}</ref><ref name="chacon2">{{cite news|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/11/21/i-ve-been-making-viral-fake-news-for-the-last-six-months-it-s-way-too-easy-to-dupe-the-right-on-the-internet.html|title=I’ve Been Making Viral Fake News for the Last Six Months. It’s Way Too Easy to Dupe the Right on the Internet.|last=Chacon|first=Marco|date=November 21, 2016|accessdate=November 27, 2016|publisher=[[The Daily Beast]]}}</ref> Chacon wrote a fake transcript for Clinton's leaked speeches in which Clinton explains [[bronies]] to [[Goldman Sachs]] bankers.<ref name="chacon" /><ref name="chacon2" /> Chacon was shocked when his fiction was reported as factual by [[Fox News]] and he heard his writings on [[Megyn Kelly]]'s ''[[The Kelly File]]''.<ref name="chacon" /><ref name="chacon2" /> [[Trace Gallagher]] repeated Chacon's fiction and falsely reported Clinton had called [[Bernie Sanders]] supporters a "bucket of losers" — a phrase made up by Chacon.<ref name="chacon" /> After denials from Clinton staff, Megyn Kelly apologized with a public retraction.<ref name="chacon" /><ref name="chacon2" /><ref name="bambury">{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/radio/day6/episode-313-montreal-worship-ban-protecting-syrian-schools-jamaican-bobsleds-fake-news-and-more-1.3863764/marco-chacon-meant-his-fake-election-news-to-be-satire-but-people-took-it-as-fact-1.3863769|title=Marco Chacon meant his fake election news to be satire — but people took it as fact|last=Bambury|first=Brent|date=November 25, 2016|work=[[Day 6]]|accessdate=November 27, 2016|publisher=[[CBC Radio One]]|authorlink=Brent Bambury}}</ref>
Chacon later told [[Brent Bambury]] of [[CBC Radio One]] program ''[[Day 6]]'' that he was so shocked at readers' ignorance he felt it was like an episode from ''[[The Twilight Zone]]''.<ref name="bambury" /> In an interview with [[ABC News]], Chacon defended his site, saying it was an over-the-top parody of fake sites to teach his friends how ridiculous they were.<ref name="jujuchang">{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Technology/fake-news-stories-make-real-news-headlines/story?id=43845383|title=When Fake News Stories Make Real News Headlines|last=Chang|first=Juju|date=November 29, 2016|accessdate=November 29, 2016|publisher=[[ABC News]]}}</ref> [[The Daily Beast]] reported on the popularity of Chacon's fictions being reported as if it were factual and noted pro-Trump [[Internet forum|message boards]] and YouTube videos routinely believed them.<ref name="chacon" /> In a follow-up piece Chacon wrote as a contributor for The Daily Beast after the 2016 U.S. election, he concluded those most susceptible to fake news were consumers who limited themselves to partisan media outlets.<ref name="chacon2" />
=== Global Associated News (MediaFetcher.com) === MediaFetcher.com is a fake news website generator. It has various templates for creating false articles about celebrities of a user's choice. Often users miss the disclaimer at the bottom of the page, before re-sharing This website has prompted many readers to speculate about the deaths of various celebrities.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/celebrity-car-crash-hoax/|title=FACT CHECK: Joe Montana Killed in Car Accident|work=Snopes.com|access-date=2018-04-17|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/sylvester-stallone-death-hoax/|title=FACT CHECK: Sylvester Stallone Death Hoax|work=Snopes.com|access-date=2018-04-17|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Huzlers === Similar to Global Associated News, many readers have been tricked into believing the satire website Huzlers. Snopes has over 30 separate fact checks on their articles, each one correcting the fake news from Huzlers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/world-suicide-rate-drops-37-following-logan-pauls-youtube-video/|title=FACT CHECK: Did the Suicide Rate Drop Following YouTube Star Logan Paul's 'Suicide Forest' Video?|work=Snopes.com|access-date=2018-04-17|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/mia-khalifa-fcc-commissioner-dms/|title=FACT CHECK: Did Mia Khalifa 'Expose' Ajit Pai After He 'Slid Into Her DMs'?|work=Snopes.com|access-date=2018-04-17|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.snopes.com/?s=huzlers.com|title=You searched for huzlers.com {{!}} Snopes.com|website=Snopes.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-17}}</ref> According to the owners Pablo Reyes, [[Huzlers]] swear they’re not trying to fool anyone.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://splinternews.com/the-founders-of-the-hottest-fake-news-site-in-america-s-1793849240|title=The founders of the hottest fake news site in America swear they’re not trying to fool anyone|last=Wile|first=Rob|work=Splinter|access-date=2018-04-17|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== 70news === 70news was another [[WordPress]]-based blog site, which produced fake news during 2016; in particular, one story falsely stating that [[Donald Trump]] had [[United States presidential elections in which the winner lost the popular vote|earned the most popular votes]] in the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 U.S. election]], fooled search engine algorithms and ranked very highly in results the day after the election.<ref name="wapo14november2016">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2016/11/14/googles-top-news-link-for-final-election-results-goes-to-a-fake-news-site-with-false-numbers/|title=Google's top news link for 'final election results' goes to a fake news site with false numbers|last=Bump|first=Philip|date=November 14, 2016|work=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=November 26, 2016}}</ref><ref name="politifact14november2016">{{cite news|url=http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2016/nov/14/blog-posting/no-donald-trump-not-beating-hillary-clinton-popula/|title=No, Donald Trump is not beating Hillary Clinton in the popular vote|last=Jacobson|first=Louis|date=November 14, 2016|work=[[PolitiFact.com]]|accessdate=November 26, 2016}}</ref>
=== Disinfomedia === In addition to sites run on a shoestring budget, there are sites with more of an infrastructure behind them: {{vanchor|Jestin Coler}} from [[Los Angeles]] founded Disinfomedia, a company that owns many fake news sites.<ref name="laurasydell">{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2016/11/23/503146770/npr-finds-the-head-of-a-covert-fake-news-operation-in-the-suburbs|title=We Tracked Down A Fake-News Creator In The Suburbs. Here's What We Learned|last=Sydell|first=Laura|date=November 23, 2016|work=[[All Things Considered]]|accessdate=November 26, 2016|publisher=[[NPR]]}}</ref> He gave interviews under a [[pseudonym]], Allen Montgomery.<ref name="laurasydell" /> With the help of tech-company engineer John Jansen, journalists from [[NPR]] found Coler's identity.<ref name="laurasydell" /> Coler explained how his intent for his project backfired; he wanted to expose alt-right [[Echo chamber (media)|echo chambers]], and point out their gullibility.<ref name="laurasydell" /> He stated his company wrote fake articles for the [[Left-wing politics|left-wing]] that were not shared as much as those from a [[Right-wing politics|right-wing]] point of view.<ref name="laurasydell" />
=== ''National Report'' & ''News Examiner'' === Both of these fake news websites heavily profited through the use of clickbait headlines, which were usually false. [[Paul Horner]], a lead writer at both of these websites, focused significantly on the election, since it drew strong ad revenue. He told ''[[The Washington Post]]'' he made $10,000 per month through ads linked to fake news.<ref name="thehollywoodreporter">{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/facebook-fake-news-writer-president-donald-trump-win-948218|title=Facebook Fake News Writer Reveals How He Tricked Trump Supporters and Possibly Influenced Election|date=November 17, 2016|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=November 18, 2016}}</ref><ref name="nathanmcalone">{{cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/fake-news-writer-paul-horner-thinks-he-got-trump-elected-2016-11|title=This fake-news writer says he makes over $10,000 a month, and he thinks he helped get Trump elected|last=McAlone|first=Nathan|date=November 17, 2016|accessdate=November 18, 2016|publisher=[[Business Insider]]}}</ref><ref name="theplaindealer">{{cite news|url=http://www.cleveland.com/open/index.ssf/2016/11/obama_urges_trump_not_to_cut_d.html|title=The fake news of Facebook|last=Goist|first=Robin|date=November 17, 2016|work=[[The Plain Dealer]]|accessdate=November 18, 2016|location=Cleveland}}</ref> After the election, Horner said that he felt his efforts helped Trump.<ref name="fakenewswriter">{{Citation|last=Dewey|first=Caitlin|title=Facebook fake-news writer: 'I think Donald Trump is in the White House because of me'|date=November 17, 2016|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-intersect/wp/2016/11/17/facebook-fake-news-writer-i-think-donald-trump-is-in-the-white-house-because-of-me/|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=November 17, 2016}}</ref> In a follow-up interview with ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', Horner revealed ''The Washington Post'' profile piece on him spurred increased interest with over 60 interview requests from media including [[ABC News]], [[CBS News]], and CBS's ''[[Inside Edition]]''.<ref name="hedegaard">{{cite news|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/news/how-a-fake-newsman-accidentally-helped-trump-win-white-house-w452488|title=How a Fake Newsman Accidentally Helped Trump Win the White House - Paul Horner thought he was trolling Trump supporters – but after the election, the joke was on him|last=Hedegaard|first=Erik|date=November 29, 2016|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|accessdate=November 29, 2016}}</ref> Horner explained his writing style: articles that appeared legitimate at the top and became increasingly absurd as the reader progressed.<ref name="hedegaard" /> These two websites often referenced each other.<ref name=":11" />
=== Christian Times Newspaper === In an interview with ''The New York Times'', Cameron Harris of Annapolis, Maryland, explains how he profited from creating fake news on his website, ChristianTimesNewspaper.com, that included a false story claiming that premarked ballots for Mrs. Clinton were being held in boxes at a warehouse in Ohio.<ref name=nytimes2017>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/18/us/fake-news-hillary-clinton-cameron-harris.html|title=From Headline to Photograph, a Fake News Masterpiece|last=Shane|first=Scott|date=2017-01-18|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2017-01-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161002195543/http://christiantimesnewspaper.com/breaking-tens-of-thousands-of-fraudulent-clinton-votes-found-in-ohio-warehouse/|title=BREAKING: “Tens of thousands” of fraudulent Clinton votes found in Ohio warehouse - Christian Times Newspaper|date=2 October 2016|publisher=}}</ref> Within a few days, the story had earned him around $5,000.<ref name=nytimes2017/>
=== ''KMT 11 News'' === During the summer of 2016, ''KMT 11 News'' published a series of fake news stories regarding celebrity appearances and filming locations in random local towns. These towns included [[Brentwood, Tennessee]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/2016/06/30/sorry-forrest-gump-2-not-filming-brentwood/86544764/|title=Sorry, Forrest Gump 2 NOT filming in Brentwood|last1=Paulson|first1=Dave|date=June 30, 2016|work=[[The Tennessean]]|accessdate=January 19, 2017}}</ref> [[Chandler, Arizona]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://ktar.com/story/1124229/cruci-no-new-harry-potter-movie-will-not-be-filmed-in-arizona/|title=Cruci-no: New 'Harry Potter' movie will not be filmed in Arizona|date=June 20, 2016|accessdate=January 19, 2017|publisher=KTAR News}}</ref> and [[Atlantic City, New Jersey]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://943thepoint.com/the-notebook-2-not-filming-in-atlantic-city-or-anywhere-else/|title='The Notebook 2′ Not Filming in Atlantic City…or Anywhere Else Read More: 'The Notebook 2' Not Filming in Atlantic City...or Anywhere Else|last1=Cataldo|first1=Laurie|date=June 14, 2016|accessdate=January 19, 2017|publisher=94.3 The Point}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://isitfakenews.com/site/kmt11.com|title=IsItFakeNews.com|website=isitfakenews.com|language=en|access-date=2018-04-17}}</ref>
== Spread and identification of fake news == 44 percent of all US adults get their news from [[Facebook]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.vox.com/2016/11/16/13626318/viral-fake-news-on-facebook|title=The scariest part of Facebook’s fake news problem: fake news is more viral than real news|date=2016-11-16|publisher=[[Vox (website)|Vox]]|accessdate=2017-04-13}}</ref> Investigations conducted in 2017 showed nearly 40 percent of content by far-right Facebook pages and 19 percent of extreme left-leaning pages were false or misleading.<ref name=":0" /> In the 10 months leading up to the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 presidential election]], 20 fake news articles shared on Facebook dramatically increased from 3 million "shares, reactions, and comments" to nearly 9 million.<ref name=":0" /> Mainstream media articles, on the other hand, declined from 12 million "shares, reactions, and comments" in February to only 7.3 million by Election Day.<ref name=":0" />
A study conducted by the [[Stanford Graduate School of Education]] from January 2015 revealed difficulties that middle, high school, and college students experienced in differentiating between advertisements and news articles, or identifying where information originated.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://ed.stanford.edu/news/stanford-researchers-find-students-have-trouble-judging-credibility-information-online|title=Stanford researchers find students have trouble judging the credibility of information online {{!}} Stanford Graduate School of Education|publisher=Stanford University|accessdate=2017-04-14}}</ref> One concern noted by researchers of the study is that democracy is at risk of devolving due to the ways in which falsehoods about civic issues can quickly spread with a growing ease of access. In one assessment, high school students were asked to evaluate two Facebook posts mentioning [[Donald Trump]]'s candidacy for president; one was from an actual [[Fox News]] account and the other was from a fake account.<ref name=":1" /> Over 30 percent of students stated that the fake account was more reliable because of its graphic elements and only a quarter recognized the significance of the blue checkmark on [[Twitter]] and Facebook, which indicates that an account was marked as legitimate.<ref name=":1" />
== U.S. Response == === Educational === Elementary school teachers have decided to challenge results from the Stanford study by showing children the importance of not being deceived by what is fake. Fifth grade teacher Scott Bedley in California created his own version of "[[Simon Says]]", in which students are given three minutes to read an article and decide whether a news story is true or false.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/ed/2017/02/16/514364210/5-ways-teachers-are-fighting-fake-news|title=5 Ways Teachers Are Fighting Fake News|accessdate=2017-04-14|publisher=[[NPR]]}}</ref> Those who think it's false are told to stand up while those who think it's true remain in their seats.<ref name=":2" /> Bedley worked with another teacher in Kansas, Todd Flory, to devise a "fake news challenge" via [[Skype]] whereby Flory's class picked two real articles and wrote a fake one, to be presented to Bedly's class in California.<ref name=":2" /> Teachers are promoting these learning techniques with the hope that such strategies and skills will stay with their students' for the rest of their adolescent and adult lives.<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vox.com/first-person/2017/3/29/15042692/fake-news-education-election|title=I taught my 5th-graders how to spot fake news. Now they won’t stop fact-checking me.|work=Vox|access-date=2018-04-17}}</ref>
Andreas Schleicher, the lead of Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development, announced in 2017 that his organization was initiating "global competencies” tests will be taken by 15-year-olds around the world alongside the OECD’s current reading, maths and science assessments, which are conducted every three years. This will test how well students can discern fake news outside of their sociopolitical bubble.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2017/mar/18/teach-schoolchildren-spot-fake-news-says-oecd|title=Teach schoolchildren how to spot fake news, says OECD|last=Siddique|first=Haroon|date=2017-03-18|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-04-17}}</ref>
Jennifer Coogan, editor in chief of education startup Newsela, has partnered with the American Press Institute to help combat fake news consumption in addition to its regular literacy boosting skill classes. She believes its is now the teacher's responsibility to help teach their students about which media to believe since it is near impossible for a parent to monitor every source that a child will read.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/newsela-teaches-kids-how-to-spot-fake-news-2017-1|title=This education startup is teaching kids how to spot fake news|work=Business Insider|access-date=2018-04-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://ca.finance.yahoo.com/news/education-startup-teaching-kids-spot-204000413.html|title=This education startup is teaching kids how to spot fake news|access-date=2018-04-17|language=en-CA}}</ref>
=== Commercial ===
==== Facebook ==== {{See also|Criticism of Facebook}} After receiving heavy criticism for not stopping the extreme number of fake news articles on its platform, [[Facebook]] announced in December 2016 that it would begin to flag fake news. If enough users flagged a story, the story would be sent to a 3rd party organization to check its veracity. If it failed, it would lose news feed priority as well as have "disputed by 3rd party fact-checkers" as a caption. Facebook is also attempting to reduce their financial incentives in an attempt to decrease the amount of fake news. The fact checking organizations involved are [[ABC News]], [[Associated Press]], [[FactCheck.org]], [[PolitiFact]] and [[Snopes.com|Snopes]].<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/dec/15/facebook-flag-fake-news-fact-check|title=Facebook to begin flagging fake news in response to mounting criticism|last=Jamieson|first=Amber|last2=Solon|first2=Olivia|date=2016-12-15|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-04-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.factcheck.org/2016/12/facebooks-fake-news-initiative/|title=Facebook's 'Fake News' Initiative - FactCheck.org|date=2016-12-22|work=FactCheck.org|access-date=2018-04-17|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vox.com/new-money/2016/11/16/13637310/facebook-fake-news-explained|title=Facebook's fake news problem, explained|work=Vox|access-date=2018-04-17}}</ref>
In 2018, Facebook has admitted that it 'fell short' in stopping outside meddling in the U.S. presidential election. This admission comes after increased scrutiny from lawmakers in a broader backlash against Silicon Valley as well as a Senate hearing for social media company executives.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2018/01/22/facebook-admits-it-sometimes-harms-democracy/|title=Facebook admits social media sometimes harms democracy|last=Phillips|first=Kristine|date=2018-01-22|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-04-17|last2=Fung|first2=Brian|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref>
==== Fact-checking organizations ==== {{See also|Fake_news_website#Fact-checking_websites_and_journalists}} In the aftermath of the election, many fact-checking websites teamed up with Facebook in order to check on the veracity of linked articles.<ref name=":3" /> Many of these organization have also posted lists of fake news websites and guides on how to identify them.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.politifact.com/punditfact/article/2017/apr/20/politifacts-guide-fake-news-websites-and-what-they/|title=PolitiFact's guide to fake news websites|work=PunditFact|access-date=2018-04-17|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":10"/>
=== Governmental ===
==== Legislative ==== Members of the [[United States Senate Select Committee on Intelligence|U.S. Senate Intelligence Committee]] traveled to Ukraine and Poland in March 2016 and heard from officials in both countries on Russian operations to influence their affairs.<ref name="angusking">{{cite news|url=http://www.pressherald.com/2016/12/01/sen-king-russian-involvement-in-u-s-election-an-arrow-aimed-at-the-heart-of-democracy/|title=Angus King: Russian involvement in U.S. election 'an arrow aimed at the heart of democracy’|last=Miller|first=Kevin|date=December 1, 2016|work=[[Portland Press Herald]]|accessdate=December 2, 2016}}</ref> U.S. Senator [[Angus King]] told the ''[[Portland Press Herald]]'' that tactics used by Russia during the 2016 U.S. election were analogous to those used against other countries.<ref name="angusking" /> King recalled the legislators were informed by officials from both Ukraine and Poland about Russian tactics of "planting fake news stories" during elections.<ref name="angusking" /> On November 20, 2016, King joined a letter in which seven members of the U.S. Senate Intelligence Committee asked President Obama to publicize more information from the intelligence community on Russia's role in the U.S. election.<ref name="angusking" /><ref name="kingamong">{{cite news|url=http://www.pressherald.com/2016/11/30/angus-king-among-senators-asking-president-to-declassify-information-about-russia-and-election/|title=Angus King among senators asking president to declassify information about Russia and election|date=November 20, 2016|work=[[Portland Press Herald]]|accessdate=December 2, 2016}}</ref> In an interview with CNN, Senator King warned against ignoring the problem, saying it was a bipartisan issue.<ref name="hackingdeclassified">{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2016/12/02/politics/democrats-russian-hacking-intelligence/|title=Democrats want Russian hacking intelligence declassified|author1=Jim Sciutto|date=December 3, 2016|accessdate=December 3, 2016|publisher=[[CNN]]|author2=Manu Raju}}</ref>
Amid worries about fake news and [[disinformation]] being spread by Russia, representatives in the [[United States Congress|U.S. Congress]] called for more action to track and counter alleged propaganda emanating from overseas.<ref name="combatpropaganda">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/economy/effort-to-combat-foreign-propaganda-advances-in-congress/2016/11/30/9147e1ac-e221-47be-ab92-9f2f7e69d452_story.html|title=Effort to combat foreign propaganda advances in Congress|last=Timberg|first=Craig|date=November 20, 2016|work=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=December 1, 2016}}</ref><ref name="representativesbacks">{{cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/us-house-representatives-backs-proposal-counter-global-russian-subversion-1594342|title=US House of representatives backs proposal to counter global Russian subversion|last=Porter|first=Tom|date=December 1, 2016|work=[[International Business Times|International Business Times UK edition]]|accessdate=December 1, 2016}}</ref> On November 20, 2016, legislators approved a measure within the [[National Defense Authorization Act]] to ask the [[United States Department of State|U.S. State Department]] act against propaganda with an inter-agency panel.<ref name="combatpropaganda" /><ref name="representativesbacks" /> The legislation authorized funding of $160 million over a two-year-period.<ref name="combatpropaganda" /> The initiative was developed through a [[bipartisan]] bill, the [[Countering Foreign Propaganda and Disinformation Act]], written by U.S. Senators Republican [[Rob Portman]] and Democrat [[Chris Murphy (Connecticut politician)|Chris Murphy]].<ref name="combatpropaganda" /> Portman urged more U.S. government action to counter propaganda.<ref name="combatpropaganda" /> Murphy said after the election it was apparent the U.S. needed additional tactics to fight Russian propaganda.<ref name="combatpropaganda" /> [[United States Senate Select Committee on Intelligence|U.S. Senate Intelligence Committee]] member [[Ron Wyden]] said frustration over covert Russian propaganda was bipartisan.<ref name="combatpropaganda" />
Republican U.S. Senators stated they planned to hold hearings and investigate Russian influence on the 2016 U.S. elections.<ref name="republicansready">{{cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/politics/ct-senate-probe-russia-trump-20161208-story.html|title=Republicans ready to launch wide-ranging probe of Russia, despite Trump’s stance|last=Demirjian|first=Karoun|date=December 8, 2016|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|accessdate=December 10, 2016|agency=[[The Washington Post]]}}</ref> By doing so they went against the preference of incoming Republican President-elect Donald Trump, who downplayed any potential Russian meddling in the election.<ref name="republicansready" /> [[United States Senate Committee on Armed Services|U.S. Senate Armed Services Committee]] Chairman [[John McCain]] and [[United States Senate Select Committee on Intelligence|U.S. Senate Intelligence Committee]] Chairman [[Richard Burr]] discussed plans for collaboration on investigations of Russian [[cyberwarfare]] during the election.<ref name="republicansready" /> [[United States Senate Committee on Foreign Relations|U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee]] Chairman [[Bob Corker]] planned a 2017 investigation.<ref name="republicansready" /> Senator [[Lindsey Graham]] indicated he would conduct a sweeping investigation in the [[115th United States Congress|115th U.S. Congress session]].<ref name="republicansready" />
==== FTC ==== In 2013, the FTC as part of a campaign to crackdown on bogus health claims charged over $1.6 million to Beony International and owner Mario Milanovic, and Beony International employee Cody Adams. They conspired to promote their own weight loss products with fake news websites. These websites pretended to be legitimate news organizations and promoted their acai berry weight-loss products heavily.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ftc.gov/news-events/press-releases/2013/02/ftc-permanently-stops-fake-news-website-operator-allegedly|title=FTC Permanently Stops Fake News Website Operator that Allegedly Deceived Consumers about Acai Berry Weight-Loss Products|date=2013-02-07|work=Federal Trade Commission|access-date=2018-04-18|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mlmlaw.com/ftc-concludes-crackdown-on-fake-news-sites-with-1-6-million-beony-settlements/|title=TC Reaches $1.6 Million Settlement with Beony {{!}} MLM Law|website=www.mlmlaw.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-18}}</ref>
==== Counter-Disinformation Team ==== The [[United States Department of State]] planned to use a unit called the Counter-Disinformation Team, formed with the intention of combating [[disinformation]] from the [[Russian government]], and that it was disbanded in September 2015 after department heads missed the scope of propaganda before the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 U.S. election]].<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/how-us-eu-failings-allowed-kremlin-propaganda-fake-news-spread-through-west-1593071|title=How US and EU failings allowed Kremlin propaganda and fake news to spread through the West|last=Porter|first=Tom|date=2016-11-28|work=International Business Times UK|access-date=2018-04-17|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url=http://observer.com/2015/11/obama-fails-to-fight-putins-propaganda-machine/|title=Obama Fails to Fight Putin’s Propaganda Machine|date=2015-11-05|work=Observer|access-date=2018-04-17|language=en-US}}</ref> The U.S. State Department put eight months into developing the unit before scrapping it.<ref name=":5" /> It would have been a reboot of the [[Active Measures Working Group]] set up by [[Presidency of Ronald Reagan|President Reagan.]]<ref name=":6" /><ref name=":7">{{Cite news|url=http://observer.com/2016/11/the-kremlin-didnt-sink-hillary-obama-did/|title=The Kremlin Didn’t Sink Hillary—Obama Did|date=2016-11-26|work=Observer|access-date=2018-04-17|language=en-US}}</ref> The Counter-Disinformation Team was set up under the [[Bureau of International Information Programs]].<ref name=":6" /><ref name=":7" /> Work began in 2014, with the intention to combat propaganda from Russian sources such as ''[[Russia Today]][[Presidency of Ronald Reagan|.]]<ref name=":6" /><ref name=":7" />'' [[United States Intelligence Community|U.S. Intelligence]] officials explained to former [[National Security Agency]] analyst and [[counterintelligence]] officer John R. Schindler that the [[Presidency of Barack Obama|Obama Administration]] decided to cancel the unit as they were afraid of antagonizing Russia.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":6" /> [[Under Secretary of State for Public Diplomacy and Public Affairs|U.S. Undersecretary of State for Public Diplomacy]] [[Richard Stengel]] was point person for the unit before it was canceled[[Presidency of Ronald Reagan|.]]<ref name=":6" /><ref name=":7" /> Stengel previously wrote about disinformation by ''Russia Today.''<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/state-department-responds-rt-russia-today-john-kerry-2014-4|title=Russia's Propaganda Channel Just Got A Journalism Lesson From The US State Department|work=Business Insider|access-date=2018-04-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/john-kerry-rt-propaganda-bullhorn-russia-today-2014-4|title=RT Is Very Upset With John Kerry For Blasting Them As Putin's 'Propaganda Bullhorn'|work=Business Insider|access-date=2018-04-17}}</ref>
== See also == {{Portal|Internet|Politics|Psychology}}
* [[Confirmation bias]] * [[Fake news]] * [[Filter bubble]] * [[List of fake news websites]] * [[List of satirical news websites]] * [[Selective exposure theory]] * [[Spiral of silence]] {{clear}}

Daro|date=November 15, 2016|publisher=[[BuzzFeed]]|author2=[[Craig Silverman]]}} * {{cite news|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/craigsilverman/viral-fake-election-news-outperformed-real-news-on-facebook|title=Viral Fake Election News Outperformed Real News On Facebook In Final Months Of The US Election|author=Craig Silverman|date=November 16, 2016|publisher=[[BuzzFeed]]}} * {{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2016/11/26/before-fake-news-there-was-soviet-disinformation|title=Before 'fake news,' there was Soviet 'disinformation'|last=Taylor|first=Adam|date=November 26, 2016|work=[[The Washington Post]]}} * {{cite news|url=http://warontherocks.com/2016/11/trolling-for-trump-how-russia-is-trying-to-destroy-our-democracy/|title=Trolling for Trump: How Russia is Trying to Destroy Our Democracy|author1=Andrew Weisburd|date=November 6, 2016|publisher=War on the Rocks|author2=Clint Watts|author3=JM Berger|author2-link=Clint Watts}} * {{cite news|url=http://www.dw.com/en/fake-news-casts-wide-net-but-has-little-effect/a-42029486|title=Fake news 'casts wide net but has little effect'|author=Elizabeth Schumacher|date=January 4, 2018|publisher=[[Deutsche Welle]]}}

{{Infobox UK legislation |short_title=The Forgery Act 1913<ref>The citation of this Act by this [[short title]] was authorised by [http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1913/27/section/22/enacted section 22] of this Act. Due to the repeal of that section, it is now authorised by section 19(2) of the [[Interpretation Act 1978]].</ref> |parliament=Parliament of the United Kingdom |long_title=An Act to consolidate, simplify, and amend the Law-relating to Forgery and kindred Offences. |year=1913 |statute_book_chapter=3 & 4 Geo 5 c 27 |introduced_by= |territorial_extent= |royal_assent=15 August 1913 |commencement=1 January 1914<ref>The Forgery Act 1913, section 22</ref> |repeal_date= |amendments= |related_legislation= |repealing_legislation= |status=Repealed |original_text=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1913/27/contents/enacted |legislation_history= |revised_text= |}}
'''The Forgery Act 1913''' (3 & 4 Geo 5 c 27) was an [[Act of Parliament|Act]] of the [[Parliament of the United Kingdom]].
This Act was repealed for [[England and Wales]] and [[Northern Ireland]] by section 30 of, and Part I of the Schedule to, the [[Forgery and Counterfeiting Act 1981]]. It was repealed for the [[Republic of Ireland]] by [http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/2001/en/act/pub/0050/sec0003.html#sec3 section 3(1)] of, and [http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/2001/en/act/pub/0050/sched1.html#sched1 Schedule 1] to, the [[Criminal Justice (Theft and Fraud Offences) Act, 2001]].
'''Section 1 - Definition of forgery'''
This section provided a definition of [[forgery]].
'''Section 2 - Forgery of certain documents with intent to defraud'''
As to the mode of trial of offences under section 2(2)(a) in England and Wales, see sections 16(1) and (3) of, and paragraph 13(a) of Schedule 2 to, and paragraph 15(a) of Schedule 3 to, the [[Criminal Law Act 1977]].
'''Section 3 - Forgery of certain documents with intent to defraud or deceive'''
'''Section 4 - Forgery of other documents with intent to defraud or to deceive a misdemeanour'''
As to the mode of trial of offences under this section in England and Wales, see section 16(3) of, and paragraph 15(b) of Schedule 3 to, the [[Criminal Law Act 1977]].
'''Section 5 - Forgery of seals and dies'''
'''Section 6 - Uttering'''
'''Section 7 - Demanding property on forged documents etc.'''
As to the mode of trial of offences under section 7(a) in England and Wales, see sections 16(1) and (3) of, and paragraph 13(b) of Schedule 2 to, and paragraph 15(c) of Schedule 3 to, the [[Criminal Law Act 1977]].
'''Section 8 - Possession of forged documents, seals and dies'''
'''Section 9 - Making or having in possession paper or implements for forgery'''
'''Section 10 - Purchasing or having in possession certain paper before it has been duly stamped and issued'''
'''Section 11 - Accessories and abettors'''
'''Section 12 - Punishments'''
'''Section 13 - Jurisdiction of quarter sessions in England'''
'''Section 14 - Venue'''
'''Section 15 - Criminal possession'''
'''Section 16 - Search warrants'''
'''Section 17 - Form of indictment and proof of intent'''
'''Section 18 - Interpretation'''
'''Section 19 - Savings'''
'''Section 20 - Repeals'''
'''Section 21 - Extent'''
'''Section 22 - Short title and commencement'''
'''Schedule'''
'''Indictments for ss. 2 and 6'''
The following specimen counts were formerly contained in paragraph 18 of the [http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1915/90/pdfs/ukpga_19150090_en.pdf Second Schedule] to the [[Indictments Act 1915]] before it was repealed.
{{Blockquote|STATEMENT OF OFFENCE.
''First Count.''
Forgery, contrary to section 2(1)(a) of the Forgery Act, 1913.
PARTICULARS OF OFFENCE.
''A.B.'', on the {{Pad|4em}} day of {{Pad|4em}}, in the county of {{Pad|4em}}, with intent to defraud, forged a certain will purporting to be the will of ''C.D.''
STATEMENT OF OFFENCE.
''Second Count.''
Uttering forged document, contrary to section 6(1)(2) of the Forgery Act, 1913.
PARTICULARS OF OFFENCE.
''A.B.'', on the {{Pad|4em}} day of {{Pad|4em}}, in the county of {{Pad|4em}}, uttered a certain forged will purporting to be the will of ''C.D'', knowing the same to be forged and with intent to defraud.}}
==See also== *[[Forgery Act]]
==References== *[[Halsbury's Statutes]], {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1913/27/contents/enacted The Forgery Act 1913], as originally enacted from the [[The National Archives (United Kingdom)|National Archives]]. *List of repeals and amendments in the Republic of Ireland from the [http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/isbc/bps1913.html Irish Statute Book]
{{UK legislation}}

revision.text:
A '''Grand illumination''' is an outdoor [[ceremony]] involving the simultaneous activation of lights. The most common form of the ceremony involves turning on [[Christmas lights (holiday decoration)|Christmas lights]].
One of the older of such community events began at [[Colonial Williamsburg]], the restored Historic District of the former [[Virginia]] capital city of [[Williamsburg, Virginia|Williamsburg]] in 1935. It is held there each year on the Sunday of the first full weekend in December. (That is, if December begins on a Sunday, the event is held the following Sunday.) Williamsburg's Grand Illumination, which also involves fireworks, is based loosely on the [[Colony and Dominion of Virginia|colonial]] (and [[England|English]]) tradition of placing lighted [[candle]]s in the windows of homes and public buildings to celebrate a special event. The winning of a war and the birthday of the reigning [[monarch]] are examples of such national events. Many candles appeared in darkened windows in New York after the [[September 11, 2001 attacks]].
In recent times, in many cities much larger than Williamsburg, such as [[Richmond, Virginia]], multiple [[skyscraper]]s and other buildings are decorated with long mostly vertical strings of lights of a common theme, and are activated simultaneously in "Grand Illumination" ceremonies. Some communities, such as [[Norfolk, Virginia]] and [[Asheville, North Carolina]], have Grand Illumination [[parade]]s. In [[Chattanooga, Tennessee]], a similar event is called the "Grand Illumination On The River." In [[Oak Bluffs, Massachusetts]], on [[Martha's Vineyard]], Grand Illumination is one of the most significant events each summer, immediately preceded by a Community Sing. In the [[United Kingdom]], the "Grand Illumination" ceremony is generally referred to as "Turning On The Lights", and occurs in virtually all towns and cities throughout the country.
==See also== *[[Christmas tree]] *[[Fourth of July]] *[[Holiday Trail of Lights]] *[[Colonial Williamsburg]]
==External links and sources== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051124160040/http://www.drellenrudolph.com/illumination/ The 'Grand Illumination' in Williamsburg's Historic District] many photos *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051225120640/http://www.downtownnorfolk.org/grand_illumination_parade.shtml Norfolk's Grand Illumination Parade] *[http://www.chattanoogan.com/articles/article_75745.asp Grand Illumination On The River, Chattanooga, Tennessee] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060820091730/http://www.mvcma.org/grand.htm Grand Illumination at the Campground in Oak Bluffs, Massachusetts]
{{Colonial Williamsburg}}
[[Category:Christmas in the United States]] [[Category:Ceremonies]] [[Category:Winter traditions]] [[Category:Colonial Williamsburg]]

{{Unreferenced|date=March 2015}} {{Advert|date=March 2015}} [[File:San Francisco Green Festival 2014.JPG|thumb|View of the San Francisco Green Festival, November 9, 2013]] [[File:Ralph Nader at the Green Festival, Washington DC, June 1, 2014.jpg|thumb|200px|Ralph Nader holding his book ''[[Unstoppable: The Emerging Left-Right Alliance to Dismantle the Corporate State|Unstoppable]]'' at the 2014 Green Festival, [[Washington D.C.]]]]
'''Green Festivals''' was the largest and longest-running [[sustainability]] event in the United States. Green Festivals brings together the world’s most trusted companies, innovative brands, national and local businesses, pioneering thinkers and consumers, in one dynamic marketplace to share solutions for living healthier, more sustainable lives. Founded in 2002, Green Festivals is a [[zero-waste]] event, with over one million attendees.
Originally, conceived by Dr. Kevin Danaher of Global Exchange and executives as sustainable event producers Seven-Star including Alan van de Kamp Grau, Georgia Malki and Joseph Malki the event series started in 2003 launching in San Francisco. Greg Roberts was also seminal in the event's creation.
Green Festival offers the widest selection of products and services to work green, play green and live green – from food, fashion and health, to energy, home renovation, garden and design. Each Green Festival also features hands-on demos, educational activities for kids and families, panels featuring [[inspirational speaker]]s, and live music and entertainment. Past speakers have included founder of RawYouth.org, [[Charles Chen]]; fashion designer [[Jeff Garner]]; vegan chef and healthy living educator [[Leslie Durso]]; [[Seth Goldman (businessman)|Seth Goldman]], president and CEO of Honest Tea; [[Amy Goodman]], investigative journalist and syndicated columnist at Democracy Now!; and [[Katrina vanden Heuvel]], Editor and Publisher of The Nation; among many others.
Green Festival is a marketplace of more than 250 [[eco-friendly]] businesses-everything from all-natural [[body care]] products and [[organic cotton]] clothing to [[Fair Trade]] gifts and home renovations from [[renewable resources]], and [[vegan]]-vegetarian offerings based on organic, non-[[genetically modified organism|GMO]] or local [[artisanal food]]s.
Green Festival events are taking place in five cities in 2017, including [[New York City]], [[Washington, D.C.]], [[San Francisco]] and [[Los Angeles]], and [[Ft. Lauderdale]]. Past festival locations include Austin, Seattle, Chicago and Denver.
Seven-Star, Inc. produced of 65 iterations of the event across the United States over its 13 year production history. In 2009, Seven-Star, Inc. won the E.P.A. Waste Wise Award for a 98.8 waste diversion effort. Seven-Star, Inc. sold its operation of the event series and passed of its assets and employees to Messe Stuttgart. In 2013, Green America and Global Exchange, two long-term partners of Green Festivals, joined forces with Messe Stuttgart, a leading international tradeshow organizer producing Europe’s largest consumer show on sustainability, green products and Fair Trade.
==See also== *[[Green politics]] *[[Sustainable living]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.greenfestivals.org Official website]
[[Category:Festivals in the United States]] [[Category:Environmental festivals]]
{{festival-stub}}

'''Illustrators for Gender Equality''' (Dibujantes por la Igualdad de Género) is an international art exhibition conceived in 2007 with the aim of encouraging gender equality through opinion cartoons.
The exhibition comprises artworks of 30 graphic artists from 20 countries, and the cartoons do not include any words in order to reach out to all audiences, regardless of language.<ref>{{cite news |author= EFE |title= DIBUJANTES POR LA IGUALDAD DE GÉNERO |url= http://www.elmundo.es/metropoli/2007/02/26/arte/1172512109.html |work= elmundo.es |publisher= Mundinteractivos, S.A |date= 2007-03-27 |accessdate=2012-08-15 }}</ref>
Till present, Illustrators for Gender Equality has been shown in [[Spain]], [[Mexico]], [[Sweden]], [[Cuba]] and [[Singapore]]; supported by organizations for the rights of women, cultural associations, governmental organizations and universities.
==Tour==
===2007===
* Galileo Showroom, Madrid (Spain). * Latinarte Showroom, Madrid (Spain). * La Paloma Cultural Center, Madrid (Spain). * Villa de Vallecas Youth Center, Madrid (Spain).
===2008===
* Royal Mail House, Madrid (Spain). * Oaxaca City Palace Museum, Oaxaca (Mexico).
===2009===
* UNAM (Autonomous University of Mexico), Méjico F.D. (Mexico). * Colima Regional Museum, Colima (Mexico). * Francisco Velázquez, Havana (Cuba). * Umeå University, Umeå (Sweden). * Pintores Gallery, Cáceres (Spain).
===2010===
* La Musa Gallery, Baracoa (Cuba).
===2011===
* Palace of Justice of Xalapa, Veracruz (Mexico).<ref>{{cite news |author = Tribunal de lo Contencioso Administrativo del Estado de Veracruz |title = DIBUJANTES POR LA IGUALDAD DE GÉNERO |url = http://tcaveracruz.gob.mx/igualdadegenero.html |work = tcaveracruz.gob.mx |publisher = Tribunal de lo Contencioso Administrativo del Estado de Veracruz |date = 2011-04-25 |accessdate = 2012-09-08 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://archive.is/20121219213412/http://tcaveracruz.gob.mx/igualdadegenero.html |archivedate = 2012-12-19 |df = }}</ref>
===2012===
* Palace of Justice of San Cristóbal de las Casas, Chiapas (Mexico). * Palace of Justice of Yucatán, Yucatán (Mexico).
===2013===
* The Arts House, [[Singapore]].<ref>{{cite news |author= The Arts House |title= Illustrators for Gender Equality |url= http://www.theartshouse.com.sg/Programmes/EventPage.aspx?EventID=2952 |work= theartshouse.com |publisher= The Arts House |date= 2013-02-01 |accessdate=2013-03-12 }}</ref> * Palace of Duke of Pastrana, [[Guadalajara]] (Spain).<ref>{{cite news |author= El Mundo |title= Cospedal inaugura la exposición 'Dibujantes por la igualdad de género' |url= http://www.elmundo.es/elmundo/2013/03/10/comunicacion/1362912096.html |work= elmundo.es |publisher= El Mundo |date= 2013-03-12 |accessdate=2013-03-10 }}</ref>
{{anchor|Drawers}} ==Artists==
'''Blasberg''' (Argentina); '''Tsocho Peev''' (Bulgaria); '''Menekse Cam''' (Turkey); '''Huang Kun''','''Yu Liang''', '''Ni Rong''' (China); '''Elena Ospina''', '''Vladdo''' (Colombia); '''Oki''' (Costa Rica); '''Falco''', '''Ares''', '''Adán''' (Cuba); '''Kilia''' (Dominican Republic); '''Pancho Cajas''' (Ecuador); '''Kimberly Gloria Choi''' (Hong Kong); '''Victor Ndula''' (Kenya), '''Boligan''', '''Dario''', '''Rocko''' (Mexico); '''Derkaoui''' (Morocco); '''Tayo Fatunla''' (Nigeria),'''Firuz Kutal''' (Norway); '''Florian-Doru Crihana''' (Romania); '''Omar Zevallos''' (Peru); '''Doris''' (Poland); '''Node''', '''JRmora''', '''Sex''', '''Enio''' (Spain); '''Miel''' (Singapore); '''Enos''' (USA).
==Bibliography==
{{reflist}} * [http://www.elpais.com/fotografia/madrid/Exposicion/Dibujantes/Igualdad/Genero/elpfot/20070227elpmad_4/Ies/ El País Newspaper] * https://archive.is/20121220194531/http://www.karikaturculerdernegi.org/detay.asp?id=6135 * http://www.entretodas.net/2007/03/08/humor-las-mujeres-en-la-muestra-«dibujantes-por-la-igualdad-de-genero»/{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * http://www.jrmora.com/blog/2009/10/16/dibujantes-por-la-igualdad-de-suecia-a-caceres/ * https://archive.is/20121209070434/http://www.extremadura.com/agenda/exposiciones/inauguracion_de_dibujantes_por_la_igualdad_de_genero.html * http://www.yucatannoticias.com/2012/06/muestra-itinerante-dibujantes-por-la-igualdad-de-generoen-los-juzgados-del-poder-judicial/{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}
