revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=November 2008}} [[Image:Steam Engines.JPG|thumb|right|280px|Rally steam engines]] '''Innishannon Steam and Vintage Rally''' is held between [[Crossbarry]] and [[Innishannon]] (Irish: Inis Eonáin), a village on the main [[Cork (city)|Cork]]–[[Bandon, County Cork|Bandon]] road (N71) in [[County Cork]], Province of [[Munster]], [[Ireland]]. The show takes place in a 38-acre site.
== History ==
The rally has been running successfully since June 1998 and was awarded charitable status in 1999. All proceeds from the event go to the [[Irish Cancer Society]]. The rally takes place every June Bank Holiday weekend in Innishannon, Cork. The founding of the event was led by well known steam preservationist Tim Nagle of Kinsale.
Over the years the event has gained significant support. In the first year IR£5000 was handed over to the Irish Cancer Society. The second year saw IR£13,500 was donated; in 2000 the amount more than doubled to IR£27,500. Unfortunately due to the [[foot-and-mouth disease]] outbreak in 2001 no rally was held, but in 2002 €35,500 went to the Irish Cancer Society. In 2003 the event raised €60,000, and in 2005 €65,000.
Over the past 14 years, the rally has raised over €970,000 for the ICS. The rally has broken the €1 million mark in 2012.
The Innishannon Steam and Vintage replaced the nearby Upton Steam Rally started in 1967/68 by Ned Foley of Youghal (Steam Roller Engine), Thos (Thomas) Scanlan of Ballyhooley (Overtime Tractor x2) and Brendan O Connell of Ballincollig (Army Truck) to fund / support Upton Brothers of Charity, the rally which ceased in 1997, due to insurance concerns and costs.
== Objectives ==
This rally was originally created to promote heritage machinery of all classes at work and to provide a suitable venue for vintage enthusiasts to display their machines, as well as allowing the general public to view rare agricultural and mechanical treasures from the past. The exhibits include huge tractors, threshers, unique cars, motorbikes, oil and steam engines as well as experiencing a working forge. There is also a pet's corner, always popular with children, a cake sale, numerous stands and stalls with art and craft displays, a dog show, sheep dog trials, road rolling, stone crushing, line dancing and a non-stop disco. This is a fun-day out for collectors, enthusiasts and visitors alike with car parking and camping facilities set up in the village. Innishannon itself dates back to the sixth century and is surrounded by an ancient woodland and castle ruins.
The rally seeks to promote steam vintage and other items of heritage and also provide a venue suitable to the enthusiast to show items of yesteryear. It also allows the public to view such rare treasures. It also seeks raise funds for a needy and deserving cause, The Irish Cancer Society.
== Event highlights == Steam Engines / Cars / Tractors / Fire Engine Display / Motorcycles / Working Area / Cake Sale / Vintage Club Displays / Sheep Dog Trials / Stackmaking / Slow Tractor Race / Slow Steam Engine Race / Queen of Steam Competition / Oil Engines / Vintage Farm Machinery / Threshing / Wood Sawing / Stone Crushing / Road Rolling / Rural Crafts / Disco Dancing / Slow Steam Engine Race with Barrels / Musical Chairs with Tractors and Steam Engines / Dog Show for all Classes / Line Dancing.
==See also== *[[List of steam fairs]]
==External links== *[http://www.isvrally.com/ Innishannon Steam and Vintage Rally – Official website]
[[Category:Steam festivals]]

{{Infobox Governor |image = JohnFHartranft.jpg |order = 17th |office = Governor of Pennsylvania |term_start = January 21, 1873 |term_end = January 21, 1879 |lieutenant = [[John Latta (Lieutenant Governor)|John Latta]] |predecessor= [[John W. Geary]] |successor = [[Henry M. Hoyt]] |birth_name = John Frederick Hartranft |birth_date = {{birth date|1830|12|16|mf=y}} |birth_place= [[New Hanover Township, Montgomery County, Pennsylvania]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1889|10|17|1830|12|16|mf=y}} |death_place= [[Norristown, Pennsylvania|Norristown]], Pennsylvania |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |spouse = Sallie Douglas Sebring |profession = [[Lawyer]] |religion = |resting_place= [[Montgomery Cemetery (West Norriton Township, Pennsylvania)]] |allegiance= United States
[[Union (American Civil War)|Union]] |branch= [[United States Army]]
[[Union Army]] |serviceyears= 1861–1865 |rank= [[File:Union Army major general rank insignia.svg|35px]] [[Brevet (military)|Brevet]] [[Major general (United States)|Major General]] |commands= |unit= |battles= [[American Civil War]]: *[[First Battle of Bull Run]] *[[Battle of Fort Stedman]] |awards= [[Medal of Honor]] }} '''John Frederick Hartranft''' (December 16, 1830 – October 17, 1889) was the [[United States]] military officer who read the death warrant to the individuals who were executed on July 7, 1865 for conspiring to assassinate American President [[Abraham Lincoln]]. Previously having achieved the rank of [[Major general (United States)|major general]] of the Union Army during the [[American Civil War]], he had also been awarded the U.S. [[Medal of Honor]] for his actions in the [[First Battle of Bull Run]]. Post-war, he served as the [[List of Governors of Pennsylvania|17th Governor]] of [[Pennsylvania]] from 1873 to 1879. ==Early life and career== Hartranft was born in Fagleysville, a village in [[New Hanover Township, Montgomery County, Pennsylvania]], near [[Pottstown, Pennsylvania|Pottstown]], the son of ethnic German Americans Mary Lydia (Bucher) and Samuel Engle Hartranft.Eicher, John H., and Eicher, David J. ''Civil War High Commands.'' Stanford University Press, 2001, p. 284. Hartranft had some local schooling in Norristown, where his family moved when he was a boy. He attended Marshall College in [[Mercersburg, Pennsylvania|Mercersburg]]—a forerunner of [[Franklin & Marshall College]] in [[Lancaster, Pennsylvania|Lancaster]]. He moved to New York, where he completed his degree in [[civil engineering]] in 1853 from [[Union College]] in [[Schenectady, New York|Schenectady]]. He briefly worked for two railroads in eastern Pennsylvania before returning home to [[Norristown, Pennsylvania|Norristown]] to assist his father in the real estate and stage line businesses. In 1854, the young man was appointed [[sheriff|deputy sheriff]] of [[Montgomery County, Pennsylvania]]. That same year, he married Sallie Douglas Sebring. They had six children, but three died in infancy. Hartranft was active in the Norristown fire company and the local [[Freemasonry|Freemason lodge]].Huskey, Stan. [https://books.google.com/books?id=NWoVBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA63 Remembering ''Norristown: Stories from the Banks of the Schuylkill River.''] Charleston, SC: History Press, 2009, p. 63. After "reading the law" as an apprentice with an established firm, Hartranft was admitted to the [[bar association|bar]] in 1860. He entered the Pennsylvania [[Militia]], being promoted to the rank of [[Colonel (United States)|colonel]]. ==Civil War== In April 1861, Hartranft raised a Montgomery County [[regiment]] of 90-day volunteers in Norristown, serving as [[Colonel (United States)|colonel]] of the 4th Pennsylvania Volunteer Infantry. When their term of enlistment was up, the regiment returned to Pennsylvania, although it was the eve of the [[First Battle of Bull Run]], and firing had already begun. Hartranft was humiliated by his men's decision to go home. He stayed to fight with the [[United States Army|Army]] on July 21, 1861. This act earned him the [[Medal of Honor]] on August 21, 1886, for volunteering his services to fellow Pennsylvanian Col. [[William B. Franklin]]. His citation reads: "Voluntarily served as an aide and participated in the battle after expiration of his term of service, distinguishing himself in rallying several regiments which had been thrown into confusion." Hartranft raised a three-year regiment, the [[51st Pennsylvania Infantry]], and became its colonel. They first served on the [[North Carolina]] coast in the [[Ambrose E. Burnside|Burnside Expedition]]. Hartranft led them in battle at [[Battle of Roanoke Island|Roanoke Island]] and [[Battle of New Berne|New Bern]]. In July 1862, Hartranft's men proceeded to [[Newport News, Virginia]], to become part of Burnside's [[IX Corps (Union Army)|IX Corps]], with whom they fought in the [[Second Battle of Bull Run]] and at [[Battle of South Mountain|South Mountain]]. They also fought at the [[Battle of Antietam]], where Hartranft led the famous charge across [[Burnside's Bridge]], suffering 120 casualties.[http://www.nationalcivilwarmuseum.org/Portals/0/PDF%27s/Hartranft2.pdf John F. Hartranft: Pennsylvania General and Governor] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160319204404/http://www.nationalcivilwarmuseum.org/Portals/0/PDF%27s/Hartranft2.pdf |date=2016-03-19 }}, ''The [[National Civil War Museum]]'' They also participated in the [[Battle of Fredericksburg]]. The 51st Pennsylvania was transferred to the [[Western Theater of the American Civil War|Western Theater]], where Hartranft saw action at the battles of [[Siege of Vicksburg|Vicksburg]], [[Battle of Campbell's Station|Campbell's Station]], and [[Siege of Knoxville|Knoxville]]; in the latter two actions, he served as commander of the 2nd Division of the IX Corps while still a colonel.Sauers, Richard A. John Frederick Hartranft. ''Encyclopedia of the American Civil War: A Political, Social, and Military History.'' Heidler, David S., and Heidler, Jeanne T., eds. W. W. Norton & Company, 2000, pp. 941-942. He commanded the 1st Brigade, 3rd Division, of the IX Corps in the 1864 [[Overland Campaign]], participating in the fighting at [[Battle of the Wilderness|the Wilderness]] and [[Battle of Spotsylvania|Spotsylvania]]. He was promoted to [[Brigadier general (United States)|brigadier general]] as of May 12, 1864. He continued in operations against [[Richmond, Virginia|Richmond]] and [[Siege of Petersburg|Petersburg]]. His brigade distinguished itself in the [[Battle of Peebles' Farm]]. When the IX Corps was reorganized, Hartranft was given command of a new 3rd Division, consisting of newly raised Pennsylvania regiments. Hartranft was [[Brevet (military)|brevet]]ted [[Major general (United States)|major general]] by [[Lieutenant general (United States)|Lt. Gen.]] [[Ulysses S. Grant]] for defeating [[Confederate States Army|Confederate]] General [[Robert E. Lee]]'s last offensive at the [[Battle of Fort Stedman]]. He brought his untested division from its reserve position and counterattacked to recover the captured fort. ==Imprisonment, trial and execution of the Lincoln assassination conspirators== In the aftermath of the assassination of United States President [[Abraham Lincoln]], Hartranft was appointed both commanding officer of the [[Old Capitol Prison]] in Washington, D.C. and as a special [[provost marshal]] during the trial of those accused in the [[Lincoln assassination]]: [[George Atzerodt]], [[David Herold]], [[Lewis Paine]] (also known as Lewis Powell), and [[Mary Surratt]], who would become the first woman to be executed by the U.S. government. The trial lasted from May 9, 1865 until the conviction of the Atzerodt, Herold, Paine, and Surratt in late June. At 1:15 p.m. on July 7, 1865, Hartranft led the four to the gallows in what is now called [[Fort Lesley McNair]]. When asked if the convicted had any final statements, the spiritual advisors of Atzerodt and Payne stated that both men wished to thank Hartranft and the officers and soldiers serving under him for the kindness they displayed during their incarceration. Following prayers for each of the prisoners, "Gen. Hartranft read the order of the War Department, embracing the President's Executive Order, for the execution," according to ''The New York Times''. The prisoners were then simultaneously executed by hanging at 1:25 p.m."[https://www.nytimes.com/1865/07/08/archives/end-of-the-assassins-execution-of-mrs-surratt-payne-herrold-and.html End of the Assassins; Execution of Mrs. Surratt, Payne, Herrold and Atzeroth [sic]....]" New York, New York: ''The New York Times'', July 8, 1865."[https://www.loc.gov/item/2018667116/ Washington, D.C. Gen. John F. Hartranft reading the death warrant to the conspirators on the scaffold]" (photograph of Hartranft with Atzerodt, Herold, Paine, and Surratt with accompanying background information from the USLOC). Washington, D.C.: Library of Congress, retrieved online September 17, 2018. ==Post-war life and political career== Following the war Hartranft switched party allegiances and became a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]]. He was appointed to serve in former general [[John W. Geary]]'s Pennsylvania administration as Auditor General from 1867 to 1873. Hartranft was elected as governor in 1872. He was a strong advocate of education, municipal reform, regulation of banking, improved industry and commerce, and the reorganization of the [[United States National Guard|National Guard]]. He supported [[suffrage]] for African Americans, fought the corrupt [[Simon Cameron]] political machine, and championed the rights of the workingman. [[File:JFHartranft.jpg|thumb|230px|John F. Hartranft after the American Civil War]] During his administration, the revision of the Commonwealth's constitution was completed and ratified as the Constitution of 1873. It prohibited special and local legislation; and increased the terms for state legislators: House terms were increased to two years instead of one, and Senate terms to four years from three. He was the 5th commander-in-chief of the Union veterans' organization, the [[Grand Army of the Republic]], serving from 1875 to 1877. He was also a member of the [[Military Order of the Loyal Legion of the United States]]. The [[United States]] celebrated its centennial as a nation in 1876. Hartranft saw that Pennsylvania led the way in the celebration that was centered in [[Philadelphia]]'s Fairmount Park. At the [[Republican National Convention]] in June 1876, he was a contender for the presidential nomination, but [[Rutherford B. Hayes]] of [[Ohio]] was eventually selected. He had served with Hartranft during the Civil War in the same army corps. During his second term, [[depression (economics)|economic depression]], low wages in industry and [[unemployment]], following the industrial boom of the early 1870s, resulted in national labor unrest and strikes culminating in the [[Great Railroad Strike of 1877]]. Serious [[civil disturbance]]s included riots associated with the railroad and general strikes of 1877 in several industrial cities: including Philadelphia, Pittsburgh, Reading and Scranton.{{efn|See also [[Pittsburgh railway riots]], [[Scranton General Strike]], [[Reading Railroad massacre]], and [[1877 Shamokin uprising]]}} There were other incidents with the [[Molly Maguires]] in the [[anthracite coal]] regions. Hartranft called out the state militia and then [[Regular Army (United States)|Regular Army]] troops to maintain order. In [[Philadelphia]], [[Reading, Pennsylvania|Reading]], and [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania|Pittsburgh]], fires were set and extensive railroad facilities and equipment burned, especially in Pittsburgh. Eleven people died along the [[Schuylkill River]] before Federal troops restored the peace. Hartranft later proposed recognition of [[labor union]]s and arbitration of claims. Concerned with the governor's precedent in calling out the militia to battle civilians in Pittsburgh, the [[District Attorney]] of [[Allegheny County, Pennsylvania|Allegheny County]] tried to force Hartranft to appear before a [[grand jury]] to explain his rationale. The courts backed Hartranft when he refused to appear. Their ruling became known as the "Hartranft Decision." Hartranft returned to his home in Montgomery County in 1879, where he accepted the position of US [[Postmaster]]. He was subsequently appointed as Port Collector for Philadelphia (1881-1885).Melvyn Dubofsky. [http://www.anb.org/articles/04/04-00476.html Hartranft, John Frederick]. ''American National Biography Online'', February 2000. Retrieved December 16, 2015. He was also reappointed to command the [[Pennsylvania National Guard]], which he had helped develop. On August 26, 1886 Hartranft was awarded the Medal of Honor for valor during the [[First Battle of Bull Run]] in 1861. John Hartranft died in Norristown and was buried in [[Montgomery Cemetery (West Norriton Township, Pennsylvania)|Montgomery Cemetery]] in [[West Norriton Township, Montgomery County, Pennsylvania]], near [[Norristown, Pennsylvania|Norristown]]. The Pennsylvania National Guard later provided an [[obelisk]] for his grave. He was succeeded as commander of the [[28th Infantry Division (United States)|Pennsylvania National Guard Division]] by [[George R. Snowden]].Samuel T. Wiley, [https://books.google.com/books?id=khQVAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA233 ''Biographical and Historical Cyclopedia of Delaware County, Pennsylvania''], 1894, p. 233. ==In memoriam== {{Infobox designation list | embed = | designation1 = Pennsylvania | designation1_offname = John F. Hartranft | designation1_type = Roadside | designation1_criteria = Civil War, Government & Politics, Government & Politics 19th Century, Governors, Military | designation1_date = May 06, 1947 | delisted1_date = | designation1_partof = | designation1_number = | designation1_free1name = Location | designation1_free1value = Sanatoga Rd. & Cross Rd., SW of Fagleysville | designation1_free2name = Marker Text | designation1_free2value = The birthplace of John F. Hartranft, Civil War hero and Pennsylvania Governor, 1873-79, is to the right on the side road. He reorganized the State Militia as part of the National Guard. | designation1_free3name = | designation1_free3value = }} [[File:John F. Hartranft statue.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Hartranft's statue on the [[Pennsylvania State Capitol]] grounds]] An equestrian statue was installed next to the Pennsylvania Capitol Building in [[Harrisburg, Pennsylvania|Harrisburg]] honors Hartranft.[http://www.civilwaralbum.com/misc9/hartranft1.htm John F. Hartranft Statue, State Capitol, Harrisburg, PA] Camp No. 15 of the [[Sons of Union Veterans of the Civil War]] is named in his honor. Marble monuments at Petersburg and Vicksburg honor his Civil War service. An elementary school in Norristown is named for the governor as well as another elementary school in Philadelphia. The [[Hartranft]] section of North Philadelphia, and a street in the [[Packer Park, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|Packer Park]] section of South Philadelphia near the sports complex, both in [[Philadelphia]], were also named in his honor. A residence hall at the University Park campus of [[Pennsylvania State University]] is named after him. Three avenues in [[Montgomery County, Pennsylvania]] are named in his honor: the first is in [[Norristown, Pennsylvania]] and is the avenue leading to the cemetery in which he is buried. The other avenues are located in nearby [[East Norriton Township, Montgomery County, Pennsylvania|East Norriton Township]] and in [[Fort Washington, Pennsylvania|Fort Washington]], [[Upper Dublin Township, Montgomery County, Pennsylvania|Upper Dublin Township]]. A street in the [[Brookline (Pittsburgh)|Brookline]] section of [[Pittsburgh|Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]] is also named after him. ==Medal of Honor citation== Rank and organization: Colonel, 4th Pennsylvania Militia. Place and date: At Bull Run, Va., July 21, 1861. Entered service at: Norristown, Pa. Born: December 16, 1830, New Hanover Township, Montgomery County, Pa. Date of issue: August 26, 1886. '''Citation:'''
Voluntarily served as an aide and participated in the battle after expiration of his term of service, distinguishing himself in rallying several regiments which had been thrown into confusion.
==See also== {{Portal|Biography|United States Army|American Civil War}} *[[List of Medal of Honor recipients]] *[[List of American Civil War Medal of Honor recipients: G–L#H|List of American Civil War Medal of Honor recipients: G–L]] *[[List of American Civil War generals (Union)]] {{clear}} ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== *Eicher, John H., and [[David J. Eicher|Eicher, David J.]], ''Civil War High Commands'', Stanford University Press, 2001, {{ISBN|0-8047-3641-3}}. *Sauers, Richard A., "John Frederick Hartranft", ''Encyclopedia of the American Civil War: A Political, Social, and Military History'', Heidler, David S., and Heidler, Jeanne T., eds., W. W. Norton & Company, 2000, {{ISBN|0-393-04758-X}}. * Sommers, Richard J., Richmond Redeemed : the Siege at Petersburg, Garden City, N.Y. : Doubleday, 1981. * Steers Jr., Edward, and Holzer, Harold, eds., ''The Lincoln Assassination Conspirators: Their Confinement and Execution, as Recorded in the Letterbook of John Frederick Hartranft'', Louisiana State University Press, 2009, {{ISBN|978-0-8071-3396-5}} *Warner, Ezra J., ''Generals in Blue: Lives of the Union Commanders'', Louisiana State University Press, 1964, {{ISBN|0-8071-0822-7}}. ==External links== *{{Cite web |accessdate=September 29, 2010 |url=http://www.lsu.edu/lsupress/bookPages/9780807133965.html |title=Hartranft's account of his time as warden of the jailed Lincoln Assassination conspirators |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100528093711/http://www.lsu.edu/lsupress/bookPages/9780807133965.html |archivedate=May 28, 2010 |df= }} *{{Cite Americana|wstitle=Hartranft, John Frederick |short=x}} *{{Find a Grave|5894512|work=Claim to Fame: Medal of Honor recipients|accessdate=September 2, 2010}} * {{Internet Archive author |sname=John F. Hartranft}} {{S-start}} {{S-off}} {{Succession box |before=[[John White Geary]] |title=[[Governor of Pennsylvania]] |years=1873–1879 |after=[[Henry Martin Hoyt]]}} {{S-end}} {{S-start}} {{S-off}} {{Succession box |title=[[List of Grand Army of the Republic Commanders-in-Chief|Commander-in-Chief]] of the [[Grand Army of the Republic]] |before=[[Charles Devens]]|after=[[John C. Robinson]] |years=1875–1877}} {{S-end}} {{Governors and Presidents of Pennsylvania}} {{United States presidential election, 1876}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hartranft, John F.}} [[Category:1830 births]] [[Category:1889 deaths]] [[Category:People from Montgomery County, Pennsylvania]] [[Category:American people of German descent]] [[Category:Pennsylvania Republicans]] [[Category:Governors of Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Republican Party state governors of the United States]] [[Category:Union Army generals]] [[Category:People of Pennsylvania in the American Civil War]] [[Category:American postmasters]] [[Category:Pennsylvania lawyers]] [[Category:Pennsylvania Auditors General]] [[Category:Grand Army of the Republic Commanders-in-Chief]] [[Category:Marshall University alumni]] [[Category:Union College (New York) alumni]] [[Category:United States Army Medal of Honor recipients]] [[Category:American Civil War recipients of the Medal of Honor]] [[Category:Burials in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:19th-century American politicians]] [[Category:People associated with the assassination of Abraham Lincoln]]

page.title: List of events at Soldier Field

revision.text:
{{short description|Wikimedia list article}} {{Citation style |date=March 2016 |details=Each paragraph has a lengthy string of references; which references support which statements in the paragraph cannot be determined by the citations as they are currently set out.}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2014}} [[File:Soldier Field east side and marina.JPG|thumb|right|250x250px|Soldier Field in 2006]] [[File:Eagles at Bears 20080928.jpg|thumb|right|250x250px|The [[Chicago Bears]] have played at Soldier Field for over 40 years. Here they are playing the [[Philadelphia Eagles]] at Soldier Field September 28, 2008.]]
[[Soldier Field]] is a stadium that opened in 1924. It has primarily served as the home field of the [[Chicago Bears]] professional football club for over four decades, but it also hosted numerous other events in its more than 90 years of existence (and was not made the home to the Chicago Bears until 1971, as prior to [[1971 NFL season|that season]] the Bears played at [[Wrigley Field]]). The Bears' intent was originally to move from Wrigley Field to [[Northwestern University|Northwestern]]'s [[Dyche Stadium]], but that move was blocked by [[Evanston, Illinois|Evanston]] as well as the [[Big Ten Conference]], so they later took the City of Chicago up on their offer to move into Soldier Field where they have since played. Soldier Field has hosted a great variety and quantity of events since it opened.<ref name="stadiumanditscity">{{cite book |last1=Ford |first1=Liam T.A. Ford |year=2009|origyear=2009|title=Soldier Field: A Stadium and Its City |edition=1st |location=Chicago |publisher=University of Chicago Press}}</ref><ref name=Images>{{cite book |last=Peterson |first=Michael Paul |date= 2007|title=Chicago's Soldier Field |location=Charleston, South Carolina; Chicago; Portsmouth; NH; San Francisco|publisher=Arcadia Publishing |isbn=978-0-7385-5150-0}}</ref><ref name=pridmore>{{cite book |last=Pridmore |first=Jay |date= 2005|title=Soldier Field|location=Petaluma, California and Warwick, England|publisher=Promagranate Communications, Inc.}}</ref><ref name=StoriedStrangeHistory/>
== 1920s == [[File:Holt tractor Soldier Field Chicago 1924.JPG|thumb|right|250x250px|Soldier Field nearing completion in 1924]]
===1924=== *September 5 was the first day of the first dedicatory event at Soldier Field. It was an athletic meet with policemen as participants, and was a fundraiser for the Chicago Police Benevolent Association, which provided support for police widows and officers disabled in the line of action. The meet's official opening ceremony on the second day featured 1,200 police officers parading through the stadium, fireworks, and music by two police bands, among other entertainment. The contests in the event included a [[chariot race]] and a game of "motorcycle polo". The opening ceremony was attended by 45,000 spectators. Events raising funds for Chicago's Policemen and Firemen Benevolent funds were a mainstay at Soldier Field until 1971.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news| title =Police Games to Open New Chicago Stadium| newspaper = Chicago Daily Tribune|date =September 5, 1924}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title =Chicago Police Field Day|newspaper =Sullivan's Englewood Times|location =Chicago|date =August 8, 1924}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title =1,200 March to Dedicate Stadium|newspaper =Chicago American|date =September 6, 1924}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last =Eckersall|first =Walter|title =Traffic Cop Wins First Police Event|newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =September 6, 1924}}</ref> *On September 10, there was yet another dedicatory event at Soldier Field. This one was the "Pageant of Music and Light", and was followed less than two weeks later by another ceremony.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news|title =South Side Business Men to Attend Song Fest in New Stadium|newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune|location =Chicago|publisher =Chicago Trbiune|date =September 10, 1924 }}</ref><ref>Citation|South Park Commissioners, memorandum (unlabeled) on the "first free use" of the stadium, n.d. (1924), Soldier Field Collection, Special Collections, Chicago Park District Headquarters; speeches folder</ref><ref>{{cite news| title =Elephants in Parade of Greatest 13 Ring Circus| newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune |date =September 21, 1924}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title =Ogden Park Activities|newspaper =Englewood Times|location =Chicago|date =September 19, 1924}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title =30,000 Voices to Dedicate Stadium in Song Pageant|newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune|date = September 10, 1924}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title =50,000 Expected at Huge Civic Pageant|newspaper =Chicago Defender (national edition)| date = September 10, 1924}}</ref> *On September 27, Soldier Field hosted a ''[[Chicago Daily News]]''-sponsored women's track meet featuring more than 500 Chicago-area participants. In addition to traditional [[track and field]] events, the competitions also included such events as a [[Basketball (ball)|basketball]] distance throw.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *On October 4, the stadium hosted its first football game, a match between [[Louisville Male High School]] and Chicago's [[Austin Community Academy High School]]. Louisville's team won 26–0.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>''[[Chicago Tribune]]'', October 2, 1924</ref><ref>{{cite news|title =Oak Park Trims Austin 13–0 to Dedicate Stadium|newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune|date =September 28, 1924}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title =Austin Again Loses to Louisville High|newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune|date =October 5, 1924}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title =Austin Preps Meet Kentucky Team Saturday|newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune|date =October 2, 1924}}</ref> *On October 9, a "Chicago Day" event, marking the anniversary of the [[Great Chicago Fire]], was attended by a crowd of 60,000. The event contained the formal dedication and official opening of Grant Park Municipal Stadium. The event included military troops partaking in a mock battle, equine performances by riders from the [[14th Cavalry Regiment|14th Cavalry]]'s Troop A, and a semi re-enactment of the [[Great Chicago Fire]] with firemen (including ten who actually had fought the Great Fire) fighting the fire using Fire King No. 1 (Chicago's first pump engine). In the re-enactment, a cow knocked over a lantern (according to lore), a replica of the [[Catherine O'Leary|O'Leary]] barn was burned down, and firemen used modern equipment to fight a fire in a mock-up of a three-story building. Following this spectacle there were police drills, performances by two police [[quartet]]s, and a [[polo]] match. The teams in the polo match were led by ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' owner [[Robert R. McCormick]] and Hotel Sherman manager Frank Bering. McCormick's team won 5–4.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=Images/><ref name=StoriedStrangeHistory/><ref>{{cite news|title =60,000 to See Chicago Fire Pageant|newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune|date =October 4, 1924}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title =Look Out Firemen: Mrs. O'Leary's Kin Meets Kin of Famous Cow|newspaper =[[Chicago Defender]] (national edition)|date = October 8, 1924}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title =Chicago's Day Recalls 53 Yrs. of City Growth|newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune|date =October 9, 1924}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title =60,000 Voice City's Spirit at Stadium Fete,|newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune|date =October 10, 1924}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title =Re-enact Fire for Chicago Day Crowd: 10 Veterans of '71 Run with Old Fire King,|newspaper =Chicago Daily News|date =October 9, 1924}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title =Chicago Stadium Has Latest Devices,|newspaper =Decatur Review|location=Decatur, Illinois|date =September 25, 1924}}</ref><ref name="ifbearsgo">{{cite news|last =Hirsley|first =Michael|title =If Bears Go, So May Soldier Field|newspaper =[[Chicago Tribune]]|date =January 15, 1996| url =http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1996-01-15/news/9601150171_1_soldier-field-historic-landmark-historic-designation | accessdate = July 5, 2014 }}</ref><ref name="kalracinghistory">{{cite web |url= http://www.kalracing.com/autoracing/Soldier_Field_History.htm |title=Soldier Field History|last= Kalwasinski|first=Stan|website=www.kalracing.com|access-date=February 7, 2015}}</ref><ref name=StoriedStrangeHistory>{{cite web |url=http://chicago.curbed.com/2016/2/3/10942386/a-brief-history-of-soldier-field |title=The Storied (and Sometimes Strange) History of Soldier Field |date=February 3, 2016 |website=chicago.curbed.com |publisher=[[Curbed]] |access-date=February 26, 2016 }}</ref> *On November 11, [[St. Viator College|Viator College]] of [[Bourbonnais, Illinois]] and [[Loras College|Columbia College]] of [[Dubuque, Iowa]] played in the 1924 Midwest Catholic League championship. The game benefited an [[American Legion]] fund for disabled veterans. The game ended 0–0. Due to poor weather conditions the attendance was only 2,000. This was the first [[college football]] game held at Soldier Field.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *On November 22, 45,000 spectators saw [[Notre Dame Fighting Irish football|Notre Dame]] play [[Northwestern Wildcats football|Northwestern]]. Notre Dame won 13 to 6. This was the first football game between two major colleges to be held at Soldier Field. Northwestern's [[Ralph Baker (halfback)|Ralph "Moon" Baker]] (a member of the [[College Football Hall of Fame]]) would later say that this game, during which he kicked two [[field goal]]s (one 34 and the other 36 yards) against the [[1924 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|1924 Notre Dame team]] that featured the "[[Four Horsemen (American football)|Four Horsemen]]", was his greatest thrill. That season Baker set a Northwestern Wildcats team record of seven field goals in a single season, a team record that was unbroken until the 1960s.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=StoriedStrangeHistory/><ref name="net">{{cite web|url=http://www.soldierfield.net/content/event-history |title=Event History |website=www.soldierfield.net |accessdate=July 2, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140713121338/http://www.soldierfield.net/content/event-history |archivedate=July 13, 2014 |df= }}</ref><ref name="hailtopurple">{{cite web|url=http://hailtopurple.com/cde/homesites.html|title=Historic Sites of All NU Home Games|website=hailtopurple.com|accessdate=July 25, 2014}}</ref><ref name="Somogyi">{{cite web |url=http://www.und.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/100512aaa.html |title=Soldier (Field) Of Fortune |last=Somogyi|first=Lou|date=October 5, 2015 |website=www.und.com |accessdate=February 1, 2015}}</ref><ref name=choose>{{cite web|url=http://www.choosechicago.com/blog/post/2013/02/10-Things-You-Didn-t-Know-About-the-History-of-Soldier-Field/560/|title=10 Things You Didn't Know About the History of Soldier Field|last=Bramford|first=Tab|date=February 13, 2013|website=www.choosechicago.com|publisher=Choose Chicago|accessdate=April 11, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=September 18, 1977 |title=Noon Baker: Former Northwestern All-American was 'happy go-lucky determined and strong' |newspaper=Rockford Register-Star |location=Rockford, Illinois }}</ref> *In December, Soldier Field hosted a state amateur [[Horseshoes|horseshoe pitching]] tournament sponsored by the Ogden Park Horseshoe Pitching Club and Chicago Playground Council.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name="Somogyi"/><ref>{{cite news|title =Ogden Entries Win Honors in Horseshoe Meet: Dan Cooper Brings State Title Back to Local Park|newspaper =Southtown Economist|location =Chicago|date =December 17, 1924}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title =Dan Cooper of Ogsden Park Wins Horseshoe Title|newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune|date =December 14, 1924}}</ref><ref name="fortune"/> *October 10 (the 53rd anniversary of the [[Great Chicago Fire]]) another dedication of the stadium was held.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *In late 1924 the South Park commissioners erected an [[ice rink]] in Soldier Field.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/>
===1925=== *On May 9, Soldier Field hosted the South Parks [[Marble (toy)|Marble]] Championship. The tournament included both adult and juvenile competitions.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *From May 22–25, the 65th Reserves and its superior outfit, the Army's Sixth Corps, sponsored the first of numerous military pageants held at Soldier Field. There were two shows a day, airplane fights in the afternoon, searchlights and antiaircraft-mimicking fireworks in the evening. The highlight of the day shows was a radio-dispatched arrangement of warplanes flying over the stadium. Audience members could hear the air-to-ground radio communication via the stadium's state-of-the-art loudspeaker system, and watch the planes respond to the ground command and perform stunts. 25,000 attended the first afternoon show, among them [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Charles G. Dawes]]. The temperature was 92 degrees. The show reenacted the [[Battle of the Argonne]] utilizing, among other things, a smoke screen and four tanks. In the first night show's reenactment an infantryman was injured when he was trampled by horses, and prior to that show a policeman partaking in a Roman-style horse race was thrown from his horse and also injured. For the final day wind kept the planes grounded, and the crowd was small due to chilly temperature that peaked near 40 degrees. Nonetheless, entire event was deemed a success.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news| title =Big War Show in Chicago Opens Next Friday| newspaper =Cook County Herald| location =[[Cook County, Illinois]]| date =May 15, 1925}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| title =You Won't See the Sham in This Sham Battle| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =May 3, 1925}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| title =Cavalry Charge to Give Thrill at Army Show| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =May 11, 1925}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| title =Mayor Orders Chicago Day of Military Show| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =April 5, 1925}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| title =Cold to Relax Its Hold on Chicago Today| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =May 25, 1925}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| title =Dawes among 25,000 Who See Big Army Show| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =May 23, 1925}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| title =Planes High Up Obey Orders of Radio on Earth| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune|date =May 24, 1925}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| title =Military Show Closes; Backers Call It Success| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =May 25, 1925}}</ref> *April 19 [[Loyola University (Chicago)|Loyola University]] held an intercollegiate track meet at Soldier Field. Amongst the participants in the competition was nine-time Olympic gold medalist (and three-time silver medalist) [[Paavo Nurmi]] of Finland who was in the last several weeks of a five-month US tour (during which he participated in 55 competitions). Nurmi had won five gold medals at the [[1924 Summer Olympics]]. Also competing was fellow Finnish Olympian [[Ville Ritola]], who was also a United States resident and had traveled with Nurmi during his tour. Nurmi defeated Ritola in the meet.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news|title =Paavo Rivals Race Today at Loyola Relays|newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune|date =April 19, 1925}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title =Nurmi Beats Ritola in 3,000-Meter Run|newspaper =[[New York Times]]|date =April 20, 1925}}</ref><ref name="Ritola">{{cite news|title =Willie Ritola, 86, Track Star; Won 5 Olympic Gold Medals|newspaper =[[New York Times]]|date =April 28, 1982}}</ref><ref name="finns">{{cite news|title =Finns Refuse to Discuss Charges on Visit Here|newspaper =Chicago Daily Tibune|date =May 8, 1925}}</ref> *In May Soldier Field held and event dubbed the "first annual Chicago Olympics", an athletics event sponsored by the Finnish-American Athletic Association. Notable male competitors include Finnish five-time Olympic gold medalist (and three-time silver medalist) [[Ville Ritola]], Finnish two-time Olympic gold medalist [[Jonni Myyrä]], American two-time Olympic gold medalist Harold Osborne. Notable female competitors included US Women's Athletics legends [[Helen Filkey]], [[Norma Zilk]], and [[Nellie Todd]] (who, along with Zilk, was a protégé of [[Chicago Maroons|University of Chicago]] track coach Tom Eck). Norma Filkey set a record in hurdles at the event, Jonni Myyrä set a javelin record at the event, Harold Osborne won as the best overall athlete of the competition, and Ville Ritola won the 2-mile race. Due largely to 90-degree heat only 2,500 spectators attended this event.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=Ritola/><ref name=finns/><ref>{{cite book|last=Guffman |first=Allen|date=2002 |title=The Olympics: A History of the Modern Games|location=Champaign, Illinois|publisher=University of Illinois Press|pages=39–42, 47–51}}</ref><ref>South Park Commissioners, "Record of Uses, Soldier Field Stadium 1924–1931" ca. 1931; Soldier Field collection, Chicago Park District Headquarters</ref><ref>{{cite news|title =Women Champions to Enter Finnish Cames|newspaper =Chicago Daily News|location =Chicago|date =May 18, 1925}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last =Krum|first =Fayette|title =Brilliant Field of Girls in Track Meet|newspaper =Chicago Daily News|date =September 26, 1924}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title =Myyra Smashes Javelin Record at Finn Games|newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune|date =June 1, 1925}}</ref> *June 13–14 Soldier Field hosted the [[1925 NCAA Men's Track and Field Championships|1925]] [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] [[NCAA Men's Division I Outdoor Track and Field Championships|Men's Track and Field Championships]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Stanford Wins National Collegiate Title: DeHart Hubbard Sets New World's Record in Broad Jump Event; Michigan Second to Cardinals; California Athletes Finish Ihird; Hartranft Breaks Collegiate Shot Put Mark|newspaper=Oakland Tribune|date=1925-06-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Hubbard, Michigan's Negro Athlete, Breaks Broad Jump Record: Experts Say Mark to Stand for All Time; Crowd Thrilled as He Leaps for Almost 26 Feet in College Meet; Shotput Mark Falls; Lanky Texas University Runner Sets New College Mark for the Mile|newspaper=Davenport Democrat and Leader|date=1925-06-14}}</ref> Notable competitors included [[DeHart Hubbard]], [[Morgan Taylor]], [[Glenn Hartranft]], [[Tom Poor]], [[Phil Northrup]], [[Frank Potts]], [[Biff Hoffman|Clifford Ellsworth "Biff" Hoffman]], and [[Hugo Leistner]]. *July 4 and 5 Soldier Field held its first [[American Independence Day|Independence Day]] celebration.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *August 15–24, 1925 the [[Chicago Association of Commerce]] sponsored the 1925 Chicago Roundup, a [[Tex Austin]]-organized nine-day professional [[rodeo]] competition at Soldier Field. [[Vice President of the United States]] [[Charles G. Dawes]] at the opening ceremonies. The ceremonies were initiated with a parade of participants and officials. Among the officials was [[Anti-Cruelty Society]] director [[Chauncey McCormick]], and among the competitors was [[Pete Knight (rodeo)|Pete Knight]]. 30,000 spectators watched the opening ceremonies, and 100,000 spectators attended the two competitive events held August 15. Daily attendance averaged 70,000 for the competition, one day the combined attendance for two events was 170,000.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *September 20 Chicago's German-American community held its first annual German Day event at Soldier Field, featuring a [[association football|soccer]] match, [[Athletics (sport)|athletics]], performances and ceremonies. The event raised funds for numerous charities. German Day events were held annually at Soldier Field until 1937, regularly drawing crowds in excess of 40,000.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *November 7 [[Northwestern Wildcats football|Northwestern]] played [[Michigan Wolverines football|Michigan]] at Soldier Field. 70,000 tickets had been sold, but just over 40,000 spectators attended due to severely inclement weather. Northwestern won 3–2.<ref name=hailtopurple/> *November 11, the [[American Legion]] and South Park commissioners organized a commemoration of [[Armistice Day]] marking the stadium's name change from "Grant Park Municipal Stadium" to "Soldier Field". The day began the firing of guns at sunrise. At eleven in the morning, a [[21-gun salute]] was fired in Chicago's [[Grant Park (Chicago)|Grant Park]] and people in the 'Chicago Loop' paused, men removing their hats, and held moment of silent prayer and reflection. In the afternoon, former [[Governor of Illinois]] [[Frank Lowden]] and naval officer [[John Rodgers (naval officer, World War I)|John A. Rodgers]] were the guests of honor in the ceremonies held at Soldier Field. At the time Rodgers was a national hero, following his attempted nonstop flight two months earlier, and was all-over the news.<ref>{{cite book |last= Simonds|first= William A.|year= 1949 |title= Kamaaina, a Century in Hawaii|chapter= Honolulu: American Factors|page= 80}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last= Fraser |first= Chelsea Curtis |date= 1942|title= Famous American Flyers |location= New York |publisher= Crowell |pages=106–122}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last= Fraser|first= Chelsea Curtis|date= 1980|title= Famous American Flyers (reprint)|location= New York|publisher= Arno Press|pages=106–122}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title = Five Men aboard Trans-Ocean Plane Now Thought Lost|newspaper = Middleton Daily Herald|location = Middleton, New York|agency = United Press (wire service)|date =September 2, 1925}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last =Rodgers|first =John A.|title =Plane Chief Tells Story of Hardship|newspaper =Helena Independent| agency=Associated Press (wire service)|date =September 12, 1925}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title =Fear Naval Plane Lost at Sea|newspaper =Middleton Daily Herald|location =Middleton, New York|agency =United Press (wire service)|date =September 2, 1925}}</ref> Lowden had been heavily involved in the effort to rename Soldier Field. Much like Rodgers, Lowden was also a big-name at the time. A former Illinois Congressman and Governor, Lowden had declined the Vice-Presidential nomination at the [[1924 Republican National Convention]],<ref name=Images/> a position which was taken by fellow-Illinoisan [[Charles G. Dawes]] (who ultimately would go on to win the 1924 election as [[Calvin Coolidge]]'s running mate). The event at Soldier Field began with decorated war veterans escorting [[Gold Star Mothers Club|Gold Star Mothers]] to their seats, and a salute fired by field artillery. The [[Flag of the United States]] was then raised, followed with a large banner baring the words 'Soldier Field' that had been carried into the stadium by the Gold Star Mothers. This was followed with a parade led by an Army general. The parade featured sailors from the nearby [[Great Lakes Naval Station]], [[Reserve Officers' Training Corps]] units, and various veterans groups (including the [[Grand Army of the Republic]]). Following the procession of the parade, Rodgers spoke about his attempted non-stop flight. Other speakers included South Park Board-member, and future-[[Mayor of Chicago|mayor]], [[Edward J. Kelley]]. The ceremony was attended by over 20,000.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=pridmore/><ref name=StoriedStrangeHistory/><ref name=ifbearsgo/><ref>{{cite news|title =City Renews Pledge to Hero Dead: 10,000 Take Part in Dedication Rite|newspaper =[[Chicago Daily News]]|date =November 11, 1925}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title =Gen. Harbord Sees Peril in Volstead Law|newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune|date =November 12, 1925}}</ref><ref>Wayne S. Cole, America First: The Battle against Intervention, 1940–41 (Madison: University of Wisconsin Press, 1953), pg. 21</ref><ref>{{cite news|title =Lowden Dedicates Chicago's Stadium|newspaper =Decatur Review|location=Decatur, Illinois| agency=[[Associated Press]] (wire service)|date =November 11, 1925}}</ref><ref>Edward J. Kelly, Soldier Field dedication speech, November 11, 1925; Soldier Field Collection, Special Collections, Chicago Park District Headquarters; dedications folder</ref>
===1926=== *After success of the 1925 Chicago Roundup, Soldier Field hosted another Chicago Roundup in 1926. The 1926 Chicago Roundup was also a great success, even managing to draw 35,000 spectators on a rainy day. *In June Soldier Field hosted the [[1926 NCAA Men's Track and Field Championships|1926]] [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] [[NCAA Men's Division I Outdoor Track and Field Championships|Men's Track and Field Championships]]. This was the second consecutive edition held at Soldier Field. The event was dubbed "the college Olympics of America".<ref>{{cite news|title=Trojans Outscore Rivals in Big Chicago Meet|newspaper=Los Angeles Times (AP wire story)|date=1926-06-13}}</ref> Notable competitors included [[Bud Houser]], [[Bob King (athlete)|Bob King]], [[John Kuck]], [[Bruce Bennett|Herman Brix]] (later known by his stage-name Bruce Bennet), [[William Droegemueller]], [[Fred Alderman]], [[Tom Sharkey]], [[Harry Hawkins]], [[Leighton Dye]], [[Ray Conger]], [[Anton Burg]], [[Phil Northrup]], [[George Hester]], and [[George Guthrie (athlete)|George Guthrie]]. [[File:International Eucharistic Congress, First General Meeting, Solemn Pontifical High Mass; His Eminence John Cardinal Bonzano, Celebrant; Choir, 60,000 parochial school children; Soldiers' Field, June 21, 1926, Chicago, Ill., U.S.jpg|thumb|right|300x300px|1926 [[Eucharistic Congress]]]] *June 21–23 the 28th International [[Eucharistic Congress]] held three days of outdoor day and evening events at Soldier Field.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> Mass was held for a total of 500,000 gathered both in and outside of Soldier Field's gates. *July 4, marking the nation's sesquicentennial (150th anniversary), the [[Loyal Order of Moose]] arranged an Independence Day program for Soldier Field.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *July 27 50,000 people attended a program held by the [[Lutheran]]s from the [[Lutheran Church–Missouri Synod|Missouri Synod]] to commemorate the USA's sesquicentennial.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *November 11 ([[Armistice Day]]) 10,000 spectators watched as Soldier Field hosted its first professional [[American football]] game, a match between the [[Chicago Bears]] and the [[Chicago Cardinals]]. The Bears defeated an injury-ridden Cardinals. Cardinals [[Halfback (American football)|halfback]] [[Red Dunn]] breaking his leg above the ankle. The first Bears touchdown in Soldier Field History occurred second quarter when [[quarterback]] [[Paddy Driscoll]] (who incidentally had previously played for the Cardinals) threw a forty-yard pass to [[Duke Hanny]], the game's sole touchdown. Driscoll also kicked for the extra point, and scoring a [[field goal]] later in the second period. The game benefited the construction of [[Dominican University (Illinois)|Rosary College]], which today is known as Dominican University.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/stadiums/soldier-field.htm |title=Soldier Field History |website=[[Pro-Football-Reference.com]]|access-date=November 10, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/play-index/tgl_finder.cgi?request=1&match=game&year_min=1920&year_max=2014&game_type=&game_num_min=0&game_num_max=99&week_num_min=0&week_num_max=99&game_day_of_week=&game_time=&time_zone=&surface=&roof=&temperature=&temperature_gtlt=lt&game_location=&game_result=&overtime=&league_id=&team_id=chi&opp_id=&team_div_id=&opp_div_id=&team_conf_id=&opp_conf_id=&date_from=&date_to=&team_off_scheme=&opp_off_scheme=&team_def_align=&opp_def_align=&stadium_id=CHI98&c1stat=&c1comp=gt&c1val=&c2stat=&c2comp=gt&c2val=&c3stat=&c3comp=gt&c3val=&c4stat=&c4comp=gt&c4val=&c5comp=&c5gtlt=&c6mult=&c6comp=&order_by=game_date&order_by_asc=&conference_game=&division_game=&tm_is_playoff=&opp_is_playoff=&tm_is_winning=&opp_is_winning=&tm_scored_first=&tm_led=&tm_trailed=&tm_won_toss=&offset=300 |title=Team Game Finder Query Results |website=[[Pro-Football-Reference.com]]|access-date=November 10, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/192611110chi.htm |title=Chicago Cardinals 0 at Chicago Bears 10|date=November 11, 1926 |website=[[Pro-Football-Reference.com]]|access-date=November 10, 2015 }}</ref> *November 26 the stadium was officially renamed "Soldier Field" at a free public event held at the stadium. Among those participating in the ceremony was [[Vice President of the United States]] [[Charles G. Dawes]].<ref name= stadiumanditscity/> [[File:The Army-Navy football game at Soldier's Field.jpg|thumb|right|300px|1926 [[Army-Navy Game]]]] *November 27 over 110,000 spectators attended the 1926 [[Army-Navy Game]]. It would decide the national championship, as Navy entered undefeated and Army had lost only to Notre Dame. The game lived up to its hype, and even though it ended in a 21–21 tie, Navy was awarded the national championship. Amongst the 110,000 in attendance (which at the time was the largest crowd for a football game) were the Vice President of the United States [[Charles G. Dawes]] as well as the [[United States Secretary of the Navy]] [[Curtis D. Wilbur]]. Also in attendance was legendary [[Notre Dame Fighting Irish football]] coach [[Knute Rockne]], who considered the game at Soldier Field important enough to warrant his missing his own team's game against [[Carnegie Mellon University|Carnegie Tech]] that day (a game which Rockne's undefeated Fighting Irish lost in an upset that was ranked the fourth-greatest upset in [[college football]] history by [[ESPN]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Tech's Greatest Victory |url=http://www.carnegiemellontoday.com/article.asp?Aid=380 |publisher=carnegiemellontoday.com |accessdate=February 18, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080317194853/http://www.carnegiemellontoday.com/article.asp?Aid=380 |archivedate=March 17, 2008 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Upset special: With Rockne gone, Irish took a Michigan-like tumble|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/wire?section=ncf&id=3006504&campaign=rsssrch&source=coach|publisher=sports.espn.go.com|accessdate=February 18, 2008}}</ref>) The game was also broadcast nationally on radio, a notable early use of the rising broadcast medium. Walter Eckersdall of the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' dubbed it to be "one of the greatest football games ever played", and proclaimed that it had been seen by "the largest crowd that ever saw a football game in this country." More than a decade later, the readers of ''[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]'' magazine voted this the best football game of all time. Even today many revere this as the greatest Army-Navy game ever.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=Images/><ref name=pridmore/><ref name=pridmore/><ref name=ifbearsgo/><ref name=choose/><ref>{{cite news|title = lSnappy Chicago Weather Freezes Army Mule and Chills Navy Goat|newspaper =Lincoln Star|date =November 27, 1926}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usna.edu/LibExhibits/Archives/Armynavy/An1926.htm|title=1926 Army-Navy Game|date=November 26, 2001|work=Library Archives|publisher=United States Naval Academy|accessdate=May 21, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title =City Dedicates Soldiers Field| newspaper =Chicago American|location = Chicago |date =November 11, 1925}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Schoor |first=Gene |date= 1989|title=Army-Navy Football: A Pictoral History of America's Most Colorful and Competitive Sports Rivalry|pages=74–76 |location=New York City|publisher=Henry Holt & Co.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=O'Donnell Bennett|first=James |title=110,000 to See Game Today|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|date=November 27, 1926}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Chicago Happy As Army-Navy Game Is landed|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|date=January 23, 1926}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Bond Fight on Stadium Perils Cadets' Game|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|date=April 20, 1926}}</ref> *November 28 12,000 spectators saw the [[Kansas City Blues/Cowboys|Kansas City Cowboys]] defeat the [[Chicago Cardinals]] 7-2 at Soldier Field.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/192611280crd.htm#player_stats |title=Kansas City Cowboys 7 at Chicago Cardinals 2 Sunday, November 28, 1926 |website=[[Pro-Football-Reference.com]]|access-date=November 10, 2015 }}</ref> *December 19, 10,000 spectators saw the [[Chicago Bears]] tie the [[Green Bay Packers]] in a game held at Soldier Field.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/192612190chi.htm |title=Green Bay Packers 3 at Chicago Bears 3 Sunday, December 19, 1926 |website=[[Pro-Football-Reference.com]]|access-date=November 10, 2015 }}</ref> *1926 marked the first year that a football game benefiting causes related to the Chicago [[Sisters of Mercy]] (amongst them the order's Catholic high schools and [[Mercy Hospital and Medical Center|Mercy Hospital]]). These games were held annually until the 1951. Most often it featured a matchup of two Catholic League schools (commonly [[St. Rita of Cascia High School|Saint Rita]] and [[Leo Catholic High School|Leo]]). Some years the game included professional or college teams. The game usually attracted between 20,000 and 30,000 spectators. It was started by Sister Mary Ricardo, who decided a football game would be a good annual fundraiser after a meeting with [[Chris O'Brien (American football)|Chris O'Brien]]. O'Brien suggested that a game against the [[Kansas City Blues/Cowboys|Kansas City Cowboys]] could be moved from [[Comiskey Park]] to Soldier Field.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news|title =Rites Monday for Nun Who Set Up Forum|newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune|date =July 11, 1959}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title =Marquette and St. Louis Renew 30 Year Rivalry|newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune|date =October 9, 1936}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title =Grid Teams to Play Sunday for High School Benefit|newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune|page=24|date =November 21, 1926}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=100 Extra Tickets for Game on Sale|newspaper=[[Chicago American]]|date=November 27, 1926}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Gilbert|first=Paul T.|title=City Turns Out to Welcome Army and Navy|newspaper=[[Chicago American]]|date=November 27, 1926}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Here Is Official Army-Navy Game Program for Today|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|date=November 27, 1926}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Fry|first=Kenneth D.|title=Army and navy Locked in Great Annual Battle|newspaper=[[Chicago American]]|date=November 27, 1926}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Maxwell|first=Don |title=News Bits of the Game the Army Played to a 21-21 Draw|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|date=November 28, 1926}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Coolidge Drops Work to Listen in on Grid Tilt|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|agency=Chicago Tribune Press Service|date=November 28, 1926}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Fur Wrapped Society Joins Football Crowd|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|date=November 28, 1926}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Crusinberry|first=James |title=Players Glad Foe Was Held to a Tie Score|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|date=November 28, 1926}}</ref> *30,000 attended a game between [[Prague]]'s [[AC Sparta of Prague|AC Sparta]] and a Chicago all-star team.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *December 19 the [[Chicago Bears]] held a home game against the [[Green Bay Packers]] at Soldier Field, with proceeds benefiting the P.J. Carr Christmas Fund. The Bears and Packers tied the game 3-3. All three of the Packers' points were scored by their [[quarterback]] [[Pid Purdy]], who also played [[baseball]] for [[Major League Baseball]]'s [[Chicago White Sox]]. The game had the potential of determining the champion of the [[1926 NFL season]] if the [[Frankford Yellow Jackets]] (from [[Philadelphia]]) lost their final game of the season, but the Yellow Jackets won their last game and were named the season's champions.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/>
===1927=== *In the Spring of 1927 [[Hakoah Vienna]] played several games at Soldier Field. They won their first two matches, defeating a [[Peel Cup]] All-Stars team and [[Chicago Sparta]], but were defeated 2-1 by an Illinois All-Stars team consisting of players from the [[Illinois State Football Association]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *August 13 [[Charles Lindberg]] made appearances before crowds at both Soldier Field and [[Comiskey Park]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *The 1927 Chicago Roundup was an even greater success than the first two Chicago Roundups, attracting more than 350,000 spectators in its 9-day run. *In 1927 Soldier Field hosted the National Interscholastic Championship. [[Eddie Tolan]] of [[Cass Technical High School]] in [[Detroit]] won the 100 and 220-yard dashes, events he would go on to win gold medals and set records for at the [[1932 Summer Olympics]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Eddie Tolan|publisher= USA Track & Field Hall of Fame|url=http://www.usatf.org/HallOfFame/TF/showBio.asp?HOFIDs=171}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Cass Flash Is Dash Finalist|work=Lima News|agency=Associated Press|date=June 4, 1927}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Tolan Ties World's Mark: Michigan Negro Runs Century Dash in 9 6-10s; Other Records Tumble in Big Ten Meet|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=May 25, 1929}}</ref> *In June Soldier Field hosted the [[1927 NCAA Men's Track and Field Championships|1927]] [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] [[NCAA Men's Division I Outdoor Track and Field Championships|Men's Track and Field Championships]].<ref>{{cite news|title=CONGER'S FAST MILE AND LOW HURDLING OF SPENCE FEATURE WINDY CITY MEET|newspaper=Los Angeles Times (AP wire story)|date=1927-06-12}}</ref> This was the third consecutive edition held at Soldier Field. Among the notable competitors were [[Fred Alderman]], [[Ed Hamm]], [[Doral Pilling]], [[James Corson]], [[Frank Cuhel]], [[Lee Bartlett]], [[Tiny Gooch]], and [[Pete Rasmus]]. *In 1927 [[Chicago Sparta]] played an exhibition match against the [[Uruguay national football team]], winners of gold at the [[1924 Summer Olympics|1924 Olympic Games]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *September 22 [[The Long Count Fight]], the second [[heavyweight]] championship [[boxing]] bout between [[Jack Dempsey]] and [[Gene Tunney]], was held at Soldier Field. The event was attended by 104,943 spectators.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=Images/><ref name=pridmore/><ref name=StoriedStrangeHistory/><ref name=choose/> *October 30 15,000 spectators saw the NFL's [[New York Yankees (NFL)|New York Yankees]] defeat the [[Chicago Cardinals]] 7-6 in a game held at Soldier Field.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/192710300crd.htm |title=New York Yankees 7 at Chicago Cardinals 6 Sunday, October 30, 1927 |website=[[Pro-Football-Reference.com]]|access-date=November 10, 2015 }}</ref> *November 26 the all-time collegiate attendance record of 123,000 plus was established as [[Notre Dame Fighting Irish football|Notre Dame]] beat [[USC Trojans football|USC]] 7–6.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=ifbearsgo/><ref name=fortune>{{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fortune/global500/2010/snapshots/6385.html |title=Fortune Global 500 2010: 64. Pemex |publisher=Fortune Magazine |accessdate=July 26, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagobears.com/tradition/sf_timeline.asp|title=Historical timeline of Soldier Field|year=2009|publisher=Chicago Bears|accessdate=May 21, 2010}}</ref> Amongst those in attendance was [[Mayor of Los Angeles|Los Angeles mayor]] [[George E. Cryer]]. In preparation for this game a thousand seats were added by the South Park Board to the venue, and a proclamation was issued by [[Mayor of Chicago|Chicago mayor]] [[William Hale Thompson|Big Bill Thomson]] encouraging residents to decorate their houses with the [[Flag of the United States]] and the colors of the two opposing teams.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *November 27 5,000 fans saw the [[Cleveland Bulldogs]] defeat the [[Chicago Cardinals]] 32-7.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/192711270crd.htm |title=Cleveland Bulldogs 32 at Chicago Cardinals 7 Sunday, November 27, 1927 |website=[[Pro-Football-Reference.com]]|access-date=November 10, 2015 }}</ref> *December 3 the first [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]] was held. 50,000 spectators attended the game, which saw [[Mount Carmel High School (Chicago)|Mount Carmel]] defeat [[Carl Schurz High School|Schurz]] 6–0.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news|title =Mt. Carmel Seen Victor over Schurz| newspaper =Suburbanite Economist|pages =9–10|date =November 29, 1927}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| title =Mt. Carmel and Schurz Groom Aerial Plays|newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune|date =November 30, 1927}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title =Mt. Carmel and Schurz Battle for the Title Today|newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune|date =December 3, 1927}}</ref><ref name="Gems">{{cite news|last=Gems|first=Gerald R.|date=Fall 1996|title=The Prep Bowl: Football and Religious Acculturation in Chicago, 1927–1963 |newspaper=Journal of Sport History 23, no.3 pages 284–302|pages=284–300}}</ref><ref name=catholicleague>{{cite web |url=http://www.chicagocatholicleague.com/static.asp?path=2854|title=CCL Football A Tradition of Excellence|website=www.chicagocatholicleague.com|publisher=[[Chicago Catholic League]]|access-date=April 1, 2015}}</ref><ref name=catholicleague2>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagocatholicleague.com/Documents/Ctrl_Hyperlink/CCL_Prep_Bowl_Champions_1927_through_2014_uid1212014334402.pdf|title=CCL_Prep_Bowl_Champions_1927_through_Present||website=.chicagocatholicleague.com|publisher=[[Chicago Catholic League]]|accessdate=April 5, 2015}}</ref>
===1928=== *Soldier Field was one of the venues of the [[1928 National Challenge Cup]] association football tournament. Notable players included the Nationals' [[Geordie Henderson]] and [[Siegfried Wortmann]], as well as the Bricklayers' [[Clem Cuthbert]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=Gems/><ref>{{cite book | last = Jose | first = Colin | title = American Soccer League, 1921-1931 | type = Hardback | publisher = The Scarecrow Press | year = 1998 | id = ({{ISBN|0-8108-3429-4}})}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" |- !Date !Team #1 !Result !Team #2 !Round !Attendance |- |January 15, 1928||Swedish-American A.C.||0-4||[[Chicago Canadian Club]]||Western Division, First Round|| |- |January 22, 1928||Vienna F.C.||1-0||Thistles F.C||Western Division, First Round|| |- |January 22, 1928||[[Chicago Sparta]]||2-0||[[Olympia F.C. (United States)|Olympia F.C.]]||Western Division, First Round|| |- ||February 5, 1928||[[Bricklayers and Masons F.C.|Chicago Bricklayers]]||4-0||Buda AA|| Western Division, Second Round|| |- |February 26, 1928||Bricklayers||1-0||Chicago Sparta ||Western Division, Semifinals|| |- |April 15, 1928||Bricklayers||0-3||[[New York Nationals (ASL)|New York Nationals]]||Tournament final (tiebreaker game)||15,000
|} *In June Soldier Field hosted the [[1928 NCAA Men's Track and Field Championships|1928]] [[NCAA Men's Division I Outdoor Track and Field Championships|NCAA Men's Track and Field Championships]].<ref>{{cite news|author=Charles W. Dunkley|title=STANFORD SCORES SMASHING WIN IN CHICAGO MEET|newspaper=Los Angeles Times (AP wire story)|date=1928-06-10}}</ref> This was the fourth consecutive edition held at Soldier Field. Among the notable competitors were [[Emerson Spencer]], [[Ed Hamm]], [[Victor Pickard]], [[Bob King (athlete)|Bob King]] [[George Simpson (runner)|George Simpson]], [[Frank Cuhel]], [[William Droegemueller]], [[Harlow Rothert]], [[Bruce Bennett|Herman Brix]] (later known by his stage-name Bruce Bennet), [[Eric Krenz]], [[Lee Bartlett]], [[Ward Edmonds]], [[George Hester]], [[Claude Bracey]], and [[Wilford Ketz]]. *In June a Women's track meet sponsored by the Chicago Evening American was held at Soldier Field, The meet featured many notable participants, but it is best remembered as the debut of future Olympic legend [[Betty Robinson]], who would go on to win two Olympic gold medals and one silver while competing for the United States. In the 100-meter race she set a world-record with a time of 12 seconds (the previous record was 12.6) in a semi-final qualifying heat (despite a strong north wind), and finished with the same time in the final, defeating [[Helen Filkey]] by 1 yard. Robinson was only 16 years of age at the time.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news|last =Corcoran|first =Jimmy| title=World's Marks Fall in Girls' Track Meet|newspaper =Chicago American|date =June 2, 1928}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Shirer|first=William|title=Chicago Girl Breaks World 100 Meter Record|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|date=August 1, 1928}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Bagnato|first=Andrew| title=She Blazed a Trail of Gold|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|date=June 5, 1988}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Craven|first=Karen|title=Olympic Gold Medalist Betty Robinson Schwartz|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|date=May 20, 1999}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title='Welcome Home' Riverdale Tells Betty Robinson|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|date=August 29, 1928}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Chicago Girls Break World Records in A.A.U. Meet|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|date =July 28, 1929}}</ref> *In 1928 [[Tex Austin]] staged his final rodeo event at Soldier Field. The event featured celebrities such as [[Hoot Gibson]] and [[Tom Mix]]. During the event Gibson shot scenes for his movie ''King of the Rodeo''.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=Images/> *The 1928 [[Peel Cup]] finals were played at Soldier Field.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *October 13 [[Notre Dame Fighting Irish football|Notre Dame]] defeated [[Navy Midshipmen football|Navy]] in a 7–0 game.<ref name=net/> Among those in attendance were [[Mayor of New York City|New York Mayor]] [[James L. Walker]] (who was in Chicago for a [[Democratic Party (USA)|Democratic]] rally) and Democratic candidate for [[Governor of Illinois|governor]] (and former [[Supreme Court of Illinois|state Supreme Court]] justice) [[Floyd Thompson (lawyer)|Floyd E. Thompson]]. This game was attended by 120,000 spectators. This game is argued to possibly hold the all-time collegiate attendance record, as some sources (such as the [[Chicago Tribune]]) reported the November 25, 1927 match at Soldier Field to have had a then all-time high attendance of 117,000, while the [[NCAA]] recorded the attendance as 120,000, which it deems to be the 'largest pre-1948 regular season college football attendance'. A figure of 123,000 was reported by the official Park District attendance count.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=fortune/><ref>{{cite news|last =Eckersall|first =Walter|title =120,000 See Notre Dame Whip Navy|newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune|date =October 14, 1928}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last =Gould|first =Alan J.|title =Notre Dame Downs Davy for Its Third Successive Loss of the Season|newspaper =Kingsport Times|location =Kingsport, Tennessee|agency =Associated Press|date =October 14, 1928}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title =Mayor Jimmie Does a Gridiron Victory Prance|newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune|date =October 14, 1928}}</ref> *1928 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]]<ref>{{cite news | title =Preps Gird for Title Combat | newspaper =[[Chicago American]] | date =December 4, 1928 }}</ref>
===1929=== *In 1929 Soldier Field hosted its first [[Sokol]] national slet. In the USA national slets (a word for gatherings) are held every four years. The 1929 slet drew 25,000. In attendance was U.S. representative [[Ruth Hanna McCormick]]. Slets included gymnastics competitions and track and field events amongst other sports. At the 1929 slet athletes from 1,200 US Sokol organizations participated in Olympic-style individual gymnastic events. Also, in the 1929 slet 2,000 Chicago youth partook in a mass gymnastic drill timed to orchestral music.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news|last=O'Hara|first=Delia|title =Gymnastics|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|date=March 28, 1979}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=25,000 Attend Czecho-Slavak Festival Here|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|date=June 17, 1929}}</ref> *In 1929 Soldier Field again hosted the South Parks [[Marble (toy)|Marble]] Championship.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news| title =Youngster of 50 Is South Parks Marbles Champ| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =May 24, 1929}}</ref> *October 19 90,000 spectators saw [[Notre Dame Fighting Irish football|Notre Dame]] defeat [[Wisconsin Badgers football|Wisconsin]] in a 19–0.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=net/><ref>Sperber, Shake Down the Thunder, page 315.</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=90,000 See Notre Dame Beat Badgers, 19–0|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|date=October 20, 1929}}</ref> *In 1929 Soldier Field held its second-ever firefighting demonstration.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *October 26 was the first time that a long-running football rivalry game between [[Tuskegee Golden Tigers football|Tuskegree]] and [[Wilberforce University]] (both historically black colleges) was held at Soldier Field. This was second time that this rivalry was ever played. The 1929 game also provided a championship among historically black colleges. Tuskegee's star player was [[College Football Hall of Fame]]-inducted [[running back]] [[Ben Stevenson (American football)|Ben Stevenson]]. The game was attended by 12,000 spectators. The game was thereafter played annually at Soldier Field until 1942, the only three exceptions being 1931 when game held at Mills Stadium in Chicago, 1932 when in place of this matchup Wilberforce played a different team at another venue in Chicago, and 1937 when the game was cancelled. After 1942 the game was moved Chicago's [[Comiskey Park]], where it was played annually until 1949. Overall, Wilberforce recorded nine victories, Tuskegee recorded eight victories, and three games were tied in the rivalry series. The rivalry series was remembered endearingly by many in Chicago's African-American community, notably singer [[Lou Rawls]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news|title=Tuskegee Wins 6–0 Game from Wilberforce|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|date=October 27, 1929}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Chicago Buildings, 'Big and Copious', Thrill Dixie Team|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|date =October 25, 1929}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Tuskegee, Wilberforce Elevens Ready|newspaper=Chicago Defender (national edition)|date =October 26, 1929}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|date=November 28, 2004|title=A Year of Honors for Lou Rawls|url=http://www.americanprofile.com/article/4456|journal=American Profile Magazine|accessdate=November 28, 2004}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Young|first=Frank|title=Athletics Serves Purpose: Fay SAYS (column)|newspaper=Chicago Defender (National Edition)|date=June 24, 1950}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Young|first=Frank A. 'Fay'|date=1995|editor=Richard Orodenker|title=Dictionary of Literary Biography: American Sportswriters and Writers on Sport|location=Detroit|publisher=Gale Group|page=332}}</ref> *November 9 [[Notre Dame Fighting Irish football|Notre Dame]] defeated [[Drake Bulldogs football|Drake]] 19–7.<ref name=net/><ref name=fortune/> *November 16 [[Notre Dame Fighting Irish football|Notre Dame]] defeated [[USC Trojans football|USC]] 19–12.<ref name=net/><ref name=fortune/>
== 1930s == {{multiple image|caption_align=center|header_align=center | align = right | direction = vertical | width = 250 | header = Postcards depicting how Soldier Field looked in the 1930s and 40s | image1 = Soldiers' Field and Field Museum at the Lake Front, Chicago (60780) (cropped).jpg | image2 = Soldiers' Field (cropped), view showing band shell, Field Museum, Shedd Aquarium, Adler Planetarium, Soldiers' Field, Northerly Island, Chicago (74767).jpg}}
===1930=== *August 23 150,000 people (with thousands more being denied admission) attended the first annual Chicagoland Music Festival. The Chicagoland Music Festival was an event both organized sponsored by the ''Chicago Tribune'', and ran for 26 years. The inaugural edition was jam-packed with performances, including a performance of the [[Anvil Chorus]] from [[Giuseppe Verdi]]'s opera ''[[Il trovatore]]'', a rendition of the [[Hallelujah Chorus]] from [[George Frideric Handel]]'s [[Messiah (Handel)|Messiah]] sung by the entire audience, numerous [[John Philip Sousa]] marches, and [[Spiritual (music)|spirituals]] like [[Swing Low, Sweet Chariot]]. Thousands of performers were involved in the event, amongst them was [[Douglas, Michigan]]'s 92-year-old W. T. Kimsey, an [[American Civil War]] [[veteran]] who had been [[Drummer boy (military)|a drummer]] in the army of [[Ulysses S. Grant]] at the [[Battle of Shiloh]]. Kimsey performed using the same drum that he played at the Battle of Shiloh.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name='ChicagolandMusicFest'>{{cite news|last=Benzkofer|first=Stephan|title =Chicagoland Music Festival was true spectacle|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/opinion/ct-chicagoland-music-festival-flashback-0817-jm-20140817-story.html|newspaper=Chicago Tribune (Online)|date=August 15, 2014|accessdate=August 15, 2014}}</ref> *In 1930 a multiple-day track meet at held at Soldier Field attracted over 40,000 spectators to its last night of events. The event was a multinational competition between athletes from the [[British Empire]] a team of US competitors. Similar events had been hosted in England, with the one at Soldier Field being the first hosted in the United States. Notable participants included [[Ralph Metcalfe]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news| last =Smith| first =Wilfrid| title =United States Beats British Athletes 9–5| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =August 28, 1930}}</ref> *In 1930 the ''[[Chicago Daily News]]'' sponsored an event benefitting the Chicago firefighter's benevolent association. This would become an annual event.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *20,000 spectators attended the 1930 Public League championship, which substituted for the [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]] (which was not played in either 1929 nor in 1930, and was decided by forfeit in 1928).<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=Gems/><ref name=catholicleague/><ref name=catholicleague2/><ref>{{cite news | title =20,000 Watch South Siders Take Crown | newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune | date =November 23, 1930}}</ref> *October 3 Soldier Field hosted [[Drake Bulldogs football#1930 Soldier Field night game|its first night football game]] when the [[Oregon Ducks football|Oregon Ducks]] defeated the [[Drake Bulldogs football|Drake Bulldogs]] 14–7. This was followed by a second college football game at Soldier Field between the [[Loyola Ramblers]] and the [[Georgetown Hoyas football|Georgetown Hoyas]]. These two games were the first-ever intersectional night games to be played in Chicago.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1499&dat=19301003&id=L7EWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=tCEEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6651,4933056 |accessdate=August 3, 2008|work=The Milwaukee Journal|title=Drake vs. Oregon Tonight |via=Google |date=March 10, 1930}}</ref> *October 9 [[William Randolph Hearst]] spoke at Soldier Field.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kinsley|first=Philip |title=Mayor Greets W. R. Hearst in Soldiers' Field|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune |date=October 10, 1930}}</ref> *November 29 [[Notre Dame Fighting Irish football|Notre Dame]] defeated [[Army Black Knights football|Army]] 7–6.<ref name=net/><ref name="Bartlet">{{cite news | last =Bartlet | first =Charles | title =C.Y.O. to Honor Prep Stars at Stadium Bouts | newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune | date =November 30, 1937}}</ref><ref name="Segreti">{{cite news | last =Segreti | first =James | title =De Correvont Injured after Score;
