Austin Triumphs 13–0 | newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune | date =December 12, 1937}}</ref><ref name="Austin Star Hurt as Team Wins 13-0">{{cite news | title =Austin Star Hurt as Team Wins 13–0 | newspaper =New York Times | agency =Associated Press | date =December 12, 1937}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite news | title =Famed Chicago Prep Visits Southland | newspaper =Los Angeles Times| date =January 1, 1938}}</ref><ref name="Associated Press">{{cite news| title =Chicago Preps Down Arizona Stars 9–6 | newspaper =[[Los Angeles Times]] | location =Los Angeles | agency =[[Associated Press]] | date =January 2, 1938}}</ref><ref name="Burns">{{cite news | last =Burns | first =Edward | title =Austin High Conquers Leo 26 to 0 Before Record Crowd | newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune | date =November 28, 1937}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite news | title =120,000 Thrilled by Boy Wonder in Chicago School Gridiron Final | newspaper =New York Times (Special Edition) | date =November 28, 1937}}</ref><ref name="Shnay">{{cite news | last =Shnay | first =Jerry | title =50 Years and 120,000 Fans Ago | newspaper =Chicago Tribune | date =November 27, 1987}}</ref><ref name="Chicago Tribune">{{cite news | title =Seat Sales for Title Prep Game Exceed $80,000 | newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune | date =November 15, 1937}}</ref><ref name="Condon">{{cite news | last =Condon | first =David | title =In the Wake of the News | newspaper =Chicago Tribune | date =May 28, 1966}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceC">{{cite news | title =Austin All Set to Bring Foot Ball Title Here | newspaper =Garfieldian | location =Garfield Park, Chicago| date = November 25, 1937}}</ref><ref name="Dunkley">{{cite news | last =Dunkley | first =Charles | title =High School Grid Star Amazes Fans | newspaper =Reno Evening Gazette | agency =Associated Press| date =November 15, 1937}}</ref>
===1931=== *In January 1931 the [[Woman's Benefit Association]] held its annual Pageant at Soldier Field.<ref name=Images/><ref>{{cite news |title=The Ladies' Review| newspaper =The Ladies' Review|location= Port Huron, Michigan |date =January 1931}}</ref> *The second Chicagoland Music Festival, held in 1931, featured [[John Philip Sousa]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=ChicagolandMusicFest/> *In 1931 the [[Ringling Brothers Barnum and Bailey Circus]] visited Soldier Field's parking lot.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *May 12 Soldier Field held its first amateur boxing event. This event was a [[Golden Gloves]] tournament sponsored by the ''Chicago Tribune''. The tournament had outgrown its former home at the [[Chicago Stadium]], and was moved to Soldier Field that year. [[Chicago Golden Gloves|The Chicago-based Golden Gloves tournament]] was the brain-child of [[Arch Ward]], and was first held in 1923, before a brief state ban, and again was revived in 1928. It had begun as a local contest, but quickly became a regional Midwestern and finally a national amateur championship. In 1931 it became an international event, with the addition of international competitors, in the case of the 1931 tournament 10 young Frenchmen were invited to participate. To ensure that in the case of rain the event could be moved to the Chicago Stadium, only 21,000 tickets were sold in advance, but on the day of the fights 40,000 showed up at Soldier Field. The ring was placed in the center of Soldier Field's arena, and was surrounded by 22,000 'ringside seats' placed on a giant, slightly sloped, floor. The bouts were kicked off following a band and fireworks. In the first bout [[Leo Rodak]] defeated [[André Perrier]] for the [[flyweight]] title.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *October 10 a crowd of 65,000 [[Notre Dame Fighting Irish football|Notre Dame]] played [[Northwestern Wildcats football|Northwestern]] to a scoreless tie.<ref name="hailtopurple"/><ref name="Somogyi"/> *[[List of schools in Chicago Public Schools#Former High Schools|Harrison]] defeated [[Mount Carmel High School (Chicago)|Mount Carmel]] 44–6 in the 1931 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref>{{cite news | last =Smith | first =Wilfrid| title =Harrison Overwhelms Mt. Carmel 44 to 6 | newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune | date =December 6, 1931}}</ref> *November 28 [[Purdue Boilermakers football|Purdue]] defeated [[Northwestern Wildcats football|Northwestern]] 7-0 in a special post-season collegiate football game at Soldier Field. Proceeds of the match went to charity.<ref name="hailtopurple"/> [[File:Soldier Field 1932 NPS.jpg|thumb|250x250px|right|Soldier Field in 1932]]
===1932=== *June 24 Soldier Field hosted a war show celebrating the bicentennial of [[George Washington]]'s birth. The show took up residence at Soldier Field for an eleven-day run. The show was opened at 8pm with a flyover by four squadrons of fighter planes escorting a plane being flown by [[Amelia Earhart]] and painted to resemble a red and white eagle. Amelia later landed and made her way to the stadium, where she was given a gold medal and she spoke to the crowd (as well as an audience listening to a radio broadcast of the event) about her flight across the atlantic the previous year.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=StoriedStrangeHistory/><ref>{{cite news| title =Planes Thrill Crowd at Military Show| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =June 25, 1932}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| title =1,500 Soldiers Will Move into Loop Wednesday| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =June 13, 1932}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| last =Laughlin| first =Kathleen| title =Amelia Flies to City; Given Noisy Ovation| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =June 25, 1932}}</ref> {{multiple image|caption_align=center|header_align=center | align = right | direction = vertical | width = 200 | header = U.S. Army Show at Soldier Field, June 24, 1932 | image1 = | image2 =}} *In 1932 the [[Ringling Brothers Barnum and Bailey Circus]] visited Soldier Field's parking lot.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *June 24-July 4 Soldier Field held the United States Army Military Tournament to celebrate the George Washington Bicentennial. The event included aerial demonstrations, combat enactments, artillery demonstrations, Olympic-style [[Athletics (sport)|athletics]] competition, a [[parade]], and [[pyrotechnics|pyrotechnic]] displays. Involved in the aerial demonstrations was Major [[1st Operations Group#1st Pursuit Group Commanders|Gerald E. Brower]].<ref name=Images/> *July 27 Soldier Field held the second-ever [[Chicago Golden Gloves]] tournament. More than 45,000 spectators attended (organizers of the event lauded it as the largest crowd in the world to have ever seen an amateur boxing tournament). This tournament featured Olympic-caliber participants from Germany. American participants won 4 of the matches, and German participants won four as well. Three of the German participants ([[bantamweight]] [[Hans Ziglarski]], [[featherweight]] [[Josef Schleinkofer]], and [[welterweight]] [[Erich Campe]]) would go on to win silver in [[Boxing at the 1932 Summer Olympics|the boxing competition]] at the [[1932 Summer Olympics]] held in Los Angeles several weeks later.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *A 1932 Post-Olympic track meet was held at Soldier Field featuring teams from 15 nations. Notable participants included US Olympian [[Ralph Metcalfe]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news| last =Smith| first =Wilfrid| title =Post Olympic Meet Produces Two World Marks| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune|date =August 19, 1932}}</ref> [[File:Century of Progress Panorama (cropped).jpg|thumb|right|200x200px|Soldier Field (far left) and the adjacent [[Century of Progress]] World's Exposition in 1933]]
===1933=== *May 27 Soldier Field opening ceremonies of the [[Century of Progress]] Worlds Fair. [[Postmaster General]] and [[Democratic National Convention|DNC]]-Chairman [[James Farley]] facilitated the opening ceremony.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news|title=Chicago Fair Opened by Farley; Rays of Arcturus Start Lights|newspaper=[[New York Times]]|date=May 28, 1933}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last= O'Donnell Bennett|first=James|title=Exposition Starts with Pageant in Soldiers' Field|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|date=May 28, 1933}}</ref> *In 1933 attendance for the annual war show was high.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *In June a [[NCAA]] track meet was held at Soldier Field, and featured such notable participants as [[african american]] track stars [[Ralph Metcalfe]] and [[Jesse Owens]]. Five records were set at this meet, one of which was set by Metcalfe.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> Both Owens and Metclaffe would go on to participate in the [[Summer Olympics]] (Owens in [[1936 Summer Olympics]] and Metclaffe in both [[1932 Summer Olympics]] and 1936), and are now largely regarded as US Olympic legends. Metclaffe, a native [[Chicagoan]], would later be elected to as an Illinois [[United States Congress|congressman]], serving four terms in the [[United States House of Representatives]]. *At the 1933 German Day Festival [[George Seibel]], a [[Pittsburgh]] lawyer, writer, friend of the novelist [[Willa Cather]], and the national president of the [[American Turnerbund]] (a [[Turners|Turnerist]] group) spoke about the contributions of German immigrants to American democracy.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *In conjunction with the [[Century of Progress]] [[World's Fair]], a very successful [[rodeo]] event was held at Soldier Field.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *In conjunction with the [[Century of Progress]] [[World's Fair]], Soldier Field again hosted the South Parks [[Marble (toy)|Marble]] Championship in 1933.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news| last =| first =| title =Sorts Tourney at Chicago Fair| newspaper =Reno Evening Gazette| location =Reno| date =April 15, 1933|agency = Associated Press}}</ref> *In conjunction with Texas Day at the World's Fair, an all-Texan cast performed a production of [[Aida]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=StoriedStrangeHistory/> *In June 50,000 attended a national [[Sokol]] slet held at Soldier Field.<ref>{{cite news| last =Mullin| first =Earl| title =50,000 Witness Sokol Festival at World's Fair| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =June 25, 1933}}</ref> *July 3 150,000 spectators attended ''A Romance of a People'', an immensely elaborate Jewish pageant telling the history of the Jewish people, staged at Soldier Field. The event was coordinated by [[Meyer Weisgal]]. [[Chaim Weizmann]] (head of the [[World Zionist Organization]] and would later become the first [[President of Israel|President]] of [[Israel]]) gave a speech to open the show. The show required over 6,000 performers. The event was so successful that it was given a repeat performance a few days later at Soldier Field<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=StoriedStrangeHistory/><ref>{{cite news| title =Jewish Musical Revives Ancient Forms| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =July 2, 1933}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Moore|first=Moore|title=Stage Effects at Jewish Fete to Make History|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|date=June 17, 1933}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Evans|first=John|title=Jewish Pageant to Depict 40 Centuries of Religion|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|date= June 9, 1933}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Pageant to Depict Rise of Religion|newspaper=[[New York Times]]|date=June 11, 1933}}</ref><ref name="Smith">{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Michael|title=Israel Science Chief Tells of Debt to City|newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=December 21, 1967}}</ref><ref name="Smith"/><ref>{{cite web|last=Evans|first=John|title=3,600 Jews Hold Full Rehearsal of Fete Tonight|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|date=June 25, 1933}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=125,000 to See Big Spectacle: Jews to present 'Romance of a People' at Chicago World's Fair|newspaper=Lowell Sun|location=Lowell, Massachusetts|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date= July 3, 1933}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=800 Policemen Clear Jam at Jewish Play|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|date=July 4, 1933}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last= O'Donnell Bennett|first=James|title=125,000 Witness Jewish Spectacle|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|date=July 4, 1933}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Duncan-Clark|first=S.J.|title=Jewish 'Romance of a People' Kindles Thrill of Faith in 150,000 Spec tators|newspaper=[[Chicago Daily News]]|date=July 5, 1933}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Evans|first=John|title=Pageant Tells 4,000 Year Epic of a Great Race|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|date=July 2, 1933}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wttw.com/main.taf?p=1,7,1,1,24|title= Romance of a People: Jewish History in Chicago 1833-1933|website=www.wttw.com|publisher=[[WTTW]]|accessdate=March 26, 2015}}</ref><ref name=repeat2>{{cite news|last=O'Donnell Bennett|first=James|title=Great Jewish Play Repeated before 55,000|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|date=July 6, 1933}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Jewish Pageant Grosses $450,000|newspaper=[[New York Times]]|date=October 20, 1933}}</ref> **75,000 spectators attended a repeat performance of ''A Romance of a People''.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=repeat2/> *A celebration the 300th anniversary of the first Swedish to immigrate to the United States was held at Soldier Field.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> {{multiple image|caption_align=center|header_align=center | align = right | direction = vertical | width = 250 | header = [[Jeannette Piccard#Balloon and Thomas Settle flights|1933 Piccard-Settle stratospheric flight]] | image1 = Navy Century of Progress.jpg | caption1 = Navy members with the balloon's gondola. | image2 = Century of Progress balloon-Chicago-1933.jpg | caption2 =Balloon taking off before and audience of 44,000 at Soldier Field}} *August 3 Soldier Field held its final [[Chicago Golden Gloves]] tournament. This tournament was held in conjunction of Chicago's [[Century of Progress|1933–1934 Century of Progress World's Fair]]. More than 48,000 people attended the matches, despite a one-day postponement due to rain. This tournament featured participants from Ireland. The first two bouts were won by Irish participants, but the next six were won by American participants. Irish [[heavyweight]] champion Patrick Mulligan was knocked out broke his ankle during his bout. This was the last edition of the Chicago Golden Gloves to be held at Soldier Field. The tournament has been held at other Chicago venues ever-since.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *August 4 40,000 spectators witnessed the inflation of the world's largest hydrogen [[gas balloon]] in preparation for [[Jeannette Piccard#Balloon and Thomas Settle flights|a stratospheric flight from Soldier Field]] by [[Jeannette Piccard|Jeannette]] and Auguste Piccard.<ref>{{cite book|author=DeVorkin, David H.|title=Race to the Stratosphere: Manned Scientific Ballooning in America|publisher=Springer-Verlag|date=1989|isbn=0-387-96953-5}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | author=Ganz, Cheryl |title=The 1933 Chicago World's Fair: A Century of Progress | publisher=University of Illinois Press | date=2008 | isbn=0-252-03357-4 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GYXD8t4DDoIC}}</ref><ref name=Navy>{{cite web| author= Unknown author| title= To Leave the Earth| publisher= U.S. Department of the Navy – Navy Historical Center| date=n.d.| url= http://www.history.navy.mil/download/space-04.PDF|format=PDF| accessdate= January 26, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Stekel, Peter |url=http://www.balloonlife.com/9707/piccard.htm |title=Don Piccard – 50 Years of Ballooning Memories |publisher=''Balloon Life'' |accessdate=February 22, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070216155254/http://www.balloonlife.com/9707/piccard.htm |archivedate=February 16, 2007 |df= }}</ref> *August 12 Soldier Field hosted a national [[African American]] athletic meet in conjunction with the 'Negro Day' event held at the [[Century of Progress]] [[World's Fair]]. The event featured such notable athletes as Olympic gold medalists [[Ed Gordon (athlete)|Edward Gordon]] and [[William DeHart Hubbard]] (the first African American to win a gold medal).<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news| title =Negro Track Stars in National Meet at Soldier Field| newspaper =Chicago Daily News| location =Chicago| date =August 2, 1933}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| title =Ajax Club, Gary, Captures Title in Negro Meet| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =August 13, 1933}}</ref> *August 12, coinciding with the Fair's Negro Day, an [[African American]] pageant entitled ''Epic of a Race'' was performed at Soldier Field. [[Chandler Owen]], who headed the organization of Negro Day events, employed author and [[WYLL|WJJD]] radio staffer Andrew Dobson as the author and theatrical producer and dance instructor Sammy Dyer as the director of the production. [[Carl Sandburg]] was consulted by Dobson on the historical accuracy of his script. Renowned actor [[Richard B. Harrison]] was the master of ceremonies for the event, which featured 1,500 performers, about 3,000 singers, music by the [[370th Infantry Regiment (United States)#8th Infantry Regiment, Illinois National Guard|8th Infantry Regiment]] Band, and portrayed 11 different historic episodes.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=StoriedStrangeHistory/> *The 1933 [[Peel Cup]] finals were played at Soldier Field.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *In the Summer of 1933 Soldier Field hosted the Forty-Sixth annual [[Amateur Athletic Union|National Amateur Athletic Union]] meet. The track and field event only managed to attract just over 8,000 spectators. A commentator wrote, "Judged solely by the caliber of its athletes, (it) was one of the best in the history of the modern games", but added "By the standards of attendance....the games flopped."<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news|title =A.A.U. Meet Is Great Show, but Flops at Gate| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =July 2, 1933}}</ref> *85,000 spectators attended the fourth annual Chicagoland Music Festival in 1933.<ref>{{cite magazine|date=September 4, 1933|title=Music: Chicagoland & Texas|url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,745994,00.html|magazine=Time Magazine|location=New York City|accessdate=August 16, 2014}}</ref> *October 1 8,000 spectators saw the [[Chicago Bears]] defeat the [[Boston Redskins]] 7-0.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/193310010chi.htm |title=Boston Redskins 0 at Chicago Bears 7 Sunday, October 1, 1933 |website=[[Pro-Football-Reference.com]]|access-date=November 10, 2015 }}</ref> *October 7 [[Northwestern Wildcats football|Northwestern]] faced [[Iowa Hawkeyes football|Iowa]] at Soldier Field. Northwestern lost 7-0.<ref name=hailtopurple/> *October 14 [[Northwestern Wildcats football|Northwestern]] tied [[Stanford Cardinal football|Stanford]] in a scoreless game at Soldier Field.<ref name=hailtopurple/> *[[Mount Carmel High School (Chicago)|Mount Carmel]] defeated [[List of schools in Chicago Public Schools#Former High schools|Harrison]] 7–0 in the 1933 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]]. The event was made official for the first time, being promoted by the [[Mayor of Chicago]] [[Edward Joseph Kelly]] himself.<ref name=Gems/><ref name=catholicleague/><ref name=catholicleague2/><ref>{{cite news| title =Mt. Carmel to Get Another Title Chance | newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =November 24, 1933}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title =Mt. Carmel Is Ready for New Title Bid | newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =December 2, 1933}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title =Mount Carmel Defeats St. Rita in Title Game | newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =December 4, 1933}}</ref> *The Canadian professional soccer champion [[Toronto Scots]] played [[St. Louis]]' Stix, Baer and Fuller team, the U.S. champions, for the North American [[association football|soccer]] title in 1933. The Scots won 2-1. This event was one of many Soldier Field sporting events that was tied-into the ongoing Worlds Fair.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/>
===1934===
*Easter of 1934 Soldier Field held its first nondenominational Protestant Easter sunrise service. A year earlier a similar event had been held near the stadium at the site of the [[Century of Progress|adjacent World's Fair]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *In 1934 attendance for the annual war show was high. Every night the show would end with a re-enactment of the World War I [[Battle of Cantigny]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *The [[International Motorcycle Association]] held a month of motorcycle races at Soldier Field beginning July 4.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *[[Al Jolson]] headlined the 1934 Chicagoland Music Festival.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *60,000 spectators attended ''O' Sing a New Song'', a pageant held at Soldier Field for the Worlds Fair's second Negro Day. The pageant was conceived by [[Associated Negro Press]] editor and [[Chicago Defender]] columnist [[Nahum Daniel Brascher]] and produced by notable author [[Noble Sissle]] and notable musician [[Eubie Blake]]. Sissle worked with ''[[Down Beat]]'' reporter [[Onah Spencer]] on writing the script. Widely renown musicians [[Harry Lawrence Freeman]], [[W. C. Handy]], [[Nathaniel Clark Smith]], and [[Jimmy Mundy]] contributed to the production. Other contributing musicians included [[J. Wesley Jones]], [[Will Marion Cook]] and [[J. Rosamond Johnson]]. Other notable performers included [[Richard B. Harrison]] (who served as the narrator). Among the most notable performers in the pageant was [[Bill Robinson]]. The production required 5,000 vocalists and 3,500 dancers. 200 men performed military maneuvers in a segment portraying black contributions to the armed-forces. A group of [[Zulu people|Zulus]] partook in a segment of the show. The show was opened by President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]], who pressed a button in the [[White House]] which remotely turned on the stadium's lighting. This intentionally mirrored President [[Grover Cleveland]] similarly opening the [[World's Columbian Exposition]] from the White House by pressing a button that turned-on the fairground's lights.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *A [[Celts (modern)|Celtic]] cultural pageant, ''Pageant of the Celt'', was performed at Soldier Field. It was narrated by [[Micheál MacLiammoir]]. The pageant required a 1,000-person choir. It proved so popular that a second performance was given at Soldier Field.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *August 24 45,000 spectators attended an all-star college football matchup between an East and a West all-star team. [[Harry Newman]] of [[Michigan Wolverines football|Michigan]] threw a touchdown pass to [[Gene Ronzani]] of [[Marquette Golden Avalanche football|Marquette]] in last minutes of play, giving the East team a victory.<ref name=collegeallstar>{{cite book |last=Schmidt |first=Raymond |year=2001 |title=Football's Stars of Summer: A History of the College All-Star Football Game Series of 1934-1976 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xiwH3cf5DvQC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false|location=Lanham, Maryland; London, England|publisher=Scarecrow Press |isbn=9780810840270 |access-date=April 21, 2015 }}</ref> *August 31 a crowd of 79,432 saw the College All-Stars play the [[Chicago Bears]] to a scoreless tie in the inaugural [[Chicago College All-Star Game]], which was the brainchild of [[Arch Ward]] (who was also the man behind the [[MLB All-Star Game]]). Like many events that were staged at Soldier Field, the College All-Star Games were sponsored by the ''Chicago Tribune''. The game raised over $4 million for charity over the course of its 42-game run. All but two of those games were held at Soldier Field, with the other two held at [[Dyche Stadium]] in 1943 and 1944. The game is considered to have been a major contributor to the growth of professional gridiron football in the United States. [[Noble Kizer]] of [[Purdue]] had been selected by a fan vote to be the coach of the College All-Star team. Players selected by vote for the team included, [[quarterback]]s [[Bernie Masterson]] [[Nebraska Cornhuskers football|Nebraska]], [[Homer Griffith]] of [[USC Trojans football|USC]], [[Joe Laws]] of [[Iowa Hawkeyes football|Iowa]]; [[Tackle (American football)|tackle]] [[Moose Krause]]; [[Halfback (American football)|halfbacks]] [[Nick Lukats]], [[George Sauer]] of Nebraska, [[Beattie Feathers]] of [[Tennessee Volunteers football|Tennessee]]; [[Guard (American football)|guards]] [[Tom Hupke]] of [[Alabama Crimson Tide|Alabama]], [[Bobby Jones (offensive lineman)|Bobby Jones]] of Indiana, and [[Aaron Rosenberg]] of USC; [[End (American football)|ends]] [[Joe Skladany]] of [[Pittsburgh Panthers football|Pittsburgh]], [[Bill Smith (American football)|Bill Smith]] of [[Washington Huskies football|Washington]] and [[Sid Gillman]] of [[Ohio State Buckeyes football|Ohio State]]. Other players included end [[Edgar Manske]] of [[Northwestern Wildcats football|Northwestern]] and halfback [[Herman Everhardus]] of [[Michigan Wolverines football|Michigan]]. Both Sauer and Krause were the co-captains of the college all-star team. In addition to Kizer the all-stars' coaching staff included [[Mai Edwards]] of [[Purdue Boilermakers football|Purdue]] and [[Jim Crowley]] of [[Fordham Rams football|Fordham]] (who would go on to coach the [[Chicago Rockets]] at Soldier Field). The entire game was covered in radio [[play-by-play]], and over 120 newspapers from 22 states requested press credentials for the event.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=collegeallstar/><ref>{{cite journal|last=Grogan|first=John|title=The College All-Star Football Classic|journal=The Coffin Corner|year=2000|volume=22|issue=2|url=http://www.profootballresearchers.org/Coffin_Corner/22-02-841.pdf|accessdate=January 30, 2012|publisher=[[Professional Football Researchers Association]]|format=PDF|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/655b55Voh?url=http://www.profootballresearchers.org/Coffin_Corner/22-02-841.pdf|archivedate=January 30, 2012|deadurl=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=College All-Star Game: A Charity Dies|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=5OMLAAAAIBAJ&sjid=jVgDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6609,1573517&hl=en|accessdate=January 30, 2012|newspaper=[[Evening Independent]]|date=December 22, 1967|agency=[[Chicago Tribune]]|page=1-C}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title =All-Star Game Moved to Dyche Stadium. | newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune | date =May 27, 1943}}</ref><ref name=footballgeography>{{cite web |url=http://www.footballgeography.com/nfl-teams-that-lost-to-non-league-opponents/ |title=NFL Teams That Lost to Non-League Opponents |date= August 19, 2013|website=www.footballgeorgraphy.com|accessdate=January 3, 2014}}</ref><ref name=Philly>{{cite book |last1= Startare |first1=Brian|last2=Reavy |first2=Kevin |date=2014 |title=This Day in Philadelphia Sports |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5HfoBAAAQBAJ&pg=PT177 |location=New York City|publisher=Sports Publishing (trademark of Skyhorse Publishing Inc.) |access-date=July 30, 2015 }}</ref> *50,000 people saw [[Robert Lindblom Math & Science Academy|Lindblom]] defeat [[Leo Catholic High School|Leo]] 6–0 in the 1934 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=Gems/><ref name=catholicleague2/><ref>{{cite news | last =Bartlett | first =Charles | title =Music Aplenty Assured at Prep Football Final | newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =November 30, 1934}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last =Bartlett | first =Charles | title =Leo Plays Lindblom Today for Prep Title | newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =December 1, 1934}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| last =Bartlett | first =Charles | title =Lindblom Defeats Leo, 6 to 0; Takes Prep Title | newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune | date =December 2, 1934}}</ref><ref name='prep'>{{cite web |url=http://prepbowl.tripod.com/id3.html|title=Past Prep Bowls|website=prepbowl.tripod.com |accessdate=July 23, 2014}}</ref>
===1935=== *Easter of 1935 23,000 people attended the nondenominational Protestant Easter sunrise service held at Soldier Field.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *May 19, Soldier Field began its long tradition of hosting midget automobile races. Midget racing star [[Marshall Lewis]] was winner of the first race held at Soldier Field, finishing first-place in the main event. 20,000 spectators attended the event.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=kalracinghistory/> *August 1935, when the west tower of the 1933 World Fair's [[Sky Ride]] was demolished, it fell into a portion of Soldier Field's exterior walls, requiring $50,000 in repairs.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=StoriedStrangeHistory/> [[File:1935 All-Star Collegiate Football (1989.222).jpg|thumb|right|150x150px|Football signed by all of the 1933 College All-Stars]] *August 29 77,450 saw the [[Chicago Bears]] defeat the College All-Stars 5–0 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]]. Fans voted [[Frank Thomas (American football)|Frank Thomas]] of [[Alabama Crimson Tide football|Alabama]] the collegiate all-stars' head coach. Over seven million votes were placed in the race for the position head coach. The vote became political, with numerous state governors publicly endorsing coaches. Other members of the coaching staff were Charles Bachman of [[Michigan State Spartans football|Michigan State]], [[Slip Madigan]] of [[Saint Mary's Gaels football|St. Mary]]'s, and Dr. C.W. Spears of [[Wisconsin Badgers football|Wisconsin]]. Amongst the alumni of the 1935 College All-Star team best known for their achievements outside of sports [[Irv Kupcinet]] of [[North Dakota Fighting Sioux|North Dakota]] (who would become a notable journalist and media personality) and [[Gerald Ford]] of [[Michigan Wolverines football|Michigan]] (who would later serve as the [[President of the United States]]).<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=pridmore/><ref name=collegeallstar/> *In 1935 the [[Ringling Brothers Barnum and Bailey Circus]] performed inside Soldier Field.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *75,000 people saw [[Robert Lindblom Math & Science Academy|Lindblom]] defeat [[Leo Catholic High School|Leo]] 6–0 in the 1935 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/>
===1936=== *July 22 the Chicago [[Catholic Youth Organization]] held its first boxing tournament at Soldier Field. This was an intercity boxing meet against New York's Catholic Youth Association. The proceeds of the tournament went to the CYO Mil Fund to help feed 35,000 students in n onsecretarian summer schools run at Chicago Catholic schools.<ref>{{cite news| title =C.Y.O. Defeat New York Boxers|newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune|date =July 23, 1936}}</ref> The Catholic Youth Organization would hold numerous intercity and international boxing tournaments at Soldier Field over the next several years.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *September 1 76,000 saw the College All-Stars tie the [[Detroit Lions]] 7–7 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]].<ref name=collegeallstar/><ref name=footballgeography/> *The 1936 edition of the German Day Festival was had a greater focus on pageantry and dancing versus the sports that were the focus of previous editions.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *In 1936 national softball championships for both men and women were held at Soldier Field. The stadium's arena was big enough to hold five softball diamonds with their home plates along the west stands (on the running track). All five were used simultaneously during the day, but only three were used at the same time for night games. Teams from 40 states and Canada participated, but rain delayed the tournament so it started two days late. A game that stood out was one attended by 15,000 spectators that featured the teams from [[Rochester, New York|Rochester]] and [[Cleveland]] facing off (Rochester, led by amateur softball legend Harold "Shifty" Gears, defeated Cleveland 2–0 in that game).<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *In 1936 the [[Ringling Brothers Barnum and Bailey Circus]] performed inside Soldier Field.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=Images/> *75,000 saw [[Austin Community Academy High School|Austin]] tie [[Fenwick High School (Oak Park, Illinois)|Fenwick]] 19–19 in the 1936 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/><ref name="I-records">{{cite web|url=http://www.ihsa.org/activity/fb/records/agen.htm#0X400|title=IHSA General Football Records|work=ihsa.org|accessdate=9 April 2009}}</ref> *In 1936 a game was held at Soldier Field between rival high schools [[Tilden High School (Chicago)|Tilden]] and [[Austin Community Academy High School|Austin]] was held at Soldier Field. During the game Tilden player [[Lou Rymkus]] blocked a kick and scored a touchdown. Rymkus would later refer to this as the most memorable game of his high school career.<ref>{{cite news|last=Denniston|first=Jack|title=Introducing|url=http://www.archives.nd.edu/Scholastic/VOL_0077/VOL_0077_ISSUE_0006.pdf|accessdate=November 19, 2012|newspaper=The Notre Dame Scholastic|date=November 13, 1942|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CIRIrFvi?url=http://www.archives.nd.edu/Scholastic/VOL_0077/VOL_0077_ISSUE_0006.pdf|archivedate=November 19, 2012}}</ref> *In late 1936 an ice rink was erected in Soldier Field.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *In 1936 the U.S. Central Ski Association held its annual ski meet at Soldier Field. They built a temporary ski jump that was 13-stories.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=ifbearsgo/> *In 1936 a Chicago-area ski group sponsored an invitational ski tournament at Soldier Field.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/>
===1937=== *February 7, 1937, the Chicago Daily Times sponsored a ski jump meet of the U.S. Central Ski Association at Soldier Field. The meet attracted 57,000 spectators, believed to be the largest crowd to ever see a ski jumping competition in the U.S. The temporary 180-foot tall all-wood ski jump tower was constructed by the Timber Engineering Company (TECO).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://foresthistory.org/chicago-ski-jumping/ |title=When Timber Engineers Brought Ski Jumping to Chicago |website=[[Forest History Society]]|access-date=November 10, 2017 }}</ref> *In 1937 Soldier Field held many events in honor of Chicago's Charter Jubilee, which was a celebration of the centennial of Chicago's 1837 incorporation as a city. The events were held between March 4 (the date of Chicago's incorporation) and October 9 (the anniversary of the Great Chicago Fire) Amongst the events Soldier Field held in celebration of the Jubilee were boxing matches.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> **Only 12,000 attended the 1937 Easter sunrise service at Soldier Field due to cold weather. The service that year was counted as a Charter Jubilee event.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> **50,000 attended a pageant celebrating the contributions of [[Poles in Chicago|Polish Chicagoans]] held as part of the Charter Jubilee.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *In 1937 attendance for the annual war show was high.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *In 1937 Soldier Field again held national softball championships for both men and women.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *In 1937 a boxing match between [[Joe Louis]] and [[James J. Braddock|Jim Braddock]] was held at Soldier Field.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *The 1937 German Day Festival was the final edition of the event to be held at Soldier Field.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *In 1937 the [[Ringling Brothers Barnum and Bailey Circus]] visited Soldier Field's parking lot.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *[[Austin Community Academy High School|Austin]] defeated [[Leo Catholic High School|Leo]] 26–0 to win the 1937 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]]; another contender for the highest attendance ever (estimated at over 120,000 spectators). Pre-game entertainment featured 'King of Jazz' [[Paul Whiteman]]. Austin was named [[High School Football National Championship|High School Football National Champions]] that season. Their star player was [[Bill Deorrevont]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=ifbearsgo/><ref name=choose/><ref name=catholicleague/><ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name="Bartlet"/><ref name="Segreti"/><ref name="Austin Star Hurt as Team Wins 13-0"/><ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref name="Associated Press"/><ref name="Burns"/><ref name="ReferenceB"/><ref name="Shnay"/><ref name="Chicago Tribune"/><ref name="Condon"/><ref name="ReferenceC"/><ref name="Dunkley"/><ref name=prep/><ref name=I-records/><ref>{{cite news| last =Dunkley | first = Charles| title =High School Grid Star Amazes Fans | newspaper = Reno Evening Gazette| location =Reno, Nevada |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date =November 15, 1937 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news| = | title =Bill de Correvont Holds the Spotlight in Chicago Game | newspaper =Stevens Point Daily Journal | location =Stevens Point, Wisconsin | agency =[[Associated Press]] | date =November 27, 1937 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news| title =Austin All Set to Bring Foot Ball Title Here | newspaper =Garfieldian | date =November 25, 1937}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Segreti |first=James |title=DeCorrevont Injured After Score|newspaper=The Chicago Daily Tribune|date=December 12, 1937}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Austin Star Hurt as Team Wins|newspaper=The New York Times|date=December 12, 1937}}</ref><ref name="William DeCorrevont Papers">Northwestern University Archives, William DeCorrevont Papers. Retrieved 2013-08-13.</ref><ref name="Bill DeCorrevont Obituary">{{cite news| url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1995-09-08/sports/9509080058_1_soldier-field-chicago-park-district-sports-scene |title=Bill Decorrevont, Celebrated Prep Star, Dead At 76 |accessdate=2013-08-13 |last=Jauss |first=Bill |date=1995-09-08 |work=Chicago Tribune}}</ref> *In 1937 the [[Norge Ski Club]] held a ski meet at Soldier Field. A 13-story 50m ski jump was erected at Soldier Field for the event. The [[Norge Ski Club]], which is based out of [[Fox River, Illinois]], is the oldest continuously operating ski club in the United States.<ref name=StoriedStrangeHistory/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.norgeskiclub.com/index.php/club-info/ |title=Club Info |website=http://www.norgeskiclub.com |publisher=Norge Ski Club |access-date=February 26, 2016 |quote=... the oldest, continuously open ski club in the United States ... The club was started in 1905 ... Another big event was when the Norge Ski Club rented out Soldier Field in Chicago and built a huge scaffolding for a jump event. They used crushed ice instead of snow to jump from and land on. It must have been exciting to jump from this tower at Soldier Field.}}</ref><ref name=skisprung>{{cite web |url=http://www.skisprungschanzen.com/EN/Ski+Jumps/USA-United+States/IL-Illinois/Chicago/0709-Soldier+Field/ |title=Soldier Field |website=skisorungschanzen.com |publisher=Ski Jumping Hills Archive |access-date=February 26, 2016 |quote=Soldier Field Jump:K-Point: 50 mYear of construction: 1937Conversions:1954Further jumps: noStatus: destroyedPlastic matting: noSki club: Norge Ski Club}}</ref> *September 1 84,560 saw the College All-Stars defeat the [[Green Bay Packers]] 6-0 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game|College All-Star Game]]. The game's only points were scored when [[TCU Horned Frogs football|Texas Christian University]]'s [[Sammy Baugh]] passed forty-seven yards to [[LSU Tigers football|Louisiana State University]]'s [[Gaynell Tinsley]]. Members of the All-Star team included [[Tippy Dye]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=collegeallstar/><ref name=footballgeography/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=AapQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=CiIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6639%2C6109944 |newspaper=Milwaukee Journal |last=Kuechle |first=Oliver E. |title=Sam Baugh's pass, stalwart defense give Stars 6–0 victory over Packers |date=September 2, 1937|page=5-part 2}}</ref>
===1938=== *April 17 50,000 attended the 1938 Easter sunrise service at Soldier Field. The service had [[Charles E. Fuller]] as its chief minister. *July 4, as part of the American Legion Fourth of July show held at Soldier Field, a 124th Artillery team played a Cuban army team to a 3–3 tie in a [[polo]] match. Also featured in the event were [[color guard]]s as well as [[drum and bugle corps (modern)|drum and bugle corps]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news| title =Climax Holiday Today: Bright Skies Promised| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =July 4, 1938}}</ref> *August 17, 1938 a [[jitterbug]] concert held at Soldier Field resulted in the so-called 'Jitterbug Riot' after crowds of about 200,000 overwhelmed the event's organizers. Performers at the event included [[Jimmy Dorsey]], [[Earl Hines]], [[Shep Fields]]. It featured a battle of the bands with 50 amateur bands and a number of the city's leading dance orchestras.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *The 1938 Chicagoland Music Festival is credited to have originated the tradition of lighting [[matches]] or [[lighters]] concerts. Among those singing was aviator [[Douglas Corrigan]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *In 1938 about 1,000 Police and Firemen participated in an event which raised funds for the benevolent funds of both groups.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *In 1938 Soldier Field again held national softball championships for both men and women.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *In 1938 the [[Ringling Brothers Barnum and Bailey Circus]] visited Soldier Field's parking lot.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *August 31 74,250 saw the College All-Stars defeat the [[Washington Redskins]] 28–16 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]]. The MVP was [[Purdue Boilermakers football|Purdue]] [[running back]] [[Cecil Isbell]].<ref name=collegeallstar/><ref name=footballgeography/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=87BQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=EiIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6582%2C2016183|newspaper=Milwaukee Journal |title=Isbell sparks rally as All-Stars beat Redskins in second half |date=September 1, 1938|page=6-part 2 }}</ref> The 1938 College All-Stars and the Redskins later would meet one another for a second game on September 5 in [[Dallas]].<ref name=footballgeography/> *September 1 80,000 people saw [[Fenger Academy High School (Chicago)|Fenger]] defeat [[Mount Carmel High School (Chicago)|Mount Carmel]] 13–0 in the [[Mount Carmel High School (Chicago)|Mount Carmel]] 44–6 in the 1938 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/><ref name=I-records/><ref>{{cite news| last =Burns| first =Edward| title =Fenger Beats Mt. Carmel for Title 13–0| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =November 27, 1938}}</ref> *September 11 20,000 spectators saw the [[Chicago Bears]] defeat the [[Chicago Cardinals]] 16-13.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/193809110chi.htm |title=Chicago Cardinals 13 at Chicago Bears 16 Sunday, September 11, 1938 |website=[[Pro-Football-Reference.com]]|access-date=November 10, 2015 }}</ref> *1938 was the final year that the U.S. Central Ski Association held its annual ski meet at Soldier Field.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/>
===1939=== *About 50,000 attended the 1939 Easter sunrise service held at Soldier Field.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *June 18, 20, 22, 24 and 25 the [[American Automobile Association]] held the World's Championship Midget Automobile Races on a wooden track erected in Soldier Field. Proceeds benefited the Hospital for Crippled Children's Chicago Unit. There was a $10,000 purse for the five-race series. Over 90,000 spectators attended the event. This was the second time that midget racing was held at Soldier Field. [[Sam Hanks]] won the first two races, and [[Ronnie Householder]] ultimately won Soldier Field's 1939 midget racing championship.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=kalracinghistory/><ref name="kalracingchamps">{{cite web |url= http://www.kalracing.com/autoracing/Soldier_Field_Track_Champions.htm |title=Soldier Field Track Champions |website=www.kalracing.com |access-date=February 7, 2015}}</ref><ref name="kalracing4">{{cite web |url=http://www.kalracing.com/autoracing/Soldier_Field_Photoscrapbook_4.htm|title= Soldier field photo scrapbook #4|date=November 26, 2013|website=www.kalracing.com|access-date=February 18, 2015}}</ref><ref>[http://www.worthyofhonor.com/Inductees/Sam_Hanks.htm Biography] at the [[National Midget Auto Racing Hall of Fame]] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120205190112/http://www.worthyofhonor.com/Inductees/Sam_Hanks.htm |date=February 5, 2012 }}</ref> *[[Fats Waller]] headlined the 1939 Chicagoland Music Festival.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *Over 98,000 spectators attended a 1939 stunt show starring "Lucky" Lee Lott at Soldier Field.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=Images/><ref>{{cite book |last=Lott |first=Lucky |year= 1994|title=Lucky Lee: The Legend of the Lucky Lee Lott Hell Drivers|location=Osceola, Wisconsin|publisher=Motorbooks International}}</ref> *August 30 81,456 saw the [[New York Giants]] defeat the College All-Stars 9–0 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]]. The MVP was [[Holy Cross Crusaders football|Holy Cross]] [[running back]] [[Bill Osmanski]].<ref name=collegeallstar/> *In 1939 the Chicago Rugby Club played two games at Soldier Field. The first game was against a Hollywood club. The second game was against a New York-East Coast all-star squad featuring high-level athletes. Chicago won the second game 24-9 and advanced to a Los Angeles game against the Hollywood Lighthorse Lancers for the national amateur rugby championship. The second game was attended by a crowd of 10,000 and was held on November 12.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news| title =Lary Kelley to Fly to Chicago for Rugby Game| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =November 7, 1939}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| last =Cass| first =Judith| title =Rugby Team to Meet New York City Club Tomorrow| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =November 11, 1939}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| last =Prell| first =Edward| title =Chicago Beats New York at Rugby,24 to 9 | newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =November 13, 1939}}</ref> *In 1939 the [[Ringling Brothers Barnum and Bailey Circus]] visited Soldier Field's parking lot.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *September 7 Soldier Field one last time held national softball championships for both men and women, organized by the [[Amateur Softball Association]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/461727102.html?dids=461727102:461727102&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Sep+06%2C+1939&author=&pub=Chicago+Tribune&desc=Play+to+Open+Tomorrow+in+Softball+Meet&pqatl=google|title=Play to Open Tomorrow in Softball Meet |newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune |date=September 6, 1939|accessdate=October 13, 2015}}</ref> *September 15 13,254 spectators saw the [[Chicago Bears]] defeat the [[Cleveland Rams]] 30-21.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/193909150chi.htm |title=Cleveland Rams 21 at Chicago Bears 30 Friday, September 15, 1939 |website=[[Pro-Football-Reference.com]]|access-date=November 10, 2015 }}</ref> *October 1 11,000 spectators saw the [[Detroit Lions]] defeat the [[Chicago Cardinals]] 17-3.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/193910010crd.htm |title=Detroit Lions 17 at Chicago Cardinals 3 Sunday, October 1, 1939 |website=[[Pro-Football-Reference.com]]|access-date=November 10, 2015 }}</ref> *75,000 people saw [[Fenger Academy High School (Chicago)|Fenger]] tie [[Mount Carmel High School (Chicago)|Mount Carmel]] 13–13 in the 1939 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/><ref name=I-records/>
== 1940s ==
===1940=== *March 24 the 1940 Easter sunrise service was held during one of the coldest Easters on record in Chicago. The temperature hardly reached the double-digits by the beginning of the service.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news|title =City Bundles Up for Its Coldest Easter Parade| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =March 24, 1940}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| last =Winn| first =Marcia| title =City's Churches Crowded with Easter Throngs| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =March 25, 1940}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| last =Moffett| first =India| title =Frigid Faithful Keep an Easter Date on Avenue| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =March 25, 1940}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| title =Weather| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune|date =March 25, 1940}}</ref> *In 1940 the [[Ringling Brothers Barnum and Bailey Circus]] visited Soldier Field's parking lot.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *July 4 the American Legion Fourth of July show at Soldier Field again featured a Polo match. This time it was an East-West match.<ref>{{cite news|title =East-West Polo for Legion Show| newspaper =Southwest Economist| date =June 19, 1940}}</ref> *August 5 Soldier Field hosted an [[Isolationism|isolationist]] "peace rally" organized by [[IOC]] member, [[USOC]] president (and future IOC vice president and IOC president) [[Avery Brundage]]. Brundage also introduced the event's featured speaker, [[Charles Lindberg]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.salon.com/2015/01/02/fdr_outsmarts_them_all_henry_ford_joseph_kennedy_charles_lindbergh_and_the_american_entrance_into_world_war_ii/ |title=FDR outsmarts them all: Henry Ford, Joseph Kennedy, Charles Lindbergh and the American entrance into World War II |last1=Wapshott |first1=Nicholas |date=January 2, 2015 |work= [[Salon (website)|Salon]] |accessdate=January 5, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://digitalcommons.chapman.edu/upi_lindbergh/26/ |title= Charles Lindbergh Speaking at Soldier Field|author= <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->|website= digitalcommons.chapman. edu|accessdate=January 5, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://cdm15046.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/singleitem/collection/p15046coll23/id/81/rec/20/ |title= Charles Lindbergh Speaking at Soldier Field|author= <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->|website= cdm15025.contentdm.oclc.org|accessdate=January 5, 2015}}</ref> *August 29 84,567 saw the [[Green Bay Packers]] defeat the College All-Stars 45–28 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]]. The MVP was [[USC Trojans football|USC Trojans]] [[running back]] [[Amby Schindler|Ambrose Schindler]]. *In 1940 the [[Society of the Holy Name|Catholic Holy Name Society]] held their inaugural annual "Holy Hour" service at Soldier Field. The event would continue be held into the 1950s<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *75,000 saw [[Fenger Academy High School (Chicago)|Fenger]] defeat [[Leo Catholic High School|Leo]] 13–0 in the 1940 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/><ref name=I-records/><ref>{{cite news| last =Segreti| first =James| title =Prep Game Forecast: Warmer; Ticket Pressure Chills Police| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =November 29, 1940}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last =Segreti | first =James | title =Fenger Whips Leo, 18–0 for City Prep Title | newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune | date =December 1, 1940}}</ref>
===1941=== *April 13 over 50,000 saw the 1941 Easter sunrise service at Soldier Field.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news| last =Evans| first =John| title =Decorate Soldiers' Field for 50,000 Worshipers| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =April 13, 1941}}</ref> *May 18, an "[[Constitution Day (United States)#I am an American Day|I am an American Day]]" event was held at Soldier Field featuring [[Helen Hayes]], [[Don Ameche]], [[Pat O'Brien (actor)|Pat O'Brien]], [[Dennis Morgan]], [[George Jessel (actor)|George Jessel]], [[Ethel Waters]], [[John Boles (actor)|John Boles]], and [[Paul Whiteman]] (with his orchestra).<ref>{{cite book |last=Rayno |first=D. |year= 2003|title=Paul Whiteman: Pioneer in American music |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=n-hYmPstZmIC&pg=PA550&lpg=PA550 |location=Lanham, Maryland|publisher=Scarecrow Press|page=555 |accessdate=April 7, 2015}}</ref> *In 1941 the [[Ringling Brothers Barnum and Bailey Circus]] visited Soldier Field's parking lot.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *A [[rodeo]] was held at Soldier Field in 1941.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *June 15 the janitors' unions held "Americanism Day" at Soldier Field. The US Drum and Bugle Corps, American Legion Bands, high school bands, and ROTC bands performed at the event.<ref name=Images/> *Over 40,000 spectators attended Soldier Field's 1941 midget auto racing championship.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *August 28 98,203 saw the [[Chicago Bears]] defeat the College All-Stars 37–13 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]]. The MVP was [[Minnesota Gophers football|Minnesota]] [[running back]] George Franck. *September 14 150,000 attended the annual [[Society of the Holy Name|Catholic Holy Name Society]] "Holy Hour" service.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news| last =Evans| first =John| title =Expect 200,000 at Holy Name Field Service| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =September 14, 1941}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title =150,000 Attend Catholic Peace Prayer Service| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =September 15, 1941}}</ref> *95,000 saw [[Leo Catholic High School|Leo]] defeat [[Tilden High School (Chicago)|Tilden]] 46–13 in the 1941 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]]. Leo was named the [[High School Football National Championship|High School Football National Champions]] that year.<ref name=catholicleague/><ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/><ref name=I-records/><ref>{{cite news | last =Segreti | first =James | title =Leo Crushes Tilden, 46–13, for City Title | newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune | date =November 30, 1941}}</ref>
===1942=== *A [[rodeo]] was held at Soldier Field in 1942 featuring movie stars [[Gene Autry]] and [[Tex Cooper]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *August 28 101,103 saw the [[Chicago Bears]] defeat the College All-Stars 21–0 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]]. The MVP was [[Minnesota Gophers football|Minnesota]] [[running back]] [[Bruce Smith (Heisman)|Bruce Smith]]. Other collegiate participants included [[Urban Odson]] *120,000 attended the 1942 [[Society of the Holy Name|Catholic Holy Name Society]] "Holy Hour" service.<ref>{{cite news| last =Evans| first =John| title =120,000 Pray for U.S. Fighting Men| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =September 14, 1942}}</ref> *In 1942 the [[Chicago Opera Company]] performed both a concert and a performance of [[Carmen]] for servicemen. The shows attracted 32,000 spectators.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *In 1942 the [[Ringling Brothers Barnum and Bailey Circus]] visited Soldier Field's parking lot.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *September 2–12 a total of 789,915 spectators attended performances of an army war show.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.selectism.com/2010/02/24/soldier-field-a-stadium-and-its-city/#slide-3 |title=SOLDIER FIELD: A STADIUM AND ITS CITY |date=February 24, 2015 |website=Selectism |access-date= December 17, 2015}}</ref> *75,000 saw [[Leo Catholic High School|Leo]] defeat [[Tilden High School (Chicago)|Tilden]] 27–14 in the 1942 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague/><ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/><ref name=I-records/><ref>{{cite news | last =Burns | first =Edward | title =Leo Defeats Tilden, 21–14, for Prep Title | newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune | date =November 29, 1942}}</ref> *December 5 [[Notre Dame Fighting Irish football|Notre Dame]] played Great Lakes in a 13–13 tie.<ref name=net/>
===1943=== *A rodeo was held at Soldier Field in 1943.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *In 1943 the [[Ringling Brothers Barnum and Bailey Circus]] visited Soldier Field's parking lot.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *September 16 a war bond show was held at Soldier Field as part of the national effort to sell war bonds. Performers included [[Judy Garland]], [[Lucille Ball]], [[Fred Astaire]]. [[Harpo Marx]], [[James Cagney]], as well as the [[Great Lakes Naval Training Station|Great Lakes Naval Training Station']] band and choir. The show raised approximately $200 million. Bond shows were also held in 1944 and 1945.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *80,000 people saw [[St. George High School (Evanston, Illinois)|St. George]] defeat [[Wendell Phillips Academy High School|Phillips]] 19–12 in the 1943 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/><ref name=I-records/><ref>{{cite news | last =Norris| first =Frank| title =St. George Beats Phillips, 19–12 for Title| newspaper =Chicago Tribune| date =November 28, 1943}}</ref>
===1944=== [[File:FDR-Soldier-Field-October-28-1944.jpg|thumb|right|250x250px|President Franklin D. Roosevelt speaking at Soldier Field]] *In June 50,000 spectators attended a national [[Sokol]] slet held at Soldier Field.<ref>{{cite news| title =Soldiers' Field Sokol Festival Thrills 50,000| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =1947}}</ref> *June 16 [[Orson Welles]] hosted a radio show at Soldier Field to benefit the Fifth War Loan Drive.<ref>[[Frank Brady (writer)|Brady, Frank]], ''Citizen Welles: A Biography of Orson Welles''. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons 1989 {{ISBN|0-684-18982-8}}</ref> *In September 1944 the [[Ringling Brothers Circus]] performed a 14-day engagement. These were amongst the Circus' first shows after the [[Hartford Circus Fire]] in July 1944 (which had resulted in over 165 deaths and 700 injuries). Due to the fire, the performances at Soldier Field were performed in the open-air, rather than under a [[Big top (circus)|big top]]. The final Sunday attracted 14,000 spectators for the matinee performance and 8,000 for the night performance. On [[Labor Day]] 9,000 attended the afternoon performance. The Circus' final performance (which occurred on a Monday night) was attended by 4,500. Excluding additional numbers that attended a 'Bond Night', the Circus attracted 145,000 despite unfavorable weather that occurred most of the opening week.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Chi Out With 145,000 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uQwEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PT37#v=onepage&q&f=false |journal=[[Billboard (magazine)|The Billboard]] |publisher=Billboard |date=September 16, 1944 |access-date=July 30, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title=Big Business For RB |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uQwEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PT54#v=onepage&q&f=false |journal=[[Billboard (magazine)|The Billboard]] |publisher=Billboard |date=September 16, 1944 |access-date=July 30, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Skidgell |first=Michael |date= 2014|title=The Hartford Circus Fire: Tragedy Under the Big Top |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IiPvAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA115#v=onepage&q&f=false |location=[[Charleston, South Carolina]], USA |publisher=The History Press |page=115 |isbn=978-1-62619-069-6 |access-date=July 30, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.circushistory.org/History/RBBB1944.htm |title=Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Route Book, 1944: The Show Goes On |last=Butler|first=Roland |website=www.circushistory.org |access-date=July 30, 2015 |quote=managed to get the circus back on the road in less than a month after the fire and carry on without its big top by giving open air performances in Akron's Rubber Bowl, the U. D. Stadium in Detroit, Chicago's mammoth Soldier Field}}</ref> *October 28 [[President of the United States]] [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] made an appearance at Soldier Field, which was the only Midwestern speaking appearance he made in his last reelection campaign. This appearance was attended by over 150,000 (with at least as many people attempting to attend that were unable to gain admission).<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=Images/><ref name=StoriedStrangeHistory/><ref name=ifbearsgo/><ref name=choose/><ref>{{cite news|last=Gentry|first=Guy |title=700,000 Tickets Out for F.D.R. Rally Tonight|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|date=October 28, 1944}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Record Crowd Hears President Give Peace Program|newspaper=[[Chicago Defender]]|date=November 4, 1944}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Roosevelt, Franklin Delano, "Campaign Address at Soldier Field, Chicago" October 28, 1944|agency=[[Associated Press]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Edwards|first=Willard |title=F.D.R. Promises New Deal No. 2; Dewey Hits at War 'Credit' Claim|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|date=October 29, 1944}}</ref><ref>[[Franklin D. Roosevelt]], "Campaign Address at [[Soldier Field]]", Oct. 28, 1944</ref><ref>{{cite news| title = Postwar Goal: 60 Million Jobs| newspaper = [[Los Angeles Times]]| date =October 29, 1944 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Record Crowd In Chicago | newspaper = [[Chicago Defender]]| date = November 4, 1944}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Kennedy|first=David M.|title=Freedom from Fear: The American People in Depression and War, 1929-1945|year=1999|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=New York City|pages=767–769; 774–775}}</ref> *[[Tilden High School (Chicago)|Tilden]] defeated [[Gordon Tech High School#Archbishop Weber High School|Weber]] 13–7 in the 1944 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/><ref>{{cite news| last =Condon| first =David| title =Tilden Beats Weber for City Title, 13 to 7| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =December 3, 1944}}</ref>
===1945=== *May 20 Soldier Field hosted a war bond show in connection with the fifth annual [[Constitution Day (United States)#I am an American Day|I am an American Day]]. The event included the presentation by General [[Alexander Vandegrift]] of the [[Medal of Honor]] to Nora Witek, whose son Frank Witek had been killed-in-action in Guam, as well as a reenactment of the [[Raising the Flag on Iwo Jima|raising of the U.S. flag]] on [[Iwo Jima]] during the [[Battle of Iwo Jima|battle of the same name]]. The flag-raising reenactment at Soldier Field was portrayed in the [[Academy Award]]-winning film [[Flags of Our Fathers (film)|Flags of Our Fathers]]. Performers at the show included [[Humphrey Bogart]] and [[Lauren Bacall]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *May 30 ([[Memorial Day]]) the [[Youth for Christ]]-movement hosted a rally to commemorate its first anniversary. Over 100,000 spectators attended. Participants included [[Charles Templeton]], [[Torrey Johnson]], and US [[military chaplain]] Robert P. Evans. The event's primary speaker was the Reverend [[Percy Crawford]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *80,000 spectators saw the 1945 [[Society of the Holy Name|Catholic Holy Name Society]] "Holy Hour" service at Soldier Field.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *July 19 the [[American Slav Congress]] hosted an event commemorating 532nd anniversary of the [[Battle of Grunwald]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *August 30 92,453 saw the [[Green Bay Packers]] defeat the College All-Stars 19–7 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]]. The MVP was [[Georgia Bulldogs football|Georgia Bulldog]] [[Charley Trippi]]. *In 1945 the [[Chicago Bears]] held their first Armed Forces Game, an exhibition game series for charity that would be played by the Bears at Soldier Field for many years.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *80,000 people saw [[Fenwick High School (Oak Park, Illinois)|Fenwick]] defeat [[Tilden High School (Chicago)|Tilden]] 20–6 in the 1945 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/><ref name=I-records/>
===1946=== *April 6 ([[Armed Forces Day|Army Day]]) President [[Harry Truman]] spoke at Soldier Field. The most important aspect of Truman's speech was that he hinted at the creation of what would later become [[NATO]]. In addition to the President, [[Mayor of Chicago|Chicago Mayor]] [[Edward J. Kelley]] and [[Chief of Staff of the United States Army|Army Chief of Staff]] (and future President of the United States) [[Dwight D. Eisenhower|General Dwight D. Eisenhower]] also spoke. The event also included a military show. The highlight of the military show was a 600 mph fly-by from two jet-powered [[Lockheed P-80 Shooting Star|P-80A]] fighters.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news | last =Wegman | first =Carl | title =Keep U.S. Mighty-Truman | newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune | date =April 7, 1946}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| title =Text of Truman Speech Given in Soldiers' Field | newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune | date =April 7, 1946}}</ref> *May 30 ([[Memorial Day]]) the [[Youth for Christ]]-movement held a well-attended rally at Soldier Field. Participants included [[Billy Graham]], [[Charles Templeton]], and [[Torrey Johnson]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *In 1946 the [[Ringling Brothers Barnum and Bailey Circus]] visited Soldier Field's parking lot.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *August 23 97,380 spectators saw the College All-Stars defeat the [[Los Angeles Rams (1946–94)|Los Angeles Rams]] 16–0 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]].<ref name=footballgeography/> The MVP was [[Michigan Wolverines football|Michigan]] [[running back]] [[Elroy Hirsch]]. *Soldier Field held a race to benefit the Chicago Park District Police Benevolent Association fund to kick-off its 1946 midget automobile racing season.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *September 13 51,962 spectators attended the [[All-America Football Conference]] [[Chicago Rockets]]' debut game. The Rockets were defeated 20-6 by the [[Cleveland Browns]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/194609130cra.htm |title=Cleveland Browns 20 at Chicago Rockets 6 Friday, September 13, 1946 |website=[[Pro-Football-Reference.com]]|access-date=November 10, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/cra/1946.htm |title=1946 Chicago Rockets |website=[[Pro-Football-Reference.com]]|access-date=November 10, 2015 }}</ref> *September 22 more than 100,000 spectators attended a Catholic Holy Hour service celebrating the newly declared [[sainthood]] of Chicago's-own [[Mother Frances Xavier Cabrini]]. The event was led by Cardinal [[Samuel Stritch]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *Ted Duncan won Soldier Field's 1946 midget racing championship.<ref name=kalracingchamps/> *85,000 people saw [[Fenger Academy High School (Chicago)|Fenger]] defeat [[Gordon Tech High School#Archbishop Weber High School|Weber]] 13–7 in the 1946 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/><ref name=I-records/>
===1947=== *June 15 12,622 attended a 25-lap midget car race. The first-place finisher was [[Ronnie Householder]], the second finisher was [[Gus Glingbell]], Sam Hanks came in third, and Teddy Duncan was fourth.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Chi Midgets Draw 12,622 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mQwEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PT79&lpg=PT79 |journal=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |publisher=Billboard |date=June 28, 1947 |access-date=October 15, 2015 }}</ref> *In 1947 auto races were held nearly every weekend from June until the end of September.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> **July 1947 25,000 spectators attended the first [[hot rod]] event at Soldier Field.<ref name=kalracinghistory/> **A midget racing event the night of July 20 was one of the earliest at Soldier Field to be televised.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> **Ted Duncan won Soldier Field's 1947 midget racing championship.<ref name=kalracingchamps/> **In August 1947 auto racing events held in a single-week were attended by over spectators total.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> ***During this week-long period 24,000 who attended a day of [[hot rod]] races sponsored by [[Granatelli]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *A [[rodeo]] competition was held at Soldier Field in July 1947 and was one of the first televised events at Soldier Field. The competition ended with its championship on July 20.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *In 1947 the [[Ringling Brothers Barnum and Bailey Circus]] visited Soldier Field's parking lot.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *At the same time as the circus, a [[General Motors]] car expo was held in Soldier Field's parking lot.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *In 1947 more than 20,000 watched a soccer match between a Chicago all-star team and a team provided by [[Hapoel]]. The game ended in a tie.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *August 22 105,840 saw the College All-Stars defeat the [[Chicago Bears]] 16–0 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=footballgeography/> The MVP was [[Illinois Fighting Illini football|Illinois]] [[running back]] [[Buddy Young|Claude Young]]. *[[Austin Community Academy High School|Austin]] defeated [[Leo Catholic High School|Leo]] 13–12 in the 1947 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/><ref>{{cite news | last =Condon | first =David | title =Austin Beats Leo, 13 to 12, for City Title| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune | date =November 30, 1947}}</ref> *In 1947 the [[Chicago Bears]]' annual Armed Forces Game was held at Soldier Field for the first time. The Bears'opponent was the [[Washington Redskins]]. Chicago won the game 28-0. The Armed Forces Game raised proceeds for the relief funds of the four branches of the US Armed Services, and was held annually from 1943 through 1970 (and was held at the Bears' home stadium, [[Wrigley Field]], for a number of those years).
===1948=== *August 22 101,220 saw the [[History of the Chicago Cardinals|Chicago Cardinals]] defeat the College All-Stars 28–0 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]]. The MVP was [[Kentucky Wildcats football|Kentucky]] [[running back]] [[Jay Rodemeyer]]. *[[Jim Rathmann]] launched his racing career at Soldier Field in 1948. He would later win the [[Indy 500]] in [[1960 Indy 500|1960]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *[[Johnny McDowell]] won Soldier Field's 1948 midget racing championship.<ref name = kalracingchamps/> *In 1948 2x Olympic gold medalist swimmer [[Vicki Draves]] turned professional when she made her debut in [[Larry Crosby]]'s "Rhapsody in Swimtime" aquatic show at Soldier Field.<ref>{{citation|last=McLellan|first=Dennis|title=Victoria Manalo Draves dies at 85; Olympic gold medal diver|newspaper=[[The Los Angeles Times]]|date=April 29, 2010|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/obituaries/la-me-victoria-draves-20100429,0,4537019.story}}</ref> *In 1948 the [[Ringling Brothers Barnum and Bailey Circus]] visited Soldier Field's parking lot.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *[[Robert Lindblom Math & Science Academy|Lindblom]] defeated [[Fenwick High School (Oak Park, Illinois)|Fenwick]] 13–7 in the 1948 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/>
===1949=== *April 17, due to cold and snowy weather, only about 35,000 attended the Easter sunrise service at Soldier Field.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news| last =Evans| first =John| title =Devout Throngs Pay Homage to Risen Savior| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =April 17, 1949}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| last =Bowman| first =Bowman| title =Sun, Snow, and a Parade of Spectacular Easter Hats| newspaper =Chicago Tribune| date =April 11, 1982}}</ref> *In 1949 the [[Ringling Brothers Barnum and Bailey Circus]] visited Soldier Field's parking lot.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *[[Al Jolson]] again headlined the Chicagoland Music Festival in 1949, having previously headlined in 1934.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *August 22 93,780 saw the [[Philadelphia Eagles]] defeat the College All-Stars 38–0 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]]. The MVP was [[Notre Dame Fighting Irish football|Notre Dame]] [[offensive lineman]] [[Bill Fischer (football player)|Bill Fischer]]. *June 19 President [[Harry Truman|Truman]] spoke at the convention of the Ancient Arabic Order of Nobles of the Mystic Shrine ([[Shriners]]) marking the group's 75th anniversary. This event was one of the first at Soldier Field to be televised. The event featured one of the largest parades in Chicago's history. The parade preceding the event at Soldier Field featured over 15,000 Shriners from 1,000 American and Canadian chapters of the group and 130 bands. The parade covered three miles and lasted five-hours. The parade was seen by approximately 500,000 spectators. Hollywood legend [[Harold Lloyd]] walked in the parade, and at the end of the convention held at Soldier Field he was named "Imperial Potentate", the national leader of the group.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=StoriedStrangeHistory/><ref>{{cite news | title =Democrats Pay $10,000 to Hear President Talk | newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune | date =July 20, 1949}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| title =Shriners' Parade Dazzles Chicago | newspaper =New York Times | date =July 20, 1949}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Donald S. Dawson, oral history interview|date= August 8, 1977|pages= 26–27|work= Truman Library |url=http://www.trumanlibrary.org/oralhist/dawsond.htm|accessdate= July 8, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| title =Truman Hints New Trouble Faces Stalin| newspaper =Los Angeles Times|agency =Associated Press| date = July 20, 1949}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| last =McCutcheon | first =John | title =500,000 Watch Gay Parade of 15,000 Nobles | newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune | date =July 20, 1949}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last =Remenih | first =Anton | title =100 Man Hours Used to Put Truman on Air | newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune | date =July 31, 1949}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last =Folliard | first =Elward T. | title =President Rejects 'Invevitable' War in Shrine Address; Warns of ERP Cut | newspaper = Washington Post | date =July 20, 1949}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title =Chairman Puts Bite on Party Workers for Democrat Picnic | newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune | date =July 28, 1949 }}</ref> *[[Gilbert "Skippy" Michaels]] won Soldier Field's 1949 [[Hurricane Hot Rod Association]] [[hot rod]] racing season, placing above future-[[Indianapolis 500|Indy 500]] champions [[Pat Flaherty (racing driver)|Pat Flaherty]] and [[Jim Rathmann]].<ref name=kalracinghistory/> *[[Eddie Haddad]] won Soldier Field's 1949 midget racing championship.<ref name = kalracingchamps/> *Gil "Skippy" Michaels won Soldier Field's 1949 stock car championship.<ref name=kalracingchamps/> *[[Pat Flaherty (racing driver)|Pat Flaherty]] won the [[hot rod]] division Soldier Field's 1949 racing championship.<ref name=kalracingchamps/> *October 28 11,249 spectators saw the [[Chicago Hornets]], who were formerly known as the Chicago Rockets, lost 14-24 to the [[Los Angeles Dons]] in what would ultimately be the Hornets' final last-ever home game<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/194910280cra.htm |title=Los Angeles Dons 24 at Chicago Hornets 14 Friday, October 28, 1949 |website=[[Pro-Football-Reference.com]]|access-date=November 10, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/cra/1949.htm |title=1949 Chicago Hornets |website=[[Pro-Football-Reference.com]]|access-date=November 10, 2015 }}</ref> *[[Schurz High School|Schurz]] defeated [[Fenwick High School (Oak Park, Illinois)|Fenwick]] 20–7 in the 1949 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/>
== 1950s == [[File:Douglas MacArthur speaking at Soldier Field HD-SN-99-03036.JPEG|thumb|right|250px|Gen. Douglas MacArthur addressing an audience of 50,000]]
===1950=== *August 11 88,885 saw the College All-Stars defeat the [[Philadelphia Eagles]] 17 -7 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]].<ref name=footballgeography/> The MVP was [[North Carolina Tar Heels football|North Carolina]] [[running back]] [[Charlie Justice (American football player)|Charlie Justice]].<ref name=Philly/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=aeFQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=DiQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6546%2C3817311 |newspaper=Milwaukee Journal |last=Kuechle |first=Oliver E. |title=College stars spring startling upset |date=August 12, 1950 |page=6}}</ref> *70,000 spectators attended the 1950 Chicagoland Music Festival. Among the performers was [[Alec Templeton]].<ref>{{cite news |last=McCutcheon |first=John Jr. |date=August 20, 2015 |title= 70,000 Cheer Music Festival Pageantry |url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1950/08/20/page/1/article/70-000-cheer-music-festival-pageantry |newspaper=Chicago Sunday Tribune |access-date=November 15, 2015 }}</ref> *[[Potsy Goache]] won Soldier Field's 1950 midget car championship.<ref name =kalracingchamps/> *In 1950 the [[Ringling Brothers Barnum and Bailey Circus]] visited Soldier Field's parking lot.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *[[Jim Rathmann]] won Soldier Field's 1950 [[stock car racing|stock car]] championship.<ref name=kalracingchamps/> *[[Mount Carmel High School (Chicago)|Mount Carmel]], coached by [[Terry Brennan]], defeated [[Lane Technical College Prep High School|Lane Tech]] 45–20 in the 1950 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]]. The Mount Carmel team was led by [[quarterback]] [[List of Notre Dame Fighting Irish starting quarterbacks|Tom Carey]].<ref name=catholicleague/><ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/><ref name=hawthornes>{{cite news |last=Milbert |first=Neil |date=July 6, 1986|title=Hawthorne's Quarterback |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1986-07-06/sports/8602180443_1_robert-carey-father-coaches|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|location=Chicago |access-date=April 1, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| last =Doherty|first =Robert| title =Lane Indians Find Caravan Much Too Strong for Ambush|newspaper =Chicago Tribune|date =December 3, 1950}}</ref>
===1951=== *In April [[General of the Army (United States)|US General]] during World War II [[Douglas MacArthur]] addressed a crowd of 50,000 at Soldier Field during his first visit to the United States in 14 years.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=Images/><ref name=choose/> *August 17 92,180 saw the saw the [[Cleveland Browns]] defeat the College All-Stars 33–0 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]]. The MVP was [[Texas Longhorns football|Texas Longhorn]] [[Bud McFadin|Lewis McFadin]]. *In 1951 the [[Ringling Brothers Barnum and Bailey Circus]] visited Soldier Field's parking lot.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *[[Jim Rathmann]] won Soldier Field's 1951 [[stock car racing|stock car]] championship.<ref name=kalracingchamps/> *[[Mount Carmel High School (Chicago)|Mount Carmel]], coached by [[Terry Brennan]], defeated [[Robert Lindblom Math & Science Academy|Lindblom]] 19–6 in the 1951 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague/><ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/>
===1952=== *May 4 Soldier Field hosted the annual Chicago Park District Police Benevolet race program.<ref name="kalracing3">{{cite web |url=http://www.kalracing.com/autoracing/soldier_field_photo_scrapbook_3.htm|title= Soldier field photo scrapbook #3|website=www.kalracing.com|access-date=February 18, 2015}}</ref> *August 15 88,316 saw the [[Los Angeles Rams (1946–94)|Los Angeles Rams]] defeat the College All-Stars 10–7 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]]. The MVP was [[Kentucky Wildcats football|Kentucky]] [[quarterback]] [[Babe Parilli]]. *In 1952 the [[Ringling Brothers Barnum and Bailey Circus]] visited Soldier Field's parking lot.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *In 1952 [[Sal Tovella]] won his first feature [[stock car racing|stock car race]] at Soldier Field. A native Chicagoan, Tovella's racing career started at Soldier Field in the early 1950.<ref name=kalracing3/> *Gil "Skippy" Michaels won Soldier Field's 1952 stock car championship.<ref name=kalracingchamps/> *[[Mount Carmel High School (Chicago)|Mount Carmel]], coached by [[Terry Brennan]], defeated [[Austin Community Academy High School|Austin]] 27–19 in the 1952 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague/><ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/>
===1953=== *August 14 93,818 saw the [[Detroit Lions]] defeat the College All-Stars 24–10 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]].
