The MVP was [[Texas Longhorns football|Texas Longhorn]] [[Gib Dawson]] *In 1953 the [[Ringling Brothers Barnum and Bailey Circus]] visited Soldier Field's parking lot.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *[[St. George High School (Evanston, Illinois)|St. George]] defeated [[Austin Community Academy High School|Austin]] 38–12 in the 1953 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/> *[[Tom Pistone]] won Soldier Field's 1953 [[stock car racing|stock car]] championships.<ref name=kalracingchamps/><ref name=kalracing4/>
===1954=== *May 2, during a "tag racing" motor event at Soldier Field, two cars caught fire. The track crew was fast to put-out the fire.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *May 8 a crowd of 13,000 watched the [[West Germany|West German]] [[association football]] team [[Dortmund Borussia]] beat the English team [[Plymouth Argyle]] 4-0.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *May 16 the [[Chicago Park District]]'s Police Benevolent Association sponsored its 9th annual Golf Trophy race at Soldier Field. More than 30,000 tickets were sold.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *June 6 a car at a racing event hit a barricade and knocked several timbers loose, but this did not cause any serious damage or injury.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *June 15 about 6,000 spectators attended a racing event featuring the [[John Francis "Irish" Horan|"Irish" Horan]]'s Lucky [[Hell Drivers]]. Alongside "Irish" Horan in this event was [[Bill Vukovich]], who had just won a second-consecutive [[Indy 500]]. *June 25 a mere 5,026 spectators attended motor racing events held at Soldier Field. This was unusual, as racing events held at Soldier Field around this time would often attract over twenty-thousand spectators. The races were popular amongst families. Nearly twenty-years after the last race was held at Soldier Field, during his tenure as the head of [[True Value Hardware]], [[Dan Cotter]] commented on the origin of his [[motorsports]] fandom, telling a ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' reporter, "Dad took me to the midget races at Soldier Field when I was eleven. I was hooked."<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *July 23 Soldier Field hosted the midget auto racing 100 Lap National Championship,. Racers included [[Tony Bettenhausen]], [[Duke Nalon]], [[Art Cross]], [[Mike Nazurek]], [[Frank Burany]], [[Roy Newman]], [[Gene Hartley]], [[Jimmy Knight]], [[Cal Niday]], [[Johnny Roberts]], [[Jack Bates]], amongst others.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *July 25 Soldier Field hosted the [[Hurricane Hot Rod Association]] Mid-Season Championship. *July 30 Soldier Field hosted the [[Circuit of Champions]] National Championship for Late Model Stocks. The primary event was a 120-lap race.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *August 13 93,470 saw the saw the [[Detroit Lions]] defeat the College All-Stars 31–6 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]]. The MVP was [[Texas Longhorns football|Texas]] [[defensive end]] Carlton Massey. *August 15 over 125,000 attended as the [[World Council of Churches]] held the Ecumenical Festival of Faith, which served as the opening ceremony for two-weeks of meetings that the World Council held in Chicago and [[Evanston, Illinois|Evanston]] (and even included a speech by President [[Dwight Eisenhower|Eisenhower]]). The ceremony featured a cast of 4,000 and was arranged by [[Helen Kromer]]. [[Henry P. Van Dusen]], president of the [[New York Union Theological Seminary]], proclaimed the event to have been "the most widely representative, most truly 'ecumenical' assemblage of the followers of Christ who have ever met 'in one accord in one place.'" Delegates attended even from four nations located behind the "[[Iron Curtain]]" ([[Czechoslavakia]], [[East Germany]], Hungary, and [[Yugoslavia]]). The ceremony was opened with a speech by [[Mayor of Chicago|Chicago mayor]] [[Martin Kennelly]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> **Hours prior to the ceremony, Soldier Field's convention halls hosted a 1,600-person banquet for delegates.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *August 21 [[Liberace]] headlined the 25th annual Chicagoland Music Festival. [[Jack Webb]] appeared at the event to promote the [[Chicago Theatre]] premiere of the film [[Dragnet (franchise)#Dragnet (1954)|Dragnet]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news |title=Liberace, Colorful Pageantry for Music Festival |url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1954/08/15/page/220/article/liberace-colorful-pageantry-for-music-festival |newspaper=Chicago Tribune |date= August 15, 1954|access-date=March 13, 2015}}</ref> *September 8 what many regard to have been Soldier Field's largest crowd ever, 260,000 spectators, attended the Marian Year tribute of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago. 180,000 were inside of the stadium, while another 80,000 gathered outside of the stadium and listened via loudspeakers. The event was led by Cardinal [[Samuel Stritch]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=StoriedStrangeHistory/><ref name=ifbearsgo/><ref name=choose/> *In 1954 160,000 spectators saw the [[Ringling Brothers Barnum and Bailey Circus]] while it visited Soldier Field's parking lot.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *54,000 spectators saw [[Fenger Academy High School (Chicago)|Fenger]] defeated [[Mount Carmel High School (Chicago)|Mount Carmel]] 20–13 in the 1954 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/> *[[Tom Pistone]] won Soldier Field's 1954 [[stock car racing|stock car]] championships.<ref name=kalracingchamps/><ref name=kalracing4/> *In 1954 an international [[ski jumping]] championship was held at Soldier Field by the Norge Ski Club.<ref name=pridmore/><ref name=StoriedStrangeHistory/><ref name=skisprung/>
===1955=== *May 25 the [[Chicago Park District]] held its annual Police Benevolent Association race. [[Mayor of Chicago|Mayor]] [[Richard J. Daley]] handed the trophy to the winner. *July 13 former President of the United States [[Harry S. Truman]] again spoke at another [[Shriners]] convention held at Soldier Field. The event was dubbed "Shrinerama" and was attended by more than 58,000 spectators. In addition to a speech from Truman, other notable facets of the event include a band of 1,500 Shriner musicians, a performance from a 1,000-voice choir, circus acts, military drills, and a mock rematch between [[Jack Dempsey]] and [[Gene Tunney]] (who had both famously faced-off for the heavyweight title at Soldier Field in the 1927 [[The Long Count Fight|Long Count Fight]]). The event concluded with a fireworks display.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=pridmore/><ref>{{cite news | title =58,000 at 'Shrinerama'; Hear Truman at Dinner | newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune | date =July 14, 1955}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| title =Mr. Truman Tells Shriners to Back U.N. Peace Efforts| newspaper =Holland Evening Sentinel | location =Holland, Michigan | publisher =United Press| date =July 14, 1955}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| title =Ex-President Reviews Parade| newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune| date =July 13, 1955}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| title =Ex-President Reviews Parade | newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune | date =July 13, 1955 }}</ref> *August 12 75,000 saw the College All-Stars defeat the [[Cleveland Browns]] 30–27 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]].<ref name=footballgeography/> The MVP was [[Notre Dame Fighting Irish football|Notre Dame]] [[quarterback]] [[Ralph Guglielmi]]. *In 1955 the [[Ringling Brothers Barnum and Bailey Circus]] visited Soldier Field's parking lot. This was the final time it would visit Soldier Field.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *[[Chicago Vocational Career Academy|Chicago Vocational]] defeated [[Gordon Tech High School#Archbishop Weber High School|Weber]] 6–0 in the 1955 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/> *[[Tom Pistone]] won Soldier Field's 1955 [[stock car racing|stock car]] championships.<ref name=kalracingchamps/><ref name=kalracing4/>
===1956=== *August 10 75,000 saw the [[Cleveland Browns]] defeat the College All-Stars 26–0 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]]. The MVP was [[Maryland Terrapins football|Maryland]] [[linebacker]] [[Bob Pellegrini]]. *July 4 attendance at the Armed Legion Show was lower than usual. Featured at the event were Stock Yards Post's Kiltie Band, [[Cook County]] Legion commander [[Milton Applebaum]], ''Alarno's Trained Pork Chops'' (a [[domestic pig|pig]] stunt troupe), two different trained [[chimpanzee]] groups, [[tame bear|dancing bear]]s, [[clown]]s, car jumping [[stunt]]s, and [[firework]]s.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *Among the 8,000 performers at the 1956 Chicagoland Music Festival were [[Al G. Wright]], [[Richard Tucker]], the Skokie American Indians drum and bugle corps (the national champions). Special guests at the included [[Richard Rodgers]] and [[Oscar Hammerstein II|Oscar Hammerstein]]. A men's and a women's singing contest were held at the event, the winners performing on the ''[[Ed Sullivan Show]]'' the following night. The competition was judged by [[Rosa Raisa]], Sonia Sharnova, and Louis Sudler. This was the final edition of the Chicagoland Music Festival.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news |last=Maxwell |first=Philip |date=August 12, 1956 |title=NIGHT OF SONG AWAITS 80,000 AT MUSIC FETE |url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1956/08/12/page/14/article/night-of-song-awaits-80-000-at-music-fete/ |newspaper=Chicago Sunday Tribune |page=1 |access-date=November 15, 2015 }}</ref> *July 21 [[Fireball Roberts|Glenn "Fireball" Roberts]] won the only [[NASCAR]] [[Sprint Cup Series|Grand National 100]] (the modern-day Sprint Cup) race held at the stadium's short track which ran across the old configuration. Roberts beat [[Jim Pascal]] but only a car's-length. Roberts passed Pascal only in the 194th lap out of 200 laps total. The order that drivers came in following Roberts then Pascal was [[Ralph Moody]], [[Speedy Thompson]], [[Frank Mundy]], [[Buck Baker]], [[Bill Champion (racing driver)|Bill Champion]], [[Paul Goldsmith]], [[Joy Fair]], [[Lee Petty]], [[Bob Esposito]], [[Frank Edwards (race car driver)|Frank Edwards]], [[Bill Massey (racing driver)|Bill Massey]], [[Chuck Mesler]], [[Al Watkins]], [[Sal Tovella]], [[Billy Myers]], [[Herb Thomas]], [[Darvin Randahl]], [[Fred Lorenzen]], [[Bob Chaunce]], [[Tom Pistone]], [[Bill Vesler]], [[Kenny Paulsen]], [[Ray Crowley]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://fantasyracingcheatsheet.com/nascar/races/results/1956/soldier-field/1956-33/466|title=OFFICIAL RACE RESULTS 1956-33||website=fantasyracingcheatsheet.com|access-date=February 8, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.laidbackracing.com/TheOldDays/SoldierFieldChicago.html|title=Checkered Flag Waves for NASCAR Legends story – Soldier Field|work=laidbackracing.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Higgins |first=Tom |url=http://www.thatsracin.com/2010/07/09/40300/chicagos-storied-soldier-field.html |title=Chicago's storied Soldier Field was once a NASCAR track |publisher=www.thatsracin.com |date=July 9, 2010 |accessdate=March 10, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110104002242/http://www.thatsracin.com/2010/07/09/40300/chicagos-storied-soldier-field.html |archivedate=January 4, 2011 |df= }}</ref> *Two [[NASCAR]] [[NASCAR Convertible Division|Convertible Division]] races were held at Soldier Field in 1956.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kalracing.com/autoracing/Soldier_Field_Photoscrapbook.htm|title= Soldier field photo scrapbook|website=www.kalracing.com|access-date=February 18, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nascar.com/en_us/news-media/featured-shows/2013/9/12/sprint-cup-series-chicagoland-throwback-thursday.html|title=Throwback Thursday: Chicagoland|work=[[NASCAR]]|date=September 12, 2013|accessdate=September 12, 2013}}</ref><ref name="NASCAR">{{cite web |url=http://www.nascar.com/en_us/news-media/articles/2012/09/15/dcaraviello-soldier-field-racing.html |title= CARAVIELLO: IN CHICAGO, NOTHING LIKE A RACE AT SOLDIER FIELD|last=Caraviello|first=David|date= September 15, 2012 |website=www.nascar.com |publisher=[[NASCAR]] |accessdate=July 30, 2014}}</ref> *In 1956 38,000 saw [[Tom Pistone]] win the Soldier Field 100. Pistone won a record 38 motor race events at Soldier Field.<ref name=NASCAR/> *[[Fred Lorenzen]] won Soldier Field's 1956 [[stock car racing|stock car]] championship.<ref name=kalracingchamps/> *[[Bert Olson]] won Soldier Field's 1956 rookie/novice [[stock car racing|stock car]] championship.<ref name=kalracingchamps/> *[[Leo Catholic High School|Leo]] defeated [[Calumet High School (Chicago)|Calumet]] 12–0 in the 1956 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]]. Jim Arneberg, who was a star [[Lineman (American football)|lineman]] for the 1941 and 1942 Leo teams coached the Leo Lions in this Prep Bowl, becoming the first person to both play and coach in the Prep Bowl.<ref name=catholicleague/><ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/>
===1957=== *June 15 Soldier Field hosted a 50-lap [[NASCAR]] Grand National race. While considered to be a [[Sprint Cup Series|Grand National]] event at the time it was held, the event does not currently appear on NASCAR's lists of Grand National events held that year. The event was won by [[Bill Brown (NASCAR driver)|Bill Brown]]<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *June 29 Soldier Field hosted a 100-lap [[NASCAR]] event, which was won by [[Glen Wood]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *August 9 75,000 saw the [[New York Giants]] defeat the College All-Stars 22–12 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]]. The MVP was [[Stanford Cardinal football|Stanford]] [[quarterback]] [[John Brodie]]. *[[List of schools of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago#Former high schools in Chicago|Mendel]] defeated [[Calumet High School (Chicago)|Calumet]] 6–0 in the 1957 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]], scoring the game's only points with a [[Hail Mary pass]] in the final play.<ref name=catholicleague/><ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/> *In 1957 [[NASCAR]] held its final [[NASCAR Convertible Division|Convertible Division]] event at Soldier Field, which was won by [[Glenn Wood]]. This was the final NASCAR event held at Soldier Field.<ref name=NASCAR/> *[[Don Oldenberg]] won Soldier Field's 1957 stock car championship.<ref name=kalracingchamps/> *[[Lou Hoehn]] won Soldier Field's 1957 rookie/novice[[stock car racing|stock car]] championship.<ref name=kalracingchamps/>
===1958=== *August 14 70,000 saw the College All-Stars defeat the [[Detroit Lions]] 35–19 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]].<ref name=footballgeography/> The MVPs were [[Illinois Fighting Illini football|Illinois]] [[Halfback (American football)|halfback]]/[[wide receiver]] [[Bobby Mitchell]] and [[Michigan State Spartans football|Michigan State]] [[quarterback]] [[Jim Ninowski]]. *The 1958 Chicagland Music Festival featured a reenactment of the [[Lincoln-Douglas Debates]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *In the Summer of 1958 the [[Christiana Brothers Circus]] visited Soldier Field's parking lot for 17 performance dates.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *[[Don Oldenberg]] won Soldier Field's 1958 [[stock car racing|stock car]] championship.<ref name=kalracingchamps/> *[[Marty Boecher]] won Soldier Field's 1958 rookie/novice[[stock car racing|stock car]] championship.<ref name=kalracingchamps/> *[[Austin Community Academy High School|Austin]] defeated [[Fenwick High School (Oak Park, Illinois)|Fenwick]] 20–7 in the 1958 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/>
===1959=== [[File:Abanderado en los juegos panamericanos 1959 (cropped).jpg|thumbnail|Opening ceremonies of the [[1959 Pan American Games]]. Wrestler [[Mario Tovar González]] can be seen serving as [[Mexico]]'s flag bearer.]] *August 14 70,000 saw the [[Baltimore Colts]] defeat the College All-Stars 29–0 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]]. The MVP was [[Michigan Wolverines football|Michigan]] [[running back]] [[Bob Ptacek]]. *August 27 Soldier Field hosted the opening ceremonies of the [[1959 Pan American Games]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=ifbearsgo/> The opening was held in sunny 90 °F (32 °C) heat, and was attended by 40,000 spectators. *Soldier Field hosted the [[Athletics at the 1959 Pan American Games|athletics component]] of the [[1959 Pan American Games]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> Notable competitors included the US' [[Greg Bell (athlete)|Greg Bell]], [[Don Bragg]], [[Earlene Brown]], [[Lee Calhoun]], [[Lester Carney]], [[Dick Cochran]], [[Hal Connolly]], [[Josh Culbreath]], [[Clifton Cushman]], [[Isabelle Daniels]], [[Bill Dellinger]], [[Charles Dumas]], [[Jim Grelle]], [[Barbara Jones (athlete)|Barbara Jones]], [[Hayes Jones]], [[Dallas Long]], [[Margaret Matthews]], [[Parry O'Brien]], [[Al Oerter]], [[Bo Roberson]], [[Wilma Rudolph]], [[Bill Sharpe (athlete)|Bill Sharpe]], [[Lucinda Williams (athlete)|Lucia Williams]], [[Dyrol Burleson]], [[Al Cantello]], [[Phil Coleman (athlete)|Phil Coleman]], [[Dave Edstrom]], [[Phil Mulkey]], [[Tom Murphy (athlete)|Tom Murphy]], [[Ray Norton]], [[Bob Backus]], [[Ann Marie Flynn]], [[Albert Hall (athlete)|Albert Hall]] and [[Max Truex]]; [[Puerto Rico]]'s [[Rolando Cruz]]; [[Trinidad and Tobago]]'s [[Clifton Bertrand]] and [[Mike Agostini]]; [[Chile]]'s [[Marlene Ahrens]]; [[Cuba]]'s [[Enrique Figuerola]] and [[Bertha Díaz]]; [[Jamaica]]'s [[George Kerr (runner)|George Kerr]], [[Malcolm Spence (Jamaican athlete)|Malcolm Spence]], [[Mel Spence]] and [[Dennis Johnson (athlete)|Dennis Johnson]]; Canada's [[Doug Kyle]], [[Sally McCallum]], [[George Stulac]] and [[Alice Whitty]]; Brazil's [[Adhemar da Silva]] and [[Wanda dos Santos]]; [[Argentina]]'s [[Osvaldo Suárez]]; [[Mexico]]'s [[Alfredo Tinoco]]. Also among the athletes competing was future [[Prime Minister of Antigua and Barbuda|Prime Minister]] of [[Antigua and Barbuda]] [[Lester Bird]]. *September 7 Soldier Field hosted the closing ceremonies of the [[1959 Pan American Games]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *November 29 the [[Arizona Cardinals|Cardinals]] played their last home game as the [[Chicago Cardinals (NFL, 1920–1959)|Chicago Cardinals]]. The following season they [[St. Louis Cardinals (NFL, 1960–1987)|moved to St. Louis]] (and later would leave St. Louis for Arizona).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wbez.org/blogs/john-r-schmidt/2012-11/farewell-big-red-103931 |title=Farewell to the Big Red |last=Schmidt |first=John R. |date=November 29, 2012 |website= wbez.org|publisher=[[WBEZ]] |accessdate=January 17, 2015}}</ref> *[[Lane Technical College Prep High School|Lane Tech]] defeated [[Fenwick High School (Oak Park, Illinois)|Fenwick]] 19–0 in the 1959 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/> *[[NASCAR Convertible Division]] race<ref>{{cite web |url=http://autoweek.com/article/nascar/look-back-soldier-field-chicago-once-hosted-nascar-cup-race |title=Remember when: Soldier Field in Chicago once hosted a NASCAR Cup race |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=January 18, 2018 |website=autoweek.com |publisher=Auto Week |access-date=January 22, 2017 |quote=}}</ref>
== 1960s == [[File:King portrait.gif|thumb|right|100x100px|[[Martin Luther King, Jr.]] led two [[Chicago Freedom Movement]] rallies at Soldier Field]]
===1960=== *August 12 70,000 saw the [[Baltimore Colts]] defeat the College All-Stars 32–7 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]]. The MVP was [[Cincinnati Bearcats]] end Jim Leo. *Soldier Field hosted the 1960 Western [[Golden Gloves]]. [[Muhammad Ali]] fought in this event, and received the Outstanding Fighter trophy for his weight class.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.collegeofidaho.edu/ourstories/spanakos |title=NICK AND PETE SPANAKOS '60 |website=www.collegeofidaho.edu|publisher=College of Idaho|accessdate=August 30, 2014}}</ref> *93,000 spectators attended two performances of the Police show, headlined by [[Jack Paar]]. Other performers included Wimpy the Clown, an acrobat named Bettina, and Trans-World Airdevils auto stunts. Stanley R. Sarbaneck, president of the benevolent association, spoke at the event.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *[[Bryant Tucker]] won Soldier Field's 1960 [[stock car racing|stock car]] championship.<ref name=kalracingchamps/> *[[Mount Carmel High School (Chicago)|Mount Carmel]], coached by [[List of Notre Dame Fighting Irish starting quarterbacks|Tom Carey]] (the older brother of their [[quarterback]] Tony), defeated [[William Howard Taft High School (Chicago)|Taft]] 27–8 in the 1960 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]]. Tom Carey became one of the first individuals to both play and coach in a Prep Bowl, having won it as a quarterback exactly ten years earlier. Jim Arneberg, who was a star [[Lineman (American football)|lineman]] for the 1941 and 1942 [[Leo Catholic High School|Leo]] teams, had previously coached the Leo Lions to a 12-0 victory over their neighborhood rival [[Calumet High School (Chicago)|Calumet]] in the 1956 Prep Bowl<ref name=catholicleague/><ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/><ref name=hawthornes/>
===1961=== *July 28 18,000 spectators attended double-header [[association football|soccer]] matches at Soldier Field. The first match was between a Chicago all-star team and the US national amateur champion [[Saint Louis Kutis]]. The Chicago all-stars won with a surprising score of 6-0. This game was followed by a benefit game for [[March of Dimes]] pinning [[Vienna]]'s Rapid team against the Español of [[Barcelona]]. Vienna won 5-4.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *August 4 66,000 saw the [[Philadelphia Eagles]] defeat the College All-Stars 28–14 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]]. The MVP was [[UCLA Bruins football|UCLA]] [[quarterback]] [[Billy Kilmer]]. *[[Bryant Tucker]] won Soldier Field's 1961 [[stock car racing|stock car]] championship.<ref name=kalracingchamps/> *83,750 people saw [[Gordon Tech High School#Archbishop Weber High School|Weber]] defeat [[Lane Technical College Prep High School|Lane Tech]] 14–12 in the 1961 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]]. Weber defeated Lane Tech after a [[muffed punt]] [[Snap (American and Canadian football)|snap]] in the last minute after Lane [[fumble]]d the ball far in its own territory with only minutes remaining.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=catholicleague/><ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/><ref name=I-records/>
===1962=== *June 17 116,000 spectators attended a [[Billy Graham]] crusade at Soldier Field. This event followed nineteen days of crussades that Graham had held at the nearby [[McCormick Place]] convention center. Those events averaged 37,000 spectators a day (the opening speech alone was attended by 33,000).<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=choose/> *The America FC of [[Rio de Janeiro]] defeated the Palmero of Italy 3-2 in a match held at Soldier Field. This was one of several [[International Soccer League]] matches that were held at Soldier Field in 1962, which altogether attracted a total of 50,000 spectators.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *August 3 65,000 saw the [[Green Bay Packers]] defeat the College All-Stars 42–20 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]]. The MVP was [[Kansas Jayhawks football|Kansas]] [[quarterback]] [[John Hadl]]. *[[Bryant Tucker]] won Soldier Field's 1962 [[stock car racing|stock car]] championship.<ref name=kalracingchamps/> *91,328 people saw [[Fenwick High School (Oak Park, Illinois)|Fenwick]] defeat [[Carl Schurz High School|Schurz]] 40–0 in the 1962 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]]. This ended a 10-0 season for the Fenwick Friars (in which they outscored their opponents 317-32). In the Prep Bowl game, Fenwick's Jim DiLullo ran for 224 yards and scored five [[touchdowns]] on just 12 [[carry (American football)|carries]]. This was the third most-attended Prep Bowl to date.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=catholicleague/><ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/><ref name=I-records/>
===1963=== *In 1963 nine [[International Soccer League]] matches were held at Soldier Field. This included the first game of a two-game championship series.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *August 2 65,000 saw the College All-Stars defeat the [[Green Bay Packers]] 20–17 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]].<ref name=footballgeography/> The MVP was [[Wisconsin Badgers football|Wisconsin]] [[quarterback]] [[Ron Vander Kelen]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=R80wAAAAIBAJ&sjid=1xAEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7296%2C487890|newspaper=Milwaukee Sentinel|last=Lea|first=Bud|title=All-Stars upset Packers|date=August 3, 1963|page=2-part 2 }}</ref> This was the final game in which the All-Stars beat their NFL competitors.<ref name=footballgeography/> *August 17 [[Lawrence Weller]] headlined the 34th annual Chicagoland Music Festival. [[Bob Bell (actor)|Bob Bell]] performed as [[Bozo the Clown]] alongside other [[Bozo's Circus]] cast members at the beginning of the Festival.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news |last=Maxwell |first=Philip |date=June 21, 1963 |title=FESTIVAL BAND OF WELK HAS ONE CHICAGOAN |url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1963/07/21/page/29/article/festival-band-of-welk-has-one-chicagoan |newspaper=Chicago Tribune |access-date=March 13, 2015}}</ref> *[[Sal Tovella]] won Soldier Field's 1963 [[stock car racing|stock car]] championship.<ref name=kalracingchamps/> *November 2 Soldier Field hosted the [[Army Black Knights football|Army]]–[[Air Force Falcons football|Air Force]] game. It was the first game between two military colleges at Soldier Field since the 1927 [[Army-Navy Game]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news|last =Wiedrich|first =Robert|title =City to Welcome 5,000 Cadets|newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune|date =November 1, 1963}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last =Bartlett|first =Charles|title =72,000 to See Air Force and Army Clash|newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune|date =November 2, 1963}}</ref> President of the United States [[John F. Kennedy]] was scheduled to make an appearance at halftime as part of his reelection campaign. Kennedy had worked with [[Mayor of Chicago|Chicago Mayor]] [[Richard J. Daley]] in attracting the game to Chicago.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news| title =Pageantry on a Grand Day for Football | newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune | date =November 3, 1963 }}</ref> *81,270 saw [[St. Rita of Cascia High School|St. Rita]] defeat [[Chicago Vocational Career Academy|Chicago Vocational]] 42–7 in the 1963 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]]. The St. Rita squad was named the [[High School Football National Championship|High School Football National Champions]] that year. Mendel [[Halfback (American football)|halfback]] John Byrne scored five touchdowns and six extra points.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=catholicleague/><ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/><ref name=I-records/>
===1964=== *Three [[International Soccer League]] games were held at Soldier Field in 1964.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *An invitational [[association football|soccer]] tournament was held at Soldier Field. The tourmament was promoted by local amateur teams, and also featured three international matches. The event culminated in a team from [[Liverpool]] winning the [[Otto Kerner, Jr.|Governor Otto Kerner]] Trophy.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *May 3 [[Bill Lutz]] won the first of Soldier Field's two [[stock car racing|stock car]] championships held in 1964.<ref name=kalracingchamps/> *May 9 [[Harry Simonsen]] won the second of Soldier Field's two [[stock car racing|stock car]] championships held in 1964.<ref name=kalracingchamps/> *In 1964 Soldier Field hosted the ''Tournament of Thrills'' racing event.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *June 21 75,000 attended a [[Chicago Freedom Movement]] rally featuring the Reverends [[Martin Luther King Jr.]] and [[Theodore Hesburgh]] (president of [[Notre Dame University]]). The Master of Ceremonies of the event was the Archbishop [[Arthur M. Brazier]]. The event's directors were [[Edgar Chandler (minister)|Edgar Chandler]] and [[Edwin C. Berry]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=StoriedStrangeHistory/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uic.edu/depts/lib/specialcoll/services/rjd/CULExhibit/Urban%20League%20Exhibit/4_1_IL%20Freedom%20Rally.htm |title=Freedom Summer in Chicago: An Anticlimax |website=www.uic.edu |publisher=[[University of Illinois at Chicago]] Library |access-date=January 27, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150227210920/http://www.uic.edu/depts/lib/specialcoll/services/rjd/CULExhibit/Urban%20League%20Exhibit/4_1_IL%20Freedom%20Rally.htm |archivedate=February 27, 2015 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> *August 7 65,000 saw the [[Chicago Bears]] defeat the College All-Stars 28–17 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]]. The MVP was [[Arizona State Sun Devils football|Arizona State]] guard Chuck Taylor. *August 15 [[Johnny Cash]] and [[June Carter Cash|June Carter]] headlined the Chicagoland Music Festival.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *November 22 Soldier Field hosted the 52nd Annual [[Chicago Catholic League|Catholic League]] Championship between [[DePaul College Prep#Archbishop Weber High School|Weber]] and [[Mount Carmel High School (Chicago)|Mount Carmel]].<ref name=Images/> *[[Gordon Tech High School#Archbishop Weber High School|Weber]] defeated [[Chicago Vocational Career Academy|Chicago Vocational]] 34–13 in the 1964 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]]. Critical to the success of Weber's 1964 season and Prep Bowl victory was [[defensive back]] [[Rich "Chico" Kurzawski]].<ref name=catholicleague/><ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/>
===1965=== *The first game of the 1965 [[International Soccer League]] season at Soldier Field was attended by 9,000 spectators. This was the league's final season.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *August 6 68,000 saw the [[Cleveland Browns]] defeat the College All-Stars 24–16 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]]. The MVP was [[Notre Dame Fighting Irish football|Notre Dame]] [[quarterback]] [[John Huarte]]. *A crowd of 10,000 (including 7,000 UIC Students) saw the [[UIC Flames|UIC Chikas]] defeat the [[Milwaukee Panthers football|Milwaukee Panthers]] 20-6 in their homecoming game at Soldier Field. The game was preceded by a parade from the University's new campus (near the [[Jane Byrne Interchange|Circle Interchange]]) to Soldier Field. The teams' homecoming festivities also included a concert at the [[Medinah Temple]] attended by over 1,000 students the night prior to the game, and a post-game dance which entertainment by such acts as [[The Cryan' Shames]] and [[Josh White]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uic.edu/depts/lib/specialcoll/exhibits/football/Circle_football/CircleFootball7.shtml |title=Intercollegiate Football at the University of Illinois at Chicago An Online Exhibit PART II: Navy Pier and Circle Campus, 1950-1973 |publisher=University of Illinois at Chicago |access-date=February 2, 2016 |quote=A Chicago Illini reporter proclaimed that, the university put on a Homecoming "worthy of the acclaim of any Big Ten school ... The bonfire was staged in the athletic field by the Dan Ryan expressway while the mixer was held in the parking lot across from Hull-House ... Friday night saw the Homecoming concert at Medinah Temple, a far cry from the Illinois Room. The concert ... was attended by over 1,000 students. On Saturday, a parade from the University to Soldier Field preceded the main event, the football game between the Chikas and the University of Wisconsin at Milwaukee." The team beat UW Milwaukee 20 to 6 before a crowd estimated at 10,000, of which 7,000 were UIC students. Following the game, students attended a dance in which they were entertained by the Cryan' Shames and blues singer Josh White.}}</ref> *November 6 Soldier Field again hosted the [[Army Black Knights football|Army]]–[[Air Force Falcons football|Air Force]] game.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *75,400 saw [[Loyola Academy]] defeat [[Chicago Vocational Career Academy|Chicago Vocational]] 33–13 in the 1965 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]]. By the time of the preceding [[Chicago Catholic League]] championship game Loyola was down to their thirdstring [[quarterback|QB]] (Ken Krakovich) and a [[Sophomore year|sophomore]] [[running back]] (Jack Spellman) due to injuries of QB [[Tim Foley]] and AllState running back Randy Marks, but Loyola nonetheless won both the Catholic League championship and Prep Bowl under those circumstances.<ref name=catholicleague/><ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/><ref name=I-records/> {{multiple image|caption_align=center|header_align=center| align = right| direction = vertical| width = 200| header = 1966 Chicago Freedom Movement rally| image1 =| caption1 = Martin Luther King, Jr. at the rally| image2 =| image3 =| image4 =}}
===1966=== *A number of international [[association football|soccer]] matches were played at Soldier Field. in 1966. many of these were exhibition matches played by touring teams.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *July 10 the [[Chicago Freedom Movement]], led by [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]], held a rally at Soldier Field. As many as 64,000 people came to hear Dr. King, [[James Meredith]], [[Floyd B. McKissick]], [[Albert Raby]] [[Joseph H. Jackson]], [[Edwin C. Berry]] as well as [[Mahalia Jackson]], [[Stevie Wonder]] and [[Peter, Paul and Mary]]. Auxiliary Bishop [[Aloysius Wycislo]] read a statement from Archbishop [[John Cody]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=Images/><ref name=choose/><ref>{{cite book |last1=Cohen|first1=Adam|last2=Taylor|first2=Elizabeth|title=American Pharaoh: Mayor Richard J. Daley: His Battle for Chicago and the Nation|year=2000|publisher=Little, Brown|location=Boston|isbn=0-316-83403-3|oclc=42392137|page={{Page needed|date=May 2010}}}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://findingaids.library.uic.edu/exhibits/CULExhibit/Urban%20League%20Exhibit/2_2_Berrys%20Influence.htm |title=Berry's Growing Influence |website=www.uic.edu |publisher=University of Illinois at Chicago Library |access-date=January 27, 2015 |quote=Edwin Berry at the Podium During the 1966 Chicago Freedom Movement Rally in Soldier Field.}}</ref> *July 23 [[Mike McGreevy]] won the last [[United States Auto Club|USAC]] midget feature race held at Soldier Field.<ref name=kalracinghistory/> *A 5-day [[rodeo]] competition was the final such event held at Soldier Field. Among the animals entered was a prized bull named Lippy Leo, owned by [[Chicago Cubs]] manager and [[Baseball Hall of Fame]]r [[Leo Durocher]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *A 1966 pageant celebrating 1,000 years of Christianity in Poland was the last large pageant to be held at Soldier Field.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *August 5 72,000 saw the [[Green Bay Packers]] defeat the College All-Stars 38–0 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]]. The MVP was [[Missouri Tigers football|Missouri]] [[quarterback]] [[Gary Lane (football player)|Gary Lane]]. *August 9 [[Barbra Streisand]] concert *[[Whitey Gerken]] won Soldier Field's 1966 [[stock car racing|stock car]] championship.<ref name=kalracingchamps/> *[[Loyola Academy]] defeated [[Chicago Vocational Career Academy|Chicago Vocational]] 20–14 in the 1966 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/>
===1967=== *April 16 about 5,000 spectators watched the [[Chicago Spurs]] of the [[National Professional Soccer League (1967)|National Professional Soccer League]] play their first game. They defeated Saint Louis 2-1. Native Chicagoan [[Willie Roy]] scored both goals for the Spurs. *August 4 70,934 saw the [[Green Bay Packers]] defeat the College All-Stars 27–0 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]]. The MVP was [[Michigan State Spartans football|Michigan States]] [[defensive end]] [[Bubba Smith|Charles Smith]]. *[[Norm Nelson]] won Soldier Field's 1967 [[stock car racing|stock car]] championship, organized in this year by the [[United States Auto Club|USAC]].<ref name=kalracingchamps/> *September 10 Soldier Field hosted the ''Mixed Breed Dog Show'', a toungue-in-cheek event organized by [[Mike Royko]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=StoriedStrangeHistory/> *In 1967 Soldier Field hosted the [[Chicago Park District]]'s '''Mum Bowl''', the championship for its football teams.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *[[Mount Carmel High School (Chicago)|Mount Carmel]] defeated [[Dunbar Vocational High School|Dunbar]] 37–0 in the 1967 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]]. This was the final year of [[Frank Maloney (American football)|Frank Maloney]]'s tenure as Mount Carmel's coach. He began his collegiate coaching career thereafter.<ref name=catholicleague/><ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/>
===1968=== *June 2 [[George Kladis]] and [[Bill Kollman]] won 20-lap [[United Auto Racing Association|UARA]] feature races at Soldier Field.<ref name=kalracinghistory/> *July 4 musician [[Al Morgan (musician)|Al Morgan]], [[WGN-AM]]'s Ray Leonard, [[WCIU-TV]]'s Ted Weber, and others participated in the annual [[American Legion]] show.<ref>{{cite news ||title=Chicago |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xgoEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA74&lpg=PA74&dq=cher+soldier+field&source=bl&ots=WxE5Ge9onr&sig=yslV5U1ukYulP409dslX72f-Dwo&hl=en&sa=X&ei=J3EwVe3eEdGHyATX64CIDA&ved=0CDMQ6AEwCDgU#v=onepage&q&f=false| magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=July 13, 1968 |access-date=April 16, 2015|page=74}}</ref> *June 7 [[Sal Tovella]] won what was the last [[stock car racing|stock car]] race held at Soldier Field, thus marking the end of an era.<ref name=kalracing3/><ref name=NASCAR/> *July 19-August 3 [[1968 Special Olympics Summer World Games|the first edition]] of the [[Special Olympics]] Summer [[Special Olympics World Games|World Games]] were held at Soldier Field in Chicago. The games spanned two days and more than 1,000 kids ages 8–18 with intellectual disabilities from 26 U.S. states and from Canada competed. The competition included [[athletics (sport)|athletics]], four different difficulty-level [[aquatic sports|aquatics]] (a pool was erected on Soldier Field's arena floor especially for these events), [[figure skating]] (an ice sheet was erected within the halls of Soldier Field), [[basketball]] (nets were erected in the stadium), and floor hockey. The event began a worldwide Special Olympics movement that thrives to this day. [[Mayor of Chicago|Mayor]] [[Richard J. Daley]] of Chicago was involved in the administration of the event, as well as the ceremonies, along with Special Olympics co-founders [[Eunice Kennedy Shriver]] and [[Anne M. Burke]] and others including Dr. [[Dr. Frank J. Hayden Secondary School#About Dr. Frank J Hayden|Frank J. Hayden]] of the [[Joseph P. Kennedy, Jr. Foundation]], [[Public figure|statesman]] [[Sargent Shriver]], [[Olympics|Olympic]] gold medalist [[decathlon|decathlete]] [[Rafer Johnson]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=Images/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.specialolympics.org/Sections/What_We_Do/Out_of_the_Shadows__Events_Leading_to_the_Founding_of_Special_Olympics.aspx |title=Out of the Shadows: Events Leading to the Founding of |publisher=Special Olympics |accessdate=July 12, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lib.niu.edu/1998/ip980517.html |title=Feature Article |publisher=Lib.niu.edu |accessdate=July 7, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.specialolympics.org/history.aspx|title=History of Special Olympics|website=specialolympics.org|publisher=[[Special Olympics]]|accessdate=May 8, 2015}}</ref> *August 2 69,917 saw the [[Green Bay Packers]] defeat the College All-Stars 34–17 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]]. The MVP was [[Syracuse Orange football|Syracuse]] [[running back]] [[Larry Csonka]]. Other collegiate participants included [[Forrest Blue]]. *August 27 a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] rally was scheduled to be held at Soldier Field. The Democratic Party had rented out Soldier Field for the entire week of the [[1968 Democratic National Convention]] held at the [[International Amphitheatre]] in Chicago. Despite deciding against seeking reelection, incumbent President [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] had planned on attended the rally, which would have also have doubled as a birthday party for him. Instead, due to riots surrounding the convention, all regular Democratic Party rallies were cancelled, and the President did not leave the [[White House]] to attend the convention.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news|last =Blatchford|first =Frank|title =Johnson's Visits to Chicago: War Often a Theme|newspaper =Chicago Daily Tribune|date =January 23, 1973}}</ref> *[[List of schools of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago#Former high schools in Chicago|Mendel]] defeated [[Chicago Vocational Career Academy|Chicago Vocational]] 41–19 in the 1968 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague/><ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/>
===1969=== *August 1 74,208 saw the [[New York Jets]] defeat the College All-Stars 26–24 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]]. The MVP was [[Cincinnati Bearcats football|Cincinnati]] [[quarterback]] [[Greg Cook]]. *In 1969 the [[Flame of Hope (Special Olympics)|Flame of Hope]] was again lit as Soldier Field hosted the inaugural edition of the annual [[Special Olympics]] Chicago. The Special Olympics Chicago have been held with Soldier Field as its main venue since, with the exception of 2002.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://sochicago.org/ |title=Special Olympics Chicago |website=sochicago.org/|publisher=Special Olympics Chicago|accessdate=May 18, 2015}}</ref> *[[Loyola Academy]] defeated [[Lane Technical College Prep High School|Lane Tech]] 26–0 in the 1969 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=Images/><ref name=catholicleague/><ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/>
== 1970s ==
===1970=== *In June Soldier Field hosted an [[association football]] match between [[Polish national football team|Poland]] and [[Portuguese national football team|Portugal]]. All fans had to sit in the west stands, due to repairs taking place on the eastern stands.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *July 4 Soldier Field's final auto racing event took place, with drag races being organized during the American Legion's annual [[Independence Day (United States)|Independence Day]] celebrations.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *July 18 Soldier Field hosted ''[[WCFL (AM)|WCFL]]'s Big Ten Summer Music Festival''. The event featured [[Chicago (band)|Chicago]], [[Illinois Speed Press]], [[The Illusion (band)|The Illusion]], It Doesn't Matter, Happy Day, Pig Iron, [[The Stooges]], [[Dreams (band)|Dreams]], [[Leon Russell]], [[MC5]], [[Funkadelic]], Joe Kelley Blues Band, [[Mason Proffit]], Bloomsbury People, [[Bush (Canadian band)|Bush]], and [[Iggy Pop]] amongst others. The event began at dawn with a fireworks display.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wolfgangsvault.com/chicago/poster-art/handbill/SOL700718.html |title=Chicago Handbill Soldier Field (Chicago, IL) Jul 18, 1970 (SOL700718-HB) |website=www.wolfgangsvault.com|accessdate=July 8, 2014}}</ref><ref name=classic>{{cite web|url=http://www.classic-rock-concerts.com/cities/133 |title=Chicago, Illinois, United States |website=www.classic-rock-concerts.com |accessdate=April 17, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150325053848/http://www.classic-rock-concerts.com/cities/133 |archivedate=March 25, 2015 }}</ref><ref name=classic2>{{cite web|url=http://www.classic-rock-concerts.com/venues/2067 |title=Soldier Field |website=www.classic-rock-concerts.com |accessdate=April 17, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141229201510/http://www.classic-rock-concerts.com/venues/2067 |archivedate=December 29, 2014 }}</ref> *The final fire show at Soldier Field occurred as a part of a lakefront festival that also included the [[Chicago Air and Water Show]]. 38,000 spectators were in attendance, including [[Mayor of Chicago|Mayor]] [[Richard J. Daley]] and Fire Commissioner Robert Quinn.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *July 31 69,940 saw the [[Kansas City Chiefs]] defeat the College All-Stars 24–3 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]]. The MVP was [[Boston University Terriers football|Boston University]] [[defensive back]] Bruce Taylor. *Soldier Field was the main venue of the ''II [[Special Olympics World Games]]'' held August 13–15, 1970. *Soldier Field hosted the ''[[Special Olympics]] Chicago''. *[[St. Rita of Cascia High School|St. Rita]] defeated [[Lane Technical College Prep High School|Lane Tech]] 12–8 in the 1970 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]]. Members of the St. Rita team included [[Billy Marek]] and [[Dennis Lick]] (who would later play at Soldier Field as a member of the Chicago Bears). The team was coached by Pat Cronin.<ref name=catholicleague/><ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/>
===1971=== *July 30 52,289 saw the [[Baltimore Colts]] defeat the College All-Stars 24–17 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]]. The MVP was [[Grambling State Tigers football|Grambling State]] [[Defensive end]] Richard Harris. *September 12 the [[Chicago Bears]] faced the [[Denver Broncos]] in their first preseason home game as tenants of Soldier Field.<ref name=Images/> *September 19 55,701 spectators saw the [[Chicago Bears]] defeat the [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] 15-3 in their first regular-season game as tenants at Soldier Field.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=Images/><ref name=choose/><ref>{{cite book |last=Taylor |first=Roy |date= 2004|title=Chicago Bears History|location=Charleston, SC; Chicago; Portsmouth, NH; San Francisco|publisher=Arcadia Publishing}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Davis |first=Jeff |date= 2005|title=Papa Bear: The Life and Legacy of George Halas|location=New York City|publisher=McGraw-Hill Education}}</ref> *[[St. Rita of Cascia High School|St. Rita]] defeated [[Morgan Park High School|Morgan Park]] 18–12 in the 1971 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]]. St. Rita defeated Lane Tech 12–8 in the 1970 Prep Bowl. Members of the St. Rita team included [[Billy Marek]] and [[Dennis Lick]] (the latter would later play at Soldier Field as a member of the Chicago Bears). The team was coached by Pat Cronin.<ref name=catholicleague/><ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/>
===1972=== *July 28 54,162 saw the [[Dallas Cowboys]] defeat the College All-Stars 20–7 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]]. The MVP was [[Auburn Tigers football|Auburn]] [[quarterback]] [[Pat Sullivan (football player)|Pat Sullivan]]. *July 4 50,000 spectators attended the annual American Legion show.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *[[Tennessee State Tigers football|Tennessee State]] defeated [[Alcorn State Braves football|Alcorn]] 40-13 in Soldier Field's annual [[American football|football]] game between historically [[African-American|black]] colleges.<ref name=sicklegrid>{{cite news |last=Conklin |first=Mike |date=July 24, 1974|title=Sickle Cell Charity grid game September 13 |url= http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1974/07/24/page/75/article/sickle-cell-charity-grid-game-sept-13 |newspaper=Chicago Tribune |access-date=April 22, 2015}}</ref> *[[St. Laurence High School|St. Laurence]] defeated [[William Howard Taft High School (Chicago)|Taft]] 24–7 in the 1972 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague/><ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/>
===1973=== *July 23 54,103 saw the [[Miami Dolphins]] defeat the College All-Stars 14–3 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]]. The MVP was [[Southern Miss Golden Eagles football|Southern Mississippi]] [[Punter (football)|punter]] [[Ray Guy]]. *[[St. Laurence High School|St. Laurence]] defeated [[Wendell Phillips Academy High School|Phillips]] 40-24 in the 1973 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague/><ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/>
===1974=== [[File:South facade including Soldier Field parking lot and bleachers; view to north - Chicago Park District Administration Building, 425 East McFetridge Drive, Chicago, Cook County, HABS ILL,16-CHIG,169-7.tif|thumb|right|250px|The North End of Soldier Field, which held such events as the "International Festival of Tennis" over the years]]
*July 10 42,000 attended the inaugural game of the [[World Football League]]'s [[Chicago Fire (WFL)|Chicago Fire]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *In 1974 the North End of Soldier Field (the end that was cut off from the main stadium by the northern end zone seats installed during the renovations completed following the arrival of the [[Chicago Bears]]) hosted the 1974 ''International Festival of Tennis''. Notable-figures that competed in the tournament include, among others, [[Lloyd Bridges]], [[Raúl Ramírez]], [[Grant Golden]], [[Stan Smith]], [[Marty Riessen]], [[Roscoe Tanner]], [[Billy Martin (tennis)|Billy Martin]]. [[Bud Collins]] called the mini-stadium at the north end of Soldier Field the best venue in the nation for events such as the [[Davis Cup]] to be held in the future. Grant Golden lauded the venue saying ''"This stadium at the north end of Soldier Field is the best in the world, and I've played 'em all,"'' and added ''"We can seat 20,000 and there isn't a bad seat in the house."'' Additionally, national reporters named Soldier Field's courts as the best in the country. The attendance was not as high as expected, with only 20,000 people attending the nearly week-long tournament, but the event was declared a success in many other respects. Over 4,400 spectators attended the final, in which Stan Smith defeated Marty Riessen. Among those spectators that attended events during tournament were [[Butch Buchholz]], [[Janet Young (tennis)|Janet Young]], [[Kim Warwick]], [[Graham Stilwell]], and [[Sue Eastman]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news |last=Markus |first=Robert |date=July 24, 1974|title=Soldier Field great place for tennis |url= http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1974/07/24/page/75/article/soldier-field-great-place-for-tennis|newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]] |access-date=April 22, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Nidetz |first=Steve |date=July 24, 1974|title=Chicago war of words must cease |url= http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1974/07/24/page/75/article/chicago-war-of-words-must-cease |newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]] |access-date=April 22, 2015}}</ref> *September 13 Soldier Field, for the fifth year, held its annual collegiate [[American football|football]] game between historically [[african american|black]] colleges. The game was played between [[Tennessee State Tigers football|Tennessee State]] and [[Central State University#Football|Central State]]. Proceeds benefited charities relating to [[sickle cell anemia]].<ref name=sicklegrid/> *[[St. Laurence High School|St. Laurence]] defeated [[Chicago Vocational Career Academy|Chicago Vocational]] 34–0 in the 1974 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague/><ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/>
===1975=== *In 1975 the North Field of Soldier Field again held the ''International Festival of Tennis''. Amongst the participants were [[Billy Martin (tennis)|Billy Martin]] and [[Roscoe Tanner]] (who won the tournament with a $9,000 purse). The attendance was even less than the previous year. Only 2,000 people attending the quarter finals (while at the same time 5,000 spectators watched a [[Chicago Sting]] game that was taking place in the South End of Soldier Field).<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=StoriedStrangeHistory/> *The [[Chicago Winds]] of the [[World Football League]] played their only season at Soldier Field in 1975. Their only win was attended by a mere 3,502 spectators at Soldier Field, with them defeating the [[Portland Thunder (WFL)|Portland Thunder]]<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *The ''Emmet Kelly Jr. Circus'', organized by Chicago Park District superintendent Edmund Kelly, performed in Soldier Field's north end for several nights beginning on June 14. Its headlining performer was Emmet Kelly Jr. playing the circus clown made famous by Emmet Kelly Sr., [[Wearie Willie]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *1975 [[Marvin Gaye]] concert in the northern arena of Soldier Field.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *August 1 54,562 saw the [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] defeat the College All-Stars 21–14 in the [[Chicago College All-Star Game]]. *[[Brother Rice High School (Chicago)|Brother Rice]] defeated [[Chicago Vocational Career Academy|Chicago Vocational]] 26–0 in the 1975 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/>
===1976=== *July 23 52,095 saw the [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] play the Chicago All-Stars in what would be the final [[Chicago College All-Star Game]]. The game was called late with 1:22 left in the third quarter due to heavy rain. Despite featuring stars such as [[Chuck Muncie]], [[Mike Pruitt]], [[Lee Roy Selmon]], and [[Jackie Slater]], the all-stars were hopelessly outmatched by the [[1976 Pittsburgh Steelers season|Pittsburgh Steelers]], winners of [[Super Bowl X]]. The star quarterback for the College All-Stars was Steeler draft pick [[Mike Kruczek]], out of [[Boston College Eagles football|Boston College]]. Late in the third quarter, with the Steelers leading 24–0, high winds prompted all-star coach [[Ara Parseghian]] to call time out. Fans began pouring out onto the field and sliding on the turf. With the rain getting harder, the officials ordered both teams to their locker rooms. All attempts to clear the field failed; the fans even tore down the goalposts. However, by this time the rain had become so heavy as to make the field unplayable even if order had been restored. Finally, at 11:01 pm NFL Commissioner [[Pete Rozelle]] and the ''Tribune'' announced that the game had been called. The news was greeted with jeers, and numerous brawls broke out on the flooded field before order was finally restored. [[Joe Washington]] of [[1975 Oklahoma Sooners football team|Oklahoma]] was selected MVP of this final College All-Star game.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=QvwjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=jH4EAAAAIBAJ&pg=6729%2C1574307 |newspaper=Milwaukee Journal |last=Shepard |first=Terry |title=Rain and fans do in players |date=July 24, 1976 |page=10}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=1KtVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=3uADAAAAIBAJ&pg=6480%2C5825113|newspaper=Eugene Register-Guard |agency=Associated Press|title=Rampaging fans, rain shorten all-star game |date=July 24, 1976|page=3B}}</ref> Chicago Tribune Charities had every intention of staging a 1977 game. However, with coaches increasingly unwilling to let their high draft picks play and insurance costs on the rise due to higher player salaries, the ''Tribune'' announced on December 21, 1976, that the game would be discontinued. Serving as the coach of the All-Stars was also the final coaching experience of [[Ara Parseghian]].<ref name="Parseghian as all-star coach">{{cite news|title=Parseghian picks All-Star team|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=gnU0AAAAIBAJ&sjid=DhMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4886,3416769&dq=parseghian+all-star&hl=en|accessdate=July 13, 2013|newspaper=Wilmington Morning Star|date=May 18, 1976|agency=United Press International|location=Chicago|page=13}}</ref><ref name="All-star game stopped">{{cite news|title=All-Star Fiasco Prompts Security|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=EhlZAAAAIBAJ&sjid=a0YNAAAAIBAJ&pg=4471,4864216&dq=parseghian+all-star&hl=en|accessdate=July 13, 2013|newspaper=The Victoria Advocate|date=July 29, 1976|agency=Associated Press|location=Chicago|page=4B}}</ref><ref name="All-star game canceled">{{cite news|title=Players differ on All-Star game|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=uR9dAAAAIBAJ&sjid=KFoNAAAAIBAJ&pg=2247,5263821&dq=college+all-star+game+canceled&hl=en|accessdate=July 13, 2013|newspaper=St. Joseph Gazette|date=December 24, 1976|agency=Associated Press|location=Biloxi, Miss.|page=3B}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_AcqAAAAIBAJ&sjid=OykEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4601%2C905014|newspaper=Milwaukee Journal |title=Game ended by Tribune |date=December 22, 1976|page=10-part 2 }}</ref> *July 25 [[ZZ Top]] concert<ref name=net/> *The [[Chicago Sting]] ended their 1976 postseason at the postseason at Soldier Field, with a double-overtime loss to Toronto. Toronto would subsequently win the league's championship that season.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *[[Chicago Vocational Career Academy|Chicago Vocational]] defeated [[St. Rita of Cascia High School|St. Rita]] 13–6 in the 1976 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/>
===1977=== *June 4 80,000 people attended as Soldier Field held the ''Super Bowl of Rock'' concert featuring [[Emerson, Lake & Palmer]],<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=classic/><ref name=classic2/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.classic-rock-concerts.com/performances/51718 |title=June 4, 1977 Emerson, Lake & Palmer ELP Works at Soldier Field, Chicago |website=www.classic-rock-concerts.com |accessdate=April 17, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150104125244/http://www.classic-rock-concerts.com/performances/51718 |archivedate=January 4, 2015 }}</ref> [[Foghat]], [[The J. Geils Band]] and The [[Climax Blues Band]]. *June 19 95,000 spectators attended a [[Pink Floyd]] 'Animals' tour concert.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=classic/><ref name=classic2/><ref>{{Citation | last = Blake | first = Mark | authorlink = Mark Blake (writer) | title = Comfortably Numb – The Inside Story of Pink Floyd | publisher = Da Capo Press | year = 2008 | pp=252–253| isbn = 0-306-81752-7}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.classic-rock-concerts.com/performances/20704 |title=June 19, 1977 Pink Floyd "In The Flesh" Tour at Soldier Field, Chicago |website=www.classic-rock-concerts.com |accessdate=April 17, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150104125035/http://www.classic-rock-concerts.com/performances/20704 |archivedate=January 4, 2015 }}</ref> *July 9 77,197 spectators attended a [[Lynyrd Skynyrd]] and [[Point Blank (band)|Point Blank]] concert.<ref name=classic/><ref name=classic2/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.classic-rock-concerts.com/performances/55356 |title=July 9, 1977 Lynyrd Skynyrd \ Point Blank at Soldier Field, Chicago |website=www.classic-rock-concerts.com |accessdate=April 17, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150104125259/http://www.classic-rock-concerts.com/performances/55356 |archivedate=January 4, 2015 }}</ref> *July 10 ''Super Bowl of Rock Game 3'' concert featuring [[Ted Nugent]], [[Lynyrd Skynyrd]], [[REO Speedwagon]], [[Journey (band)|Journey]] and [[38 Special (band)|.38 Special]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=classic/><ref |website=www.classic-rock-concerts.com |accessdate=April 17, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150104125510/http://www.classic-rock-concerts.com/performances/63731 |archivedate=January 4, 2015 }}</ref> *August 13 [[Peter Frampton]]<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> concert, with [[Bob Seger]] & The Silver Bullet Band, [[Rick Derringer]] and [[UFO (band)|UFO]]. *In 1977 [[Pelé]] made his final Soldier Field appearance in a [[Chicago Sting]] match against the [[New York Cosmos (1970–85)|New York Cosmos]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *[[St. Rita of Cascia High School|St. Rita]] defeated [[Lane Technical College Prep High School|Lane Tech]] 20–8 in the 1977 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/> *November 20, despite playing with [[Influenza|flu]] symptoms, [[Chicago Bears|Bears]] [[running back]] [[Walter Payton]] managed to rush for 275 yards in forty carries, beating a single-game record that [[O.J. Simpson]] had set the previous year. More than 49,000 fans attended the game, which saw the Bears defeat the [[Minnesota Vikings]] 10-7.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/>
===1978=== *July 4 18,000 attended the 1978 American Legion show.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *July 8 [[The Rolling Stones US Tour 1978]] concert, with [[Journey (band)|Journey]], [[Southside Johnny & The Asbury Jukes]] and [[Peter Tosh]]. A sour note of the event though came with Soldier Field's second accidental death on-record, a concertgoer fell 30 feet from a walkway at the stadium and was pronounced dead on arrival at [[Mercy Field, with performances by [[Parliament-Funkadelic]], [[A Taste of Honey (band)|A Taste of Honey]],<ref name=stadiumanditscity/>[[The Bar-Kays]], and [[Con Funk Shun]]. *[[St. Laurence High Sullivan High School|Sullivan]] 34–8 in the 1978 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/>
===1979=== *July 4 15,000 attended the 1979 American Legion show.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *[[Julian High School (Chicago)|Julian]] defeated [[Joliet Catholic Academy|Joliet Catholic]] 30–22 in the 1979 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/>
== 1980s ==
===1980=== *July 19 [[Smokey Robinson]] concert, with [[The O'Jays]]. *[[Brother Rice High School (Chicago)|Brother Rice]] defeated [[Julian High School (Chicago)|Julian]] in the 1980 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=prep/>
===1981=== *July 4 6,500 attended the 1981 American Legion show, which also included a [[World Football League|WFL]] [[Chicago Fire (WFL)|Chicago Fire]] game against the [[Shreveport Steamer]]. The Fire won 25-15.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *[[Mount Carmel High School (Chicago)|Mount Carmel]] defeated [[Paul Robeson High School (Chicago)|Robeson]] 14–6 in the 1981 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]]. Mount Carmel were defending [[Illinois High School Association|IHSA]] champions, having won the state title in 1980.<ref name=catholicleague/><ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/> [[File:Soldier Field in 1982 NPS (cropped).jpg|thumb|right|175x175px|Soldier Field in 1982]]
===1982=== *[[Gordon Tech High School]] defeated [[Julian High School (Chicago)|Julian]] 24–0 in 1982 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague/><ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/>

web|url=http://www.classic-rock-concerts.com/performances/65075 |title=August 18, 1983 Laura Branigan ChicagoFest at Soldier Field, Chicago |website=www.classic-rock-concerts.com |accessdate=April 17, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150418065715/http://www.classic-rock-concerts.com/performances/65075 |archivedate=April 18, 2015 }}</ref> *October 13 David D. Meilahn made the first-ever commercial [[mobile phone|cell phone]] call from his 1983 [[Mercedes-Benz 380SL]] at Soldier Field on a [[Motorola DynaTAC]]. This is considered a major turning point in communications. The call was to Bob Barnett, the former president of [[Ameritech Mobile Communications]], who then placed a call on a DynaTAC from inside of a [[Chrysler]] [[convertible]] to the grandson of [[Alexander Graham Bell]] who was in Germany.<ref name=StoriedStrangeHistory/><ref>{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F04EED8173BF935A35752C0A9669C8B63 |title=Cell Phones Ruin the Opera? Meet the Culprit |work=The New York Times |first=Ted |last=Oehmke |date=January 6, 2000 |accessdate=2009-05-26}}</ref> *[[Mount Carmel High School (Chicago)|Mount Carmel]] defeated [[Simeon Career Academy|Simeon]] 28–6 in the 1983 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/> *6,000 spectators saw the [[Chicago Sting]] win a [[North American Soccer League]] playoff match at Soldier Field. This was the Sting's last postseason game at Soldier Field.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/>
===1984=== *[[De La Salle Institute|De La Salle]] defeated [[Julian High School (Chicago)|Julian]] 25–20 in the 1984 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/>
===1985=== *August 9 a sold-out crowd of 71,222 attended a [[Bruce Springsteen]] & The [[E Street Band]] [[Born in the U.S.A. Tour]] concert.<ref name=net/><ref name=classic/><ref name=classic2/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.classic-rock-concerts.com/performances/65025|title=Bruce Springsteen & The E Street Band at Soldier Field, Chicago|website=www.classic-rock-concerts.com|accessdate=April 17, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.classic-rock-concerts.com/performances/13318 |title=Bruce Springsteen at Soldier Field, Chicago |website=www.classic-rock-concerts.com |accessdate=April 17, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150104124952/http://www.classic-rock-concerts.com/performances/13318 |archivedate=January 4, 2015 }}</ref> *[[Mount Carmel High School (Chicago)|Mount Carmel]] defeated [[Lane Technical College Prep High School|Lane Tech]] 19–14 in the 1985 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/> *[[1985–86 NFL playoffs|1985 NFC Divisional Playoff]]: [[1985 Chicago Bears season|Bears]] 21, [[1985 New York Giants season|New York Giants]] 0.<ref name=net/> *[[1985–86 NFL playoffs|1985 NFC Championship Game]] took place in Soldier Field, where the [[1985 Chicago Bears season|Bears]] defeated the [[1985 Los Angeles Rams season|Los Angeles Rams]] 24–0.<ref name=net/>
===1986=== *[[Loyola Academy]] defeated [[Simeon Career Academy|Simeon]] 14–12 in the 1986 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/> *November 23 [[Jerry Markbreit]] began what would be a 23-season career as an NFL referee (during which he would become one of the league's most recognizable referees) when he refereed a game between the Chicago Bears and the [[Green Bay Packers]]. In the second quarter of the game, Bears quarterback [[Jim McMahon]] was intercepted, and as he watched the proceedings downfield, Packers defensive end [[Charles Martin (football player)|Charles Martin]] picked up McMahon and bodyslammed him shoulder-first into the [[AstroTurf]]. Martin remained hovered over an injured McMahon on one knee and taunted him until Bears offensive tackle [[Jimbo Covert]] barreled full-speed into Martin. Despite strenuous protests from Packers coach [[Forrest Gregg]], Markbreit ejected Martin, Markbreit's first ejection as an NFL official. When describing the penalty, Markbreit stated that Martin "stuffed" McMahon into the ground. Martin was suspended for two games by NFL commissioner [[Pete Rozelle]], the longest suspension for an on-field incident until [[Tennessee Titans]] defensive tackle [[Albert Haynesworth]] was suspended five games by commissioner [[Roger Goodell]] for stomping on the face of [[Dallas Cowboys]] center [[Andre Gurode]] during an October 1, 2006 game During the game, Martin wore a "hit list" towel with the numbers of several Bears listed, including those of McMahon, running back [[Walter Payton]], wide receiver [[Willie Gault]], and center [[Jay Hilgenberg]]. The call was largely credited by the media and NFL executives in helping Markbreit land the assignment as the referee of [[Super Bowl XXI]] two months later.<ref>{{cite web | first= | last= | url=http://www.nfl.com/teams/story/TEN/9700907 | title=Titans' Haynesworth gets five-game suspension | publisher=NFL.com | date=2006-10-02 | accessdate=2006-10-04 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061013112235/http://www.nfl.com/teams/story/TEN/9700907 |archivedate = 2006-10-13}}</ref> *[[1986–87 NFL playoffs|1986 NFC Divisional Playoff]]: [[1986 Washington Redskins season|Washington Redskins]] 27, [[1986 Chicago Bears season|Bears]] 13.<ref name=net/>
===1987=== *July 31, 1987 a sold-out crowd of 46,923 attended a [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] [[Who's That Girl World Tour]] performance, with [[Level 42]] as the opening act. The concert grossed $751,854.<ref name=net/><ref name=TaySwiftRecord>{{cite web |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/music/ct-taylor-swift-sells-out-both-chicago-shows-sets-female-record-soldier-field-20150720-story.html |title=Taylor Swift sells out both Chicago shows, sets female record: Soldier Field |last=Swartz |first=Tracy |date=July 20, 2015 |work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |access-date=July 29, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal| publication-date = August 1, 1987| title = Billboard Boxscore| periodical = Billboard| publication-place = New York City| issn =0006-2510}}</ref> *[[Gordon Tech High School]] defeated [[Julian High School (Chicago)|Julian]] 29–14 in the 1987 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/> *[[1987–88 NFL playoffs|1987 NFC Divisional Playoff]]: [[1987 Washington Redskins season|Washington]] 21, [[1987 Chicago Bears season|Bears]] 17.<ref name=net/><ref name=catholicleague/> [[File:Soldier Field Chicago aerial view.jpg|thumb|right|250x250px|Soldier Field in 1988]] [[File:Fog Bowl 1988.jpg|thumb|right|250px|The 'Fog Bowl']]
===1988=== *November 28 2,500 spectators saw [[Loyola Academy]] defeat [[Julian High School (Chicago)|Julian]] 21–6 in the 1988 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/> *[[1988–89 NFL playoffs|1988 NFC Divisional Playoff]]: [[1988 Chicago Bears season|Bears]] 20, [[1988 Philadelphia Eagles season|Philadelphia Eagles]] 12 (this game is best remembered as the [[Fog Bowl (American football)|Fog Bowl]], where a dense fog covered the stadium, reducing visibility to 15–20 yards.)<ref name=net/> *During the annual ''[[Special Olympics]] Chicago'' in 1988, the ''[[Keith Magnuson]] Spirit Award'' was presented for the first time. The Spirit Award is presented annually to a team which models the Special Olympics mission by "encouraging physical fitness, demonstrating courage, experiencing joy, and participating in the sharing of gifts, skills, and friendship with their families, community, and other Special Olympic athletes throughout the calendar year".<ref name=Images/> *The [[1988–89 NFL playoffs|1988 NFC Championship Game]] took place here, where the [[1988 Chicago Bears season|Bears]] lost to eventual [[Super Bowl XXIII]] champions [[1988 San Francisco 49ers season|San Francisco 49ers]] 28–3.<ref name=net/> *[[Julian High School (Chicago)|Julian]] defeated [[Fenwick High School (Oak Park, Illinois)|Fenwick]] 48–14 in the 1989 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=prep/>
===1989=== *July 20–22 Soldier Field hosted the [[Marlboro Cup (soccer)|Marlboro Cup]]. Among those playing were [[Brian Bliss]], [[Bruce Murray (soccer)|Bruce Murray]], [[David Vanole]], [[Diego Francolino da Silva|Diego Silva]], [[Eduardo de la Torre]], [[Hugo Pérez (soccer)|Hugo Pérez]], [[Jimmy Banks]], [[John Stollmeyer]], [[Juan Davila (soccer)|Juan Davila]], [[Julio Rodas]], [[Ken Snow]], [[Krzysztof Warzycha|Krzysztof "Kristof" Warzycha]], [[Luis Antonio Valdéz]], [[Mike Windischmann]], [[Paul Caligiuri]], [[Steve Snow]], [[Steve Trittschuh]], [[Tab Ramos]] and [[Tony Meola]]. The tournament's promotor was [[Mundail Sports Group]], a group that was chaired by [[Clive Toye]]. The final was attended by 25,102 spectators, which at the time was the largest crowd that had attended a [[Association football|soccer]] match at Soldier Field since 1976.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesm/marlboro.html|title=Marlboro Soccer Cup Series (USA) 1987-1990|accessdate=December 8, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Young |first=Janet |date=July 22, 1989 |title=U.s. Team Looks For Prestige |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1989-07-22/sports/8902200177_1_david-vanole-marlboro-cups-world-cup |newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]] |access-date=October 6, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Young |first=Janet |date=July 20, 1989 |title=Marlboro Play Loses Some Zip |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1989-07-20/sports/8902190099_1_marlboro-cups-world-cup-polish |newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]] |access-date=October 6, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Young |first=Janet |date=July 21, 1989 |title=U.s. The game was won by Jackson State.<ref name=cfc1/><ref name=cfc2>{{cite news |last=Deardorff |first=Julie |date=October 8, 1994 |title=Game's Not Only Thing In Classic |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1994-10-08/sports/9410080010_1_chicago-football-classic-south-carolina-state-black-colleges |newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]] |access-date=November 27, 2016}}</ref> *[[Mount Carmel High School (Chicago)|Mount Carmel]] defeated [[Bogan High School (Chicago)|Bogan]] 34–14 in the 1993 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/>
===1994=== *July 12 a sold-out crowd of 51,981 attended a [[Pink Floyd]] [[The Division Bell Tour]] concert. The show grossed $2,056,105.<ref name=classic/><ref name=classic2/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.classic-rock-concerts.com/performances/37526|title=July 12, 1994 Pink Floyd at Soldier Field, Chicago|website=www.classic-rock-concerts.com|accessdate=April 18, 2015}}</ref> *July 17, 1994, preceding the opening match (also held at Soldier Field), the stadium hosted the opening ceremonies of the [[1994 FIFA World Cup|1994]] [[FIFA]] [[FIFA World Cup|World Cup]]. The temperature was hot, at 97° Fahrenheit, at the beginning of the ceremonies, but dropped down to a cooler 83° by the start of the opening match.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> The event featured [[Oprah Winfrey]], [[Diana Ross]], [[Darryl Hall]], [[Jon Secada]], [[Richard Marx]], President [[Bill Clinton]], [[Mayor of Chicago]] [[Richard M. Daley]], World Cup chairman and [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] [[Alan Rothenberg]], 1,500 local high-school students, a 300-person children's choir, and two-thousand volunteer dancers.<ref name=Worldcup1>{{cite news |last=Cart |first=Julie |date=June 18, 1994 |title=WORLD CUP USA '94 / THE FIRST ROUND : After the Fall, Show Goes On |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1994-06-18/sports/sp-5645_1_world-cup |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |access-date=November 20, 2016}}</ref><ref name=wc1>{{cite news |last=Cart |first=Julie |date=June 18, 1994 |title= U.S. Puts Its Spin on Ball at Kickoff of World Cup : Soccer: Clinton joins German, Bolivian leaders at tourney's Chicago opening. First Rose Bowl game today.|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1994-06-18/news/mn-5399_1_world-cup |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |access-date=September 14, 2015}}</ref> Portions of the performance included music and folk dancers from the 24 nations that were competing in the World Cup.<ref name=wc1/> Over 750 million viewers worldwide watched the ceremony on television.<ref name=Worldcup1/>
