|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150418063658/http://www.classic-rock-concerts.com/performances/18028 |archivedate=April 18, 2015 }}</ref> *October 8 the [[Alabama State Hornets football|Alabama State Hornets]] and the [[Jackson State Tigers football|Jackson State Tigers]] competed in the Chicago Football Classic. The halftime entertainment featured a "battle of the bands" between both schools' [[marching band]]s. Portions of the pre-game ceremonies honored both Jackson State alumni [[Lewis Tillman (American football)|Lewis Tillman]] and Alabama State alumni [[Jesse White (politician)|Jesse White]]. One of the star athletes competing in this game was Alabama State's [[Reggie Barlow]]. The game was won by Jackson State.<ref name=cfc2/><ref name=cfc3>{{cite news |last=Gottesman |first=Andrew |date=October 1, 1995 |title=Jackson State Takes Classic |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1995-10-01/sports/9510010244_1_chicago-football-classic-grailyn-pratt-alabama-state |newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]] |access-date=November 27, 2016}}</ref> *[[Brother Rice High School (Chicago)|Brother Rice]] defeated [[Lane Technical College Prep High School|Lane Tech]] 28–22 in the 1994 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/>
===1995=== *July 8 and 9 [[Grateful Dead]] concerts, with [[The Band]]. The concert on the 9th was the Grateful Dead's final concert before the death of [[Jerry Garcia]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref name=classic/><ref name=classic2/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.classic-rock-concerts.com/performances/59735 |title=July 8, 1995 The Grateful Dead at Soldier Field, Chicago |website=www.classic-rock-concerts.com |accessdate=April 19, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150418063701/http://www.classic-rock-concerts.com/performances/59735 |archivedate=April 18, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.classic-rock-concerts.com/performances/59736 |title=July 9, 1995 The Grateful Dead at Soldier Field, Chicago |website=www.classic-rock-concerts.com |accessdate=April 19, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150418072455/http://www.classic-rock-concerts.com/performances/59736 |archivedate=April 18, 2015 }}</ref> *July 11 [[Pearl Jam]] [[Vitalogy Tour]] concert, with [[Bad Religion]] and [[Otis Rush]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.classic-rock-concerts.com/performances/37526|title= July 12, 1994 Pink Floyd at Soldier Field, Chicago |website=www.classic-rock-concerts.com|accessdate=April 19, 2015}}</ref> *In 1995 Soldier Field was the venue of two international soccer games.<ref name=ifbearsgo/> *In 1995 Soldier Field hosted a [[skateboarding]] tournament.<ref name=ifbearsgo/> *In 1995 Soldier Field hosted a [[street hockey]] tournament.<ref name=ifbearsgo/> *In 1995 Soldier Field hosted several ethnic and religious festivals including German, Indian, Pan-American, and Polish ones.<ref name=ifbearsgo/> *September 30 36,712 spectators saw the [[Jackson State Tigers football|Jackson State Tigers]] defeat the [[Alabama State Hornets football|Alabama State Hornets]] 24-22. This was the third-straight year that Jackson State won the game. Among the star athletes competing in this game was Alabama State's [[Reggie Barlow]].<ref name=cfc3/> *1,100 people saw [[Loyola Academy]] defeat [[Julian High School (Chicago)|Julian]] 15–14 in the 1995 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=ifbearsgo/><ref name=prep/>
===1996=== *May 11–12 Soldier Field's parking lot hosted the annual Windy City Weedfest. This was an event organized by supporters of [[marijuana]]/ [[cannabis]] [[Cannabis in the United States|legalization]]. The event was attended by over 25,000. The event had been held elsewhere in Chicago in previous years. Rev [[Michael Pfleger]] was present to protest marajuana use at the event. Following the festival, the [[Chicago Park District]] (owners of the stadium) refused to allow the event to be held at Soldier Field again due to widespread cannabis use at the event.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/><ref>{{cite news |title= 'Weed Wackin" Pfleger |url=http://digitalcommons.colum.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1352&context=cadc_chronicle| newspaper=Columbia Chronicle |location=[[Columbia College Chicago]] |date=May 13, 1996|access-date=December 1, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Ritter |first=Jim |date=May 13, 1996 |title=Joint Venture: Law Ignores Weedfest |url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-4334044.html |newspaper=[[Chicago Sun-Times]] |page=6 |accessdate= November 15, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Gregory |first=Ted |date=May 13, 1996 |title=Pastor protests parks-sanctioned marijuana fest |newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]] |page= 5 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Fencik |first=Joan |date=May 22, 1996 |title=Weedfest facts |url= |newspaper=Chicago Tribune | page=16 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Byrne |first=Dennis |date=May 14, 1996 |title= Dazed and Confused |newspaper=[[Chicago Sun-Times]] |page=29 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Jepsen |first=Cara |date=October 11, 2001 |title=Group Efforts: the return of the pot fest |url=http://m.chicagoreader.com/chicago/group-efforts-the-return-of-the-pot-fest/Content?oid=906703 |newspaper=[[Chicago Reader]] |access-date=November 15, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last= |first= |date=Summer 1996 |title=Chicago Authorities Criticized for Lack of Law Enforcement at "Weedfest" |url=http://www.ndsn.org/summer96/hempfest.html |newspaper=NewsBriefs |publisher=National Drug Strategy Network |access-date=November 15, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=DeBartolo |first=Anthony |date=May 8, 1998 |title=Grass Roots. Marijuana Lovers Find Themselves In A Legal Thicket |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1998-05-08/features/9805080264_1_marijuana-laws-federal-court-robert-macdonald |newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]] |access-date=November 15, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Gregory |first=Ted |date=May 13, 2015 |title=Pastor Protests Marijuana Fest Soldier Field Event Ignites Controversy |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1996-05-13/news/9605130011_1_soldier-field-chicago-park-district-illegal |newspaper=Chicago Tribune |access-date=November 15, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Lessner |first=Lori |date=May 17, 1996 |title=Daley, Cops Meet about Weedfest; City Permit in Doubt Unless Pot Use Stops |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1996-05-17/news/9605170100_1_illegal-permit-rally |newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]] |access-date=November 15, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2002-01-16/news/0201160340_1_permit-rallies-supreme-court |title=Top court OKs Chicago park permits |last= Crawford Greenburg|first=Jan |date=January 16, 2002 | work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |access-date=November 15, 2015 }}</ref> *September 14, 1996 [[Little Feat]] concert, with [[Taj Mahal (musician)|Taj Mahal]]. *In 1996 the [[Promise Keepers]] drew 69,000 to an event at Soldier Field.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *[[Loyola Academy]] defeated [[Dunbar Vocational High School|Dunbar]] 28–8 in the 1996 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/>

== 2000s ==
===2000=== *May 13 [[Wilco]] concert. *[[2000 U.S. Cup]]: {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; width:60%;" |- !Date !Team #1 !Result !Team #2 !Spectators |- |June 4, 2000||{{fb|IRL}}||style="text-align:center;"|2–2||{{fb|MEX}}||style="text-align:center;"|36,469 |} *June 29 and 30 [[Dave Matthews Band]] concerts, with [[Ben Harper]] & The Innocent Criminals and [[Ozomatli]] *July 20–22 [[Bassmaster Classic]] weigh-ins were held at Soldier Field. The boats used in the competition were docked nearby at Burnham Harbor. The competition took place within the Chicago-area in [[Lake Michigan]] and its connected waterways. The Bassmaster Classic is a major fishing competition, sometimes dubbed to be the "[[Super Bowl|Superbowl]] of Fishing". Live coverage of the event was streamed online. This was the 30th edition of the competition. 45 competitors participated in the competition At the end of the competition, a closing ceremony was held at Soldier Field with performances (including [[Grammy Awards|Grammy]]-winning singer [[Trisha Yearwood]]) and fireworks. Competitor, and [[Bassmaster Classic XXIX|1999]] champion, Davy Hite, failed to defend his title in the 2000 edition. The winner of the competition was Woo Daves, who, at 54, became the oldest person to win a Bassmaster Classic title. It was Daves' 15th time competing in the Classic. Daves received a $100,000 prize. In descending order, the top six finishers were Woo Daves ([[Spring Grove, Virginia]]), Mark Rizk ([[Antelope, California]]), Shaw Grigsby Jr. ([[Gainesville, Florida]]), [[Rick Clunn]] ([[Ava, Missouri]]), Kotaro Kiriyama (Tokyo, Japan), and Norio Tanabe (Tokyo, Japan). This was the 27th consecutive (and overall) Classic that third-place finisher Rick Clunn had competed in. It was [[Kevin VanDam]]'s 10th consecutive Classic, with VanDam then having managed to make the Classic every season of his ten-years in [[Bass Anglers Sportsman Society|B.A.S.S.]] competition. This was also the Larry Nixon's 22nd, Gary Klein's 19th, Georg Cohcharn's 18th, and Ron Sheffield's 12th total Classic. The 2000 edition was considered to be one of the most challenging editions of the Bassmaster Classic. Chicago was the third northern location to host the event, with [[Alexandria Bay]], [[New York City]] ([[Saint Lawrence River]]) and [[Cincinnati]] ([[Ohio River]]) having previously hosted the 1980 and 1983 editions, respectively.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.zeiners.com/classic2000.html |title=BASS Masters Classic 2000 Chicago - July 20-22, 2000 |date=July 22, 2000 |website=www.zeiners.com |access-date=February 2, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Thomas |first=Gary |date=July 2000 |title=The BassMasters Classic |url=http://www.lib.niu.edu/2000/oi000705.html |newspaper=Outdoors Illinois |location=[[Illinois]] |access-date=February 26, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bassmaster.com/35-milestones-bass-history |title=35 milestones in bass history |date=March 4, 2008 |website=w—.bassmaster.com |publisher=[[Bass Anglers Sportsman Society]] |access-date=February 26, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=B.A.S.S. Masters Classic headed for Chicago |url=http://www.toledoblade.com/frontpage/2000/07/13/B-A-S-S-Masters-Classic-headed-for-Chicago.html |newspaper=[[The Blade (Toledo, Ohio)|The Blade]] |location=Toledo, Ohio |date=June 13, 2000 |access-date=February 26, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite press release |author=Office of the [[Governor of Illinois]] ([[George Ryan]]) |date=July 12, 2000 |title=Illinois Welcomes Bass Masters Classic |url=http://www3.illinois.gov/pressreleases/ShowPressRelease.cfm?SubjectID=3&RecNum=1187 |location=Illinois |publisher=Illinois Government News Network |access-date=2016-02-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Bean |first=Covey |date=July 16, 2000 |title=Hook, skyline and sinker Chicago's bright lights surround Bassmasters |url=http://newsok.com/article/2704561 |newspaper=[[The Oklahoman]] |location=Oklahoma City |access-date=February 26, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=July 8, 2000 |title=BASS Masters Classic |url=http://www.greenevillesun.com/sports/bass-masters-classic/article_bd2682d9-2780-580f-b56b-a5b59c444944.html |newspaper=[[The Greeneville Sun]] |location=Greeneville, Tennessee|access-date=February 26, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Bass Masters Classic |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1955&dat=20000716&id=9P0hAAAAIBAJ&sjid=3KMFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4623,301281&hl=en |newspaper=[[Reading Eagle]] |location=Reading, Pennsylvania |date=July 16, 2000 |access-date=February 26, 2016|quote=The 30th Bass Masters Classic will be held on Lake Michigan near Chicago July 20–22. ===2001=== [[File:XflNight.JPG|thumb|right|250px|The [[XFL]] [[Chicago Enforcers]] play at Soldier Field]] *February 10 [[XFL]] [[Chicago Enforcers]] first home game. Was played against [[NY/NJ Hitmen]].<ref name="aboutxflschedule">{{cite web|url=http://football.about.com/library/weekly/bl_xflschedule.htm|title=Xtreme Football League! 2001 Schedule|accessdate=July 4, 2014}}</ref> *April 7 [[XFL]] [[Chicago Enforcers]] final home game. Was played against [[Orlando Rage]].<ref name=aboutxflschedule/> *June 16 and 17 [['N Sync]] [[PopOdyssey]] concerts, with [[BBMak]], [[3LW]] and [[Dream (American group)|Dream]]. *June 24 30,000 attended a celebration of the new millennium held by Chicago's Catholic archdiocese.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *July 6 and 7 [[Dave Matthews Band]] concerts, with [[Buddy Guy]] and [[Angélique Kidjo]]. These two concerts were attended by a total of 170,000 concertgoers.<ref name=Images/> Recordings from the later date were included on [[Warehouse (Dave Matthews Band)#The Warehouse 5 Volume 2|The Warehouse 5 Volume 2]]. *September 1 the [[Jackson State Tigers football|Jackson State Tigers]] faced the [[Howard Bison football|Howard Bisons]] in the Chicago Football Classic.<ref>{{cite news |title=Classic renamed for Payton |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2001-09-01/sports/0109010173_1_chicago-football-classic-historically-black-colleges-jackson-state |newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]] |date=September 1, 2001 |access-date=February 2, 2016 }}</ref> The game was attended by 50,000 spectators. *September 9 Soldier Field hosted [[2001 Women's U.S. Cup]]. These matches were preceded by an opening match at Schwaben Field in the Chicago suburb of [[Buffalo Grove]] two days prior. The second game played at Soldier Field was the third and the final game played in the tournament, as the tournament's additional matches were cancelled following the [[September 11 attacks|9/11 terrorist attacks]], which occurred while the tournament was still in its [[Round-robin tournament|round-robin]] phase. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; width:60%;" |- !Date !Team #1 !Result !Team #2 !Spectators |- |September 9, 2001||{{fb|USA}}||style="text-align:center;"|4–1||{{fb|GER}}||style="text-align:center;"|10,235 |- |September 9, 2001||{{fb|CHN}}||style="text-align:center;"|3–0||{{fb|JPN}}||style="text-align:center;"| |} *[[Mount Carmel High School (Chicago)|Mount Carmel]] defeated [[Morgan Park High School|Morgan Park]] 50–0 in the 2001 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/> *[[2001–02 NFL playoffs|2001 NFC Divisional Playoff]]: [[2001 Philadelphia Eagles season|Philadelphia]] 33, [[2001 Chicago Bears season|Bears]] 19. This was also the last home game before the renovations took place.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> [[File:Meigs field USGS 2002.jpg (Cropped, Soldier Field).png|thumb|right|125x125px|Overhead view of Soldier Field in 2002, during its renovation.]]
===2002=== No events took place due to Soldier Field's renovation.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> [[File:Soldier Field in 2003 NPS.jpg|thumb|125x125px|left|Soldier Field in 2003]] [[File:Meigs field runway4 (Cropped).JPG|thumb|125x125px|Soldier Field in April 2003]]
===2003=== *The Chicago Bears moved back into Soldier Field for after playing their home games in [[Memorial Stadium (Champaign)|Memorial Stadium]] at the [[University of Illinois]] in [[Champaign, Illinois|Champaign]] for [[2002 Chicago Bears season|their 2002 season]].<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> The Chicago Fire also returned after spending a season at [[Benedetti–Wehrli Stadium]] in [[Naperville, Illinois|Naperville]]. *In the autumn the newly reopened stadium hosted a meeting of [[AT&T]]'s Illinois salespeople in its banquet hall lounge.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *[[Loyola Academy]] defeated [[Simeon Career Academy|Simeon]] 22–14 in the 2003 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/> *The week after [[Christmas]] a winter festival, including [[snowman]] building contest, was held in the newly created parkland surrounding the renovated stadium.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> [[File:FHCC Sailors present finishing medals at Soldier Field 10 Mile 140524-N-ME988-123.jpg|thumb|left|125px|The Soldier Field 10 Mile has been held annually since 2004.]] [[File:Poland scores.jpg|thumb|right|125px|July 11, 2004 USA vs. Poland international-friendly]]
===2004=== *In early 2004 a [[snowboarding]] competition was held at Soldier Field's sledding hill (part of the new parkland that was created around the stadium during its renovation).<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *May 29 the inaugural edition of the Soldier Field 10 Mile was held. This race has been held every year since.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://soldierfield10.com/results |title=Results |website=soldierfield10.com |publisher=Soldier Field 10 Mile |accessdate=October 12, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.doitsports.com/newresults3/client/55901_66713_2004.htm |title=Soldier Field 10 miler |website=www.doitsports.com |access-date=October 12, 2015 |quote=Soldier Field 10 miler Chicago, Illinois May 29, 2004}}</ref> *July 11 USA vs. Poland international-friendly soccer match. The game finished 1–1.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ussoccer.com/stories/2014/03/17/11/22/arena-calls-18-players-for-july-11-friendly-vs-poland-in-chicago |title=Arena Calls 18 Players for July 11 Friendly vs. Poland in Chicago |date=June 30, 2004 |website=www.ussoccer.com |publisher=[[US Soccer]] |access-date=October 15, 2015}}</ref><ref name=US-Poland>{{cite web |url=http://www.ussoccer.com/stories/2014/03/17/11/25/us-mens-national-team-draws-poland-2-2-at-soldier-field |title= U.S. Mens National Team Draws Poland 2-2 at Soldier Field |date=October 9, 2010 |website=www.ussoccer.com |publisher=[[US Soccer]] |access-date=October 15, 2015 |quote=In the first of their final three matches in 2010, the U.S. Men's National Team drew with Poland 2-2 behind goals from Jozy Altidore and Oguchi Onyewu in front of 31,696 fans at Soldier Field. The U.S. twice took the lead, on Altidore's goal in the 13th minute and again on Onyewu's in the 52nd, but Poland was able to respond both times to earn the draw. The tie was the second straight for the U.S. against Poland on home soil as the last match between the two countries on July 11, 2004 – which was also played at Soldier Field – ended in a 1-1 draw.}}</ref><ref name=USA-Poland>{{cite web |url=http://www.teamusa.org/US-Soccer/Features/2010/August/18/U-S-Men-s-National-Team-set-to-face-Poland-on-Oct-9-at-Chicago-s-Soldier-Field |title=U.S. Men's National Team set to face Poland on Oct. 9 at Chicago's Soldier Field |date=August 18, 2010 |website=www.teamusa.org |publisher=Team USA Soccer |access-date=October 15, 2015}}</ref> *October 9 the [[Mississippi Valley State Delta Devils football|Mississippi Valley State Delta Devils]] faced the [[Grambling State Tigers football|Grambling State Tigers]] in the Chicago Football Classic.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Ebony College Calendar |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aNkDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA138&lpg=PA138 |journal=[[Ebony (magazine)|Ebony]] |date=September 2004 |access-date=February 2, 2016 }}</ref> *[[Brother Rice High School (Chicago)|Brother Rice]] defeated [[Lane Technical College Prep High School|Lane Tech]] in the 2004 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/><ref name=prep/> [[File:Stadechicago.JPG|thumb|right|125px|Soldier Field in 2005]]
===2005=== *In 2005 the inaugural Kickoff Classic, an annual preseason Soldier Field matchup of two high-ranking high school football teams, was played.<ref name=stadiumanditscity/> *September 10 [[The Rolling Stones]] [[A Bigger Bang (concert tour)|A Bigger Bang]] concert, with [[Los Lonely Boys]]<ref name=net/> *[[Morgan Park High School|Morgan Park]] defeated [[Brother Rice High School (Chicago)|Brother Rice]] in the 2005 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/> *[[2005–06 NFL playoffs|2005 NFC Divisional Playoff]]: [[2005 Carolina Panthers season|Carolina Panthers]] 29, [[2005 Chicago Bears season|Bears]] 21 [[File:Gay Games 2006, Chicago.jpg|thumb|125x125px|right|Opening ceremonies of the 2006 Gay Games]]
===2006=== *July 15 Soldier Field hosted the opening ceremonies of the [[2006 Gay Games]]. 40,000 spectators attended. [[Mayor of Chicago]] [[Richard M. Daley]] delivered a speech at the event. The ceremony featured the likes of [[George Takei]], [[Megan Mullally]], [[Margaret Cho]], [[Greg Louganis]], [[Jody Watley]], [[Frankie Knuckles]], [[Andy Bell (singer)|Andy Bell]], [[Staceyann Chin]], [[Jorge Valencia]], [[Keith Boykin]], [[James Hormel]], [[Holly Near]], [[Barbara Higbie]], [[Nedra Johnson]], [[Teresa Trull]], [[Kate Clinton]], [[Saskia Webber]], [[Billy Bean]], [[Heather Small]], [[Esera Tuaolo]], and [[Suzanne Westenhoefer]]. The event also included a performance by the cast of [[Avenue Q]]. Among the event's several choreographers was [[Christopher Harrison (choreographer)|Christopher Harrison]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Chicago Games |url=http://www.gaygameschicago.org/images/ceremonies/Opening/OCprogram.pdf |title=Opening Ceremony Program |accessdate=2006-12-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060810062506/http://www.gaygameschicago.org/images/ceremonies/Opening/OCprogram.pdf |archivedate=August 10, 2006 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://gaygameschicago.com/ |title=Gay Games Chicago |website=gaygameschicago.com |accessdate=September 30, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140517093001/http://gaygameschicago.com/ |archivedate=May 17, 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gettyimages.com/detail/news-photo/megan-mullally-at-the-opening-of-the-seventh-gay-games-at-news-photo/117929396|title=Gay Games - Opening Ceremony - July 15, 2006 |website=www.gettyimages.com |publisher=Getty Images |access-date=November 9, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Armour |first=Terry |date=July 16, 2006 |title='Will and Grace' meetS Gay Games |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2006-07-16/news/0607160334_1_gay-games-mayor-richard-daley-olympics |newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]] |access-date=November 9, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Armour |first=Terry |date=October 30, 2005 |title=Soldier Field has been picked to host the opening... |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2005-10-30/news/0510300252_1_soldier-field-ceremonies-softball-and-tennis |newspaper=Chicago Tribune |access-date=November 9, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.globalgayz.com/usas-gay-games-opening-ceremony-2/627/ |title=USA – Gay Games: Opening Ceremony |date=January 1, 2011 |website=globalgayz.com |accessdate=September 29, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140930013357/https://www.globalgayz.com/usas-gay-games-opening-ceremony-2/627/ |archivedate=September 30, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Mullally Joins Gay Games Slate |url=http://www.windycitymediagroup.com/lgbt/Mullally-Joins-Gay-Games-Slate/11732.html |newspaper=[[Windy City Times]] |location=[[Chicago]] |date=June 14, 2006 |access-date=November 9, 2015 }}</ref> *July 21 60,000 spectators attended [[Bon Jovi]] concert, with [[Nickelback]], on the [[Have a Nice Day Tour]]. The concert lasted three hours, the longest a concert had ever at Soldier Field.<ref name=Images/> *October 11 [[The Rolling Stones]] [[A Bigger Bang (concert tour)|A Bigger Bang]] concert, with [[Elvis Costello]] & The Imposters.<ref name=net/> *[[Brother Rice High School (Chicago)|Brother Rice]] defeated [[Hubbard High School (Illinois)|Hubbard]] 24–14 in the 2006 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/> *[[2006–07 NFL playoffs|2006 NFC Divisional Playoff]]: [[2006 Chicago Bears season|Bears]] 27, [[2006 Seattle Seahawks season|Seattle Seahawks]] 24 (OT) [[File:20070110 Soldier Field (2).JPG|thumb|125x125px|right|Soldier Field in 2007]]
===2007=== *January 21 the [[2006–07 NFL playoffs|2006–2007 NFC Championship Game]] granted the [[2006 Chicago Bears season|Bears]] their second trip to the [[Super Bowl XLI|Super Bowl]], the first in 21 years, with a 39–14 victory over the [[2006 New Orleans Saints season|New Orleans Saints]].<ref name=Images/> *[[2007 CONCACAF Gold Cup|2007]] [[CONCACAF Gold Cup]] {{clear}} {| class="wikitable" |- !Date !Time ([[Central Time Zone|CDT]]) !Team #1 !Res. !Team #2 !Round !Spectators |- |June 21, 2007||18:00||{{fb|CAN}}||style="text-align:center;"|1–2||{{fb|USA}}||Semi-finals||style="text-align:center;"|50,760 |- |June 21, 2007||18:00||{{fb|USA}}||style="text-align:center;"|2–1||{{fb|MEX}}||[[2007 CONCACAF Gold Cup Final|Final]]||style="text-align:center;"|60,000 |} [[File:The Crowd at Soldier's Field (1043829789).jpg|thumb|right|250x250px|Crowd at the AFL-CIO Working Families Vote Presidential Forum]] [[File:AFL-CIO Presidential Forum (1044684750) (cropped).jpg|thumb|250x250px|(from left to right) [[Joe Biden|Biden]], [[Hillary Clinton|Clinton]], [[Chris Dodd|Dodd]], [[John Edwards|Edwards]] and [[Dennis Kucinich|Kucinich]] during the AFL-CIO Working Families Vote Presidential Forum ([[Barack Obama|Obama]] and [[Bill Richardson|Richardson]], who were to the left of Biden, are not pictured) ]] *August 7 [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] [[2008 Democratic presidential candidates|presidential candidates]] [[Hillary Clinton]], [[Barack Obama]], [[Joe Biden]], [[Bill Richardson]], [[Chris Dodd]], [[John Edwards]], and [[Dennis Kucinich]] participated in the [[AFL-CIO]] [[Democratic Party presidential debates, 2008#August 7, 2007 – Chicago, Illinois|Working Families Vote Presidential Forum]], a Democratic Presidential debate, was held at Soldier Field before a crowd of approximately 15,500 union members. The forum was moderated by [[Keith Olbermann]] broadcast by [[MSNBC]]. The candidates spoke from a stage in Soldier Field's north end zone.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://chicago.suntimes.com/politics/7/71/175993/sweet-column-afl-cio-presidential-forum-tuesday-in-chicago |title=Sweet column: AFL-CIO presidential forum Tuesday in Chicago. |last=Sweet |first=Lynn |date=November 20, 2013 |website=[[Chicago Sun-Times]] |access-date=December 19, 2015 |quote=On Tuesday, seven of the eight Democratic candidates will gather on a stage at Soldier Field — in the north end zone — for the AFL-CIO's Working Families President Forum. It's the latest in a string of Democratic forums and debates, different because the audience will be between 12,000 and 14,000 union members and their families, drawn from Chicago's extensive labor community and union activists from surrounding states. The forum, moderated by MSNBC's Keith Olbermann, runs for 90 minutes, starting at 6 p.m. It will be televised live on MSNBC and XM satellite radio.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.massaflcio.org/afl-cio-holds-presidential-endorsement |title=AFL-CIO Holds Off On Presidential Endorsement |date=August 8, 2007 |website=http://www.massaflcio.org |publisher=Massachusetts AFL-CIO |access-date=December 19, 2015 |quote=Following its Presidential Forum attended by 17,500 union members here last night }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=The Democratic Candidates Forum |url=http://mobile.nytimes.com/2007/08/08/us/politics/07demsforum.html?pagewanted=all&referer=&_r=0 |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=December 19, 2015 |access-date=December 19, 2015 }}</ref> [[Hillary Clinton|Clinton]] was, at the time, a [[United States Senate|Senator]], a former [[First Lady of the United States|First Lady]], and would later become [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]] and serve as the Democratic nominee for President in the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016]]. [[Barack Obama|Obama]] was, at the time, a Senator, and would ultimately become President. [[Joe Biden|Biden]] was, at the time, a senator, and would ultimately become [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]]. [[Bill Richardson|Richardson]] was, at the time, [[Governor of New Mexico]] and was also a former [[United States Secretary of Energy|Secretary of Energy]], [[United States Ambassador to the United Nations|UN Ambassador]], and [[U.S. House of Representatives|Representative]]. [[John Edwards|Edwards]] was a former senator and had previously been the Democratic Nominee for Vice President in the [[2004 United States Presidential Election|2004 election]]. [[Chris Dodd|Dodd]] was, at the time, a Senator and a former Representative. [[Dennis Kucinich|Kucinich]] was, at the time, a Representative and the former [[List of mayors of Cleveland|Mayor of Cleveland]]. *The 2007 edition of the annual [[Special Olympics]] Chicago featured an opening ceremony with a performance by the [[Jesse White Tumbling Team]] and a speech from Special Olympics Illinois [[Chief Executive Officer|CEO]] Doug Snyder. The [[Keith Magnuson]] Spirit Award was presented by Keith's son Kevin Magnuson to the [[D.S. Wentworth School]], largely due to the efforts of their lead coach Ophelia Doyle who accepted the award for the school's team.<ref name=Images/> *2007 [[Chicago Trophy]] football tournament: {| class="wikitable" |- ! Date ! Team 1 ! Result ! Team 2 |- |July 27, 2007||{{flagicon|Italy}} [[Reggina Calcio]]||| 1-1||{{flagicon|Poland}} [[Wisła Kraków]] |- |July 27, 2007||{{flagicon|Spain}} [[Sevilla FC]]||1-0||{{flagicon|Mexico}} [[Club Toluca]] |- |July 29, 2007||{{flagicon|Italy}} [[Reggina Calcio]]||0-2||{{flagicon|Mexico}} [[Club Toluca]] |- |July 29, 2007||{{flagicon|Spain}} [[Sevilla FC]]||0-1||{{flagicon|Poland}} [[Wisła Kraków]] |} *August 26, at the halftime of a high school football game at Soldier Field [[Fenwick High School (Oak Park, Illinois)|Fenwick]] and [[Hubbard High School (Chicago)|Hubbard]] at [[Soldier Field]], [[Johnny Lattner]]'s #34 jersey was retired by Fenwick. Lattner played for Fenwick when he was in high school, and would later go on to play football collegiately (where he would win the 1953 [[Heisman Trophy]]) and professionally. This was the first time Fenwick had ever retired a number.<ref>{{cite news|title=All-America |work=Time Magazine |date=November 9, 1953 |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,819176-4,00.html |accessdate=May 30, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930065813/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0%2C9171%2C819176-4%2C00.html |archivedate=September 30, 2007 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Sakamoto |first=Bob |date=August 24, 2007 |title=New generation takes up the family business |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2007-08-24/news/0708221149_1_receiver-state-titles-bears |newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]] |access-date=October 23, 2015 }}</ref> *September 1 the [[2007 Northern Illinois Huskies football team|NIU]] faced the [[2007 Iowa Hawkeyes football team|University of Iowa]] in the first [[College Football|Division I College Football]] game at Soldier Field since its renovations. Iowa defeated NIU 16-3. A capacity crowd of 61,500 attended the game, setting a [[Mid-American Conference]] record for a home game in football (the match was considered a home game for NIU).<ref name=openbuildings/> *September 9 the [[United States men's national soccer team|United States men's soccer team]] played [[Brazil national football team|Brazil national team]] in a friendly match.<ref name=csc/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2007-10-05/sports/0710050028_1_soldier-field-gold-cup-toyota-park|title=Soldier Field big time host|accessdate=July 15, 2014}}</ref> *[[St. Rita of Cascia High School|Saint Rita]] defeated [[Morgan Park High School|Morgan Park]] 50–0 in the 2007 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/> [[File:Fan photo from Sunday night game, Sept 2008.jpg|thumb|125x125px|right||The Bears playing at Soldier Field in 2008]] [[File:Soldier FieldChi.jpg|thumb|125x125px|right|Soldier Field in 2008]]
===2008=== *June 8 33,608 attended an [[Exhibition game|international friendly]] between [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]] and [[Peru national football team|Peru]], which Mexico won 4-0.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.lasoccernews.com/teams/mexico2.php?article_id=2991 |title= Cruising to Victory Mexico Tops Peru 4-0 at Soldier Field |author= |date= 8 June 2008 |work=LA Soccer News |accessdate=15 June 2010}}</ref> *June 21 [[Kenny Chesney]] concert, with [[Keith Urban]], [[LeAnn Rimes]] and [[Gary Allan]].<ref name=net/> *August 3 [[CD Guadalajara]] vs. [[FC Barcelona]] international-friendly soccer match. Barcelona won the match 5–2. *October 11 and 12 Chicago Country Music Festival *[[Loyola Academy]] defeated [[Lane Technical College Prep High School|Lane Tech]] 17-0 in the 2008 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/> [[File:Chicago City Views Summer 2009 Raed Elaydi (32).JPG|thumb|250x250|Right|Soldier Field in 2009.]] [[File:UsavsHonduras.JPG|thumb|125x125px|right||The US faces Honduras at Soldier Field during the 2009 CONCACAF Gold Cup.]]
===2009=== *May 30 4,300 spectators were in attendance as Soldier Field played host to its first lacrosse match. For their season-opener the [[Major League Lacrosse]]'s [[Chicago Machine (MLL)|Chicago Machine]] faced the [[Boston Cannons]] at Soldier Field. The Cannons defeated the Machine 16-14. This was the first professional lacrosse match ever played within the city limits of Chicago, as all previous Chicago Machine games had been played in suburban locations.<ref name=lax1>{{cite web |url=http://www.oursportscentral.com/services/releases/?id=3791025 |title=Pro Lacrosse at Soldier Field |date=March 17, 2009 |website=www.oursportscentral.com |publisher=Our Sports Central |access-date= October 15, 2015|quote=On May 30, for the first time ever, lacrosse will be played at Chicago's historic Soldier Field. The Chicago Machine and the Chicago Park District announced today that the professional lacrosse team will play two home games at Soldier Field – its home opener on Saturday, May 30 and the final game of the season on Saturday, August 8. The May 30 game will also be the first time that the Major League Lacrosse has been played in the City of Chicago. The Chicago Machine has played all of its home games at suburban locations during its first three seasons.}}</ref><ref name=lax2>{{cite web |url=http://www.oursportscentral.com/services/releases/?id=3876134 |title=Pro Lacrosse Returns to Soldier Field on August 8 |date=July 31, 2009 |website=www.oursportscentral |publisher=Our Sports Central |access-date=October 15, 2015 |quote=Chicago, Illinois – The Chicago Machine professional lacrosse team returns to Soldier Field on Saturday, August 8, for the final game of the regular 2009 season against the Long Island Lizards. Pending results of games on August 1, the game could have play-off implications for the young Chicago franchise. Gates open at 6 pm for the 7 pm game. All seats are $20 and tickets are available at www.chicagomachine.com, through Ticketmaster outlets, or by calling (312) 255-1522. Chicago had its 2009 home opener at Soldier Field on May 30, 2009, a game it lost to the Boston Cannons 16 to 14 in front of 4,300 fans. This was the first time lacrosse had ever been played at the legendary stadium and was one of Chicago's largest home audiences ever.}}</ref><ref name=lax3>{{cite web |url=http://www.oursportscentral.com/services/releases/?id=3881273 |title=Machine Back to Soldier Field Tomorrow |date=August 7, 2009 |website=www.oursportscentral.com |publisher=Our Sports Central |access-date=October 15, 2015 |quote=The Chicago Machine will return to Soldier Field tomorrow, Saturday, August 8, for the final game of the season against the Long Island Lizards.}}</ref><ref name=lax4>{{cite web |url=http://articles.chicagobreakingnews.com/2009-03-17/news/28523614_1_host-lacrosse-soldier-field-home-opener |title=A first -- Soldier Field to host lacrosse |date=March 17, 2009 |website=articles.chicagobreakingnews.com |publisher=Chicago Breaking News |access-date=October 15, 2015 |quote=For the first time ever, lacrosse will be played at Chicago's historic Soldier Field, the Daily Herald reports. The Chicago Machine and the Chicago Park District announced today that the professional lacrosse team will play two home games at Soldier Field, including its home opener on May 30. That opener will also be the first time that Major League Lacrosse has been played in Chicago. The Chicago Machine has played all of its home games at suburban locations during its first three seasons. The second game at Soldier Field will be the final game of the season on Aug. 8.}}</ref><ref name=lax5>{{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/03/18/soldier-field-to-host-two_n_176299.html |title=Soldier Field To Host Two Pro Lacrosse Games, First Time Game To Be Played At Stadium |date=April 18, 2015 |website=www.huffingtonpost.com |publisher=[[Daily Herald (Arlington Heights)|Daily Herald]] (republished by [[Huffington Post]]) |access-date=October 15, 2015 |quote=For the first time ever, lacrosse will be played at Chicago's historic Soldier Field. The Chicago Machine and the Chicago Park District announced Tuesday that the professional lacrosse team will play two home games at Soldier Field}}</ref><ref name=lax6>{{cite web |url=http://prev.dailyherald.com/story/print/?id=279667 |title=Soldier Field set to host 2 Machine lacrosse games |date=March 17, 2009 |website=[[Daily Herald (Arlington Heights)|Daily Herald]] |access-date=October 15, 2015 |quote=or the first time ever, lacrosse will be played at Chicago's historic Soldier Field. The Chicago Machine and the Chicago Park District announced Tuesday that the professional lacrosse team will play two home games at Soldier Field, including its home opener on May 30. That opener will also be the first time that Major League Lacrosse has been played in Chicago. The Chicago Machine has played all of its home games at suburban locations during its first three seasons. The second game at Soldier Field will be the final game of the season on Aug. 8.}}</ref><ref name=lax7>{{cite web |url=http://prev.dailyherald.com/story/?id=279667 |title=Soldier Field set to host 2 Machine lacrosse games |date=April 17, 2009 |website=dailyherald.com |publisher=[[Daily Herald (Arlington Heights)|Daily Herald]] |access-date=October 15, 2015 |quote=For the first time ever, lacrosse will be played at Chicago's historic Soldier Field. The Chicago Machine and the Chicago Park District announced Tuesday that the professional lacrosse team will play two home games at Soldier Field, including its home opener on May 30. That opener will also be the first time that Major League Lacrosse has been played in Chicago. The Chicago Machine has played all of its home games at suburban locations during its first three seasons. The second game at Soldier Field will be the final game of the season on Aug. 8.}}</ref><ref name=lax8>{{cite web |url=http://www.nbcchicago.com/news/sports/Lacrosse-Comes-To-Soldier-Field.html |title=Lacrosse Comes To Soldier Field |website=www.nbcchicago.com |publisher=[[National Broadcasting Corporation]] |access-date=October 15, 2015 |quote=Lacrosse is coming to Chicago's historic Soldier Field for the first time ever, the Daily Herald reports. The Chicago Machine and the Chicago Park District announced Tuesday that the professional lacrosse team will play two home games at Soldier Field, including its home opener on May 30. That opener will also be the first time that Major League Lacrosse has been played in Chicago. The Chicago Machine has played all of its home games at suburban locations during its first three seasons. The second game at Soldier Field will be the final game of the season on Aug. 8.}}</ref> *June 13 [[Kenny Chesney]] concert, with [[Lady Antebellum]], [[Miranda Lambert]], [[Montgomery Gentry]] and [[Sugarland]] *[[2009 CONCACAF Gold Cup|2009]] [[CONCACAF]] [[CONCACAF Gold Cup|Gold Cup]]<ref name=csc/> {{clear}} {| class="wikitable" |- !Date !Time ([[Central Time Zone|CDT]]) !Team #1 !Res. !Team #2 !Round !Spectators |- |July 23, 2009||18:00||{{fb|HON}}||style="text-align:center;"|0–2||{{fb|USA}}||Semi-finals||style="text-align:center;"|55,173 |- |June 23, 2009||21:00||{{fb|CRC}}||style="text-align:center;"|1–1||{{fb|MEX}}||Semi-finals||style="text-align:center;"|55,173 |} [[File:09122009 U2360SnowPatrol.JPG|thumb|right|125px|Soldier Field configured for [[U2 360° Tour|360° Tour]] in 2009]] [[File:Defense.gov photo essay 090915-A-2050S-248.jpg|thumb|right|125x125px|2009 Medal of Honor Convention]]
*August 8 [[Major League Lacrosse]]'s [[Chicago Machine (MLL)|Chicago Machine]] hosted the [[Long Island Lizards]] at Soldier Field for their season closer.<ref name=lax1/><ref name=lax2/><ref name=lax3/><ref name=lax4/><ref name=lax5/><ref name=lax6/><ref name=lax7/><ref name=lax8/> *September 12 and 13 [[U2]] kicked off the second leg of their [[U2 360° Tour|360° Tour]] with to sold-out concerts, with [[Snow Patrol]] and [[Interpol (band)|Interpol]], attended by a cumulative 135,872 concertgoers.<ref name=net/> These concerts opened up [[U2]]'s [[U2 360° Tour|360° Tour]] in North America. One of the dates set Soldier Field's post-renovation attendance record at the time, with 67,936 spectators.<ref name=deadNYT>{{cite web |url=http://mobile.nytimes.com/blogs/artsbeat/2015/07/06/grateful-dead-breaks-soldier-field-records/?_r=0&referrer= |title=Grateful Dead Break Soldier Field Records |last=Chow |first=Andrew R. |date=July 5, 2015 |website=[[New York Times]] |access-date=July 9, 2015}}</ref><ref name=deadmusictimes>{{cite web |url=http://www.musictimes.com/articles/42265/20150705/grateful-dead-set-soldier-field-attendance-record-u2-fare-thee-well.htm |title=Grateful Dead Set Soldier Field Attendance Record From U2 at 'Fare Thee Well' |last=Book |first=Ryan |date=July 5, 2015 |website=www.musictimes.com |access-date=July 9, 2015}}</ref><ref name=deadkomo>{{cite web |url=http://www.komonews.com/news/entertainment/Grateful-Dead-break-records-with-final-shows-311755361.html? |title=Grateful Dead smash attendance records with final shows |date=July 6, 2015 |work=[[Komo News]] |access-date=July 9, 2015}}</ref><ref name=deadbillboard>{{cite web |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/grateful-dead/6620076/grateful-dead-fare-thee-well-sets-record-attendance-at-chicagos?mobile_redirection=false |title=Grateful Dead Fare Thee Well Sets Attendance Record at Chicago's Soldier Field |last=Waddell |first=Ray |date=July 4, 2015 |website=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=July 9, 2015}}</ref> *September 15 Soldier Field hosted the 2009 Medal of Honor Convention. *[[St. Rita of Cascia High School|Saint Rita]] defeated [[Simeon Career Academy|Simeon]] 34–20 in the 2009 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/>

===2011=== *June 2011 international soccer match between [[Chicago Fire Soccer Club|Chicago Fire]] and [[Manchester United]].<ref name=csc/> *Soldier Field was a venue of the [[2011 CONCACAF Gold Cup]] hosting two matches: {{clear}} {| class="wikitable" |- !Date !Time ([[Central Time Zone|CDT]]) !Team #1 !Res. !Team #2 !Round !Spectators |- |June 12, 2011||18:00||{{fb|SLV}}||style="text-align:center;"|6–1||{{fb|CUB}}||Group A||style="text-align:center;"|62,000 |- |June 12, 2011||20:00||{{fb|MEX}}||style="text-align:center;"|4–1||{{fb|CRC}}||Group A||style="text-align:center;"|62,000 |} *July 5 a sold-out crowd of 64,297 attended an [[U2]] [[U2 360° Tour|360° Tour]] concert, with [[Interpol (band)|Interpol]].<ref name=net/> *August 2011 the U.S. Paralympic Team Valor Games Midwest were held at Soldier Field.<ref name=csc/> *August 23 [[Wayne Baker Brooks]] Band concert, with [[Sugar Blue]]. *September 3 the [[Texas A&M Aggies football|Texas A&M Aggies]] faced the [[Hampton Pirates football|Hampton Pirates]] in the Chicago Football Classic.<ref name=WCL14TH/> *September 17 the [[2011 Northern Illinois Huskies football team|Huskies]] returned to play the [[2011 Wisconsin Badgers football team|Wisconsin Badgers]] in a game that was called "Soldier Field Showdown II".
===2012=== [[File:President Barack Obama throws a football.jpg|thumb|right|175x175px|President [[Barack Obama]] throws a football at Soldier Field after the [[2012 Chicago Summit]]]] [[File:NATO Summit 120518-G-PL299-036.jpg|thumb|right|175x175px|Soldier Field during the [[2012 Chicago Summit]] with Coast Guard boats stationed at nearby Burnham Harbor]] *May 2012, United States President [[Barack Obama]] held a [[NATO]] summit (the 2012 Chicago Summit) at Soldier Field.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagobears.com/news/NewsStory.asp?story_id=8826|title=President Obama throws football at Soldier Field|publisher=Chicago Bears|date=May 21, 2012|accessdate=July 24, 2012}}</ref> Chicago was also supposed to host the [[38th G8 summit]] just prior to the NATO summit, but on May 5, 2010, the White House announced a last-minute venue change for the G8 Summit. The G8 Summit was instead held at [[Camp David]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Pace|first=Julie|title=G8 summit moved to Camp David last-minute|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Latest-News-Wires/2012/0305/G8-summit-moved-to-Camp-David-last-minute|accessdate=March 7, 2012|newspaper=Christian Science Monitor|date=March 5, 2012}}</ref> *June 16 and 17 the first annual [[Spring Awakening (festival)|Spring Awakening Music Festival]] was held at Soldier Field. It has been held at Soldier Field every year since. The lineup featured [[Moby]], [[Skrillex]], [[Afrojack]], [[Diplo]], [[Flux Pavilion]], [[Laidback Luke]], [[Wolfgang Gartner]], [[A-Trak]], [[Ferry Corsten]], [[Markus Schulz]], [[Hardwell]], [[Arty (musician)|Arty]], Claude Vonstroke, [[Derrick Carter]], [[Dillon Francis]], [[Destructo]], [[Downlink]], [[Felix Cartal]], [[Gabriel & Dresden]], [[Curtis Jones]] (as 'Green Velvet'), Joachim Garraud, [[Kill The Noise]], Lance Herbstrong, Midnight Conspiracy, [[Morgan Page]], Nathan Scott, [[Nervo (duo)|Nervo]], and Nobody Beats the Drum.<ref name=net/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://chicagoist.com/2014/12/03/spring_awakening_music_festival_ins.php|title=Spring Awakening Music Festival Instates Age Limitation For 2015|work=Chicagoist|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160204224045/http://chicagoist.com/2014/12/03/spring_awakening_music_festival_ins.php|archivedate=February 4, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=springlineup>{{cite web |url=http://springawakeningfestival.com/lineup/past-lineups |title=Past Lineups |website=springawakeningfestival.com |publisher=[[Spring Awakening (festival)|Spring Awkening Music Festival]] |access-date=October 22, 2015 }}</ref> *July 7 a sold-out crowd of 51,100 attended a [[Kenny Chesney]] and [[Tim McGraw]] [[Brothers of the Sun Tour]] concert with [[Jake Owen]] and [[Grace Potter and the Nocturnals]]. *August 2 Soldier Field hosted the Terrapin 5K & Music Festival. *September 1 [[2012 Northern Illinois Huskies football team|NIU]] hosted the [[2012 Iowa Hawkeyes football team|Iowa Hawkeyes]] in a season opener that was called "Soldier Field Showdown III". *October 6 [[Notre Dame Fighting Irish football|Notre Dame]] hosted a game at Soldier Field against the [[Miami Hurricanes football|University of Miami]] as part of their [[Shamrock Series]]. *[[Simeon Career Academy|Simeon]] defeated [[Brother Rice High School (Chicago)|Brother Rice]] 14–12 in the 2012 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/>
===2013=== *February 17 [[Notre Dame Fighting Irish men's ice hockey|Notre Dame]] and [[Miami RedHawks men's ice hockey|Miami of Ohio]] as well as [[Wisconsin Badgers men's ice hockey|Wisconsin]] and [[Minnesota Golden Gophers men's ice hockey|Minnesota]] played a collegiate hockey double-header at Soldier Field for the ''[[OfficeMax]] [[Hockey City Classic]]''. The Notre Dame-Miami game was the first outdoor hockey game in the history of the stadium. The ''Hockey City Classic'' is run by Chicago-based Intersport. Participants in the 2013 edition included several future NHL players, such as Notre Dame's [[Anders Lee]], Wisconsin's [[Jake McCabe]], and Minnesota's [[Nate Schmidt]], [[Nick Bjugstad]], and [[Erik Haula]].<ref name=choose/><ref name=2015HockeyCity>{{cite web |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/college/ct-hockey-soldier-field-spt-0208-20150207-story.html|title=Warm weather, poor attendance mar ambiance for Hockey City Classic |last=Goldstein |first=Steven |date=February 8, 2015 |work=Chicago Tribune |access-date=February 9, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagonow.com/chicago-sports-guru/2012/07/college-hockey-doubleheader-coming-to-soldier-field-hockey-city-classic/ |accessdate=November 17, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120725035223/http://www.chicagonow.com/chicago-sports-guru/2012/07/college-hockey-doubleheader-coming-to-soldier-field-hockey-city-classic/ |archivedate=July 25, 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hockeycityclassic.com/page/show/1299783-in-the-pros |title=In the Pros |website=www.hockeycityclassic.com |publisher=Hockey City Classic |access-date=November 3, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hockeycityclassic.com/page/show/1317697-outdoor-college-hockey-through-the-years |title=OUTDOOR COLLEGE HOCKEY THROUGH THE YEARS |website=www.hockeycityclassic.com |publisher=Hockey City Classic |access-date=November 3, 2015 |quote=HOCKEY CITY CLASSIC (Feb. 17, 2013 – Soldier Field, Chicago, Ill.) – In an event that attracted more than 52,000 fans to the first outdoor hockey event at Soldier Field, one of the most famous stadiums in the country, the University of Wisconsin scored three second-period goals to edge the University of Minnesota, 3-2. The first game was also a one-goal thriller, as Notre Dame defeated Miami of Ohio, 2-1.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hockeycityclassic.com/page/show/1299782-2013 |title=2013 |website=www.hockeycityclassic.com |publisher=Hockey City Classic |access-date=November 3, 2015 |quote=FEBRUARY 17, 2013 – SOLDIER FIELD, CHICAGO Notre Dame 2, Miami University 1 – Playing in its first-ever outdoor hockey game in program history, the University of Notre Dame built a two-goal lead and held off a late Miami University rally to earn a 2-1 victory in front of 52,051 fans at Soldier Field in Chicago, Ill. "It was a great atmosphere and an unbelievable experience", Notre Dame defenseman Sam Calabrese said. The game featured stellar play from both goaltenders, including Notre Dame's Steven Summerhays, who stopped 22 of 33 shots fired his way on the day. Mario Lucia got the scoring started for the Fighting Irish when he whipped a one-timer past RedHawks net-minder Ryan McKay at 12:42 in the second period. Notre Dame added to its lead early in the third period when Jeff Costello banged in a rebound of Anders Lee shot to give the Irish a two-goal advantage. Miami cut the Irish's lead in half a little over a minute later thanks to a goal by Kevin Morris, but Summerhays and the Notre Dame defense stood tall and fought off the late charge. Wisconsin 3, Minnesota 2 – Wisconsin used three second-period goals to build a lead and withstood a third-period surge to defeat Minnesota, 3-2, at Soldier Field. John Rumpel recorded 36 saves, with 15 of those stops coming in the opening 20 minutes. "His performance in the first period allowed us to get our feet out and underneath us", Badgers coach Mike Eaves said. "Then we rode an explosive period in terms of goal scoring for us." The Badgers scored all three of their goals in a remarkable 3 minutes and 19 seconds in the second period as Kevin Schulze, Brendan Woods and Sean Little all found the back of the net. Minnesota mounted a furious rally in the closing period, scoring twice, but Rumpel came up with his biggest save of the day when he turned away the Golden Gophers' final shot at the buzzer to preserve the win.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://assets.ngin.com/attachments/document/0060/1042/Minn_WI_2013.pdf |title=Hockey Game Box Score (Final) #2 Minnesota vs #18 Wisconsin (Feb 17, 2013 at Chicago) |website=assets.ngin.com/ |access-date=November 3, 2015 |quote=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://assets.ngin.com/attachments/document/0060/1032/Miami_Notre_Dame_Box_2013.pdf |title=Hockey Game Box Score (Final) #12 Notre Dame vs #3 Miami (Feb 17, 2013 at Chicago, Ill.) |website=assets.ngin.com |access-date=November 3, 2015}}</ref> <!-- template: |- | [[League]] || [[Home team]] || homescore–awayscore || [[Visiting team]] || {{sort|074554|74,554}} (attendance number) --> {|class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size: 95%;text-align: center;" |- !League ! class="unsortable" |Home team ! class="unsortable" |Score ! class="unsortable" |Visiting team !! class="unsortable" |Attendance |- | [[Central Collegiate Hockey Association|CCHA]] || [[Notre Dame Fighting Irish men's ice hockey|Notre Dame Fighting Irish]] || 2–1 || [[Miami RedHawks men's ice hockey|Miami Redhawks]] || rowspan=2|52,051 |- | [[Western Collegiate Hockey Association|WCHA]] || [[Wisconsin Badgers men's ice hockey|Wisconsin Badgers]] || 3–2 || [[Minnesota Golden Gophers men's ice hockey|Minnesota Golden Gophers]] |} *A ''Chicago Gay Hockey Association'' intra-squad game was held in affiliation with the Hockey City Classic in 2013.<ref name="gayhockey">{{cite web |url=http://www.windycitymediagroup.com/m/APPredirect.php?AID=50295|title=CGHA to skate at Soldier Field after Hockey City Classic |last=Forman |first=Ross |date=January 24, 2015 |website=[[Windy City Times]] |accessdate=February 1, 2015}}</ref> *July 2013 Big Ten 10k.<ref name=csc/> *July 7 25,000 spectators attended a ''[[Leo Messi|Messi]] and Friends vs. the World'' charity [[association football]] match. Alongside Lionel Messi, the event featured [[Carlos Bocanegra]], [[Florent Malouda]], [[Alex Song]], [[Dani Osvaldo]], [[Thierry Henry]], and others. Players including [[Cesc Fàbregas]], [[Giovani dos Santos]], [[David Luiz]], [[Robert Lewandowski]], [[Sergio Agüero]] and [[Kevin-Prince Boateng]] were originally scheduled to participate in the match, but all were ultimately unable to. Messi's all-star team defeated the "World" team 9–6.<ref>{{cite news|last=Ecker|first=Danny|date=July 5, 2013|title=Soccer star Messi's Soldier Field game unveils final rosters|url=http://www.chicagobusiness.com/article/20130705/BLOGS04/130709902/soccer-star-messis-soldier-field-game-unveils-final-rosters|newspaper=[[Crain's Chicago Business]]|access-date=April 5, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://prosoccertalk.nbcsports.com/2013/07/05/messi-and-friends-match-in-chicago-marred-by-mass-player-cancellations/|title=Messi and Friends match in Chicago marred by mass player cancellations|last=Bonn|first=Kyle|date=July 5, 2013|website=prosoccertalk.nbcsports.com|publisher=[[National Broadcasting Company]]|access-date=April 5, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csnchicago.com/fire/messi-and-friends-match-tanks-chicago|title=Messi and Friends' match tanks in Chicago|date=July 8, 2013|website=prosoccertalk.nbcsports.com|publisher=[[Comcast SportsNet Chicago]]|access-date=April 5, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Ecker|first=Danny|date=July 3, 2013|title=Major roster changes for Messi & Friends game at Soldier Field|url=http://www.chicagobusiness.com/article/20130703/BLOGS04/130709913/major-roster-changes-for-messi-friends-game-at-soldier-field|newspaper=[[Crain's Chicago Business]]|access-date=April 5, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=McCarthy|first=Jack|date=July 6, 2013|title=Messi's all-stars prevail at Soldier Field|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2013-07-06/sports/ct-spt-0707-messi-soccer-chicago-20130707_1_lionel-messi-soldier-field-all-stars|newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]] |access-date=April 5, 2015}}</ref> *July 12 a sold-out crowd of 45,178 attended a [[Bon Jovi]] [[Because We Can (concert tour)|Because We Can]] concert, with The J. [[File:2014 NHL Stadium Series, Soldier Field.JPG|thumb|right|175x175px|The [[2014 NHL Stadium Series]] featuring the [[Chicago Blackhawks]] and [[Pittsburgh Penguins]]]]
===2014=== *March 1 the [[Chicago Blackhawks]] played against the [[Pittsburgh Penguins]] as part of the [[2014 NHL Stadium Series|2014]] [[National Hockey League|NHL]] [[NHL Stadium Series|Stadium Series]]. The Blackhawks defeated the Penguins 5–1 before a sold-out crowd of 62,921.<ref>[http://www.nhl.com/ice/news.htm?id=668767/ ]{{dead link|date=August 2014}}</ref> *June 13–15 Soldier Field hosted the [[Spring Awakening (festival)|Spring Awakening Music Festival]]. The lineup featured [[Tiesto]], [[Diplo]], [[Kaskade]], Knife & Party, [[Pretty Lights]], [[Big Gigantic]], [[Benny Benassi]], [[Dillon Francis]], [[Eric Prydz]], [[Flux Pavilion]], [[Steve Aoki]], [[A-Trak]], [[Kill The Noise]], Claude Vonstroke, [[Curtis Jones]] (as 'Green Velvet'), [[Borgore]], [[Chuckie (DJ)|Chuckie]], [[3LAU]], [[Alex Metric]], [[Alvin Risk]], [[Andy C]], [[Arty (musician)|Arty]], [[Blasterjaxx]], Caked Up, Candyland, Carnage, [[Datsik (musician)|Datsik]], [[Derrick Carter]], [[Destroid]], [[DVBBS]], [[Dyro]], Feed Me, [[Ferry Corsten]], Gladiator, Gregori Klosman, [[Kap Slap]], [[Kill Paris]], [[Laidback Luke]], Manic Focus, [[Markus Schulz]], Midnight Consipracy, Nick Catchdubs, [[Nervo (DJs)|Nervo]], Oliver Ookay, [[Paper Diamond]], [[Pete Tong]], [[Sander van Doorn]], Sandro Silva, DJ Snake, Thomas Gold, and [[Tommy Trash]].<ref name=net/><ref name=springlineup/> *June 27–29, 2014 Soldier Field served as a landmark along the route of the Chicago installment of the [[2014 ITU World Triathlon Series]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://chicago.triathlon.org/athlete_info/age_group/sprint|title=ITU World Triathlon Series Chicago|accessdate=August 18, 2014}}</ref> *July 1 28,000 attended a viewing party of the broadcast [[2014 World Cup]] Round of 16 game between the United States and Belgium. The show grossed $3,754,362. This concert broke the record the highest-attended [[country music]] concert at Soldier Field.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tasteofcountry.com/luke-bryan-stadium-attendance-record-chicago-2014/ |title=Luke Bryan Sets Stadium Attendance Record for a Country Concert |date= September 3, 2014 |website=tasteofcountry.com |publisher=Taste of Country |accessdate=September 5, 2014}}</ref> *September 20 Soldier Field hosted the Annual Chicago Football Classic, which was played between [[Morehouse College]] and [[Central State University]]. Morehouse won 43-9. The halftime show featured Tone Kapone and Shag from [[WPWX|Power 92]], [[WGCI-FM]] personality Leon Rogers, and [[Spenzo]] who performed his song ''Wife Er'' along with a new song. Spenzo was joined by [[Diggy Simmons]], son of [[Run DMC]] member [[Joseph Simmons|Joseph "Rev Run" Simmons]]. The halftime show ended with a battle of the bands between the Morehouse and Central State marching bands.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://chicagodefender.com/2014/09/21/hbcu-alumni-and-students-head-to-soldier-field-as-the-sun-washed-away-the-rain-at-the-17th-annual-chicago-football-classic/|last=Tomlin|first=Terrence|title=HBCU Alumni and Students Head To Soldier Field As The Sun Washed Away The Rain At The 17th annual Chicago Football Classic|date=September 2014|website=[[Chicago Defender]] |accessdate=October 24, 2014}}</ref> *November 1, 2014 Soldier Field hosted its first international [[rugby union]] [[Test match (rugby league)|test match]] between the [[United States national Rugby Union team|United States]] and [[All Blacks|New Zealand]] as part of the [[2014 end-of-year rugby union tests]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/sport/news/article.cfm?c_id=4&objectid=11233010 |title=All Blacks: Chicago likely test venue – Sport – NZ Herald News |publisher=Nzherald.co.nz |date= |accessdate=2014-08-10}}</ref> More than half of the 61,500 tickets were sold within two days.<ref>[http://usarugby.org/mens-eagles-news/item/more-than-30000-tickets-sold-for-all-blacks-matchup-at-soldier-field "More than 30,000 tickets sold for All Blacks matchup at Soldier Field"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140624100330/http://usarugby.org/mens-eagles-news/item/more-than-30000-tickets-sold-for-all-blacks-matchup-at-soldier-field |date=June 24, 2014 }}, USA Rugby, June 18, 2014.</ref> The attendance was a capacity crowd of 61,500. This set the record for the most attended international rugby test held in the United States, surpassing the previous record by over 40,000. The All Blacks beat the USA Eagles 76-6.<ref>{{cite web|title=Rugby match draws 61,500 to Soldier Field|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/breaking/ct-rugby-us-new-zealand-spt-1102-20141101-story.html||last=McCarthy|first=Jack|date=November 1, 2014|website=www.chicagotribune.com|accessdate=November 2, 2014}}</ref><ref name=allblacksbiz>{{cite web |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/chicago/news/2015/11/16/new-zealand-ireland-rugby-match-at-soldier-field.html |title=New Zealand-Ireland rugby match at Soldier Field nearly set |date=November 16, 2015 |website=www.bizjournals.com |access-date=November 23, 2015 }}</ref><ref name=allblackscrain>{{cite news |last=Ecker |first=Danny |date=November 13, 2015 |title=Soldier Field to host New Zealand-Ireland rugby match: report |url=http://www.chicagobusiness.com/article/20151113/BLOGS04/151119912/soldier-field-to-host-new-zealand-ireland-rugby-match-report |newspaper=[[Crain's Chicago Business]] |access-date=November 23, 2015 }}</ref><ref name=rugbysun>{{cite web |url=http://chicago.suntimes.com/sports/7/71/1101186/chicago-will-host-blacks-rugby-match-ireland |title=Chicago will host All Blacks rugby match against Ireland |last=Thele |first=Kyle |date=November 14, 2015 |work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]] |access-date=November 23, 2015 }}</ref> *[[Loyola Academy|Loyola]] defeated [[Curie Metropolitan High School|Curie]] 14-7 in the 2014 [[Chicago Prep Bowl|Prep Bowl]].<ref name=catholicleague2/>
===2015=== *February 5 the organizers of the ''2015 Coyote Logistics Hockey City Classic'' launched a 12-day winter festival at Soldier Field with a ''Unite on the Ice'' event benefiting [[St. Jude Children's Research Hospital]]. The event included a celebrity hockey game with former [[National Hockey League|NHL]] and [[American Hockey League|AHL]] players, as well as a public free skate at Soldier Field. Participants in the celebrity game included [[Éric Dazé]], [[Jamal Mayers]] and [[Gino Cavallini]]. [[Denis Savard]] was in attendance, serving as an 'honorary coach' during the game.<ref name=medillhockey>{{cite web |url=http://news.medill.northwestern.edu/chicago/public-skating-charity-game-at-soldier-field-thursday/ |title=PUBLIC SKATING, CHARITY GAME AT SOLDIER FIELD THURSDAY |last=Romano |first=Sara |date=February 4, 2015 |website=news.medill.northwestern.edu |publisher=[[Northwestern University]] |access-date=July 5, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20150304201037/http://news.medill.northwestern.edu/chicago/public-skating-charity-game-at-soldier-field-thursday/ |archivedate=March 4, 2015 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> *February 7 Soldier Field hosted the [[2015 Hockey City Classic]], the second edition of the game to be held at Soldier Field. The games of the 2015 ''[[Coyote Logistics]] Hockey City Classic'' had to be delayed due to unusually warm weather (42 °F) and complications with the quality of the ice. The 2015 edition of the Hockey City Classic featured a match between [[Miami RedHawks men's ice hockey|Miami of Ohio]] and [[Western Michigan Broncos men's ice hockey|Western Michigan]], followed by a match between the [[Big Ten]]'s [[Michigan Wolverines men's ice hockey|Michigan]] and [[Michigan State Spartans men's ice hockey|Michigan State]]. = Grateful Dead - Fare Thee Well - Soldier Field - Chicago - 2015.jpg | image2 = Fare Thee Well, July 3, 2015 - Mickey Hart on the Jumbotron (1).jpg | image3 = Fare Thee Well - Celebrating 50 Years of the Grateful Dead 15.jpg}} *July 3–5, 2015 the [[Grateful Dead]] performed a series of three reunion concerts at Soldier Field celebrating the band's 50th anniversary. This was a portion of a concert series entitled "[[Fare Thee Well: Celebrating 50 Years of the Grateful Dead]]", which were their first concerts since their July 1995 concert at Soldier Field. The three concerts at Soldier Field were originally to be their only concerts, but due to overwhelming ticket demand the series was expanded to include two dates at [[Levi's Stadium]] in [[Santa Clara, California]] (in the [[San Francisco Bay area]]) performed the weekend prior to the Soldier Field concerts. The band at the concerts consisted of the surviving Grateful Dead members [[Bob Weir]], [[Phil Lesh]], [[Bill Kreutzmann]] and [[Mickey Hart]], who had no performed together since [[The Dead (band)|the Dead]]'s 2009 tour, who were joined by [[Trey Anastasio]], [[Bruce Hornsby]] and [[Jeff Chimenti]]. The concerts at Soldier Field were also broadcast with a live [[Simulcasting|simulcast]] seen by hundreds of thousands on [[pay-per-view]] [[cable television]], (for free) on [[YouTube]], on large screens at multiple concert venues in the United States, in movie theaters, as well as in various [[pay per view]] services. Satellite radio service [[Sirius]] played the concerts, with a slight delay, on their Grateful Dead channel. The pay-per-view set a new record for a music event with more than 400,000 subscriptions, surpassing a 1999 simulcast by the [[Backstreet Boys]] which drew 160,000 subscriptions. The concerts at Soldier Field were documented by director [[Martin Scorsese]] for a film. Recordings from the concert will be released as a live album on November 20, 2015. There will be three different versions of the recording. Each concert was attended by over 70,000 (more than 210,000 overall). The first date drew 70,764, setting a new record for attendance at Soldier Field post-renovation, a record that was surpassed the next night when 70,844 attended the second concert. Among those in attendance were [[Bill Murray]], [[George R. R. Martin]], [[Katy Perry]] and [[John Mayer]], [[Al Franken]], [[Perry Farrell]], [[Bill Walton]], [[Jenny Lewis]], [[John Popper]], [[Chloë Sevigny]], [[Liz Phair]], [[David Axelrod (musician)|David Axelrod]], and [[Sonic Youth]]'s [[Lee Ranaldo]].<ref name=deadNYT/><ref name=deadmusictimes/><ref name=deadkomo/><ref name=deadbillboard/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://my.chicagotribune.com/#section/-1/article/p2p-82552527/ |title=Grateful Dead to celebrate 50 years at Soldier Field this summer |last=Kot |first=Greg |date=January 16, 2015 |work=Chicago Tour]] concerts *July 23 and 24 [[Coldplay]] [[A Head Full of Dreams Tour]] concerts with [[Alessia Cara]] and [[Foxes (singer)|Foxes]]<ref>{{cite news |last=Legaspi |first=Althea |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/music/ct-ent-0725-coldplay-review-20160724-story.html |title=Rain can't dampen Coldplay party at Soldier Field |work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |date=2016-07-24 |accessdate=2016-07-24 }}</ref> *November 5 the [[New Zealand national rugby union team|New Zealand All Blacks]] faced [[Ireland national rugby union team|Ireland]] in Soldier Field's third-ever international rugby match. This was the first time the two teams have faced one another in the United States. Ireland won the match 40-29, marking the first time they have ever defeated the All Blacks in International Test rugby. This game was part of "The Rugby Weekend", which also featured a game between the [[United States national rugby union team|US Eagles]] and the [[Maori All Blacks]] at [[Toyota Park]] one day earlier.<ref name=allblacksbiz/><ref name=allblackscrain/><ref name=rugbysun/> The Maori All Blacks won the match 52-7.
===2017=== *June 3 and 4 [[U2]] [[The Joshua Tree Tour 2017]] concert with [[The Lumineers]]. *June 18 [[Metallica]] [[WorldWired Tour]] concert.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/chicagoinc/ct-metallica-coming-to-soldier-field-in-june-20170213-story.html | last=Williams| first=Kevin | title=Metallica coming to Soldier Field in June| website=chicagotribune.com| publisher=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=February 13, 2017|access-date=February 14, 2017}}</ref> *2017 [[Warrior Games]] opening ceremony on July 1, 2017.<ref name=WarriorGamesSchedule>{{cite web |url=http://warriorgamesfamilyprogram.org/schedule/ | title=schedule| website=warriorgamesfamilyprogram.org | publisher=Warrior Games Family Program|access-date=February 13, 2017}}</ref> *The parkland adjacent to the stadium will host the field competitions of the 2017 Warrior Games on July 5, 2017.<ref name=WarriorGamesSchedule/> *[[2017 MLS All-Star Game|2017]] [[Major League Soccer All-Star Game]] on August 2, 2017<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.dnainfo.com/chicago/20170131/downtown/mls-major-league-soccer-all-star-game-soldier-field |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202074936/https://www.dnainfo.com/chicago/20170131/downtown/mls-major-league-soccer-all-star-game-soldier-field |dead-url=yes |archive-date=February 2, 2017 |title=Major League Soccer All-Star Game To Be Held At Soldier Field |last=Matthews |first=David |date=January 31, 2017 |website=dnainfo.com |publisher=[[DNAinfo.com]] |access-date=January 31, 2016 }}</ref> *[[Coldplay]] is returning to Soldier Field on August 17, 2017, for their [[A Head Full of Dreams Tour]]. *In 2017 Soldier Field will host the annual [[Illinois–Northwestern football rivalry|Land of Lincoln Trophy]] rivalry game between [[2017 Northwestern Wildcats football team|Northwestern]] and [[2017 Illinois Fighting Illini football team|Illinois]].<ref name=CBSNU-IL/><ref name=csnNU-IL/>
== Scheduled upcoming events ==
===2010s===
====2019==== *In 2019 Soldier Field will host the annual [[Illinois–Northwestern football rivalry|Land of Lincoln Trophy]] rivalry game between [[Northwestern Wildcats football|Northwestern]] and [[Illinois Fighting Illini football|Illinois]].<ref name=CBSNU-IL/><ref name=csnNU-IL/>
===2020s===
====2024==== *In 2021 Soldier Field will host [[Notre Dame Fighting Irish Football|Notre Dame]] vs. [[Wisconsin Badgers football|Wisconsin]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/college/ct-spt-0814-notre-dame-wisconsin-football-20170813-story.html | last=Greenstein| first=Teddy | title=Done deal: Notre Dame, Wisconsin will clash at Soldier and Lambeau fields| website=chicagotribune.com| publisher=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=August 13, 2017|access-date=October 1, 2017}}</ref> *In 2024 Soldier Field will celebrate the hundredth anniversary of its opening.
