revision.text:
{{Infobox concert tour | concert_name = Madonna: Tears of a Clown | image = Madonna Tears of a Clown.png | landscape = yes | image_size = 250px | alt = Picture of a clown's face with sad expression, in front of a whirling colorful backdrop. | caption = Promotional banner for the concert | artist = [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] | start_date = {{Start date|2016|3|10}} | end_date = | number_of_shows = {{unbulleted list|1 in Oceania|1 in North America|2 Total}} | attendance = 2,000 | last_tour = [[Rebel Heart Tour]]
(2015–2016) | this_tour = '''Madonna: Tears of a Clown'''
(2016) }} '''Madonna: Tears of a Clown''' is a show by American singer [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]], first held at the [[Forum Theatre]] in [[Melbourne]], [[Australia]] on March 10, 2016. The singer had not included Australia during her previous five concert tours, until the [[Rebel Heart Tour]] (2015–2016), so she created the show for her Australian fans since they had waited so long for her to perform there. Madonna explained that the idea behind Tears of a Clown was to combine music and storytelling, being influenced by clowns. Tickets for the first show were made available to members of Madonna's official fan club, Icon, and were non-transferable, with the person's name printed on them. The first show of Tears of a Clown started four hours late, with the delay being caused by Madonna rehearsing. It consisted of Madonna singing acoustic versions of her songs while dressed as a clown, interspersed with the singer telling jokes and anecdotes. Tears of a Clown received positive reviews from critics who appreciated the stripped down, confessional nature of the singer's performance and the choice of the songs and the comedy. Madonna refuted reports of her being drunk on stage, calling them false and sexist. She revived the show on December 2, 2016, performing at Miami's Faena Forum as a benefit gala, to auction memorabilia and raise money for her [[Raising Malawi]] charitable foundation. Tickets were expensive, and the auctioned items included Madonna's tour dress and wedding photographs, as well as paintings that she owned. ==Background== [[File:Flinders St - Forum Theatre.jpg|thumb|left|[[Forum Theatre]], the location of the show in Melbourne]] Madonna had last toured in Australia in 1993 with [[The Girlie Show World Tour]], her fourth concert tour. The country was skipped for the next five tours until the singer released her thirteenth studio album, ''[[Rebel Heart (Madonna album)|Rebel Heart]]'' (2015).{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/madonna-to-tour-australia-for-the-first-time-in-23-years-20150302-13t5s5.html|title=Madonna to tour Australia for the first time in 23 years|date=March 1, 2015|accessdate=March 2, 2015|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]}} To promote the album, Madonna announced the [[Rebel Heart Tour]], and confirmed that she would be coming to Australia with the concert, as well as visit New Zealand for the first time.{{cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop-shop/6487508/madonna-to-launch-rebel-heart-world-tour-in-august|title=Madonna To Launch 'Rebel Heart' World Tour in August|last=Waddell|first=Ray|date=March 2, 2015|accessdate=March 2, 2015|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]}} Before arriving in Australia, Madonna announced an extra show on March 10, 2016, at Melbourne's [[Forum Theatre]]. The show was billed as an intimate gig, and was described by the singer as a fusion of music, art and comedy. It was titled as Madonna: Tears of a Clown show and was created for the singer's Australian fans, who had waited for her to perform there for the last 23 years. During her promotional appearance at ''[[The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon]]'' in April 2015, Madonna confessed that she is a "kind of closet comedian" and did a skit on the show; she added, "I always do extravaganzas, they always cost a billion dollars to make ... nobody makes any money ... and sometimes I dream about simplicity." During the show, the singer explained her decision to do Tears of a Clown:
I've had this idea in my head for this show Tears of a Clown which is a combination of music and storytelling. Because at the end of the day I do think of myself as a story teller. But it's rough as f---, {{sic}} so bear with me and give me all the support you can. It's from the heart. I chose to debut this work in progress, this rough rehearsal, here in Australia because I feel so bad about cancelling on you guys the last time. I'm sorry. You've been so patient, you waited for so long, I feel like I owe you a present, so this is your present... I want to make a disclaimer... If anyone thinks they came here to see a finished final show, there's the door. This is some brand spanking new shit. I don't know if you like it raw.{{cite web|first=Cameron |last=Adams |url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/music/tours/review-madonna-is-late-loose-and-ultra-personal-at-her-fanonly-tears-of-a-clown-show-in-melbourne/news-story/9e7544d51ef1b27e248171cdbdf0c51b |title=Emotional Mads opens up about son |publisher=[[News.com.au]] |date=March 10, 2016 |accessdate=March 13, 2016}}
Tickets were made available to members of Madonna's official fan club, Icon, and winners with details announced at Madonna.com and through concert promoter [[Telstra]]'s promotional webpage.{{cite web |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6898205/madonna-intimate-music-art-comedy-club-show-australia |title=Madonna Announces Intimate Music, Art and Comedy Club Show for Australian Fans |last1=Brandle |first1=Lars|date=March 3, 2016 |work=Billboard |accessdate=March 3, 2016}} According to newspaper reports, the tickets were non-transferable, and had the person's name printed on them. However, all of them were in the [[Seating assignment|general admission]] category at Forum Theatre, which holds a maximum capacity of 1,500. With the production design and addition of catwalk, the space allocated became smaller than that.{{cite web|url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/music/madonna-has-started-rehearsing-her-music-and-stand-up-comedy-show-tears-of-a-clown-in-melbourne/news-story/d1a530df8eadfcbe4c41918fb7340a27 |title=Madonna in Australia on Rebel Heart tour: Tears of a Clown rehearsals under way |publisher=News.com.au |date=March 9, 2016 |last=Adams |first=Cameron |accessdate=March 13, 2016}} Prior to the show ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'' reported that fans started queuing up in front of the venue, while Madonna rehearsed inside, as well as at [[Melbourne Park Multi-Purpose Venue|Hisense Arena]]. Images and songs rehearsed were leaked to fan website Drownedmadonna.com, along with Madonna's manager [[Guy Oseary]] uploading pictures on [[Instagram]]. Madonna made several references to clowns on her own Instagram account, including uploading a short video of her riding a small tricycle.{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/countdown-on-for-madonnas-tears-of-a-clown-comedy-show-before-rebel-heart-tour-20160310-gnflhv.html|title=Countdown on for Madonna's Tears of a Clown 'comedy' show before Rebel Heart tour|last=Northover|first=Kylie|date=March 10, 2015|accessdate=March 14, 2015|work=The Sydney Morning Herald}} The show was confirmed to be recorded and released along with the DVD for the Rebel Heart Tour.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/madonna-concert-than-four-hours-late/ |title=Madonna starts Melbourne concert more than four hours late |publisher=[[CBS News]] |date=November 10, 2015 |accessdate=March 13, 2016}} ==Synopsis== [[File:Madonna - Tears of a clown (26013429350).jpg|thumb|200px|Madonna began the show by entering the stage on a tricycle and dressed as a clown.]] On the day of the show, the doors at Forum Theatre were supposed to open at 8:30pm, but since Madonna rehearsed well into the night, the show started later at midnight. The show started with Madonna appearing onstage, in a clown's costume consisting of a billowing dress, pink and yellow stalkings, riding a tricycle and circled round it. She finally reached the front of the stage and fell down from the cycle. After conversing with the audience and throwing candy at them. Madonna started singing [[Stephen Sondheim]]'s "[[Send in the Clowns]]", written originally for the 1973 musical, ''[[A Little Night Music]]'', with images from [[Charlie Chaplin]] films displayed on the backdrop. She continued with "[[Drowned World/Substitute for Love]]" while standing in the center. Three songs followed with Madonna joining the band and sitting down with her guitar, including "X-Static Process", a cover of [[Elliott Smith]]'s "Between the Bars", "Nobody's Perfect" and "Easy Ride". All the songs had displays showing circus themed videos; following this Madonna started singing the song "Intervention", while displaying an image of her son Rocco; the singer referred to her custody battle with ex-husband [[Guy Ritchie]] about Rocco. Other acoustic versions of songs followed, including "I'm So Stupid", "Paradise (Not for Me)", "[[Joan of Arc (Madonna song)|Joan of Arc]]" and "[[Don't Tell Me (Madonna song)|Don't Tell Me]]". Before performing the next song, "Mer Girl", Madonna explained that once she was at her father's house and she visited the place where her mother was buried; the place, overgrown with weed, became an inspiration behind the song.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-35783922|title=Madonna clowns around and sheds tears for Rocco at Melbourne show|last=Savage|first=Mark|date=March 11, 2016|accessdate=April 4, 2016|publisher=[[BBC News]]}} Then Madonna sang an acoustic version of "[[Borderline (Madonna song)|Borderline]]" followed by "[[Take a Bow (Madonna song)|Take a Bow]]". The encore was an acoustic version of "[[Holiday (Madonna song)|Holiday]]" featuring Madonna playing the [[ukulele]] accompanied by her band and her dancers dressed as clowns.{{cite web|url=http://fasterlouder.junkee.com/inside-madonnas-intimate-tears-of-a-clown-show-in-melbourne/858982|title=Inside Madonna's intimate 'Tears of a Clown' show in Melbourne|last=S. He|first=Richard|date=March 11, 2016|accessdate=April 4, 2016|publisher=Junkee.com}} ==Critical response== [[File:Madonna - Tears of a clown (26193856572).jpg|thumb|left|200px|Madonna playing the ukulele while performing "[[Holiday (Madonna song)|Holiday]]", the show's final song.]] Cameron Adams from [[News.com.au]] wrote: "[Madonna] poured much of her sadness into her intimate two-hour Tears of a Clown show, peppering emotional renditions of her hits with cheeky jokes and banter."{{cite web|url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/music/tours/madonna-tears-of-a-clown-intimate-concert-for-fans-at-the-forum-in-melbourne/news-story/c42664cdd548419736bc51b3e062e525 |title=Madonna at Forum in Melbourne for Tears of a Clown Show |publisher=News.com.au |last=Adams |first=Cameron |date=March 9, 2016 |accessdate=March 13, 2016}} In another article reviewing the show, Adams noted that Tears of a Clown was "the sort of thing you never thought you'd see a superstar do". He complimented Madonna's jokes, chatting about her life in-between songs, for being "raw and vulnerable" and confessed that it was "fascinating — and difficult — to watch. We're not used to Madonna on stage doing anything less than a fully rehearsed, slick stage show." Concluding the review, Adams believed that Tears of a Clown professed Madonna's touring direction into the future. Writing for ''[[The Independent]]'' Nick Levine noticed that the singer "tested out her stand-up comedy skills with a series of risqué jokes and took the opportunity to defend her controversial fashion sense."{{cite web|first=Nick |last=Levine |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/news/madonna-plays-gig-dressed-as-a-clown-and-rides-a-child-s-tricycle-for-tears-of-a-clown-show-a6923206.html |title=Madonna plays gig dressed as a clown and rides a child’s tricycle for 'Tears of a Clown' show |work=[[The Independent]] |date=March 10, 2016 |accessdate=March 13, 2016}} Debbie Cuthbertson from ''The Sydney Morning Herald'' gave a positive review of the show, saying "For the queen of self-control, it was an open, at times even vulnerable insight into her persona. She seemed relaxed, drinking Cosmopolitans as she spoke at length between songs." Cuthbertson also commended the choice of Forum Theatre as a venue believing it to be "inspired, and her crew lit up the grand old dame in a way that showcased all her delicate charms in a way I can't recall any other act having ever done."{{cite news|first=Debbie |last=Cuthbertson |url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/madonnas-intimate-melbourne-show-tears-of-a-clown-a-unique-confessional-20160311-gng3fr.html |title=Madonna's intimate Melbourne show Tears of A Clown a unique confessional |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=March 11, 2016|accessdate=March 13, 2016}} Lachlan Kanoniuk, music critic for ''[[The Guardian]]'', noted the "bawdy" jokes and anecdotes shared onstage by Madonna. He went on to describe the show as "a weird mix of old vaudevillian-style, M15+, smut humour and bad wordplay; some jokes about clowns, sex jokes that were really quite bad but she had such great comedic delivery". Kanoniuk also compared the show to [[Prince (musician)|Prince]]'s [[Piano & A Microphone Tour]], and complimented her singing during "Between the Bars", describing it as "no costume changes, no highly synchronised dance moves, just Madonna playing an acoustic guitar and baring her soul on stage."{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/mar/11/madonna-clowns-around-at-melbourne-show-after-three-hour-delay|title=Madonna Clowns Around at Melbourne Show After Three Hour Delay|first=Lachlan |last=Kanoniuk|work=[[The Guardian]]}} Francis Gibb from ''[[The Times]]'' found Madonna's performance during "Intervention" as an intimate and "naked" moment for the singer due to the legal battle.{{cite news|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/life/celebrity/article4710837.ece |title=Tears of a clown as Madonna sobs for son |work=[[The Times]] |last=Gibb |first=Francis |date=March 10, 2016 |accessdate=March 13, 2016|subscription=yes}} Jon Lisi from ''[[PopMatters]]'' observed that unlike the Rebel Heart Tour, Madonna had "something to say" with Tears of a Clown show. However he was confused whether Madonna was being vulnerable as a clown or it was a case of the singer "[[Internet troll|trolling us]]". Citing the instance of singing "Intervention" for Rocco, Lisi explained that "Of course she loves her son, but maybe this was less about her pain and more about the press’ exploitation of her pain. As the show got more intimate with each song and personal anecdote, a disturbing thought crept into my mind: what if it was meant to be a joke?" Lisi concluded that the show had the ability "represent a transitional point in [Madonna's] career", although the purpose was still unclear.{{cite web|url=http://www.popmatters.com/column/is-madonna-tears-of-a-clown-a-laughing-matter/|title=Is 'Madonna Tears of a Clown' a Laughing Matter?|last=Lisi|first=Jon|date=May 3, 2016|accessdate=May 26, 2016|work=[[PopMatters]]}} After the show ended, several media outlets reported that Madonna may have been drunk during the performance; however, Madonna blasted these reports, by responding: "Thanks for supporting me. Too bad people don't know the art of acting and playing a character. I could never do any of my shows high or drunk. And yes underlying all of this is sexism and mysongony {{sic}} which proves that not only do we not get equal pay but we are still treated like heretics if we step out of line and think outside the box! Sexism is alive and kicking but i am #livingforlove."{{cite news|url=http://mic.com/articles/137938/madonna-calls-backlash-for-her-tears-of-a-clown-performance-in-australia-sexist|title=Madonna Calls Backlash for Her 'Tears of a Clown' Performance in Australia Sexist|last=Leung|first=Andrew|date=March 15, 2016|accessdate=March 17, 2016|publisher=[[Mic (media company)|Mic]]}} ==Successive show== In October 2016, Madonna announced plans of collaborating with [[Art Basel]] to revive the Tears of a Clown show, at a benefit gala on December 2, 2016 at [[Miami Beach]]'s Faena Forum. The location was developed by Argentine hotelier and real estate developer, [[Alan Faena]], and the show would coincide with the opening of the Forum. The concert was held along with an accompanying art auction and dinner, to benefit Madonna's [[Raising Malawi]] foundation to support their projects like Mercy James Pediatric Surgery Hospital in Malawi, as well as art and education initiatives for impoverished children in the country. Madonna herself auctioned some of her art collection, as well as never-before-seen pictures from her marriage to actor [[Sean Penn]], photographed by [[Herb Ritts]]. Tickets were highly priced, at general admission of $5,000 with VIP meet-and-greet packages coming at $150,000.{{cite news|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/community/miami-dade/article117046648.html|title=For $5,000, you can see Madonna dressed as a clown. Oh yes, she'll sing|last=Herrera|first=Chabeli|date=November 25, 2016|accessdate=November 26, 2016|work=[[Miami Herald]]}} She also auctioned the flapper dress from Rebel Heart Tour, [[model (person)|modelled]] by singer [[Ariana Grande]] during the show. Penn was present in the audience and bid on several items, and at one point handcuffed Madonna and crawled through her legs for generating a higher bid. Madonna was aided by her son David Banda, who was adopted by the singer from Malawi; Banda introduced Madonna and told the audience who bought the tickets about how "lucky" he was. The Tears of a Clown show was over an hour long, with Madonna giving her opinions on the [[2016 United States Presidential Election]], panning President elect [[Donald Trump]]. One of the new songs included in the set list was [[Britney Spears]]' "[[Toxic (song)|Toxic]]" (2004), which Madonna sang slowly, as images of Trump were displayed in video backdrops. The singer also spoke about the turmoils of the [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]] and the [[Dakota Access Pipeline protests]], and then sang "[[American Life (song)|American Life]]" (2003). Other songs performed included "[[Express Yourself (Madonna song)|Express Yourself]]" (1989), "[[Beautiful Stranger]]" (1999) and "Don't Tell Me" (2000). During "Holiday", one fan got the chance to hold Madonna's microphone as she played the ukulele and sang, as well as another fan donating $150,000 in exchange for kissing the singer.{{cite news|url=http://extratv.com/2016/12/02/madonna-clowns-around-at-miami-fundraiser-zings-president-elect-trump/|title=Madonna Offers to Remarry Sean Penn at Miami Fundraiser, Zings President-elect Trump|date=December 2, 2016|accessdate=December 3, 2016|work=[[Extra (U.S. TV program)|Extra]]}} In total, Madonna raised about US$7.3 million from her own items. The [[Associated Press]] reported that "[the] night was punctuated by [Madonna's] sardonic humor, corny clown jokes, controversial political statements and heartfelt moments about how much the hospital project means to her."{{cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2016/12/03/madonna-raises-75m-for-malawi-slams-trump-in-miami-show.html|title=Madonna raises $7.5M for Malawi, slams Trump in Miami show|date=December 2, 2016|accessdate=December 3, 2016|publisher=[[CNBC]]}} ==Set list== {{hidden | titlestyle = background: #ccccff; font-size: 100%; width: 65%; text-align:center; | bodystyle = text-align: left; font-size: 100%; width: 75%; | title = Melbourne, Australia {{nobold|– March 10, 2016}} | content = #"[[Send In the Clowns]]" #"[[Drowned World/Substitute for Love]]" #"X-Static Process" #"Between the Bars" ([[Elliott Smith]] cover) #"Nobody's Perfect" #"Easy Ride" #"Intervention" #"I'm So Stupid" #"Paradise (Not for Me)" #"[[Joan of Arc (Madonna song)|Joan of Arc]]" #"[[Don't Tell Me (Madonna song)|Don't Tell Me]]" #"Mer Girl" #"[[Borderline (Madonna song)|Borderline]]" #"[[Take a Bow (Madonna song)|Take a Bow]]" #"[[Holiday (Madonna song)|Holiday]]" }} {{hidden | titlestyle = background: #ccccff; font-size: 100%; width: 65%; text-align:center; | bodystyle = text-align: left; font-size: 100%; width: 75%; | title = Miami, United States {{nobold|– December 2, 2016}} | content = #"Send In the Clowns" #"Like it Or Not" #"[[Toxic (song)|Toxic]]" ([[Britney Spears]] cover) #"I'm So Stupid" #"[[Beautiful Stranger]]" #"Easy Ride" #"[[American Life (song)|American Life]]" #"Don't Tell Me" #"[[Express Yourself (Madonna song)|Express Yourself]]" #"Holiday" }} ==Shows== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |+ List of concerts, showing date, city, country, venue and attendance |- ! scope="col" style="width:12em;"| Date ! scope="col" style="width:10em;"| City ! scope="col" style="width:10em;"| Country ! scope="col" style="width:16em;"| Venue ! scope="col" style="width:10em;"| Attendance |- ! scope="row" style="text-align:center;" | March 10, 2016 | [[Melbourne]] | [[Australia]] | [[Forum Theatre]] | 1,500 |- ! scope="row" style="text-align:center;" | December 2, 2016 | [[Miami]] | [[United States]] | Faena Forum | 500 |- |} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category}} * [https://www.telstra.com.au/thanks/music/madonna-competition One Night, One Center Spotlight, One Madonna] at [[Telstra]] {{Madonna}} {{Good article}} [[Category:2016 concerts]] [[Category:2016 in American music]] [[Category:2016 in Australian music]] [[Category:2016 in Florida]] [[Category:2010s in Melbourne]] [[Category:2010s in Miami]] [[Category:American comedy]] [[Category:Australian comedy]] [[Category:Clowning]] [[Category:Comedy events]] [[Category:December 2016 events in the United States]] [[Category:Madonna (entertainer) concerts]] [[Category:March 2016 events]] [[Category:Music in Melbourne]] [[Category:Music of Miami]] [[Category:Storytelling events]]

{{Multiple issues| {{notability|Organizations|date=May 2016}} {{refimprove|date=August 2016}} }} {{Infobox organization |motto = Charismatic, Reliable and Behavior |formation = 2014 |type = [[Beauty pageant]] |headquarters = [[N'Djamena]] |language = [[French language|French]] |leader_title = |leader_name = |key_people = Ministry of Culture, Chad |budget = |name = Miss Chad (Tchad) |location = [[Chad]] |membership = [[Miss World]] |num_staff = |website = }} '''Miss Chad''' (or "Miss TCHAD") is a national [[beauty pageant]] in [[Chad]]. The pageant runs to select its winner to the [[Miss World]]. The Miss Tchad is sponsored by Ministry of Culture, Chad since 2014. ==Titleholders== {| class="sortable" border="5" cellpadding="3" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #FFFFFF; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse; font-size: 95%; text-align:center" |- bgcolor="#787878" colspan=10 align="center" |width="30"|Year||width="170"|Miss Tchad||width="300"|Placement at Miss World |- | 2014 | Sakadi Djivra | The People's Choice (''Top 10'') |- | 2015 | Élise Dagossé | Did not compete |- | 2016 | Sylviane Leloum | Did not compete |- | 2017 | Valerie Chollet | Did not compete |- |} {{Portal|Chad}} {{Miss World countries and territories}} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Miss World by country|Chad]] [[Category:Chadian awards]] [[Category:Events in Chad]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox magazine | title = NEWS | image_file = | image_size = | image_caption = | editor = Peter Pelinka | editor_title = Editor-in-chief | frequency = [[Weekly]] | circulation = 135,875 (2013) | category =[[News magazine]] | company =[[Gruner + Jahr]] | publisher = | founded = 1992 | firstdate = October 1992 | country = [[Austria]] | based = [[Vienna]] | language =[[German language|German]] | website = [http://www.news.at/magazin ''NEWS''] | issn = | oclc = }}
'''''NEWS''''' is an Austrian weekly [[news magazine]] published in [[German language|German]] and based in [[Vienna]], [[Austria]]. The weekly is the major news magazine in the country.<ref>{{cite web|title=Presse, Druckschriften|url=http://austria-forum.org/af/AEIOU/Presse,_Druckschriften/Presse,_Druckschriften_english|work=Austria Forum|accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref>
==History and profile== ''NEWS'' magazine was established by Helmut and Wolfgang Fellner and was first published in October 1992.<ref name=ibook>{{cite web|title=Press freedom and pluralism in Europe|url=http://www.intellectbooks.co.uk/File:download,id=724/9781841502434.251.pdf.|work=Intellect Books|accessdate=6 October 2013|author=Martina Thiele}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=The New Österreich|url=http://www.viennareview.net/news/austria/the-new-osterreich|accessdate=6 October 2013|newspaper=The Vienna Review|date=1 October 2006|author=Paul Krauskopf}}</ref><ref name=cstu>{{cite web|title=Austria|url=http://countrystudies.us/austria/127.htm|work=Country Studies|accessdate=16 August 2014}}</ref> The Verlagsgruppe NEWS was the publisher of the magazine which is published weekly.<ref name=kat8/><ref name=rustel/> The Fellner brothers sold the magazine to [[Gruner + Jahr]],<ref name=gj>{{cite web|title=World of media. Austria|url=http://www.guj.de/en/world-of-media/news-aut/|work=G + J|accessdate=5 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|editor=Georgios Terzis|title=European Media Governance: National and Regional Dimensions|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=68nbtqst-CsC&pg=PA64|year=2007|publisher=Intellect Books|isbn=978-1-84150-192-5|page=64}}</ref> a subsidiary of [[Bertelsmann]].<ref>{{cite book|author1=Paul Murschetz|author2=Matthias Karmasin|editor=Paul Murschetz|title=State Aid for Newspapers|date=2013|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|location=Berlin Heidelberg|isbn=978-3-642-35691-9|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=v6-9BAAAQBAJ&pg=PA134|accessdate=30 December 2014|chapter=Austria: Press Subsidies in Search of a New Design}}</ref>
''NEWS'' covers entertainment and life style topics<ref>{{cite book|editor1=Mary Kelly|editor2=Gianpietro Mazzoleni|editor3=Denis McQuail|title=The Media in Europe: The Euromedia Handbook|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HYCVxSFNNpkC&pg=PA5|date=31 January 2004|publisher=SAGE Publications|isbn=978-0-7619-4131-6|page=5}}</ref> as well as news on current affairs, politics and culture.<ref name=pub1/>
In the 1990s Senta Ziegler served as the [[editor-in-chief]] of the magazine.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Rules of Media Etiquette|url=http://www.herbig.net/foreign-rights/non-fiction/detailview/product//the-rules-of-media-etiquette.html|work=Herbig|accessdate=8 October 2013}}</ref> Until 2008 Andreas Weber was the editor-in-chief of the weekly.<ref name=kat8>{{cite web|title=Editorial changes at Verlagsgruppe NEWS|url=http://www.featuresexec.com/bulletin/news_article.php?id=6791#.Uk_zHmRJVgs|work=Media Bulletin|accessdate=5 October 2013|author=Katja Böttcher|date=4 September 2008}}</ref> Then Atha Athanasiadis served as the editor-in-chief of the ''NEWS'' magazine from 2008 to February 2010.<ref name=friz>{{cite web|title=Austrian magazine NEWS appoints new editorship|url=http://www.featuresexec.com/bulletin/news_article.php?id=10422#.Uk_ysmRJVgs|work=Media Bulletin|accessdate=5 October 2013|author=Frizzi Seltmann|date=25 February 2010}}</ref> The editor-in-chief of the magazine is Peter Pelinka who was appointed to the post in February 2010.<ref name=pub>{{cite web|title=Peter Pelinka is the New Editor-in-Chief of NEWS Magazine|url=http://www.publicitas.com/home/media-news-events/news-detail/?newsid=36927&title=austria-peter-pelinka-is-the-new-editor-in-chief-of-news-magazine#.Uk_tc2RJVgs|work=Publicitas|accessdate=5 October 2013|date=24 February 2010}}</ref> Corinna Milborn and Silvia Meister are the deputy editors of the weekly.<ref name=pub/>
==Circulation== The 1993 circulation of ''NEWS'' was more than 200,000 copies.<ref name=cstu/> The market share of the magazine was 19.3% in 2000.<ref name=pref>{{cite web|title=Austria|url=http://www.pressreference.com/A-Be/Austria.html|work=Press Reference|accessdate=7 October 2013}}</ref> The magazine had a circulation of 254,000 copies in 2003.<ref name=rustel>{{cite web|title=Media Markets: Austria Country Overview|url=http://oldtelecoms.kondrashov.ru/world/austria.html|work=Russian Telecom|accessdate=1 January 2015|date=August 2004}}</ref> Its readership in 2005 was about 14%, making it the first in its category.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Günter Bischof|author2=Fritz Plasser|title=The Changing Austrian Voter|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EK81N6akyEUC&pg=PT133|date=January 2008|publisher=Transaction Publishers|isbn=978-1-4128-1932-9|page=133}}</ref> In 2007 the magazine had a circulation of 285,000 copies.<ref>{{cite web|author=Anne Austin et. al.|title=Western Europe Market & Media Fact|url=http://conan.lib.muohio.edu/ebooks/Western_Europe_Market_MediaFact_2008/Western%20Europe%20Market%20&%20MediaFact%202008.pdf|work=ZenithOptimedia|accessdate=8 April 2015|date=2008}}</ref>
For the first half of 2008 the magazine had a circulation of 125,710 copies.<ref>{{cite web|title=Austria: New circulation figures for the 1st half 2008|url=http://www.publicitas.com/en/home/media-news-events/news-detail/?newsid=24173&title=austria-new-circulation-figures-for-the-1st-half-2008#.UlQTYmRJVgs|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131014172112/http://www.publicitas.com/en/home/media-news-events/news-detail/?newsid=24173&title=austria-new-circulation-figures-for-the-1st-half-2008#.UlQTYmRJVgs|dead-url=yes|archive-date=14 October 2013|work=Publicitas|accessdate=8 October 2013|date=20 August 2008}}</ref> It was the third best-selling magazine in the country in 2008.<ref>{{cite news|author=Thomas Hochwarterlump|title=Der Standard extends its readership as Die Presse's numbers slump|url=http://austriantimes.at/index.php?id=12135-newentry|accessdate=1 January 2015|work=Austrian Times|date=3 March 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150101144308/http://austriantimes.at/index.php?id=12135-newentry|archivedate=1 January 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The circulation of the magazine was 215,000 copies in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|title=Western Europe Media Facts. 2011 Edition|url=http://conan.lib.muohio.edu/ebooks/Western_Europe_Market_MediaFact/2011/Western%20Europe%20Market%20&%20MediaFact%202011.pdf|work=ZenithOptimedia|accessdate=6 March 2016}}</ref> The 2012 circulation of the magazine was 125.751 copies<ref name=gj/> and it was 135,875 copies in the first half of 2013.<ref name=pub1>{{cite web|title=List of represented titles. Magazines|url=http://www.publicitas.com/fileadmin/uploads/common/Promotions/2013-11_Rep_List_MAGAZINES.pdf|work=Publicitas International AG|accessdate=29 October 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141030071650/http://www.publicitas.com/fileadmin/uploads/common/Promotions/2013-11_Rep_List_MAGAZINES.pdf|archivedate=30 October 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Incidents== In June 2005, ''NEWS'' was fined by an Austrian court following its publication of then Finance Minister [[Karl Heinz Grasser]]'s photos kissing Fiona Swarovski, an heiress of the [[Swarovski|Swarovski crystal dynasty]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Austrian court fines magazine for publishing photos of finance minister kissing heiress|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-109754723.html|accessdate=5 October 2013|work=Associated Press|date=8 June 2005|location=Vienna}}{{Subscription required|via=Highbeam}}</ref>
==See also== [[List of magazines in Austria]]
==References== {{Reflist|33em}}
==External links== * [http://www.news.at/magazin Official website]
{{Bertelsmann}}

revision.text:
[[File:Red Square 1977-11-07-32.jpg|thumb|October Revolution Day in 1977.]] '''October Revolution Day''' (officially '''Day of the Great October Socialist Revolution''', {{lang-ru|День Великой Октябрьской социалистической революции}}) was a [[public holidays in the Soviet Union|public holiday]] in the [[Soviet Union]], officially observed on [[November 7]] from 1927 to 1990.<ref name="rians">{{cite news |title=День Октябрьской революции 1917 года |url=https://ria.ru/spravka/20171107/1507990701.html |accessdate=26 October 2018 |work=РИА Новости |date=7 November 2017 |language=ru |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171111115316/https://ria.ru/spravka/20171107/1507990701.html |archive-date=2017-11-11 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>
For Soviet families, it was a holiday tradition to partake in a shared morning meal, and to watch the October Revolution Parade broadcast on television.<ref name="rians"/>
A holiday canon was established during the Stalinist period, and included a workers' demonstration, the appearance of leaders on the podium of the [[Lenin's Mausoleum|Mausoleum]], and, finally, the military parade on [[Red Square]], which was held unfailingly every year, most famously in [[1941 October Revolution Parade|1941]], as the Axis forces were advancing on Moscow.<ref name="rian08"/>
October Revolution Day, which had been the main holiday of the year during the Stalinist period, gradually lost importance in the 1970s, falling behind the [[Victory Day (9 May)|Victory Day]] and [[Novy God|New Year]] celebrations.<ref name="rian08"/>
==Post-Soviet observance== In [[Kyrgyzstan]], the holiday was observed until 2017, when it was replaced by the 'Days of Ancestral History and Memory' on November 7 and 8.<ref>{{cite news |title=Президент Киргизии постановил отмечать 7-8 ноября Дни истории и памяти предков |url=https://www.interfax.ru/world/584663 |accessdate=26 October 2018 |work=Interfax.ru |date=26 October 2017 |language=ru-RU |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180601162819/http://www.interfax.ru/world/584663 |archive-date=2018-06-01 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>
As of 2018, October Revolution Day remains an official holiday in [[Belarus]], though the original significance has faded and it is simply regarded as a day off.<ref>{{cite news |title=Минчане о 7 ноября: «Это праздник, но какой - не помню» |url=https://www.kp.by/daily/26603/3619348/ |accessdate=26 October 2018 |work=Комсомольской правды |date=6 November 2016 |language=ru}}</ref> Similarly, in the unrecognized [[Transnistrian]] Republic, the day is officially a public holiday, but it is regarded by locals as devoid of its original meaning.<ref>{{cite news |last1= |title=7 ноября в Приднестровье по-пролетарски празднуют лишь коммунисты |url=https://www.dw.com/ru/7-%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%8F%D0%B1%D1%80%D1%8F-%D0%B2-%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%8C%D0%B5-%D0%BF%D0%BE-%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8-%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%B4%D0%BD%D1%83%D1%8E%D1%82-%D0%BB%D0%B8%D1%88%D1%8C-%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%BC%D1%83%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%81%D1%82%D1%8B/a-4867744 |accessdate=26 October 2018 |work=Deutsche Welle |date=7 November 2009 |language=ru |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170522140645/http://www.dw.com/ru/7-%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%8F%D0%B1%D1%80%D1%8F-%D0%B2-%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%8C%D0%B5-%D0%BF%D0%BE-%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8-%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%B4%D0%BD%D1%83%D1%8E%D1%82-%D0%BB%D0%B8%D1%88%D1%8C-%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%BC%D1%83%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%81%D1%82%D1%8B/a-4867744 |archive-date=2017-05-22 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>
In Russia, the holiday was repurposed several times. In 1995, President [[Yeltsin]] reestablished a November 7 holiday to commemorate the [[Battle of Moscow (1612)|liberation of Moscow]] from the Polish army in 1612.<ref name="rian08">{{cite news |title=7 ноября: пять праздников одного дня. Справка |url=https://ria.ru/society/20081107/154584399.html |accessdate=27 October 2018 |work=РИА Новости |date=7 November 2008 |language=ru |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518122913/http://ria.ru/society/20081107/154584399.html |archive-date=2015-05-18 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> The next year, it was renamed 'Day of Accord and Reconciliation'.<ref name="rian08"/> From 2004, November 7 became one of several [[Days of Military Honour]] and ceased to be a day off.<ref name="rians"/>
==See also== * [[1990 October Revolution Parade]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Annual Great October Socialist Revolution Parade}}
[[Category:October Revolution parades]] [[Category:Public holidays in the Soviet Union]] [[Category:November events]] [[Category:Former public holidays]] [[Category:Public holidays in Belarus]] [[Category:Public holidays in Transnistria]]

revision.comment: I changed those references to the history of the organization, name changes through time and added information regarding recent activity.
revision.text:
The '''Palmer R. Chitester Fund''' is now '''Free To Choose Network,''' a [[Libertarianism|libertarian]]-leaning Pennsylvania [[nonprofit corporation]] based in [[Erie, Pennsylvania]].
The Network has three main initiatives: * Free To Choose Media, which produces television programs and videos making classical liberal economic and political ideas accessible to a popular audience * izzit.org,which produces media for children, sometimes adapting public television broadcasts for a school audience<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=One Eye To Protecting The Brand |url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-508414_ITM |work=Entertainment Marketing Letter |publisher= |date=1 Aug 1999 |accessdate=2008-07-04 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=The Right Whines |url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-28311411_ITM |work=The Nation |publisher= |date=2 Oct 2000 |accessdate=2008-07-04 }}</ref><ref>[http://archive.salon.com/media/feature/2000/02/25/stossel/index.html Prime-time propagandist, Is ABC's John Stossel a reporter or a right-wing apparatchik? By David Mastio] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090622003554/http://archive.salon.com/media/feature/2000/02/25/stossel/index.html |date=2009-06-22 }}</ref> * The Idea Channel - specializing in video recording of conversations between scholars, including several Nobel Prize winners <!-- Image with inadequate rationale removed: [[Image:Free to Choose.jpg|thumb|right|150px|The cover of ''[[Free to Choose]]'' by [[Milton Friedman|Milton]] and [[Rose Friedman]] (1980), the bestselling book that accompanied the 10-part PBS series produced by the Palmer R. Chitester Fund.]] -->
The Palmer R. Chitester Fund ( Free To Choose Network) was founded by Bob Chitester, using start-up money provided by a number of charitable sources and named in honor of his father. At the time, Bob Chitester was the general manager of two public broadcasters in [[Erie, Pennsylvania]]: the [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]] channel [[WQLN (TV)|WQLN-TV]] and the [[National Public Radio|NPR]] station [[WQLN-FM]].
== History == The origins of the foundation lay in PBS's broadcast of ''The Age of Uncertainty'' (1975), a 13-part [[BBC]] series produced by liberal economist [[John Kenneth Galbraith]].<ref name="heartland1">{{cite web|url=http://www.heartland.org/policybot/results.html?artId=20187 |title=Personal Reflections on Milton Friedman - by Bob Chitester - News Releases |publisher=Heartland.org |date= |accessdate=2010-09-26}}</ref> The chairman of the [[Corporation for Public Broadcasting]] was a classical liberal economist, [[W. Allen Wallis]], who had met Chitester in 1975 when he participated in a symposium on "Technology and Society" arranged by Chitester in Erie and learned that Chitester shared his classical liberal economic views.<ref name="heartland1"/> Wallis and Chitester both believed that PBS should produce a classical liberal response to ''The Age of Uncertainty''. Wallis therefore introduced Chitester to his old friend [[Milton Friedman]] in early 1977 (shortly after Friedman won the [[Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences]]).<ref name="heartland1"/> As a result, Chitester raised the necessary funding and Executive Produced a 10-part PBS series entitled ''[[Free to Choose]]'', which first aired in early 1980. Friedman also co-authored a book with his wife [[Rose Friedman]] that was based on the television series. This book spent 5 weeks at the top of the [[List of New York Times Non-Fiction Best Sellers|''New York Times'' Non-Fiction Best Sellers List]] in 1980.
It was in the context of producing the ''Free to Choose'' series that Chitester first organized Amagin, Inc., which became the Palmer R. Chitester Fund, which became Free To Choose Network. Under the trademark Free To Choose Media it continues to produce media describing classical liberal economic ideas to a mass audience. Beginning in 1999, the Palmer R. Chitester Fund, was licensed by [[ABC News]] to distribute [[John Stossel]] TV specials under the brand "Stossel in the Classroom". The license was cancelled in 2004.
Free To Choose Media has produced a number of programs for public TV including: a biography of Milton Friedman, entitled ''The Power of Choice -'' ''The Ultimate Resource'' (named after the 1981 book ''[[The Ultimate Resource]]'' by [[Julian Lincoln Simon]]) -''Turmoil and Triumph'' a biography of George Shultz - ''The Power of the Poor,'' hosted by Peruvian economist Hernando de Soto - ''India Rising'', hosted by Swedish scholar Johan Norberg - ''The Real Adam Smith, hosted by Johan Norberg.''
The organization currently known as izzit.org was initially called In the Classroom Media.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.freetochoosemedia.org/production/ultimate_resource/press/production_team_bios.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-11-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080724173057/http://www.freetochoosemedia.org/production/ultimate_resource/press/production_team_bios.pdf |archivedate=2008-07-24 |df= }}</ref> Izzit.org provides teachers with materials on current events and other topics for in-classroom use. Izzit.org has used celebrities (e.g. [[Drew Carey]]) in some of its productions.
The Idea Channel no longer markets the documentaries produced by Free To Choose Media. Much of the Palmer R. Chitester Fund archival footage now appears on YouTube.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.freetochoosemedia.org Homepage of Free To Choose Media] * [http://www.izzit.org/ izzit.org] * [http://www.chitester.net/ Chitester Creative Associates, an organization associated with Free to Choose Media]

revision.text:
[[File:Samyak fest.jpg|thumb|Images of Dipankar Buddha at Kathmandu Durbar Square during Samyak]] [[File:Samyak 2002.jpg|thumb|Samyak 2002 at Bhuikhel]] {{Buddhism}} '''Samyak''' ([[Devanagari]]: सम्यक) is an almsgiving Buddhist festival celebrated in the [[Kathmandu Valley]] in [[Nepal]]. During the ceremony which is held on a large open ground, hundreds of images of [[Dīpankara Buddha]] are assembled, and gifts of different types of food are made to the deities and the Buddhist community.<ref>{{cite news|last=Lewis|first=Todd T. |title=Notes on the Uray and the Modernization of Newar Buddhism |url=http://www.thlib.org/static/reprints/contributions/CNAS_23_01_08.pdf |accessdate=7 February 2013 |newspaper=Contributions to Nepalese Studies |date=January 1996}} Page 112.</ref>
Samyak is the most spectacular [[Newar Buddhism|Newar Buddhist]] celebration. It is observed at different intervals in the three cities of the valley -- every 12 years in [[Kathmandu]], every five years in [[Patan, Nepal|Lalitpur]] and annually in [[Bhaktapur]]. The first documented Samyak festival in Kathmandu took place in 1015 AD (135 [[Nepal Era]]).<ref>{{cite book |last=O'Rourke |first=Mary-Jo |editor-first=Darasha |editor-last=Newami |title=The Samyak Festival of Kathmandu |publisher=Dharma Ratna Shakya |date=1993|chapter=The Samyak Festival of Kathmandu}}</ref>
The festival brings together a wide cross-section of [[Newar]] society, including priests, artisans, traders, musicians and farmers. Each group has a defined role designed to highlight social harmony. The ceremony celebrates the practice of giving to the Buddhas and monks in the Newar Buddhist tradition. The Samyak festival in Kathmandu is held at [[Kathmandu Durbar Square]] and the field of [[Bhuikhel]] at the foot of [[Swayambhu]] hill.<ref>{{cite book |last= Lewis |first= Todd Thornton |authorlink= |title= Popular Buddhist Texts from Nepal: Narratives and Rituals of Newar Buddhism |url= https://books.google.com.np/books?id=pC_XoZsvBuIC&pg=PA225&dq=samyak+nepal&hl=en&sa=X&ei=2uj7UeXdOs2krQfIrIHgCA&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=samyak%20nepal&f=false |accessdate=2 August 2013 |year=2000 |publisher= State University of New York Press |location= |isbn= |page=}}</ref>
==Day One==
On the first day, large images of Dipankar Buddha are brought out of sacred courtyards and private homes and displayed at Durbar Square in a row to receive offerings from devotees.
==Day Two==
On the second day, the statues are carried in procession to [[Bhuikhel]] and assembled on the field. Priests receive alms consisting of different kinds of sacred foods in a ceremony held in the presence of the king.
The offerings are made by members of the [[Uray (caste group)|Uray]] caste group.<ref>{{cite news|last= van den Hoek |first= Bert |title= Gender and Caste in the Perfect Buddhist Gift the Samyak Mahadana in Kathmandu, Nepal |url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:CpCdBJpQoo4J:www.thlib.org/static/reprints/contributions/CNAS_23_01_12.pdf+samyak+hoek&hl=en&gl=np&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESgtPkaxuQpgv6rH251CXWy3q9BDSzdSDLz5XnmIlw5GYwI6s_se5u-e_ffqh4EU2fFWj0dwdhU14K3t6JhoihZQBE139PkyrK21rWPRE5q6fm30FLb2uIEsv77dBd83eUMUJRRc&sig=AHIEtbTNtnbSPRoL7hSTpz9q3pNRE0qHhQ |accessdate=8 February 2013 |newspaper=Contributions to Nepalese Studies |date=January 1996}} Page 199.</ref> Each subgroup performs a task that has been assigned by tradition.<ref>{{cite web | last =Lewis| first =Todd T.| authorlink = | coauthors = | url = http://college.holycross.edu/faculty/tlewis/PDFs/Buddhist_Merchants_in_Kathmandu.pdf| title =Buddhist Merchants in Kathmandu: The Asan Twah Market and Uray Social Organization | work = Contested Hierarchies | publisher = Oxford: Clarendon Press | date=1995 | accessdate = 8 February 2013}} Page 47.</ref>
* [[Tuladhar]]s of [[Asan, Kathmandu|Asan]] sew and distribute leaf plates * Tuladhars of Nyata cook and serve rice * [[Sthapit]]s build the wooden viewing stand * [[Tamrakar]]s play the trumpet * [[Kansakar]]s prepare and serve five types of foods * Sikhrakars supply clay pots * [[Bania (Newar caste)|Bania]]s serve a sweet drink * Rajkarnikar serve confections<ref>Tuladhar, Suman Kamal (coordinator) (2012). ''Udaaya Research.'' Kathmandu: Udaaya Samaj. Page 44.</ref> <ref>Gellner, David N. and Quigley, Declan (1995). ''Contested hierarchies: a collaborative ethnography of caste among the Newars of the Kathmandu Valley, Nepal.'' Clarendon Press. {{ISBN|0198279604}}, 9780198279600. Page 52.</ref>
==Misā Samyak==
Misā Samyak, which means Women's Samyak, is held on the third day. The image of Goddess Ajimā Dyah is brought down from her shrine at Swayambhu for the ceremony.<ref>{{cite book |last=Vaidya |first=Karunakar |authorlink= |title=Buddhist Traditions and Culture of the Kathmandu Valley, Nepal |url=https://books.google.com.np/books?ei=Uq_7UayTMY2HrAfI0YB4&id=glsEAAAAYAAJ&dq=bhakta+bir+singh&q=misa#search_anchor |accessdate=2 August 2013 |year=1986 |publisher=Shajha Prakashan |location= |isbn= |pages=120-121}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last= van den Hoek |first= Bert |title= Gender and Caste in the Perfect Buddhist Gift the Samyak Mahadana in Kathmandu, Nepal |url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:CpCdBJpQoo4J:www.thlib.org/static/reprints/contributions/CNAS_23_01_12.pdf+samyak+hoek&hl=en&gl=np&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESgtPkaxuQpgv6rH251CXWy3q9BDSzdSDLz5XnmIlw5GYwI6s_se5u-e_ffqh4EU2fFWj0dwdhU14K3t6JhoihZQBE139PkyrK21rWPRE5q6fm30FLb2uIEsv77dBd83eUMUJRRc&sig=AHIEtbTNtnbSPRoL7hSTpz9q3pNRE0qHhQ |accessdate=8 February 2013 |newspaper=Contributions to Nepalese Studies |date=January 1996}} Page 199.</ref>
==Timetable==
The regular Samyak ceremony is held at intervals of 12 years. However, a special one can be called between the scheduled occurrences by a sponsor. The most recent one took place in 2005.
In Lalitpur, the Samyak festival is held at [[Nagbahal]]. The latest one occurred in 2012.
In Bhaktapur, Samyak is celebrated annually on the feast day of Ghyah Chāku Sanlhu ([[Maghe Sankranti]]) which usually falls on January 15.<ref>{{cite news |date=14 January 2014|title=Kanhay Khwopay Samyak |trans-title=Samyak in Bhaktapur tomorrow |language=Newari|newspaper=Sandhya Times |location=Kathmandu |page=1}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Infobox artwork | title = Shabash Bangladesh | painting_alignment = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | image_file = Shabash Bangladesh.jpg | image_size = 220px | alt = | caption = সাবাশ বাংলাদেশ | artist = [[Nitun Kundu]]{{cite web|url=http://bengali.cri.cn/461/2012/03/23/41s122049.htm|title=সাবাশ বাংলাদেশ - Radio Cina Internazionale|work=cri.cn}} | catalogue = | year = {{start date|1991}} | completion_date = | material = | subject = Liberation War of Bangladesh | height_metric = | width_metric = | length_metric = | diameter_metric = | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | dimensions_ref = | metric_unit = m | imperial_unit = ft | condition = | city = [[University of Rajshahi]], [[Rajshahi]], [[Bangladesh]] | museum = | accession = | coordinates = {{Coord|24.22|88.36|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | owner = [[University of Rajshahi]] | url = }} '''Shabash Bangladesh''' (Bravo Bangladesh) ({{Lang-bn|সাবাশ বাংলাদেশ}}) is a [[sculpture]] in [[Bangladesh]]. It is located at [[Rajshahi University]] premises. Shabash Bangladesh is another state of the art sculpture created to pay tribute to those killed in the [[Bangladesh Liberation War|Liberation War of Bangladesh]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bssnews.net/newsDetails.php?cat=0&id=393837$date=2014-03-05&dateCurrent=2014-03-09|title=News Details|work=bssnews.net}} [[Nitun Kundu]] is the sculptor of Shabash Bangladesh. The name of the sculpture comes from a poem named "Durmor" by [[Sukanta Bhattacharya]]. The last four lines of which is engraved under the structure: {{pull quote|1=সাবাস বাংলাদেশ
এ পৃথিবী অবাক তাকিয়ে রয়
জ্বলে পুড়ে মরে ছারখার
তবু মাথা নোয়াবার নয়।}} Translation : {{pull quote|"Bravo Bangladesh!
The world is amazed!
fired, burned, died and destroyed
but never gave up!"}} ==Gallery==
সাবাশ বাংলাদেশ (15).jpg সাবাশ বাংলাদেশ (11).jpg Shabash Bangladesh (Bravo Bangladesh) (7).jpg
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Commonscat|Shabash Bangladesh}} {{Bangladesh Liberation War}} [[Category:Monuments and memorials in Bangladesh]] [[Category:Aftermath of the Bangladesh Liberation War]] {{Bangladesh-struct-stub}}

'''Skimming''' refers to the illegal transfer of funds from casinos to outside personnel without official documentation. Skimmed money is usually transferred in cash to [[tax evasion|evade taxes]] and to fund [[organized crime]] anonymously. The quantities of money skimmed are usually small portions of the casino's total profit so as not to arouse suspicion from regulators or law enforcement.
"In May of 1963...the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] turned over to the [[United States Department of Justice|Justice Department]] a two-volume document called "The Skimming Report," which detailed the illegal siphoning off of [[gambling]] profits by [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]] [[casino]]s to avoid [[taxes]]."<ref name="Navasky">Victor Navasky, ''Kennedy Justice'', (Lincoln: iUniverse.com, Inc., 2000), p 89.</ref> The report documented how pre-tax profits from casinos were being routed to various organized crime syndicates across the nation. No one could be prosecuted as the FBI obtained its information by illegally [[wiretap|bugging]] casino money rooms. The money rooms are where the cash from the betting floor is counted and recorded on the casino's books.
Skimming by diverting pre-tax profits is just one of many possible methods. In casinos the patron is betting against the house, so the house has an incentive to fix the games (cards, roulette, slots, etc.). In pari-mutuels (horse and dog track, [[jai alai]]) the house instead gets a fixed percentage of the total amount bet, so is theoretically less likely to fix the games. However, pari-mutuels use sophisticated computer systems to handle customer bets and a major scandal involving [[Autotote]], a major supplier of these systems, has been exposed.<ref name="Autotote">[[2002 Breeders' Cup betting scandal]], 2002 Breeders' Cup betting scandal</ref>
Other methods of skimming, such as arranging for particular employees of organized crime to be allowed to win in rigged games, were sometimes used.
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Commercial crimes]] [[Category:Gambling terminology]] [[Category:Organized crime activity]]
