{{Infobox television | show_name = Sons of Liberty | image = Sons of Liberty poster.jpg | image_size = 200px | image_alt = | caption = | show_name_2 = | genre = [[Historical drama]] | creator = | based_on = | developer = | writer = {{Plainlist| * Stephen David * [[David C. White]] * [[Kirk Ellis]]}} | director = [[Kari Skogland]] | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Ben Barnes (actor)|Ben Barnes]] * [[Marton Csokas]] * [[Ryan Eggold]] * [[Michael Raymond-James]] * [[Rafe Spall]] * [[Henry Thomas]] * [[Jason O'Mara]] * [[Dean Norris]]}} | theme_music_composer = [[Hans Zimmer]] | composer = [[Lorne Balfe]] & The Bleeding Fingers Custom Music Shop | country = United States | language = English | num_seasons = | num_episodes = 3 | list_episodes = | executive_producer = {{Plainlist| * Stephen David * Elaine Frontain Bryant * Matthew Gross * Russell McCarroll}} | producer = {{Plainlist| * Mitch Engel * Tim W. Kelly * Peter Feldman * Matthew Stillman * David Minkowski}} | editor = Paul Trejo | location = [[Buftea, Romania]] | cinematography = [[George Steel (cinematographer)|George Steel]] | camera = | runtime = 84–86 minutes | company = Stephen David Entertainment
Stillking Films
A+E Studios | distributor = [[History (U.S. TV network)|History]] | channel = History | picture_format = | audio_format = | first_aired = {{Start date|2015|1|25}} | last_aired = {{Start date|2015|1|27}} | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = | website = http://www.history.com/shows/sons-of-liberty | website_title = | production_website = | production_website_title = }} '''''Sons of Liberty''''' is an American television [[miniseries]] dramatizing the early [[American Revolution]] events in [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]], the start of the [[American Revolutionary War|Revolutionary War]], and the negotiations of the [[Second Continental Congress]] which resulted in the drafting and signing of the 1776 [[United States Declaration of Independence]] in [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]]. Directed by [[Kari Skogland]], the three-part miniseries premiered on [[History (U.S. TV network)|History]] on January 25, 2015. The series' theme music was composed by [[Hans Zimmer]].{{cite news |last=Webb Mitovich |first=Matt |date=November 4, 2014 |title=History Sets Date for ''Sons of Liberty'' Miniseries — Watch the First Teaser |url=http://tvline.com/2014/11/04/history-sons-of-liberty-miniseries-premiere-date-promo/ |publisher=[[TVLine]] |access-date=January 27, 2015}} ==Plot== The miniseries centers primarily on the years (1765-1776) prior to start of the [[American Revolutionary War]], and focuses on historical figures and pivotal events between the (then) [[Thirteen Colonies|British Colonies]] and the mother country of [[Great Britain]] to whom then [[British America]] owed its allegiance, particularly the events that led to resistance to the crown and creation of the [[Sons of Liberty]], a group that coalesced to resist & disrupt attempts by the [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|British Parliament]] and crown to tax and govern the colonies. The actions of the Sons of Liberty were the first beginnings of what would eventually become the American or [[Continental Army]]. These take place mostly in and around [[Boston]] & the then [[Province of Massachusetts Bay|colony of Massachusetts]]. Various American Revolutionary figures such as [[Samuel Adams]], [[John Adams]], [[Benjamin Franklin]], [[John Hancock]], [[Paul Revere]], [[George Washington]] and British General [[Thomas Gage]] are central characters in various episodes. Additionally, creation of the [[Continental Congress|Colonial Congress]], the [[United States Declaration of Independence|Declaration of Independence]] and the eventual outbreak of the Revolutionary War are depicted. '''Tagline:''' (during the teaser trailer) {{quote|There's the revolution you know. And the one that's about to begin.}} ==Cast and characters== * [[Ben Barnes (actor)|Ben Barnes]] as [[Samuel Adams|Samuel "Sam" Adams]]{{cite web|url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2014/06/04/history-sons-of-liberty-miniseries-starring-ben-barnes-henry-thomas/|title=History's 'Sons of Liberty' miniseries casts Dean Norris, Ben Barnes, Henry Thomas |first=James |last=Hibberd |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |date=June 4, 2014 |accessdate=September 15, 2014}} * [[Marton Csokas]] as General [[Thomas Gage]] * [[Ryan Eggold]] as Dr. [[Joseph Warren]] * [[Michael Raymond-James]] as [[Paul Revere]] * [[Rafe Spall]] as [[John Hancock]] * [[Henry Thomas]] as [[John Adams]] * [[Jason O'Mara]] as [[George Washington]] * [[Dean Norris]] as [[Benjamin Franklin]] * [[Emily Berrington]] as [[Margaret Kemble Gage]] * [[Sean Gilder]] as [[Thomas Hutchinson (governor)|Thomas Hutchinson]] * [[Kevin Ryan (actor)|Kevin J. Ryan]] as [[John Pitcairn]] * [[Shane Taylor]] as [[Captain Thomas Preston]] * [[Jimmy Akingbola]] as [[Peter Salem]]{{cite web|title=Sons of Liberty Full Cast & Crew|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3782838/fullcredits?ref_=tt_cl_sm#cast|website=IMDB|accessdate=28 January 2015|ref=IMDBCastAndCrew}} ==Episodes== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" width="100%" style="margin-right: 0;" |- ! style="background-color: #0000FF; color: #ffffff;"| No. ! style="background-color: #0000FF; color: #ffffff;"| Title ! style="background-color: #0000FF; color: #fgffff;"| Directed by ! style="background-color: #0000FF; color: #ffffff;"| Written by ! style="background-color: #0000FF; color: #ffffff;"| Original air date ! style="background-color: #0000FF; color: #ffffff;"| U.S. viewers
(in millions) |- {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 1 |Title = A Dangerous Game{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/moviewatch/sons-of-liberty/listings/|title=Sons of Liberty (History) |publisher=[[The Futon Critic]]|accessdate=January 22, 2015}} |DirectedBy = [[Kari Skogland]] |WrittenBy = [[Kirk Ellis]] and Stephen David & [[David C. White]] |ShortSummary =Still a group of colonies living under British oppression in 1765, local gangs fight each other over turf in the streets of Boston, much less thinking of starting a revolution. When tax collector and pub owner Sam Adams doesn't pay his own taxes, the Crown puts out a warrant for his arrest, leading to the destruction of Royal Governor Thomas Hutchinson's mansion. Wealthy businessman, John Hancock, and Adams, establish a black-market smuggling operation and boycott all goods from [[Loyalist (American Revolution)|Tory]] shops, identifying them with a "T" painted on their storefronts. But an altercation between a loyalist and a Colonist mob lead to a young boy's murder. Then, in 1770, after a conflict escalates with the Redcoats turn into a [[Boston Massacre|massacre]], the wheels are put in motion to start a resistance against British tyranny. |OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2015|1|25}} |Viewers = 3.29{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2015/01/27/cable-top-25-nfl-pro-bowl-tops-cable-viewership-for-the-week-ending-january-25-2015/356179/|title=Cable Top 25: NFL Pro Bowl Tops Cable Viewership for the Week Ending January 25, 2015|last=Kondolojy|first=Amanda|date=January 27, 2015|work=TV by the Numbers|accessdate=January 28, 2015}} |LineColor = 0000FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 2 |Title = The Uprising |DirectedBy = Kari Skogland |WrittenBy = Stephen David & David C. White |ShortSummary =After the Colonists [[Boston Tea Party|destroy 600,000 pounds of tea]] into the [[Boston Harbor]] in 1773, [[George III of the United Kingdom|King George]] sends General Thomas Gage to Boston to remove Governor Hutchinson from office and restore balance. Sam, Hancock, and John Adams set off for Philadelphia to gather arms and support at the [[Pennsylvania House of Representatives|Pennsylvania State House]], and meet the intense George Washington, a delegate from Virginia. Hancock financially supports Sam and his recruits to begin training their own rebel army on a rural farm outside the city. When the British catches wind of it, they order their capture, leading [[Paul Revere]] to set out on his famous ride to warn of the Redcoats coming into Lexington in 1775. Meanwhile, the newly formed Colonial militia clash with the British Army in the [[shot heard round the world]]. |OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2015|1|26}} |Viewers = 2.83{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2015/01/27/monday-cable-ratings-love-hip-hop-monday-night-raw-top-night-black-ink-crew-street-outlaws-more/355768/|title=Monday Cable Ratings: 'Love & Hip Hop' & 'Monday Night RAW' Top Night + 'Black Ink Crew', 'Street Outlaws' & More|last=Kondolojy|first=Amanda|date=January 27, 2015|work=TV by the Numbers|accessdate=January 28, 2015}} |LineColor = 0000FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 3 |Title = Independence |DirectedBy = Kari Skogland |WrittenBy = ''Story by:'' Stephen David & David C. White and Kirk Ellis
''Teleplay by:'' Stephen David & David C. White |ShortSummary =The start of the [[American Revolution]] begins as the Redcoats and the Massachusetts militia continue to fight at the [[Battles of Lexington and Concord]]. Now that the battles develop into a full-blown [[American Revolutionary War|war]], Sam and Hancock enlist Ben Franklin help them convince state delegates to support their cause for freedom. Meanwhile, General Gage charges [[Battle of Bunker Hill|Bunker Hill]], causing the Patriots to suffer a major defeat. The loss inspires a document—the [[Declaration of Independence]]—written up by Thomas Jefferson, is signed by the [[Second Continental Congress]] on July 4, 1776. Colonists celebrate the [[Evacuation Day (Massachusetts)|evacuation]] of British troops in Boston. The newly formed [[Continental Army]], led by General Washington will be put to the test when the Royal Navy's ships attack [[New York Harbor]]. |OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2015|1|27}} |Viewers = 3.30{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2015/01/28/tuesday-cable-ratings-the-real-housewives-of-beverly-hills-tops-night-pretty-little-liars-the-haves-and-the-have-nots-sons-of-liberty-more/356497/|title=Tuesday Cable Ratings: 'The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills' Tops Night + 'Pretty Little Liars', 'The Haves and the Have Nots', 'Sons of Liberty' & More|last=Kondolojy|first=Amanda|date=January 28, 2015|work=TV by the Numbers|accessdate=January 28, 2015}} |LineColor = 0000FF }} |} ==Production== According to ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'', production on ''Sons of Liberty'' began in the summer of 2014.{{cite news| url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/dean-norris-stars-historys-miniseries-709275 | work=The Hollywood Reporter | title=Dean Norris Among Stars in History's Miniseries 'Sons of Liberty' | date=June 4, 2014}} The miniseries was also going to feature the minor story lines of [[Benedict Arnold]] and [[Patrick Henry]].http://www.thewrap.com/tv/article/history-developing-american-revolution-miniseries-sons-liberty-85361/ ==Release== The first teaser trailer was released on September 1, 2014, during ''[[Houdini (miniseries)|Houdini]]'', which incorrectly revealed a December 2014 release date and featured [[The Rolling Stones]]' "[[Paint It Black]]".{{YouTube |id=lXHQRPAmEtE |title="Sons Of Liberty - Promo #1"}} In Australia, ''Sons of Liberty'' aired on [[SBS One]] from February 5, 2015 as a six-part series.{{cite web|publisher=[[TV Tonight]]|first=David|last=Knox|title=Airdate: Sons of Liberty|url=http://tvtonight.com.au/2015/01/airdate-sons-of-liberty.html|date=16 January 2015|accessdate=16 January 2015}} In the United Kingdom, ''Sons of Liberty'' aired on [[History (U.S. TV channel)|History Channel]] from June 2, 2015, also as a six-part series. ===Home media=== ''Sons of Liberty'' was released on DVD and Blu-ray on May 26, 2015. ==Reception== ===Historical authenticity=== The History Channel billed the series as a "dramatic interpretation of events"{{cite web|title=History Channel's Sons of Liberty Series|work=History|date=January 23, 2015|url=http://www.history.com/shows/sons-of-liberty/articles/historians-view|accessdate=January 27, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209223451/http://www.history.com/shows/sons-of-liberty/articles/historians-view|archivedate=February 9, 2015|df=}} and a work of "historical fiction", arguing the goal of the miniseries was "to capture the spirit of the time, convey the personalities of the main characters, and focus on real events that have shaped our past". Nevertheless, the series has attracted criticism for its historical inaccuracies.{{cite news|last=Mcnamara|first=Mary|title='Sons of Liberty' takes a few too many liberties on History|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=January 24, 2015|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/tv/la-et-st-sons-of-liberty-review-20150124-column.html|accessdate=January 27, 2015}}{{cite news|last=Verenna|first=Thomas|title=Discover the Truth Behind History Channel's Sons of Liberty Series|work=American Revolution Journal|date=January 23, 2015|url=http://allthingsliberty.com/2015/01/discover-the-truth-behind-history-channels-sons-of-liberty-series/|accessdate=January 27, 2015}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Wikiquote}} * {{official website|http://www.history.com/shows/sons-of-liberty}} * {{IMDb title|id=3782838|title=Sons of Liberty}} {{History films}} {{Samuel Adams}} {{John Hancock}} {{John Adams}} {{Benjamin Franklin}} {{George Washington}} {{John Dickinson}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sons of Liberty (miniseries)}} [[Category:2015 American television series debuts]] [[Category:2015 American television series endings]] [[Category:2010s American drama television miniseries]] [[Category:English-language television programs]] [[Category:Films about Presidents of the United States]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of George Washington]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Thomas Jefferson]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Benjamin Franklin]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of John Adams]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of John Quincy Adams]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Samuel Adams]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of John Hancock]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Paul Revere]] [[Category:History (U.S. TV channel) original programs]] [[Category:Historical television series]] [[Category:Television series about the American Revolution]] [[Category:Television series based on actual events]]

{{Infobox motorsport championship | name = Speed Energy Formula Off-Road | logo = Formula Off-Road logo.png | caption = | category = [[Off-road racing]] | country = [[United States]]
[[Australia]]
[[China]] | region = [[North America]]
[[Australia]]
[[Asia]] | inaugural = 2013 | folded = | classes = Stadium Super Truck | tires = [[Toyo Tires]] | champion driver = [[Paul Morris (racing driver)|Paul Morris]] | website = http://www.stadiumsupertrucks.com | current_season = 2018 Speed Energy Formula Off-Road season }} The '''Speed Energy Formula Off-Road presented by Traxxas''' (popularly known as the '''Stadium Super Trucks''') is an American [[off-road racing]] series. The series was formed by former [[IndyCar]] and [[NASCAR]] driver [[Robby Gordon]] in 2013. Sanctioned by the [[United States Auto Club]] (USAC),{{cite web|url=http://stadiumsupertrucks.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/SST-Deck.pdf|title=PowerPoint Presentation|work=Speed Energy Formula Off-Road|accessdate=May 10, 2017|format=PDF}} the Trucks originally competed primarily in [[American football]] [[stadium]]s, but in 2014 began racing mostly on [[street circuit]]s. ==History== [[File:Stadium Super Trucks Robby Gordon leads exhibition at Crandon 2012.jpg|thumb|right|2012 exhibition at Crandon]] By 2011, there was speculation that after his NASCAR career was over, Robby Gordon would bring back the concept of stadium off-road racing that [[Mickey Thompson]] had invented.{{cite book|last=Arneson|first=Erik|title=Mickey Thompson: The Fast Life and Tragic Death of a Racing Legend|year=2001|publisher=MotorBooks International|isbn=1616730129|page=274|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IPl4smar1HAC&pg=PA274&lpg=PA274&dq=%22robby+gordon%22+1989+Mteg&source=bl&ots=rJxIu1a04d&sig=yIgGAmI9875YbJuWHOf2cO-bmmA&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_xZrUbKlLIfVyAGo7oCIAg&ved=0CEYQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=%22robby%20gordon%22%201989%20Mteg&f=false}} Gordon announced the formation of the Stadium Super Trucks (SST) in 2012, modeling the series after Thompson's [[Mickey Thompson Entertainment Group|MTEG]] stadium series;{{cite web|title=About SST|url=http://stadiumsupertrucks.com/ssts/about/|publisher=Stadium Super Trucks|accessdate=April 14, 2013}} early in his career, Gordon had won the 1989 MTEG championship as a 20-year-old. The Stadium Super Trucks held an exhibition race at [[Crandon International Off-Road Raceway]] after the conclusion of the World Championship races on September 2, 2012.{{cite web|last=Crowley|first=Jon|url=http://sxsnews.com/index.php/2012/08/stadium-super-trucks-debut-this-weekend-in-crandon/|title=Stadium SUPER Trucks Debut this Weekend in Crandon|publisher=Side x Side Industry News|date=August 31, 2012|accessdate=February 2, 2016}} The Stadium Super Trucks began with a twelve-race season in [[2013 Stadium Super Trucks season|2013]]. The series held their first official race at the [[University of Phoenix Stadium]] on April 6, 2013.{{Cite episode |title=Stadium Super Trucks |url= |accessdate=April 14, 2013 |series=Stadium Super Trucks |credits= |network=NBC |station=[[WGBA]] |location=[[Green Bay, Wisconsin]] |date=April 14, 2013 |season= |seriesno= |number= |minutes= |time= |transcript= |transcripturl= |quote= |language=}}{{cite web|title=2013 Official Schedule|url=http://stadiumsupertrucks.com/ssts/tour/|publisher=Stadium Super Trucks|accessdate=April 14, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019124159/http://stadiumsupertrucks.com/ssts/tour/|archivedate=October 19, 2013|df=}} The race was won by [[Rob MacCachren]], [[Justin Matney]] finished second, and Gordon passed the flipped-over truck of [[P. J. Jones]] on the final lap for third.{{cite web|title=Stadium Super Trucks: Robby Gordon races to Third Place in SST debut|url=http://www.marathonrally.com/news/stadium_super_trucks_robby_gordon_races_to_third_place_in_sst_debut.22937.0.html|publisher=Marathon Rally.com|accessdate=April 14, 2013}} Gordon and MacCachren battled throughout the 2013 season, and Gordon won the championship by seven points.{{cite news|last=Wagner|first=Jan|url=http://www.delmartimes.net/2013/11/22/automatters-stadium-super-trucks-at-caesars-palace/|title=AutoMatters: Stadium SUPER Trucks at Caesars Palace|newspaper=Del Mar Times|date=November 22, 2013|accessdate=November 25, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131128020357/http://www.delmartimes.net/2013/11/22/automatters-stadium-super-trucks-at-caesars-palace/|archivedate=November 28, 2013|df=}} As support events, the series scheduled [[monster truck]]s, quad bikes and [[Side by Side (UTV)|Side by Side UTVs]]. [[File:Stadium Super Trucks Crandon 2013 Round 10.jpg|thumb|left|Race at Crandon in 2013]] On December 11, 2013, Gordon announced that the series will be among the events held at the [[X Games Austin 2014|X Games Austin]] in 2014.{{cite web|url=http://xgames.espn.go.com/rally-moto-x/article/10121804/robby-gordon-stadium-super-trucks-series-added-x-games-austin|title=Super Trucks event added to X Games Austin|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=December 11, 2013|accessdate=December 11, 2013}} On March 4, 2014, the series was rebranded as the "Speed Energy Formula Off-Road Presented By Traxxas".{{cite web|url=http://stadiumsupertrucks.com/rebranded/|title=SST Trucks To Race In Rebranded SPEED Energy Formula Off-Road Presented By Traxxas|work=Stadium Super Trucks|date=March 4, 2014|accessdate=March 4, 2014}} The series' X Games final was held at [[Circuit of the Americas]] on June 8.{{cite web|url=http://stadiumsupertrucks.com/ssts/sst-to-join-x-games-austin-in-2014/|title=SST TO JOIN X GAMES AUSTIN IN 2014|work=Stadium Super Trucks|date=December 11, 2013|accessdate=December 11, 2013}} [[Apdaly Lopez]] won the gold medal; [[Sheldon Creed]] and Gordon earned silver and bronze, respectively.{{cite web|url=http://xgames.espn.go.com/events/2014/austin/results/400549635/stadium-super-trucks|title=STADIUM SUPER TRUCKS - FINAL|work=[[X Games]]|accessdate=June 8, 2014}} On September 23, 2014, sponsorship marketing company [[Elevation Group]] purchased a 40 percent stake in the series.{{cite web|last=Ryan|first=Nate|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/motorsports/2014/09/23/robby-gordon-stadium-super-truck-series-elevation-group-nascar-indycar/16096297/|title=Robby Gordon's stadium truck series adds owners|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|date=September 23, 2014|accessdate=October 3, 2014}} In 2015, the series entered a partnership with [[all-terrain vehicle]] manufacturer [[Arctic Cat]], which led to the creation of the Arctic Cat Stadium Side-by-Side (SXS) Racing Series as a support series to the SST.{{cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20150825005535/en/Arctic-Cat-Partners-Robby-Gordon%E2%80%99s-SST-Series|title=Arctic Cat Partners with Robby Gordon’s SST Series|work=[[Business Wire]]|date=August 25, 2015|accessdate=December 31, 2015}} In late 2014 and into 2015, the series expanded outside the United States and Canada, starting with the [[2014 Race of Champions]] in [[Barbados]].{{cite web|last=DiZinno|first=Tony|url=http://motorsports.nbcsports.com/2014/12/04/robby-gordons-stadium-super-trucks-come-to-roc/|title=Robby Gordon’s Stadium SUPER TRUCKS come to RoC|publisher=[[NBC Sports]]|date=December 4, 2014|accessdate=December 31, 2015}} With the support of driver [[Craig Dontas]] and former [[Adelaide 500]] general manager Nathan Cayzer, Formula Off-Road expanded into Australia for the 2015 season.{{cite web|url=https://www.speedcafe.com/2018/05/06/rights-deal-signed-super-trucks-australia/|title=Rights deal signed for Super Trucks in Australia|work=[[Speedcafe]]|date=May 6, 2018|accessdate=May 6, 2018}} In May, the trucks were invited to the [[Goodwood Festival of Speed]] in England.{{cite web|url=http://stadiumsupertrucks.com/ssts/stadium-super-trucks-reach-another-milestone-with-a-prestigious-invitation-to-englands-goodwood-festival-of-speed-june-25-28/|title=Stadium Super Trucks Reach Another Milestone With A Prestigious Invitation to England’s Goodwood Festival of Speed June 25–28|work=Speed Energy Formula Off-Road|date=May 14, 2015|accessdate=May 16, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150527210217/http://stadiumsupertrucks.com/ssts/stadium-super-trucks-reach-another-milestone-with-a-prestigious-invitation-to-englands-goodwood-festival-of-speed-june-25-28/|archivedate=May 27, 2015|df=}} Formula Off-Road returned to stadiums in December 2017 with the inaugural Stadium Super Trucks World Championship Finals in California's [[Lake Elsinore Diamond]] baseball park.{{cite web|url=http://stadiumsupertrucks.com/stadium-super-trucks-world-championship-finals-set-for-december-15-16-at-lake-elsinore-diamond-stadium/|title=Stadium SUPER Trucks World Championship Finals Set For December 15 & 16 At Lake Elsinore Diamond Stadium|work=Speed Energy Formula Off-Road|date=October 6, 2017|accessdate=October 6, 2017}} Although he did not compete for the weekend, [[Paul Morris (racing driver)|Paul Morris]] clinched the 2017 championship with [[Jerret Brooks]] driving his No. 67 truck.{{cite web|last=Nguyen|first=Justin|url=http://overtakemotorsport.com/2017/12/17/sst-race-rock-world-championship-recap/|title=SST: Race & Rock World Championship Recap|publisher=Overtake Motorsport|date=December 17, 2017|accessdate=May 5, 2018}} In May 2018, Gordon formed a three-year partnership with [[Boost Mobile]] to keep the series in Australia beyond the 2019. As part of the agreement, the series' Australian operations were handled by Cayzer and Morris' [[Paul Morris Motorsport]]. However, in September, the [[Confederation of Australian Motor Sport]] (CAMS) revoked their licence over safety concerns, a decision particularly spurned by an incident in the May race at [[Barbagallo Raceway]] in which [[Matt Nolan (racing driver)|Matt Nolan]]'s truck's wheel came off during a wreck and hit a spectator bridge.{{cite web|last=Howard|first=Tom|url=https://www.speedcafe.com/2018/09/20/cams-suspends-super-trucks-on-safety-grounds/|title=CAMS suspends Super Trucks on safety grounds|publisher=[[Speedcafe]]|date=September 20, 2018|accessdate=October 11, 2018}} A court hearing overseen by the [[Supreme Court of Victoria]] took place a month later. The series' defense, led by [[Queen's Counsel]] [[barrister]] Stewart Anderson, said new wheels would be built with forged [[billet aluminium]] that makes them heavier and less likely to detach than the current cast alloy. Retired Supercar driver [[Larry Perkins]] also gave his support after inspecting them earlier in the year, comparing the trucks' safety to the Supercars. Anderson further stated CAMS and SST had formed an agreement in February in which the former expressed satisfaction at the series, yet CAMS made the decision to suspend the series in May and did not inform SST officials until July, which Gordon stated was a breach of contract.{{cite web|last=Harris|first=Geoffrey|url=https://www.motoring.com.au/motorsport-robby-gordon-cams-slug-it-out-in-court-115026/|title=MOTORSPORT: Robby Gordon, CAMS slug it out in court|publisher=Motoring.com.au|date=October 5, 2018|accessdate=October 11, 2018}} On October 11, judge [[John Digby (judge)|John Digby]] ruled in favor of CAMS.{{cite web|last1=Howard|first1=Tom|last2=Herrero|first2=Dan|url=https://www.speedcafe.com/2018/10/11/court-upholds-super-trucks-suspension/|title=Court upholds Super Trucks suspension|publisher=[[Speedcafe]]|date=October 11, 2018|accessdate=October 11, 2018}} Six days after the ruling, the series aligned with the [[Australian Auto Sport Alliance]]'s [[Australian Motor Racing Series]] (AMRS) to remain in the country. The AASA, which is not affiliated with CAMS, and the [[NSW Sport and Recreation]] approved Formula Off-Road for competition in AMRS events following a risk assessment.{{cite web|last=Coch|first=Matt|url=https://www.speedcafe.com/2018/10/23/sydney-motorsport-park-confident-of-sst-safety2/|title=Sydney Motorsport Park confident of SST safety|publisher=[[Speedcafe]]|date=October 22, 2018|accessdate=October 22, 2018}} The trucks' first race weekend under the AMRS banner took place nine days later at the [[Sydney Motorsport Park]].{{cite web|last1=Coch|first1=Matt|last2=Herrero|first2=Dan|url=https://www.speedcafe.com/2018/10/17/stadium-super-trucks-to-race-in-sydney-next-week/|title=Stadium Super Trucks to race in Sydney next week|publisher=[[Speedcafe]]|date=October 17, 2018|accessdate=October 22, 2018}} To close out the 2018 season, the series organized the Robby Gordon Off-Road World Championships at [[Glen Helen Regional Park|Glen Helen Raceway]] from November 30 to December 2.{{cite web|last=Ochsner|first=Shaun|url=http://www.fourwheeler.com/news/1809-massive-payout-for-inaugural-robby-gordon-off-road-championships-at-glen-helen/|title=Massive Payout for Inaugural Robby Gordon Off-Road Championships at Glen Helen|publisher=''[[Four Wheeler]]''|date=September 4, 2018|accessdate=October 11, 2018}} ==Drivers== The series typically featured racers who have competed in off-road events; in the inaugural race, off-road racers included Robby Gordon, [[Championship Off-Road Racing]] driver [[Rob MacCachren]], [[TORC: The Off Road Championship|TORC]] driver [[Sheldon Creed]] and motocross rider [[Jeff Ward (motorsports)|Jeff Ward]]. The 2013 season also featured drivers from other disciplines, like [[Arie Luyendyk Jr.]] and [[Paul Tracy]] (IndyCar), [[Nick Baumgartner]] (Olympic [[Snowboard cross|snowboarding]]) and [[Traxxas]] owner [[Mike Jenkins (racing driver)|Mike Jenkins]]. Other drivers who have competed in the series include Moto X biker [[Jeremy Stenberg]]{{cite web|url=http://xgames.espn.go.com/xgames/video/12969533/x-games-austin-preview-jeremy-stenberg|title=X Games Austin preview -- Jeremy Stenberg|work=[[X Games]]|accessdate=June 5, 2015}} and four-time [[AMA Supercross Championship]] winner [[Ryan Villopoto]].{{cite web|url=http://actionsportsconnection.com/4x-supercross-champion-ryan-villopoto-make-stadium-super-trucks-debut-sst-race-rock-world-championship/|title=4x SuperCross Champion Ryan Villopoto to make Stadium SUPER Trucks Debut at SST Race & Rock World Championship|work=Action Sports Connection|date=December 13, 2017|accessdate=December 13, 2017}} Like Gordon, other NASCAR drivers have competed in the series. At [[X Games Austin 2015]], among the NASCAR competitors were [[1989 NASCAR Winston Cup Series]] champion [[Rusty Wallace]],{{cite web|last=Fryer|first=Jenna|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Sports/wireStory/rusty-wallace-compete-off-road-truck-race-games-30064675|title=Rusty Wallace to Compete in off-Road Truck Race at X Game|publisher=[[ABC News]]|date=April 2, 2015|accessdate=April 2, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150403102720/http://abcnews.go.com/Sports/wireStory/rusty-wallace-compete-off-road-truck-race-games-30064675|archivedate=April 3, 2015 }} [[road course ringer]] [[Boris Said]]{{cite web|url=http://www.k1speed.com/blog/boris-said-to-race-off-road-trucks-at-x-games.html|title=Boris Said to Race Off Road Trucks at X Games|work=[[K1 Speed]]|date=May 14, 2015|accessdate=May 27, 2015}} and former [[Nationwide Series]] driver and eleven-time X Games medalist [[Travis Pastrana]].{{cite web|url=http://xgames.espn.go.com/xgames/events/2015/austin/article/12927656/x-games-austin-preview-road-truck-racing|title=Off-Road Truck Racing: Teen Drivers|work=[[X Games]]|date=June 2, 2015|accessdate=June 5, 2015}} [[P. J. Jones]] also made starts for Gordon's [[Robby Gordon Motorsports]] team in NASCAR,{{cite web|url=http://www.racing-reference.info/drivdet/jonesp.01/2007/W|title=P.J. Jones: 2007 NASCAR Nextel Cup Results|work=Racing-Reference|accessdate=January 29, 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.racing-reference.info/drivdet/jonesp.01/2010/W|title=P.J. Jones: 2010 NASCAR Sprint Cup Results|work=Racing-Reference|accessdate=January 29, 2016}} while [[Justin Lofton]] raced in NASCAR with Speed Energy sponsorship.{{cite web|url=http://racing-reference.info/race/2012_North_Carolina_Education_Lottery_200/C|title=2012 North Carolina Education Lottery 200|work=Racing-Reference|accessdate=February 1, 2016}} In December 2017, Xfinity Series driver [[Casey Mears]], the son of off-road and stadium truck racer [[Roger Mears]], made his Formula Off-Road debut at Lake Elsinore.{{cite web|last=Spencer|first=Lee|url=https://www.motorsport.com/truck/news/nascar-casey-mears-stadium-super-trucks-987086/|title=Casey Mears excited to go truckin' again ahead of SST debut|publisher=[[Motorsport.com]]|date=December 8, 2017|accessdate=December 8, 2017}} In 2016, [[Sara Price]] became the first female driver in series history when she made her debut at Toronto.{{cite web|last=Fabrizio|first=Tony|url=http://www.espn.com/espnw/sports/article/17546751/sara-price-making-impression-super-trucks-series|title=Super woman: Sara Price making impact on Super Trucks Series|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=September 16, 2016|accessdate=October 13, 2016}} ==Tracks== [[File:Traxxis Stadium Super Trucks -Honda Toronto Indy 2016 (28254768011).jpg|thumb|[[Dustin Scott]] and [[Toby Price]] racing at [[Honda Indy Toronto]] in 2016]] During its inaugural season, the series raced predominantly in stadiums filled with dirt like the [[Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum]], while also running on [[street circuit]]s as a supporting event for the IndyCar Series. Eventually, the series focused almost exclusively on street courses. "Before you know it, we're doing 10 street races instead of stadiums and dirt races, which brings it to a completely different fan audience," Gordon stated.{{cite news|last=Baker|first=Matt|url=http://www.tampabay.com/sports/autoracing/grand-prix-of-st-petersburg-life-after-nascar-leads-robby-gordon-to/2316279|title=Grand Prix of St. Petersburg: Life after NASCAR leads Robby Gordon to Stadium Super Trucks series|newspaper=[[Tampa Bay Times]]|date=March 11, 2017|accessdate=March 12, 2017}} On the street courses, aluminum ramps are placed on the track;{{cite web|url=https://traxxas.com/racing/news/Stadium-Super-Trucks-are-coming-city-near-YOU|title=Stadium Super Trucks are coming to a city near YOU!|work=[[Traxxas]]|accessdate=December 31, 2015}} the ramps are 17 feet, 6 inches long and 2'8" high, and trucks enter them at speeds of {{convert|70|mph|km/h}}.{{cite news|url=http://projects.statesman.com/xgames/xgames-supertruck.php|title=ATX Marks the Spot: X Games Stadium Super Trucks|newspaper=[[Austin American-Statesman]]|accessdate=December 31, 2015}} The series eventually began an expansion into Australia, which began in 2015 with races at the [[Adelaide Street Circuit]] in Australia as a support event for the [[V8 Supercars]]' [[Adelaide 500]].{{cite web|url=http://www.racer.com/latest-stories/item/109901-stadium-super-truck-series-heading-for-australia-in-2015|title=Stadium Super Truck Series heading for Australia in 2015|work=[[Racer (magazine)|Racer]]|date=October 16, 2014|accessdate=October 17, 2014}} Further Australian events were held at the [[Surfers Paradise Street Circuit]] as a support race for the [[Gold Coast 600]],{{cite web|last=Kirby|first=Cameron|url=http://autoaction.com.au/stadium-super-trucks-invade-gold-coast/|title=Stadium Super Trucks to invade Gold Coast|publisher=Auto Action|date=May 27, 2015|accessdate=May 27, 2015}} at the [[Valvoline Raceway]] for the [[Ultimate Sprintcar Championship]]{{cite web|url=http://www.speedcafe.com/2015/10/16/super-trucks-sydney-show-switches-venue/|title=SUPER TRUCKS SYDNEY SHOW SWITCHES VENUE|work=Speedcafe|date=October 16, 2015|accessdate=October 20, 2015}} and at the [[Homebush Street Circuit]] for the [[Sydney 500]].{{cite web|url=http://www.v8supercars.com.au/news/championship/stadium-super-trucks-set-for-sydney/|title=Stadium Super Trucks set for Sydney|work=[[V8 Supercars]]|date=November 6, 2015|accessdate=February 2, 2016}} In 2017, Formula Off-Road ran at [[Barbagallo Raceway]] as an undercard for the [[Perth SuperSprint]], marking the first time the series raced on a permanent circuit.{{cite web|last=Herrero|first=Dan|url=http://www.speedcafe.com/2017/05/03/brabham-anticipating-barbagallo-truck-advantage/|title=Brabham anticipating Barbagallo Truck advantage|publisher=[[Speedcafe]]|date=May 3, 2017|accessdate=May 4, 2017}} In June, the series made its debut on an [[oval track]] at the [[Texas Motor Speedway]], running as a support event for IndyCar's [[Rainguard Water Sealers 600]].{{cite news|last=Davison|first=Drew|url=http://www.star-telegram.com/sports/nascar-auto-racing/texas-motor-speedway/article98379187.html|title=Texas Motor Speedway adds ‘extreme motorsports’ truck race in 2017|newspaper=[[Fort Worth Star-Telegram]]|date=August 27, 2016|accessdate=September 1, 2016}} Later in the month, the series raced at the [[Hidden Valley Raceway]] in Australia's [[Darwin, Northern Territory|Darwin]] as part of the Supercars' [[Darwin Triple Crown]] weekend.{{cite web|last=Herrero|first=Dan|url=http://www.speedcafe.com/2017/05/17/stadium-super-trucks-make-darwin-debut/|title=Stadium Super Trucks to make Darwin debut|publisher=[[Speedcafe]]|date=May 17, 2017|accessdate=June 13, 2017}} On July 29, the series partnered with [[Monster Jam]] to race at [[Beijing National Stadium]] in China, the first Chinese-based event for Formula Off-Road.{{cite web|url=http://stadiumsupertrucks.com/stadium-super-trucks-set-to-race-in-beijing-with-monster-jam/|title=Stadium SUPER Trucks To Race In Beijing, China With Monster Jam|work=Speed Energy Formula Off-Road|date=July 27, 2017|accessdate=July 27, 2017}}{{cite web|last=Murray|first=Richie|url=http://www.usacracing.com/news/silver-crown/item/6505-swanson-and-coons-silver-crown-stride-unbreakable-thus-far-at-toledo|title=Swanson and Coons' Silver Crown Stride Unbreakable Thus Far at Toledo|work=[[United States Auto Club]]|date=July 26, 2017|accessdate=July 27, 2017|quote=(Joe) Liguori has stepped out of his own No. 4 to wheel the Fred Gormly-RPM No. 98 after regular driver Davey Hamilton, Jr. got the call for a drive this weekend in Beijing, China with the Robby Gordon Stadium SUPER Truck Series.}} Two months later, the series raced at [[Watkins Glen International]] as a support event for IndyCar's [[Grand Prix at The Glen]]; instead of the {{convert|3.37|mi|km|adj=on}} layout used by IndyCar, the trucks raced on the {{convert|2.45|mi|km|adj=on}} course.{{cite news|last=Legare|first=Andrew|url=http://www.stargazette.com/story/sports/2017/08/10/wgi-adds-super-trucks-indycar-weekend/556897001/|title=WGI adds SUPER Trucks to IndyCar weekend|newspaper=[[Star-Gazette]]|date=August 10, 2017|accessdate=August 10, 2017}} The Glen was removed for the [[2018 IndyCar Series]] season, and Formula Off-Road instead announced plans to join the series at [[Road America]]; for the event, the trucks raced on a shortened course that bypasses turns 6 to 12.{{cite news|last=Kallman|first=Dave|url=http://www.jsonline.com/story/sports/motor/2017/10/17/road-america-adds-off-road-trucks-nascar-xfinity-series-weekend/763013001/|title=Road America adds stadium off-road trucks to NASCAR Xfinity Series weekend|newspaper=[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]]|date=October 17, 2017|accessdate=October 17, 2017}} For the final laps of the Road America race, however, the drivers raced through the entire course. ==Trucks== [[File:Stadium Super Truck of Robby Gordon.JPG|thumb|The Stadium Super Truck of Robby Gordon at the [[2015 Clipsal 500 Adelaide]]]] Powered by a 600-hp [[Chevrolet]] [[LS based GM small-block engine|LS V8 engine]],{{cite web|last=Thomas|first=Phillip|url=http://hooniverse.com/2014/06/06/2014-x-games-motorsports-preview-grc-grc-lites-and-stadium-super-trucks/|title=2014 X Games: Motorsports Preview – GRC, GRC Lites, and Stadium SUPER Trucks|publisher=Hooniverse|date=June 6, 2014|accessdate=February 24, 2016}} the trucks weigh {{convert|2900|lb|kg}} and are built with a steel-tube frame and fiberglass body. The trucks are 13'5" long and 5'2" high, feature a three-speed transmission and can reach speeds as high as {{convert|140|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}. A portion of the frame protects the driver from rolls. The truck's high [[center of mass]] and soft suspension makes the vehicle prone to rolling. Next to the driver is a {{convert|5|gal|l|adj=on}} jug that catches fluids which may have spilled from damage that the truck sustains.{{cite web|last=Webster|first=Larry|url=http://www.roadandtrack.com/motorsports/a26660/stadium-super-trucks-test/|title=How Robby Gordon's Flying Stadium Super Trucks Have Brought the Crazy Back to Road Racing|publisher=''[[Road & Track]]''|date=October 1, 2015|accessdate=December 31, 2015}} Each truck has [[Department of Transportation]]-approved [[Toyo Tires]].{{cite web|url=http://www.racer.com/latest-stories/item/110069-stadium-supertrucks-gets-set-for-vegas-finale|title=Stadium Supertrucks gets set for Vegas finale|work=[[Racer (magazine)|Racer]]|date=October 21, 2014|accessdate=February 24, 2016}} In 2012, Gordon ended his NASCAR career, believing the top teams had a large advantage over the smaller teams due to the amount of money spent. As a result, Gordon wanted the Stadium Super Trucks to be a "drivers' series"; with this philosophy, all trucks are identical to each other,{{cite web|last=O'Neil|first=Devon|url=http://xgames.espn.go.com/xgames/events/2014/austin/article/11001254/robby-gordon-debut-super-trucks-x-games|title=Racing's best-kept secret: SUPER Trucks|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=June 10, 2014|accessdate=February 24, 2016}} though drivers are allowed to change some aspects of their trucks, such as the [[spring rate]]s, ride heights and [[camber angle|camber]].{{cite web|url=http://stadiumsupertrucks.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/SSTRaceRulesandProcedures.pdf|title=SST Race Rules and Procedures|work=Speed Energy Formula Off-Road|accessdate=February 23, 2016|format=PDF}} ==Media coverage== The 2013 SST events were televised tape-delayed on [[National Broadcasting Corporation|NBC]] and [[NBC Sports Network]];{{cite web|url=https://www.sbnation.com/nascar/2012/12/29/3814204/justin-lofton-reduces-nascar-schedule-2013-to-stadium-truck-series|title=Justin Lofton reduces NASCAR schedule next season to focus on Stadium Truck Series championship|last=Weaver|first=Matt|date=April 14, 2013|work=SBNation|accessdate=2012-12-29}} seven were televised on NBC and five on NBC Sports Network.{{cite web|last=Guise|first=Curtis|title=Former ARCA Series Champion Justin Lofton To Compete in Stadium SUPER Trucks|url=http://www.race-dezert.com/home/former-arca-series-champion-justin-lofton-to-compete-in-stadium-super-trucks-41745.html|publisher=Race Dezert.com|accessdate=April 14, 2013}} Most of the twelve races in 2013 were televised on Sunday afternoons.{{cite news|last=Rettie|first=John|title=NBC to Broadcast Robby Gordon’s Stadium Super Trucks|url=http://www.roadandtrack.com/go/news/racing/nbc-to-broadcast-robby-gordons-stadium-super-trucks-38693|accessdate=April 14, 2013|newspaper=[[Road & Track]]|date=September 18, 2012}} In 2014, NBCSN returned to broadcast the season's races, but was later replaced by [[CBS Sports Network]] in September.{{cite web|url=http://taylornicolesnyder.weebly.com/about-me.html|title=ABOUT TAYLOR....|work=[[Taylor Snyder]]|quote=She currently works as the field reporter for "SPEED Energy Formula Off Road Presented by Traxxas" (Stadium Super Trucks) which airs on "CBS Sports Network" (previously shown on "NBC Sports Network").}}{{Cite tweet |user=SSuperTrucks|number=646480592175890432|date=September 22, 2015|title=The SST races will now be televised on the @CBSSports Network, starting on Sept. 23rd with the @ToyotaGPLB , 7pm/et}} The X Games events were aired nationally on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]].{{cite web|url=http://stadiumsupertrucks.com/largest-traxxas-field-in-history-to-race-at-x-games-austin/|title=Largest TRAXXAS Field in History to Race at X Games Austin|work=Speed Energy Formula Off-Road|date=June 7, 2014|accessdate=January 1, 2016}} As of the 2017 season, races are streamed live on the series' website and [[Facebook]] page. When the series raced in Australia, viewers in the country and [[New Zealand]] were prohibited from watching online and instead watched on [[Fox Sports (Australia)|Fox Sports]].{{cite web|url=http://www.off-road.com/blog/2017/05/08/sheldon-creed-earns-second-stadium-super-trucks-win-of-season/|title=Sheldon Creed Earns Second Stadium Super Trucks Win of Season|work=Off-Road|date=May 8, 2017|accessdate=August 10, 2017}} ==Points system== ''Source:'' {{cite web|url=http://stadiumsupertrucks.com/results/standings/|title=STANDINGS|work=SPEED Energy Formula Off-Road|accessdate=December 14, 2014}} {| | {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:85%; text-align:center" |- ! rowspan=2| Points ! colspan=28| Position |- ! 1st ! 2nd ! 3rd ! 4th ! 5th ! 6th ! 7th ! 8th ! 9th ! 10th ! 11th ! 12th ! 13th ! 14th ! 15th |- ! Heat | 12 | 10 | 8 | 7 | 5 | 4 | 3 | 2 | 1 | colspan=7| |- ! Final | 25 | 22 | 20 | 18 | 16 | 15 | 14 | 13 | 12 | 11 | 10 | 9 | 8 | 7 | 6 |} | style="vertical-align:top;" | {| style="margin-right:0; font-size:85%; text-align:center;" class="wikitable" |- ! colspan=2 |
Bonuses
|- ! Most laps led | 3 |- ! Inversion | 1 |- ! Qualifying | 1 |} |} ==Champions== ===By season=== {|class="wikitable" style="font-size: 90%;" |- !scope=col| Season !scope=col| Driver !scope=col| {{tooltip|No.(s)|Truck number(s)}} !scope=col| Races !scope=col| {{tooltip|FQ|Fastest qualifiers}} !scope=col| {{tooltip|W|wins}} !scope=col| Top

rowspan=2| 2 | {{sortname|Robby|Gordon}} | [[2013 Stadium Super Trucks season|2013]], [[2014 SPEED Energy Formula Off-Road season|2014]] |- | {{sortname|Sheldon|Creed}} | [[2015 Speed Energy Formula Off-Road season|2015]], [[2016 Speed Energy Formula Off-Road season|2016]] |- ! 1 | {{sortname|Paul|Morris|dab=racing driver}} | [[2017 Speed Energy Formula Off-Road season|2017]] |} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Stadium Super Trucks}} *[http://www.stadiumsupertrucks.com Official website] {{Stadium Super Trucks}} {{Off-road racing}} {{Stadium Super Trucks tracks}} {{USAC}} [[Category:Auto racing organizations in the United States]] [[Category:Off-road racing series]] [[Category:Recurring sporting events established in 2013]] [[Category:2013 establishments in the United States]] [[Category:Auto racing series in the United States]] [[Category:Auto racing series in Canada]]

'''Stimulus-triggered acquisition of pluripotency''' (also known as '''STAP''') was a proposed method of generating [[pluripotent]] [[stem cell]]s by subjecting ordinary cells to certain types of stress, such as the application of a bacterial toxin, submersion in a weak acid, or physical trauma.<ref name='natnews'>{{cite news | first = David | last = Cyranoski | title = Acid bath offers easy path to stem cells | date = 2014-01-29 | publisher = Nature Publishing Group | url = http://www.nature.com/news/acid-bath-offers-easy-path-to-stem-cells-1.14600 | work = Nature News | accessdate = 2014-01-30}}</ref><ref name='bbc'>{{cite news | first = James |last = Gallagher | title = Stem cell 'major discovery' claimed | date = 2014-01-29 | url =https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-25917270 | work = BBC News | accessdate = 2014-01-31}}</ref> The technique gained prominence in January 2014 when research by [[Haruko Obokata]] et al. was published in ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]''. Over the following months, all scientists who tried to duplicate her results failed, and suspicion arose that Obokata's results were due to error or [[Scientific misconduct|fraud]]. An investigation by her employer, [[RIKEN]], was launched. On 1 April 2014, RIKEN concluded that Obokata had falsified data to obtain her results.<ref name=falsified>{{cite news|title=Obokata falsified data in STAP papers: probe|date=1 April 2014|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2014/04/01/national/obokata-falsified-data-in-stap-papers-probe/|work=The Japan Times|first=Masaaki|last=Kameda|first2=Tomoko|last2=Otake|accessdate=2 April 2014}}</ref> On 4 June 2014, Obokata agreed to retract the papers.<ref name=retract>{{cite news|title=Japan researcher agrees to withdraw disputed stem cell paper|author=Elaine Lies|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/06/04/us-japan-stemcells-researcher-idUSKBN0EF0SO20140604|newspaper=Reuters|date=4 June 2014|accessdate=4 June 2014}}</ref> On August 5, 2014, [[Yoshiki Sasai]]—Obokata's supervisor at RIKEN and one of the coauthors on the STAP cell papers—was found dead at a RIKEN facility after an apparent suicide by hanging.<ref name=Suicide>{{cite news|title=STAP paper co-author Sasai commits suicide|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2014/08/05/national/embattled-stap-study-co-author-dies-after-apparent-suicide-bid/|accessdate=5 August 2014|work=The Japan Times}}</ref>
STAP would have been a radically simpler method of stem cell generation than previously researched methods as it requires neither [[Somatic-cell nuclear transfer|nuclear transfer]] nor the introduction of [[Induced pluripotent stem cell|transcription factors]].<ref name="STAP Nature Paper">{{cite journal|last=Obokata|first=Haruko|title=Stimulus-triggered fate conversion of somatic cells into pluripotency|journal=Nature|date=2014-01-30|volume=505|issue=7485|pages=641–647|doi=10.1038/nature12968|pmid=24476887|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v505/n7485/abs/nature12968.html|accessdate=7 March 2014|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
==Overview== [[Haruko Obokata]] claimed that STAP cells were produced by exposing [[PTPRC|CD45<sup>+</sup>]] [[Murinae|murine]] spleen cells to certain stresses including an acidic medium with a [[pH]] of 5.7 for half an hour.<ref name="STAP Nature Paper" /><ref name=Aaacccid2014>{{cite web | last = NHS Choices| authorlink = National Health Service (England) | title = Breakthrough in stem cell creation using acid bath - What did the research involve?| quote = They put them in a weak acid solution (pH 5.7) for 30 minutes at 37°C, and then put them into petri dishes and grew them at normal pH.| publisher = nhs.co.uk | date = 2014-01-30 | url = http://www.nhs.uk/news/2014/01January/Pages/Breakthrough-in-stem-cell-creation-using-acid-bath.aspx| accessdate = 2014-02-06 }}</ref> Following this treatment, the cells were verified to be pluripotent by observing increasing levels of [[Oct-4]] (a [[transcription factor]] expressed in embryonic stem cells) over the following week using an Oct4-[[green fluorescent protein|GFP]] [[transgene]].<ref name="STAP Nature Paper" /><ref name='newsci'>{{cite news | first = Helen | last = Thomson | title = Stem cell power unleashed after 30 minute dip in acid | date = 2014-01-29 | url =https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg22129542.500-stem-cell-power-unleashed-after-30-minute-dip-in-acid.html | work = New Scientist | accessdate = 2014-01-31}}</ref> On average only 25% of cells survived the acid treatment, but over 50% of those that survived converted to Oct4-GFP<sup>+</sup>CD45<sup>−</sup> pluripotent cells.<ref name='STAP Nature Paper' /> The researchers also claimed that treatment with bacterial toxins or physical stress were conducive to the acquisition of pluripotent markers.<ref name=natnews /> STAP cells injected into mouse embryos grew into a variety of tissues and organs found throughout the body. According to the researchers, the [[Chimera (genetics)|chimaeric]] mice "[appeared] to be healthy, fertile, and normal" after one-to-two years of observation.<ref name='guard' /> Additionally, these mice produced healthy offspring, thereby demonstrating germline transmission which is "a strict criterion for pluripotency as well as genetic and epigenetic normality."<ref name="STAP Nature Paper" />
STAP cells were supposedly able to differentiate into [[placenta]]l cells, meaning they would be [[totipotency|more potent]] than [[embryonic stem cell]]s or [[induced pluripotent stem cell]]s (iPS).<ref name='natnews' /> It was not clear why ordinary cells do not convert into stem cells when subjected to similar stimuli under ordinary conditions, such as acidity in the body; Obokata et al. suggested that ''[[in vivo]]'' inhibitory mechanisms may block conversion to pluripotency.<ref name="STAP Nature Paper" /> Research is underway to generate stimulus-triggered acquisition of pluripotency (STAP) cells using human tissue: in February 2014, Charles Vacanti and Koji Kojima ([[Harvard University|Harvard]] researchers originally involved in the discovery and publication of STAP) claimed to have preliminary results of STAP cells generated from human [[fibroblast]]s, but concomitantly cautioned that these preliminary results require further analysis and validation.<ref name="STAP Human Tissue NS Article">{{cite web|last=Thomson|first=Helen|title=Extraordinary stem cell method tested in human tissue|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn25004-extraordinary-stem-cell-method-tested-in-human-tissue.html#.UxnFXvmwLMp|work=New Scientist|publisher=New Scientist|accessdate=7 March 2014}}</ref>
==History== In the early 2000s, [[Charles Vacanti]] and Martin Vacanti conducted studies that led them to the idea that stem cells - [[spore-like cells]] - could be spontaneously recovered from ordinary tissues that are stressed via mechanical injury or increased acidity.<ref name=Vacanti20140209>{{cite web | last = Connor | first = Steve | title = Exclusive: The miracle cure - scientists turn human skin into stem cells | quote = | publisher = independent.co.uk | date = 2014-02-09 | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/science/exclusive-the-miracle-cure--scientists-turn-human-skin-into-stem-cells-9117102.html| accessdate = 2014-02-09 }}</ref>
The technique for producing STAP cells was subsequently studied by Obokata at the [[Brigham and Women's Hospital]] (BWH), while she was studying as a post doc under Charles Vacanti, and then at the [[RIKEN]] Center for Developmental Biology in [[Japan]].<ref>{{cite web | first = Kerry | last = Grens |title=New Method for Reprogramming Cells |date=29 January 2014 |publisher=The Scientist |url=http://www.the-scientist.com/?articles.view/articleNo/39025/title/New-Method-for-Reprogramming-Cells/}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=STAP cell pioneer nearly gave up on her research |date=30 January 2014 |publisher=The Asahi Shimbun |url=http://ajw.asahi.com/article/behind_news/AJ201401300073 |archiveurl=https://archive.today/20140130205546/http://ajw.asahi.com/article/behind_news/AJ201401300073 |archivedate=30 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> In 2008, while working at [[Harvard Medical School]], she verified at the request of Charles Vacanti that some of the cultured cells she was working with shrank to the size of stem cells after being mechanically injured in a [[capillary tube]].<ref name='natnews' /><ref name='guard' /> She went on as directed, to test the effects of various stimuli on cells. After modifying the technique, Obokata was able to show that [[white blood cells]] from newborn mice could be transformed into cells that behaved much like stem cells. She repeated the experiment with other cell types including brain, skin, and muscle cells with the same result.<ref name='guard' />
Initially Obokata's findings were met with skepticism, even among her coworkers. "Everyone said it was an artefact – there were some really hard days", she recalled.<ref name='natnews' /> The manuscript describing the work was rejected multiple times before its eventual publication as an article (together with a shorter jointly-written "letter") within the journal ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]''.<ref name='guard'>{{cite news | first = Ian | last = Sample | title = Simple way to make stem cells in half an hour hailed as major discovery | date = 2014-01-29 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/science/2014/jan/29/make-stem-cells-major-discovery-acid-technique | work = The Guardian | accessdate = 2014-01-31}}</ref> A series of experiments, first turning a mouse embryo green by fluorescently tagging STAP cells, then videotaping the transformation of T-cells into pluripotent cells, finally convinced skeptics that the results were real.<ref name='natnews' />
===Investigation into disputed claims=== In the months after the two ''Nature'' papers <ref name='guard'/> were released, all scientists who tried to duplicate Obokata's results failed and suspicion arose that her results were due to error or fraud. An investigation into alleged irregularities was launched by RIKEN on 15 February 2014. The allegations questioned the use of seemingly duplicated images in the papers, and reported failure to reproduce her results in other prominent stem-cell laboratories. ''Nature'' also announced that they were investigating. Several stem-cell scientists defended Obokata or reserved their opinion while the investigation was ongoing.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Cyranoski | first1 = David | title = Acid-bath stem-cell study under investigation | date = 17 February 2014 | doi = 10.1038/nature.2014.14738 | url = http://www.nature.com/news/acid-bath-stem-cell-study-under-investigation-1.14738 | journal = [[Nature (journal)|Nature]] | accessdate = 20 February 2014 }}</ref> To address the problem of reproducibility in other laboratories, Obokata published some technical 'tips' on the protocols on 5 March while promising that the detailed procedure would be published in due course.<ref>Haruko Obokata, Yoshiki Sasai and Hitoshi Niwa (March 2014). [http://www.nature.com/protocolexchange/protocols/3013 Essential technical tips for STAP cell conversion culture from somatic cells]. Nature Protocols Discussion Forum</ref>
On 11 March, Teruhiko Wakayama, one of Obokata's coauthors, urged all the researchers involved to withdraw the articles, citing many "questionable points".<ref>{{cite news|title=Prof. wants STAP findings withdrawn|url=http://www.the-japan-news.com/news/article/0001109178|newspaper=The Yomiuri Shimbun|date=11 March 2014|accessdate=17 March 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140317012922/http://the-japan-news.com/news/article/0001109178|archivedate=17 March 2014|df=}}</ref> Charles Vacanti said he opposed their retraction and posted a "revised protocol" for creating STAP cells on his own website, which was taken down after he resigned his BWH post.<ref>Charles A Vacanti (2014)[https://web.archive.org/web/20151009073931/https://research.bwhanesthesia.org/research-groups/cterm/stap-cell-protocol PROTOCOL FOR GENERATING STAP CELLS FROM MATURE SOMATIC CELLS]. Center for Tissue Engineering & Regenerative Medicine.</ref>
On 14 March, RIKEN released an interim report of the investigation. Out of the six items being investigated, the committee concluded that there was inappropriate handling of data on two items, but did not judge the mishandling as research misconduct.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.riken.jp/en/pr/press/2014/20140314_1/|title=Interim report on the investigation of the Obokata et al. articles|author=Press Release|publisher=RIKEN|date=14 March 2014|accessdate=17 March 2014}}</ref> On 1 April, RIKEN concluded that Obokata had engaged in "research misconduct", falsifying data on two occasions. The co-authors were cleared of misconduct, but bore "grave responsibility" for not verifying the data themselves. RIKEN also announced that an internal group had been established to verify whether the ‘stimulus-triggered acquisition of pluripotency’ is reproducible.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.riken.jp/en/pr/press/2014/20140401_2/|title=Report on STAP Cell Research Paper Investigation|author=Press Release|publisher=RIKEN|date=1 April 2014|accessdate=2 June 2014}}</ref> Obokata maintained her innocence and said she would appeal the decision.<ref name="falsified" /> On 4 June 2014, Obokata agreed to retract both the article and the "letter".<ref name="retract"/> The article was officially retracted on 2 July 2014. An article analyzing the controversy concluded that while issues of image manipulation, duplication and plagiarism were potentially detectable, the reviewers could not have concluded that the article was the product of academic misconduct prior to acceptance.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Cyranoski|first1=David|title=Research integrity: Cell-induced stress|url=http://www.nature.com/news/research-integrity-cell-induced-stress-1.15507|website=Nature|accessdate=5 August 2014}}</ref>
In the wake of the controversy, observers, journalists, and former members of RIKEN have stated that the organization is riddled with unprofessional and inadequate scientific rigor and consistency, and that this is reflective of serious issues with scientific research in Japan in general.<ref>Otake, Tomoko, "[http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2014/04/20/national/stapgate-shows-japan-must-get-back-to-basics-in-science/#.U1WkzMKRVZI ‘STAPgate’ shows Japan must get back to basics in science]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 21 April 2014</ref><ref>Schreiber, Mark, "[http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2014/07/05/national/media-national/ongoing-obokata-story-seeks-scandal/#.U7qcsY2KB9A Ongoing Obokata story seeks out scandal]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 5 July 2014, p. 19</ref>
RIKEN commissioned a team of scientists to attempt to verify Obokata's original results and asked Obokata to participate in the effort. On 5 August 2014, Obokata's supervisor and co-author of the original paper, [[Yoshiki Sasai]], was discovered dead by apparent suicide by hanging in a building at the RIKEN facility in Kobe, Japan.<ref>[[Kyodo News]], "[http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2014/08/05/national/embattled-stap-study-co-author-dies-after-apparent-suicide-bid/#.U-IWe40cR9A STAP paper co-author Sasai commits suicide]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 6 August 2014, p. 1</ref> On 24 September 2015, the RIKEN scientists reported that Obokata's STAP cells came from embryonic stem cell contamination,<ref name="KonnoKasukawa2015">{{cite journal|last1=Konno|first1=Daijiro|last2=Kasukawa|first2=Takeya|last3=Hashimoto|first3=Kosuke|last4=Itoh|first4=Takehiko|last5=Suetsugu|first5=Taeko|last6=Miura|first6=Ikuo|last7=Wakana|first7=Shigeharu|last8=Carninci|first8=Piero|last9=Matsuzaki|first9=Fumio|title=STAP cells are derived from ES cells|journal=Nature|volume=525|issue=7570|year=2015|pages=E4–E5|issn=0028-0836|doi=10.1038/nature15366|pmid=26399834}}</ref> while on the same day, research groups who had attempted to reproduce the STAP protocol jointly reported that they had found it irreproducible.<ref name="De Los AngelesFerrari2015">{{cite journal|last1=De Los Angeles|first1=Alejandro|last2=Ferrari|first2=Francesco|last3=Fujiwara|first3=Yuko|last4=Mathieu|first4=Ronald|last5=Lee|first5=Soohyun|last6=Lee|first6=Semin|last7=Tu|first7=Ho-Chou|last8=Ross|first8=Samantha|last9=Chou|first9=Stephanie|last10=Nguyen|first10=Minh|last11=Wu|first11=Zhaoting|last12=Theunissen|first12=Thorold W.|last13=Powell|first13=Benjamin E.|last14=Imsoonthornruksa|first14=Sumeth|last15=Chen|first15=Jiekai|last16=Borkent|first16=Marti|last17=Krupalnik|first17=Vladislav|last18=Lujan|first18=Ernesto|last19=Wernig|first19=Marius|last20=Hanna|first20=Jacob H.|last21=Hochedlinger|first21=Konrad|last22=Pei|first22=Duanqing|last23=Jaenisch|first23=Rudolf|last24=Deng|first24=Hongkui|last25=Orkin|first25=Stuart H.|last26=Park|first26=Peter J.|last27=Daley|first27=George Q.|title=Failure to replicate the STAP cell phenomenon|journal=Nature|volume=525|issue=7570|year=2015|pages=E6–E9|issn=0028-0836|doi=10.1038/nature15513}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=STAP revisited|journal=Nature|volume=525|issue=7570|year=2015|pages=426–426|issn=0028-0836|doi=10.1038/525426a}}</ref>
==Implications== If the findings had proven to be valid, stimulus-triggered pluripotency cells could have been generated more easily and efficiently than by existing iPS techniques.<ref name='natnews' /> And adapted to human tissue, the technique could have led to cheap and simple procedures to create patient-specific stem cells. Stem-cell researcher Dusko Ilic of [[King's College London]] called STAP cells "a major scientific discovery that will be opening a new era in stem-cell biology".<ref name='guard' /> [[Shinya Yamanaka]], a pioneer of iPS research, called the findings "important to understand nuclear reprogramming ... [and] a new approach to generate iPS-like cells".<ref name='natnews' /> The idea that STAP cells can form placental tissue meant they could have made cloning considerably easier by bypassing the need for a donor egg and ''in vitro'' cultivation.<ref name='natnews' />
One previous way of creating stem cells has been via genetic manipulation of adult cells into iPS cells. Progress on iPS-based therapies has been slow due to regulatory hurdles surrounding genetic manipulation.<ref name='guard' /> Additionally, iPS techniques have an observed efficiency of around 1%, significantly lower than the claimed efficiency of STAP.<ref name='natnews' />
==See also== *[[Induced stem cells]] *[[Muse cell]] *[[Stem cell controversy]] *[[Masayuki Yamato]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==Further reading== *{{cite journal|last1=Baumann|first1=Kim|title=Stem cells: Reprogramming with low pH|journal=Nature Reviews Molecular Cell Biology|volume=15|issue=3|year=2014|pages=149–149|issn=1471-0072|doi=10.1038/nrm3754|pmid=24518367}} *{{cite journal|last1=Obokata|first1=Haruko|last2=Sasai|first2=Yoshiki|last3=Niwa|first3=Hitoshi|last4=Kadota|first4=Mitsutaka|last5=Andrabi|first5=Munazah|last6=Takata|first6=Nozomu|last7=Tokoro|first7=Mikiko|last8=Terashita|first8=Yukari|last9=Yonemura|first9=Shigenobu|last10=Vacanti|first10=Charles A.|last11=Wakayama|first11=Teruhiko|title=Bidirectional developmental potential in reprogrammed cells with acquired pluripotency|journal=Nature|date=29 January 2014|volume=505|issue=7485|pages=676–687|doi=10.1038/nature12969|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v505/n7485/full/nature12969.html|accessdate=5 August 2014|pmid=24476891}} *[http://www.riken.jp/en/pr/topics/2014/20140306_1/ Update on the STAP cell papers]. March 6, 2014 *{{cite web|title=The rise and fall of STAP|journal=Nature|url=http://www.nature.com/news/stap-1.15332}} *{{cite web|title=The Stress Test|journal=The New Yorker|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2016/02/29/the-stem-cell-scandal}}
==External links== *[https://stap-hope-page.com/ STAP HOPE PAGE] by Haruko Obokata, March 25, 2016 *[http://www.riken.jp/en/pr/topics/2014/20140130_1/ Stress turns ordinary cells pluripotent] News release at RIKEN with videos.

revision.text:
__NOTOC__ {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Use British English|date=March 2014}} [[File:Tea_dance_as_pictured_by_Marguerite_Martyn,_1920.jpg|thumb|right|A tea dance in St. Louis, Missouri, as drawn by artist-reporter [[Marguerite Martyn]] in 1920.]] [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-K0623-0502-001, Berlin, Tanztee im "Esplanade".jpg|thumb|A [[jazz band]] at the tea dance in [[Hotel Esplanade Berlin]], 1926]] [[File:London in the Spring of 1941- Everyday Life in London, England D2974.jpg|thumb|A tea dance in progress somewhere in the [[West End of London]], Spring 1941. A violinist plays in the foreground.]]
A '''tea dance''', also called a '''''thé dansant''''' (French for "dancing tea"), was historically a [[dance (event)|dance]] held on a summer or autumn afternoon or early evening, from 4 to 7 p.m. In the English countryside, a [[garden party]] sometimes preceded the dance.<ref name="Partygiving">''Party-giving on Every Scale'', London, n.d. (1880) "Afternoon Dances".</ref>{{rp|26f}} The function evolved from the concept of the [[afternoon tea]], and J. Pettigrew traces its origin to the [[French colonial empires|French colonization]] of [[Morocco]].<ref name="Pettigrew">[http://www.teamuse.com/article_010702.html Pettigrew, J., 2001. "Waltz Around a Tea Table," ''TeaMuse''], [online]. July 2001.</ref>
Books on [[Victorian era|Victorian-era]] etiquette, such as ''Party-giving on Every Scale'' (London, n.d. [1880]), included detailed instructions for hosting such gatherings. By 1880, it was noted that "[a]fternoon dances are seldom given in London, but are a popular form of entertainment in the suburbs, in garrison-towns, watering-places, etc."<ref name="Partygiving"/>{{rp|26}} Tea dances were given by [[Royal Navy]] officers aboard ships at various naval stations, the expenses shared by the captain and officers, as they were shared by colonels and officers at barrack dances in [[Officers' mess|mess room]]s ashore.<ref name="Partygiving"/>{{rp|27–28}}
The usual refreshments in 1880 were [[tea]] and [[coffee]], ices, [[champagne]]-cup and [[claret]]-cup, fruit, sandwiches, cake and [[cookie|biscuits]].<ref name="Partygiving"/>{{rp|29}} Even after the introduction of the [[phonograph]], the expected feature was a live [[orchestra]] – often referred to as a [[palm court]] orchestra – or a small band playing light classical music. The types of dances performed during tea dances included [[waltzes]], [[tango (dance)|tango]]s and, by the late 1920s, the [[Charleston (dance)|Charleston]].<ref name="Pettigrew"/>
The expenses of a seated supper, wine, and candles associated with a [[ball (dance)|ball]] were obviated by the tea dance. A stiff waxed canvas dancing cloth strained over the drawing-room carpet was considered sufficient, rather than taking up the carpet and waxing the floor in preparation for dancing.<ref name="Partygiving"/>{{rp|26f, 29}} The dining room served as the tea-room, with the dining-tables arranged at one end as a [[buffet]]. For the older generation, a tea dance was a reception akin to an "at home". Floral decorations were modest.
==World records== Four World Record Tea Dances have been held in the early 21st century. In [[Glasgow]] in December 2008, some 408 dancers gained the record during the city's Winterfest celebrations. The programme of music for the event was provided by the Scottish swing dance band That Swing Sensation,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.swingsensation.co.uk|title=Glasgow Wedding Swing Big Band - Live Swing Dance Music around Scotland|work=swingsensation.co.uk}}</ref> with dance hosts the Fly Right Dance Company.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.flyrightdanceco.com|title=Fly Right Dance Co, performing & teaching vintage dance in Scotland|work=Fly Right Dance Company}}</ref> The previous record was set in 2005 by a total of 195 couples, who danced in London's [[Trafalgar Square]].
Subsequently, the [[Royal Opera House]] in London held a World Record attempt on 8 July 2010 in Trafalgar Square, with the unofficial total being 507 dancers.
Hot on the heels of the London event, Glasgow's [[George Square]] was the venue for the current official record, set on 12 September 2010, with 4,000 dancers.<ref>http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/4000/largest-tea-dance</ref><ref>{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0l5HlCa2Z-8|title=Guinness World Record Tea Dance Award for Glasgow|date=13 September 2010|work=YouTube}}</ref>
==In popular culture== Tea dances are a common cultural reference in early 20th-century British and American fiction as a staple of genteel society, where people normally attend these receptions while visiting resort towns, especially coastal ones such as [[Brighton]], [[the Hamptons]], [[Provincetown]], or [[Ogunquit]]. The 1925 hit [[Broadway musical]], ''[[No, No, Nanette]],'' features a tea dance as the occasion for the plot's climax: the main characters travel to [[Atlantic City, New Jersey|Atlantic City]] (the same musical also features the famous song "[[Tea for Two (song)|Tea for Two]]," which is sung prior to this scene).
In the United States, since the late 20th century, the term has been broadened to refer to any casual afternoon dance event. During an afternoon dance in 1981, the [[Hyatt Regency walkway collapse|Hyatt Regency walkway]] in [[Kansas City, Missouri]] collapsed, killing 114 people and injuring 200.
==See also== * [[I-Beam (nightclub)|I-Beam]] Gay nightclub in San Francisco that had a popular tea dance on Sunday nights from 1978 to 1992. * [[Tea party]] * [[Tea (meal)]]

The '''Teatro delle Quattro Fontane''' ('''Theatre of the Four Fountains''') is an [[opera house]] in [[Rome]], Italy, designed (in part) by [[Gian Lorenzo Bernini]] and built in 1632 by the [[Barberini]] family.<ref>''Music and Spectacle in Baroque Rome: Barberini Patronage Under Urban VIII'' by Frederick Hammond</ref> It was located in ''Via delle Quattro Fontane'', near the [[Piazza Barberini]] and the [[Quattro Fontane]] or ''Four Fountains''.
==History==
The theatre opened in [[1632 in music|1632]] with the [[opera]], ''Sant' Alessio'' (''Saint Alexis''; first performed in 1631), composed by [[Stefano Landi]] to a [[libretto]] by [[Giulio Rospigliosi]], a protégé of the Barberini [[Pope Urban VIII]], later himself elected [[Pope Clement IX]].<ref>[http://www.hoasm.org/VIIF/VIIFBalletOpera.html HOASM: Opera and Ballet]</ref> The theatre could seat 3000.<ref>[http://arts.jrank.org/pages/4854/opera-houses.html Great Opera Houses, History of Opera, Architecture 91:, The Opera House, Theatre Crafts]</ref>
The theatre closed temporarily in 1642 at the height of the Barberini [[Wars of Castro]] with the [[House of Farnese|Farnese]] [[Duke of Parma|Dukes of Parma]] which became incredibly expensive for the family and the [[Holy See]]. The theatre had not yet reopened before when its patrons, the three Barberini nephews of Pope Urban ([[Francesco Barberini (seniore)|Francesco Barberini]], [[Antonio Barberini]] (Antonio the Younger), and [[Taddeo Barberini]]), were sent into exile by the newly elected [[Pope Innocent X]].
Finally in 1653, after more than 10 years with its doors closed, Taddeo's son [[Maffeo Barberini (1631-1685)|Maffeo Barberini]] returned to [[Rome]] and married [[Olimpia Giustiniani]]; finally reconciling the Barberini with the papacy. As the new [[Palestrina|Prince of Palestrina]] he reopened the theatre and recommenced performances.
In 1632, the theatre was rebuilt and was particularly active during the late 1940s, after [[World War II]].
The building was converted into a modern [[Movie theater|cinema]] in the 1960s and now houses the ''Multisala Barberini'' (''Multiplex Barberini'') which shows a full range of modern [[film]]s.
==See also== *[[Baroque architecture]] *[[List of theatres and opera houses in Rome]]
